name: 2019 - J. Manufacturing Processes - Zhang, Chaudhari, Wang - Surface quality and material removal in magnetic abrasive finishing of sele-part-1
fileName: 2019 - J. Manufacturing Processes - Zhang, Chaudhari, Wang - Surface quality and material removal in magnetic abrasive finishing of sele.md
content:
# Surface quality and material removal in magnetic abrasive finishing of selective laser melted 316L stainless steel
Jiong Zhang, Akshay Chaudhari, Hao Wang

artmentoflygilUeigege

# ARTICLEINFO
Keywords:   
Magnetic abrasive finishing   
Selective laser melting   
Slope angle   
Surface roughness   
Material removal rate

# ABSTRACT
As one of the most important additive manufacturing (AM) techniques,selective laser melting (SLM) shows great potential in directly producing functional tooling and complex structural parts through layer-by-layer fabrication.However,some critical isses such as poor surface finish,insufficient dimensional accuracy and inadequate fatigue life need to be addressed systematically before SLMcould be widely applied in industries.Though the capabilities of some conventional finishing techniques such as machining,abrasive finishing and electrochemical polishing on surface finish of components generated by SLM have been explored by some researchers,there is still a great research gapon finishing AM-ed surfaces uniformly due to their high complexity.In this paper,the effect of slope angle on surface finish of the samples fabricated by SLM is characterized by scanning electron microscope and profilometer.Magnetic abrasive finishing (MAF),as a flexible polishing technique,has ben developed to polish the samples generated by SLM with diferent slope angles.Surface roughness and material removalrate are recorded and evaluated during MAF process.To reveal the underlying mechanism,an analytical model of materialremovalrateis devised bycorrelating initial surface roughness of workpiece generated by SLM with abrasive indentation depth,which eventually determines the total material removal volume in MAF process.
summary: ABSTRACT, ARTICLEINFO, Surface quality and material removal in magnetic abrasive finishing of selective laser melted 316L stainless steel

name: 2019 - J. Manufacturing Processes - Zhang, Chaudhari, Wang - Surface quality and material removal in magnetic abrasive finishing of sele-part-2
fileName: 2019 - J. Manufacturing Processes - Zhang, Chaudhari, Wang - Surface quality and material removal in magnetic abrasive finishing of sele.md
content: As one of the most important additive manufacturing (AM) techniques, selective laser melting (SLM) has great potential in directly producing functional tooling and complex structure parts through layer by layer fabrication.Highly promising applications could be expected in aerospace,mold and die,as well as biomedical industries.However, to liberate the enormous potential of SLM,the long-standing issues,such as support structure removal,poor surface finish,insuficient dimensional accuracy,inadequate fatigue life,need to be addressed systematically.Unlike traditional manufacturing process in which surface roughness is uniform, SLM generates components with varied surface roughness and topography due to combined effect of stair effect, balling effect, rippling effect and partially bonded particles.Characterizing and improving surface roughness of workpiece fabricated by SLMis of great importance to both academia and industry.

name: 2019 - J. Manufacturing Processes - Zhang, Chaudhari, Wang - Surface quality and material removal in magnetic abrasive finishing of sele-part-3
fileName: 2019 - J. Manufacturing Processes - Zhang, Chaudhari, Wang - Surface quality and material removal in magnetic abrasive finishing of sele.md
content: Multiple studies have been conducted for characterization and measurement of AM-ed surface topography of various building directions.Strano et al.[1] proposed a mathematical model to predict surface roughness of AM-ed flat surface at different slope angles considering both stair effect and partially bonded particles effect.The predicted surface roughness (Ra) was found to be in good agreement with experiments except for the $0 ^ { \circ }$ slope angle sample.Covarrubias and Eshraghi [2] experimentally studied the effect of build angle on surface roughness and surface texture in Nickel alloy IN718 fabricated by SLM. They concluded that the maximum surface roughness appeared at $\boldsymbol { 1 5 ^ { \circ } }$ build angle (the angle between the measured surface and horizontal plane） and minimum surface roughness occurred at $0 ^ { \circ }$ build angle (measured surface parallel to horizontal plane).Besides,they found the surface roughness for surfaces slope angles of $\boldsymbol { 1 5 ^ { \circ } }$ $3 0 ^ { \circ }$ $4 5 ^ { \circ }$ ${ { 6 0 } ^ { \circ } }$ and $7 5 ^ { \circ }$ matched well with those theoretically calculated considering stair effect.Alrbaey et al.[3] employed Renishaw SLM 125 to print $3 1 6 \mathrm { L }$ samples with different inclined angle.However, their measurement results showed a linear relationship between inclined angle and surface roughness (Ra) while the maximum surface roughness Ra appeared at $0 ^ { \circ }$ inclined angle.The authors attributed the linear relationship to stair effects,which indicated the effect of partially bonded particles was not predominant. In the work contributed by Urlea and Brailovski [4],EOS M280 metal printer was employed to fabricate Ti-6Al-4V alloy components. The authors found the aerial surface roughness Sa increased as the build angle increased until $6 7 . 5 ^ { \circ }$ build angle while Sa of the downskin surfaces $( 1 1 2 .

name: 2019 - J. Manufacturing Processes - Zhang, Chaudhari, Wang - Surface quality and material removal in magnetic abrasive finishing of sele-part-4
fileName: 2019 - J. Manufacturing Processes - Zhang, Chaudhari, Wang - Surface quality and material removal in magnetic abrasive finishing of sele.md
content: 5 ^ { \circ }$ build angle and $\boldsymbol { 1 3 5 ^ { \circ } }$ build angle) were much larger than the average Sa of the upskin surfaces (top surface of $2 2 . 5 ^ { \circ }$ $4 5 ^ { \circ }$ and $6 7 . 5 ^ { \circ }$ build angle). It should be noted that heat treatment was conducted for the above-mentioned samples.Snyder et al.[5] studied the effect of building direction on internal surface roughness as well as accuracy. They employed computed tomography scan (CTscan),a non-destructive measurement method,to characterize the surface roughness and accuracy.Though the resolution was not high enough,surface roughness and accuracy data could still be acquired and distinguished.It was found that building in the vertical direction resulted in the best surface roughness Ra $8 . 4 \mu \mathrm { m }$ and best runout, concentricity,and circularity. Investigations have been done to improve surface roughness by optimizing process parameters to improve surface roughness in DMLS [6].However,it is not always possible to optimize scan speed,laser power,hatch distances,etc.to minimize surface roughness due to shape limitations,density and strength issues.The SLM-ed surface has to undergo post-processing. Over the years,multiple methods have been used to improve surface finish of parts produced by SLM.

name: 2019 - J. Manufacturing Processes - Zhang, Chaudhari, Wang - Surface quality and material removal in magnetic abrasive finishing of sele-part-6
fileName: 2019 - J. Manufacturing Processes - Zhang, Chaudhari, Wang - Surface quality and material removal in magnetic abrasive finishing of sele.md
content: To some extent,improving surface finish of parts generated by SLM can be categorized as freeform surface and intricate internal surfaces finishing problem,for example internal channel or lattice structure. Techniques which could be applied for finishing freeform surfaces have been adopted to process parts produced by SLM, such as laser remelting which is also referred to as laser polishing [3],electropolishing [7], machining [8] and abrasive finishing [9].Laser remelting is a surface treatment technique employed during or after SLM to modify the surface microstructure and roughness.Alrbaey et al.[3] claimed an $8 0 \%$ improvement in surface roughness and almost $1 0 0 \%$ density of remelted zone without external and internal porosities on the treated surface.Yasa and Kruth [1O] reported an experimental study on the effect of laser re-melting on stainless steel $3 1 6 \mathrm { L }$ workpiece fabricated by SLM. They concluded that though longer production time is needed, the porosity of part generated by SLM decreased from $0 . 7 7 \%$ to $0 . 0 3 6 \%$ and surface roughness reduced from $1 2 \mu \mathrm { m }$ to $1 . 5 \mu \mathrm { m }$ .Ukar,et al. [11] investigated the application of laser polishing on DIN 1.2379 tool steel. An average surface roughness below $0 . 5 \mu \mathrm { m }$ Ra was achieved while a softened layer of $2 0 0 \mu \mathrm { m }$ was formed after laser polishing. Lamikiz, et al.[l2] also presented their study on laser polishing of sintered AISI 420 stainless steel. The final roughness reached Ra $1 . 2 \mathrm { - } 1 . 3 \mu \mathrm { m }$ from initial Ra $7 . 5 \mu \mathrm { m }$ .Metallurgical analysis showed that the laser polished surface is more homogeneous than the initial sintered material. It was also reported that stair effect of SLM parts can be eliminated with the optimized laser polishing parameters when the surrounding powder particles were blown away [13].
summary: 1.2. Methods of improving surface quality for AM-ed parts - Part 1/4

name: 2019 - J. Manufacturing Processes - Zhang, Chaudhari, Wang - Surface quality and material removal in magnetic abrasive finishing of sele-part-7
fileName: 2019 - J. Manufacturing Processes - Zhang, Chaudhari, Wang - Surface quality and material removal in magnetic abrasive finishing of sele.md
content: However, a soft layer of hundreds of micrometers induced by laser re-melting on the AM-ed surface is undesirable as a mold surface which needs to be hardened (heat affected zone,HAZ,in laser remelting/polishing). Shot peening as another important surface treatment technique has also been widely used for form correction as well as hardening of the AM-ed metal surface.In the process, compressive residual stresses are induced in the surface layer by bombarding high-velocity particles.However,the use of laser polishing and shot peening is subject to the complexity of the surface produced and target form accuracy and roughness. In many cases, the surfaces are inaccessible and untreatable with the above mentioned methods. Recently, Yung et al.[14] developed a layered laser polishing method to polish complex surface such as convex surface,concave surface and slant surface.In this layered laser polishing method, the targeted surface was divided by layers and the defocusing distance of the laser was adjusted accordingly. Recently, Ghosh et al.[15] proposed layer-by-layer combination of laser powder bed fusion (LPBF) and laser machining to fabricate complex parts for the sake of minimizing side-wall roughness. The surface roughness $\left( \mathbb { R } \mathbf { q } \right)$ on side wall was greatly improved from $3 1 ~ \pm ~ 8 \mu \mathrm { m }$ to $0 . 3 7 ~ \pm ~ 0 . 2 \mu \mathrm { m }$ though submicrometer laser-induced periodic surface structures appeared in the finished surface. Urlea and Brailovski [4] employed electropolishing to process Ti-6Al-4V alloy components produced by SLM with several inclined angles and the surface roughness Ra could be reduced to a uniform Ra of $1 { - } 3 \mu \mathrm { m }$ within $3 0 \mathrm { { m i n } }$ regardless of the fact that the initial surface roughness Ra varies from $4 \mu \mathrm { m }$ 0 $\mathrm { ~ \textit ~ { ~ O ~ } ~ } ^ { \circ }$ inclined angle, upskin) to $2 3 \mu \mathrm { m }$ $( 1 3 5 ^ { \circ }$ ,downskin).
summary: 1.2. Methods of improving surface quality for AM-ed parts - Part 2/4

name: 2019 - J. Manufacturing Processes - Zhang, Chaudhari, Wang - Surface quality and material removal in magnetic abrasive finishing of sele-part-8
fileName: 2019 - J. Manufacturing Processes - Zhang, Chaudhari, Wang - Surface quality and material removal in magnetic abrasive finishing of sele.md
content: Mass reduction was found to increase linearly with processing time,indicating a stable material removal rate. Alrbaey et al.[7] electropolished the selective laser melted $3 1 6 \mathrm { L }$ stainless steel samples pretreated by laser remelting.In their study, stair effect on surface finish was eliminated by laser remelting and surface roughness Ra was improved to $1 . 4 \mu \mathrm { m }$ .The surface roughness Ra was further improved to below $0 . 5 \mu \mathrm { m }$ within $3 0 { \mathrm { - } } 6 0 \operatorname* { m i n }$ of electropolishing.Tyagi et al.[16] compared the performance of chemical polishing and electropolishing on SLS $3 1 6 \mathrm { L }$ workpiece regarding surface roughness and accessbility. They found that electropolishing could achieve better surface finish than chemical polishing; however,it could not polish internal surface without a counter electrode inserted. On the other hand,chemical polishing could effectively reduce surface roughness of the external and internal surface simultaneously. Mohammadian et al.[17] developed a combined chemical-abrasive flow polishing method for Inconel 625 samples generated by SLM. Surface roughness Ra on a $\boldsymbol { 1 5 ^ { \circ } }$ inclination surface was improved by $4 3 \%$ after 1- h finishing. However, those chemical/electrochemical based finishing methods encounter chemical hazards and are generally not environmentally friendly.Li et al.[9] investigated the grindability of sintered nickel-base superalloy FGH96 and found the roughness of ground surface is most sensitive to depth of cut and least sensitive to the abrasive wheel speed. By developing porous metal-bonded cubic boron nitride (CBN) grinding wheels, Zhao etal.[18] achieved lower ground surface hardness and higher material removal rate compared with conventional vitrified wheel.However, the wear and pullout of abrasive grain may shorten the grinding wheel life,especially in high speed grinding [19]. name: 2019 - J. Manufacturing Processes - Zhang, Chaudhari, Wang - Surface quality and material removal in magnetic abrasive finishing of sele-part-9
fileName: 2019 - J. Manufacturing Processes - Zhang, Chaudhari, Wang - Surface quality and material removal in magnetic abrasive finishing of sele.md
content:
[2O] employed magnetic abrasive finishing (MAF) to process selective laser melted 316L flat surface and the surface roughness was reduced to below $1 \mu \mathrm { m }$ Rz from initial $1 0 2 \mu \mathrm { m }$ Rz after $1 2 0 \mathrm { m i n }$ ，which shows the effectiveness of MAF.On the other hand,due to its high flexibility and accessibility,MAF could be applied for freeform finishing with a multiple-axis platform,such as 5-axis machining centers and robotic polishing systems.However,to date,no studies have been done on the effect of initial surface roughness in terms of both the SLM building strategy and effectiveness of mechanical polishing methods.

Surface roughness and mechanical properties of parts built by SLM vary according to the shape which can be characterized by the slopes. The scope of the paper is to investigate the polishability of selective laser melted parts with different slope angles by MAF,a nonconventional and flexible finishing technique.As a fundamental study on MAF of surfaces generated by SLM,7 representative surfaces with different slope angles were fabricated by an EOS M290 Metal 3D Printer to simulate surfaces from complex components. Surface roughness and topography were characterized,and effect of slope angle was investigated. Material removal rate for the developed polishing process was modelled by considering the effect of initial surface roughness. Dimensional accuracy is not the focus of this paper since it is mainly determined by the printing process but the main function of MAF is to reduce surface roughness rather than improve dimension accuracy.
summary: 1.2. Methods of improving surface quality for AM-ed parts - Part 4/4

fileName: 2019 - J. Manufacturing Processes - Zhang, Chaudhari, Wang - Surface quality and material removal in magnetic abrasive finishing of sele.md
content: Block samples with a dimension of $2 0 \mathrm { m m } \times 2 0 \mathrm { m m } \times 5 \mathrm { m m }$ were printed at various slope angles by an EOS M29O Metal 3D Printer,as seen in Fig.1.They represented typical surfaces on complex parts generated by SLM. The surface of interest was the $2 0 \mathrm { m m } \times 2 0 \mathrm { m m }$ upskin surface.The slope angle 0 was defined by the angle between the upskin surface and laser beam,e.g. for $0 ^ { \circ }$ sample the upskin surface was parallel to the laser beam while for $9 0 ^ { \circ }$ sample the upskin surface was perpendicular to the laser beam.It should be noted that $0 ^ { \circ }$ and $9 0 ^ { \circ }$ samples were printed in another batch and not shown in Fig.1.For each slope angle,6 identical samples were printed. Since the scope of the paper is to study the polishability of selective laser melted parts with different angles,the printing parameters were kept constant for all samples and those parameters were default parameters which resulted in the highest density and mechanical strength.These parameters are listed in Table 1. The chemical composition of EOS 17-4 PH stainless steel powderis presented in Table 2 and the morphology of the powder under scanning electron microscope (SEM) is shown in Fig.2.It should be noted that for samples with a slope angle larger than $4 5 ^ { \circ }$ ，support structure is essential. The support structure was printed by different parameters so that it could ensure the successful printing of the designed structures and could also be easily removed.Nevertheless,the existence of support structure in this research will not affect the targeted surfaces since they are under downskin surfaces.After printing, the samples were detached from the substrate without heat treatment. The residual powder on the sample was cleaned by compressed air blaster.

name: 2019 - J. Manufacturing Processes - Zhang, Chaudhari, Wang - Surface quality and material removal in magnetic abrasive finishing of sele-part-13
fileName: 2019 - J. Manufacturing Processes - Zhang, Chaudhari, Wang - Surface quality and material removal in magnetic abrasive finishing of sele.md
content:
Due to its flexibility,magnetic abrasive finishing (MAF) was employed to polish the samples generated by SLM.Fig.3(c) illustrates the working principle of the MAF involved in this paper.The workpiece was sandwiched between an upper magnet and a lower magnet. With this configuration,magnetic abrasives could form a stable polishing brush in the imposed magnetic field and a pressure was generated between the polishing brush and workpiece surface [22].The lower magnet and the workpiece were stationary while the upper magnet was subject to reciprocating motion with the magnet holder.As the magnet holder vibrated,a relative movement between the polishing brush and workpiece facilitated the mechanical material removal process.The magnetic flux density in the operating zone was simulated by a software package Finite Element Method Magnetics (FEMM) and the parameters are listed in Table 3.It should be noted that permanent magnets with N50 grade were used in the simulation as it resembled the magnets used in the experiments.Fig.3(a) and (b) show the simulation results of magnetic flux density distribution without and with bottom magnet, respectively.It is seen that with bottom magnet,the magnetic flux density is concentrated more towards the workpiece,which results in stronger bonding force of magnetic abrasive particles in the polishing zone.The simulation results are consistent with the distribution of magnetic abrasive particles between the magnet and the workpiece as shown in Fig. 3(c, d).

![](images/9f354f3372c27f98e2095f836de9c6e492a97a215893e7049fed9134efe27ee9.jpg)

name: 2019 - J. Manufacturing Processes - Zhang, Chaudhari, Wang - Surface quality and material removal in magnetic abrasive finishing of sele-part-14
fileName: 2019 - J. Manufacturing Processes - Zhang, Chaudhari, Wang - Surface quality and material removal in magnetic abrasive finishing of sele.md
content: The developed polishing setup is depicted in Fig.4.The vibrating movement of the MAF tool was driven by a pneumatic linear vibrator (Oli F15). The vibration amplitude used in this experiment was $2 0 \mathrm { m m }$ based on length measurement and vibration frequency was $2 8 . 8 \mathrm { H z }$ based on spectrum analysis of force signals.More detailed features of the linear vibrator could be referred to our report [23].A magnet holder was mounted at the end of the vibration rod and a Grade N50 Nd-Fe-B magnet with a dimension of $2 0 \times 5 \times 3 \mathrm { m m }$ was fixed on the top face of the magnet holder.To generate a stable polishing brush and prevent the magnetic abrasive particles from escaping during polishing, a $2 5 \times 2 5 \times 3 \mathrm { m m }$ magnet plate was placed below the workpiece.A dynamometer (Kistler 9256C1) was used to control the constant normal force $\mathrm { F } = 5 \mathrm { N }$ for all the polishing experiments by adjusting the gap between the polishing brush and the workpiece through a manual Zstage (Edmund Optics). Since the study focuses on the development of a rapid polishing technique for selective laser melted surfaces rather than an ultra-fine finishing process,only G5O steel grits with an average diameter of $5 0 0 \mu \mathrm { m }$ were employed as the abrasives in the experiments. The SEM images of the G5O steel grits were shown in Fig.5.It is seen that these grits have irregular shapes but sharp edges,which may act as cutting edges to remove asperities on the surface generated by SLM.

After every $1 5 \mathrm { - m i n }$ interval, surface roughness, surface topography and the mass of samples were measured and recorded.Mass reduction of the samples was measured by A&D GR2oO analytical balance with $0 . 1 \mathrm { m g }$ resolution and it was used to characterize the material removal. The polishing media, G5O steel grits,were renewed every $1 5 \mathrm { { m i n } }$ .After 75-min polishing,surface roughness of all samples reached a plateau. It is noted that the surface roughness measurement direction was always perpendicular to the polishing direction and each polished surface was measured three times. name: 2019 - J. Manufacturing Processes - Zhang, Chaudhari, Wang - Surface quality and material removal in magnetic abrasive finishing of sele-part-18
fileName: 2019 - J. Manufacturing Processes - Zhang, Chaudhari, Wang - Surface quality and material removal in magnetic abrasive finishing of sele.md
content: Fig.7 shows representative SEM images of surface topography evolution for $0 ^ { \circ }$ sample during polishing process.It can be clearly seen that as polishing process progresses,the unmolten particles,balling and rippling on the initial sample surface are gradually removed and finally obvious scratches are generated.The initial and final surface topography as well as surface roughness profile for all the samples are shown in Fig.8.The as-printed surface topography shows insignificant stair effect,which is distinct from the printing results studied by Strano et al.[1].And the effect of unmolten particles is predominant followed by rippling and balling effect. On ${ { 6 0 } ^ { \circ } }$ sample surface,numerous particles agglomerate on the interface layer.The polishing results show that most unmolten particles can be removed after 75-min polishing except $3 0 ^ { \circ }$ ， $4 5 ^ { \circ }$ and ${ { 6 0 } ^ { \circ } }$ samples on which some particles still exist in the valleys.Regarding the surface profile,the peaks are flattened but the valleys are still maintained for $\boldsymbol { 1 5 ^ { \circ } }$ to $7 5 ^ { \circ }$ samples.More detailed analysis on surface roughness will be presented in the next section.The material removal mechanism will be proposed and analysed in Section 3.3.
summary: 3.1. Characterisation of the as-printed surface topography and roughness - Part 2/2

content: Eq.(1) shows that the surface roughness will increase as the slope angle θ increases,as seen in Fig.lO(b).However,as the slope angle increases,the distance between two consecutive steps $L _ { S } = t _ { L }$ ·tanθ will increase rapidly,as seen in Fig.1O(c). In case of ${ { 6 0 } ^ { \circ } }$ slope angle, $L _ { S }$ is only $6 9 \mu \mathrm { m }$ and is less than laser spot size of $8 0 \mu \mathrm { m } .$ ，which means the molten pool can cover at least two steps.When slope angle increases to $7 5 ^ { \circ }$ $L _ { S }$ reaches $1 4 9 \mu \mathrm { m }$ .In this case, $L _ { S }$ is much larger than both laser spot size $8 0 \mu \mathrm { m }$ and hatch distance of $9 0 \mu \mathrm { m }$ 、Thus,the molten pool of subsequent layers will not overlap.The percentage of unmolten particles also reduces and improvement in surface finish is observed.Another important effect of these parameters is the degree to which the unmolten particles are fused with the layers.As the slope angle increases,the partially molten particles are fused effectively up to ${ { 6 0 } ^ { \circ } }$ .As the slope angle increases to $9 0 ^ { \circ }$ ,the stair effect is not applicable and the top surface of $9 0 ^ { \circ }$ sample benefits from multiple laser remelting processes as most of the partially bonded particles are significantly fused, which results in the best surface roughness at $9 0 ^ { \circ }$ . It should be noted that there is a slightly decrease in initial surface roughness for $4 5 ^ { \circ }$ sample.This trend of the initial Ra is in accordance with that from Strano et al.[1] and Boschetto et al. [24].Detailed theoretical modelling of the as-printed surface roughness refers to the research conducted by Boschetto et al.[24].The trend of the polished surface roughness against slope angle almost conforms with the initial one while the improvement of surface roughness Ra slows down with increasing polishing time,e.g.

content:
after 75-min polishing,surface roughness remains almost the same as that after $6 0 { \cdot } \mathrm { { m i n } }$ polishing. The change of Rp,Rv and $\mathrm { R } z$ (arithmetical mean of peaks,valleys and P-V values,respectively) before and after polishing is plotted in Fig.11,which shows that the average decrease in $\mathrm { R p }$ is $7 3 . 7 \%$ ,almost twice as that in Rv.The high peaks of the initial surface are gradually flattened while the valleys are partially retained.This may be due to the poor accessbility of the relatively large magnetic abrasives. The reduction in $\mathrm { R } z$ reflects the combined effect of $\mathrm { R p }$ and Rv after polishing.These results corroborate the analysis in Section 3.1.

Fig.12 presents both surface roughness (Ra) and material removal against polishing time. The surface roughness improves as the polishing time increases,the improvement of the surface roughness decreases gradually,and surface roughness reaches plateau after $6 0 { \cdot } \mathrm { { m i n } }$ polishing.The average decrease in surface roughness Ra is $5 6 . 1 \%$ and the maximum decrease of $7 5 . 7 \%$ is achieved on $0 ^ { \circ }$ samples,which may be due to the easy removal of weak bonded particles on $0 ^ { \circ }$ samples. On the other hand, the material removal shows an approximately linear trend against polishing time.Thus,linear fitting with least square method is employed to calculate the material removal rate based on experimental data and the results are shown in Fig.l3(a) and (b).It should be noted that the y-axis in Fig.l3(b) represents material removal rate (MRR) in mg/min.It is found that MRR is significantly different among the seven samples,i.e.MRR of $0 ^ { \circ }$ sample and ${ { 6 0 } ^ { \circ } }$ sample is almost two times higher than that of $\boldsymbol { 1 5 ^ { \circ } }$ sample.

content: The only difference among these seven samples is the slope angle, which has shown significant effect on surface topography and roughness.Before proceeding to the modelling of material removal mechanism,it is essential to verify if there is any significant difference on mechanical properties among these seven samples.As an important indicator for workpiece mechanical properties,microhardness of the sample surfaces is measured by a Shimadzu HMV-2 micro hardness tester (Vickers hardness).The $2 0 \mathrm { m m } \times 2 0 \mathrm { m m }$ sample surface was ground using $\# 1 2 0$ $\# 6 0 0$ $\# 1 0 0 0$ ， $\# 1 5 0 0$ $\# 2 0 0 0$ grits sand paper and polished to mirror surface using $5 \mu \mathrm { m }$ and $1 \mu \mathrm { m }$ alumina slurry with polishing pad before microhardness test. The surface roughness of polished surface is less than Ra $1 0 \mathrm { n m }$ (Tylor Hobson Talysurf profilometer,evaluation length: $5 \mathrm { m m }$ ，cutoff: $0 . 0 8 \mathrm { m m }$ ).For each sample, five sites (S1,S2,S3,S4,and S5) on a $9 \mathrm { m m } \times 9 \mathrm { m m }$ square surface were observed and three points were taken at each site with a $2 0 0 \mathrm { - } \mu \mathrm { m }$ interval,as shown in Fig.14(a). The load was $9 8 0 . 7 \mathrm { m N }$ and dwell time was $_ { 1 5 s }$ .The average (AVG) value and standard deviation (SD） of microhardness on each site for every sample are shown in Table 4.It is seen that there is no significant difference of microhardness among the five sites on a single sample. Thus, the mechanical properties on one single sample are assumed to be uniform.On the other hand, totally 15 measurements on one sample mitigate the effect of microstructure on hardness.The average value and standard deviation of microhardness for all seven surfaces are plotted in Fig.14(b).

To model the material removal rate,the following assumptions are made based on previous observation and analysis:

(1） The magnetic abrasive is supposed to be rigid sphere with uniform diameter $\mathrm { D } = 5 0 0 \mu \mathrm { m } ;$   
(2) The interaction between abrasives is ignored;   
(3) Polishing pressure is constant;   
(4) The sink-in and pile-up effect of indentation is ignored;and (5) Material removal has linear relationship with time.

The material removal model is based on abrasive indentation and scratching. The total material removal is contributed by all active abrasives.This material removal process is induced by the abrasiveworkpiece interaction under an applied load.The abrasive will indent into the workpiece surface due to the polishing pressure,as seen in Fig.15.According to Hertz contact theory,the indentation depth $h$ could be calculated as Eq. (2) [25]:

h = \left( \frac { 3 F _ { a } } { 8 E } \right) ^ { 2 / 3 } \frac { 1 } { D ^ { 1 / 3 } }
$$

where $F _ { a }$ is normal force on one abrasive, $E$ is Young's modulus of workpiece material and $D$ is abrasive diameter. It should be noticed that Eq.(1) is indentation depth on a perfectly flat surface which may not be suitable for rough surface generated by SLM.Literatures also show that surface roughness of workpiece is one of the dominant factors which affect the contact pressure distribution and indentation depth [26].

Chen et al. [27] numerically modelled the nanoindentation process on AISI 3l6L steel and found that the indentation depth increased as surface roughness increased from 2 to $3 7 \mathrm { n m } \mathrm { R a }$ .To consider the effect of initial surface roughness Ra on indentation depth,Eq.(2) is modified as follows by introducing a surface roughness coefficient $k$ as in Eq. (3):

$$
h _ { m } = \bigg ( \frac { 3 F _ { a } } { 8 E } \bigg ) ^ { 2 / 3 } \cdot \frac { 1 } { D ^ { 1 / 3 } } \bullet k \bullet R a
$$

The cross section of indentation is a circular segment and its area could be presented as Eq. (4):

$$
A = { \frac { D ^ { 2 } } { 8 } } ( \alpha - s i n \alpha )
$$

where $\alpha$ is the central angle which could be calculated by sphere abrasive diameter $D$ and indentation depth $h$ [28].

For calculation convenience,Eq.(4) could also written as Eq. (5) [28]:

$$
A = { \frac { 2 } { 3 } } c h _ { m } + { \frac { h ^ { 3 } } { 2 c } }
$$

where $c$ is the length of the chord given by Eq. (6):

$$
c = 2 \sqrt { h _ { m } ( D - h _ { m } ) }
$$

$$
V _ { 0 } = A L = L { \left( \frac { 2 } { 3 } c h _ { m } + \frac { h _ { m } { } ^ { 3 } } { 2 c } \right) }
$$

where $L$ is the length of workpiece.If the number of active abrasives is $N _ { i }$ ,the total material removal of one pass polishing can be written as Eq. (8):

$$
V = N A L = L N \left( \frac { 2 } { 3 } c h _ { m } + \frac { h _ { m } { } ^ { 3 } } { 2 c } \right)
$$

The material removal rate MRR in mg/min can be calculated by Eq. (9):

$$
M R R = { \frac { V } { t } } = \rho N A L N _ { P } { \bullet } 1 0 ^ { 6 }
$$

where $\rho$ is the density of workpiece, $N _ { P }$ is total number of pass per min and $N _ { P } = 6 0 f _ { p }$

The number of active abrasives can be estimated by the abrasive diameter and dimension of top magnet.As seen in Fig.16,the total number of abrasive contacting workpiece is $L _ { M } W _ { M } / D ^ { 2 }$ ,supposing the sphere abrasives are regularly packed,where $L _ { M }$ and $W _ { M }$ are length and width of top magnet,respectively.However,due to the flexibility of magnetic abrasive brush and the vibration-asssted polishing process, only the abrasives on the edge of the top magnet will be involved in material removal.Therefore,the number of active abrasives is written as Eq. (10):

$$
N = { \frac { L _ { M } } { D } }
$$

(5)All the as-printed samples show almost identical values of microhardness where the slope angle is not a significant factor. This observation rules out the potential influence of hardness variation on the material removal rate,which corroborates the postulation that the initial surface roughness is the dominant factor in this study; and   
(6) By correlating surface roughness and indentation depth,the developed theoretical model is proven to be able to effectively capture the linear trend between initial surface roughness Ra and material removal rate.

This study is focused on finishing flat surfaces by MAF.The flexibility of MAF allows it to be applied to complex geometry parts by incorporating MAF to multi-axis platforms such as machining center and robotic polishing station.The high conformity of the MAF polishing media is also beneficial to uniform finishing.Moreover,based on the observations in this study,it is recommended that finishing parameters must be adjusted according the initial surface roughness for complex components fabricated by SLM.

# ARTICLEINFO
summary: Experimental characterization and micromechanical-statistical modeling of 316L stainless steel processed by selective laser melting

name: 2020 - Computational Materials Science - Wang et al. - Experimental characterization and micromechanical-statistical modeling of 316L st-part-2
fileName: 2020 - Computational Materials Science - Wang et al. - Experimental characterization and micromechanical-statistical modeling of 316L st.md
content:
# ABSTRACT
Keywords:   
Selective laser melting   
X-ray computed tomography   
Mechanical properties   
Micromechanical-statistical modeling

Additive manufacturing (AM) is regarded as one of the breakthrough innovations since the 19th century,whose impact on the manufacturing world is recognized as the same with the impact of airplaneon the transportation industry [1].Selective laser melting (SLM),one of the most popular AM techniques for processng metalic materials,has demonstrated its great potentials in medical,aerospace and automotiveapplications.The SLM technique itself is a complex metallurgical process,involving multi-physics phenomenon in laser scanning, powder melting and bonding procedure.Such a process may introduce a variety of defects and flaws such as pores and cracks,significantly reducing the mechanical performance of the final products.In this paper,we present experimental studies and micromechanical modeling to investigate the efects of the internal pores on the mechanical properties of 316L stainless steel (SS316L）processed by the SLM technique.Specifically,the internal pore characteristics such as size,morphology,spatial distribution and porosity (defined as the total volume of the pores divided by the total volume of the material) of the SLMprocessed SS316L is experimentally characterized and correlated with the mechanical properties.More importantly,a micromechanical model taking into account the statistical pore characteristics from the XCT analysis is developed to predict the elastic properties of the SS316L product.The numerical prediction results show good agreement with two analytical models and the experimental characterization of the mechanical properties.The present study provides future designers a methodology in predicting the mechanical properties using the XCT analysis results,which is a promising possibility of saving the expensive cost on destructive testing.

name: 2020 - Computational Materials Science - Wang et al. - Experimental characterization and micromechanical-statistical modeling of 316L st-part-3
fileName: 2020 - Computational Materials Science - Wang et al. - Experimental characterization and micromechanical-statistical modeling of 316L st.md
content:
Asa well-known additive manufacturing technique,selective laser melting (SLM) process has demonstrated growing applications in various industrial fields due to its capability of fabricating metallic parts with complex geometries and handling wide ranges of materials [1-4]. During the SLM process,a computer-controlled laser beam is implemented on a powder bed platform to selectively melt and bond a thin layer of the metallic powder into a designed slice of solid. Subsequently, additional layers of powder are applied on top of the previously created solid slice,solidified by the selective laser scanning and bonded to the processed layers such that the entire product is successively built in a layer-by-layer manner [5-7].

Different from the conventional manufacturing methods,such a layer based manufacturing process gives rise to a higher risk of introducing inhomogeneities,in particular a variety of defects and flaw, which affect the mechanical behavior of the final products significantly.

The formation of the internal defects is directly related to the choices of process parameters like laser power, scanning speed and hatch distance. For example, insufficient laser power results in low energy input giving rise to unmolten powder particles [8].A fast scanning speed leads to balling effects generating pores or voids in the SLM parts [9-11]. Similarly,a large hatch distance induces the imperfect bonding between adjacent scanning tracks and layers [12].

name: 2020 - Computational Materials Science - Wang et al. - Experimental characterization and micromechanical-statistical modeling of 316L st-part-4
fileName: 2020 - Computational Materials Science - Wang et al. - Experimental characterization and micromechanical-statistical modeling of 316L st.md
content: As reported by an increasing number of recent literature,X-ray computed tomography (XCT) has been recognized as the most effective nondestructive testing method for inspecting the internal defects of products fabricated by additive manufacturing [13-15]. One significant advantage of XCT over the other contact or non-contact measurement techniques is that it is a powerful volumetric measurement tool in evaluating the three-dimensional statistical details of the internal defects (such as microscopic pores) including their morphology [16],size [17],density [18,19] and spatial distribution [8]. Thus XCT has been popularly deployed to analyze the correlation between pore characteristics and the mechanical properties of the SLM processed products. Salarian et al. [7] characterized detailed pore information including size,morphology and orientation using XCT and established a relationship between these pore characteristics and tensile properties of Inconel 625 samples fabricated by SLM technique.Siddique et al.[20] highlighted the effects of pore morphologies,spatial locations and clustering on the fatigue life of SLM processed AlSil2 alloy. Zhang et al. [21]deployed XCT to investigate the porosity-driven cracking mechanism and to bridge the gaps between SLM process parameters and internal structure of 316L stainless steel.A recent review [22] summarized the current development of XCT porosity characterization and its contributions on analyzing mechanical properties of additively manufactured products.

name: 2020 - Computational Materials Science - Wang et al. - Experimental characterization and micromechanical-statistical modeling of 316L st-part-5
fileName: 2020 - Computational Materials Science - Wang et al. - Experimental characterization and micromechanical-statistical modeling of 316L st.md
content: As pointed out in [23],it is meaningful to make use of the threedimensional pore characteristics including distribution,size,morphology and density,characterized by XCT analysis,in predicting their effects on the mechanical properties of the final product.The concept of such predictions were realized in a few recent works by combining the XCT analysis with numerical techniques such as finite element scheme, which demonstrates great capability in incorporating the pore characteristics to predict the mechanical properties.Esposito et al.[9] proposed an interaction procedure between XCT and the finite element method in predicting the mechanical behavior of AlSiloMg fabricated by the SLM technique.The numerical results were verified with the relevant experimental results.Glinz et al. [18] deployed XCT in analyzing the pore size distribution of seven SLM fabricated Ti6Al4V pedicle screws,and generating finite element model by extracting several cubic regions of interest from the reconstructed three dimensional model of each screw to correlate the pore size distribution and elastic properties.However,as reported by the recent review [22], the great potential of numerical modeling on a basis of the XCT data has not been explored extensively.Particularly, the studies on micromechanical modeling for bridging the microscopic defect details characterized by XCTanalysis and the mechanical properties of additively manufactured materials are still very limited.

name: 2020 - Computational Materials Science - Wang et al. - Experimental characterization and micromechanical-statistical modeling of 316L st-part-6
fileName: 2020 - Computational Materials Science - Wang et al. - Experimental characterization and micromechanical-statistical modeling of 316L st.md
content: This paper presents a micromechanical model with statistical consideration of pore characteristics to predict the mechanical properties of metals processed by selective laser melting.Here we take the example of 316L stainless steel (SS3l6L),a high strength stainless steel with good corrosion resistance,which has been commonly used in aerospace,automotive and medical industries [24-26].On a fundamental step,SS316L tensile testing specimens are designed and fabricated usinga variety of SLM process parameters.Subsequently,experimental techniques such as XCT analysis and destructive testing are used to characterize and correlate the quantitative details of internal pores and mechanical properties of the SS3l6L specimens.Last but not the least,a micromechanical model taking into account the statistical pore characteristics from the XCT analysis is proposed to predict the mechanical properties of the SLM processed Ss316L.The accuracy of the prediction results is verified by the experimental characterization as well as the existing analytical solutions.

name: 2020 - Computational Materials Science - Wang et al. - Experimental characterization and micromechanical-statistical modeling of 316L st-part-7
fileName: 2020 - Computational Materials Science - Wang et al. - Experimental characterization and micromechanical-statistical modeling of 316L st.md

name: 2020 - Computational Materials Science - Wang et al. - Experimental characterization and micromechanical-statistical modeling of 316L st-part-8
fileName: 2020 - Computational Materials Science - Wang et al. - Experimental characterization and micromechanical-statistical modeling of 316L st.md
content:
In this study,a 316L stainless steel powder supplied by EOS GmbH (Electro Optical Systems,Krailling/Munich,Germany） was used with the particle size generally ranging between $2 0 ~ { \mu \mathrm { m } }$ and $5 0 ~ { \mu \mathrm { m } }$ .Tensile test specimens were designed to follow ASTME8 testing guidelines [27] and fabricated by EOS M290 SLM system,equipped with a 400 W Yb Fibre laser of focus diameter $0 . 1 \ \mathrm { m m }$ To investigate the effects of pore characteristics on the mechanical properties of the SS316L parts,two levels of energy input, reflected by the values of scanning speed and hatch distance (defined as the distance between adjacent scan tracks) given in Table 1,are selected to fabricate the tensile specimens. Such a printing recipe is composed of the process parameters selected in the reasonable ranges provided by EOS and it is expected to fabricate the parts with a variety of microscopic internal structures.It is worthwhile to mention that parameter optimization is not the purpose of this paper and therefore not performed.Note that the energy input in $J / m m ^ { 3 }$ of a SLM system is defined as Table 1 Four SLM parameter sets for processing the tensile specimens.
Specimen setEnergy input (J/mm3)Scanning speed (mm/s)Hatch distance (mm)Hatch power (W)Layer thickness (mm)

name: 2020 - Computational Materials Science - Wang et al. - Experimental characterization and micromechanical-statistical modeling of 316L st-part-9
fileName: 2020 - Computational Materials Science - Wang et al. - Experimental characterization and micromechanical-statistical modeling of 316L st.md
content: Foreach parameter set in Table 1, three specimens were fabricated in scattered locations of the printing platform to take into account the variations of the SLM process.All the testing specimens were printed in the same orientations as illustrated in Fig.1.As suggested by EOS GmbH,an optimized angle $\boldsymbol { 8 5 ^ { \circ } }$ was applied between the specimen and recoater movement direction for a good quality of recoating.The laser moves in a zigzag pattern with a rotation of $6 7 ^ { \circ }$ between each successive layer to minimize the anisotropy in the mechanical properties. After the fabrication,a standard sandblasting was applied on all the specimens to improve the surface finish.

name: 2020 - Computational Materials Science - Wang et al. - Experimental characterization and micromechanical-statistical modeling of 316L st-part-10
fileName: 2020 - Computational Materials Science - Wang et al. - Experimental characterization and micromechanical-statistical modeling of 316L st.md
content:
X-ray computed tomography was performed using Phoenix Nanotom M(General Electric Company,Pennsylvania,USA) to characterize the internal features of the SLM processed SS316L.A sufficiently large region within the gauge length of the tensile specimen was selected as the region of interest for the XCT characterization. ![](images/7bf195a21214cb53f9724dda8273005c10243b6dd05a49d9f3e5344169ccf23f.jpg) Fig.1.An illustration of printing orientation for a representative tensile specimen.The grey region illustrates a portion of the printing platform and the building direction is along the $\mathbf { z }$ -axis. Table 2 Parameters of XCT scanning and data acquisition.
XCT parameterValue
Voltage (kV)160
Current (μA)145
Filter1 mm Copper
Number of images1600
Voxel size (μm)6
Magnification16.67×
Exposure time (ms)1000
![](images/e1fbaeef4606db61039ff89aa42907fd0cdd5fef53400fa52e93ef605e8bc72d.jpg) Fig.2. Schematic illustration of a cone-beam XCT system. Consistent scanning and data acquisition parameters inclusive of voltage,current,source filter,number of images acquired,voxel size, magnification and exposure time summarized in Table 2 were used for all the scans.The voxel size was selected as $6 \mu \mathrm { m }$ which determined the lower limit of the pore sizes to be detected.The upper limit of the detected pore sizes was set as $1 . 4 ~ \mathrm { m m }$ ,which was proved to be sufficiently large to capture the population of the pores.In this study, the pore size is characterized as the diameter of the circumscribed sphere of the pore.
summary: 2.2. Quantitative characterization for internal pores - Part 1/2

name: 2020 - Computational Materials Science - Wang et al. - Experimental characterization and micromechanical-statistical modeling of 316L st-part-11
fileName: 2020 - Computational Materials Science - Wang et al. - Experimental characterization and micromechanical-statistical modeling of 316L st.md
content:
As illustrated in Fig.2,a cone beam of X-rays transmits through the specimen rotating over $3 6 0 ^ { \circ }$ and attenuates due to scattering and absorption caused by the physical geometry and the material properties. The transmitted signal of the X-ray beam is captured by the areal array detector such that the 2D image of the attenuation distribution at a specific scanned angle is recorded. Upon the completion of the rotation, thousands of 2D images are acquired and subsequently used to reconstruct a high resolution 3D volume by a computing algorithm.In this study, the specimens were placed as close as possible to the X-ray source to optimize the magnification and resolution of the imaging process.

After the scanning and reconstruction,a porosity analysis module together with VG Studio Max3.0 (Volume Graphics GmbH, Heidelberg, Germany) were applied to analyze the internal imperfections such as pores and inclusions by investigating voxel data sets and thereafter to provide the statistical information consisting of the details of each individual defect. The pore analysis was performed by using the VGDefX algorithm [28] in three steps.First,each voxel of the scanned specimen was investigated to determine whether it represents a part of a defect; Second,all the connected voxels picked up in the first step were grouped together and identified as one defect; Last,each defect candidate was analyzed to determine the pore details such as volume, equivalent diameter,morphology and so on.The statistical pore characteristics obtained from the XCT analysis will be used in constructing the micromechanical model in Section 3.
summary: 2.2. Quantitative characterization for internal pores - Part 2/2

name: 2020 - Computational Materials Science - Wang et al. - Experimental characterization and micromechanical-statistical modeling of 316L st-part-12
fileName: 2020 - Computational Materials Science - Wang et al. - Experimental characterization and micromechanical-statistical modeling of 316L st.md
content:
Tensile tests were conducted following ASTM E8 guidelines to determine the mechanical properties of the SLM processed SS316L.The three specimens processed by each parameter set given in Table 1 were tested using a universal testing machine (Shimadzu SFL-25AG,Shimadzu Corp.,Japan) equipped with a load cell 25oKN.A full-field deformation measurement technique,2D digital image correlation (DIC),was adopted to measure the axial and transverse strains of each specimen.To implement the DIC technique,high contrast black and white speckles were applied on one surface of the specimen by mists of spray paint. Each specimen was then clamped at the two ends by two pairs of grips (Fig.3),separated at a speed of $1 . 5 \mathrm { m m / m i n }$ until fracture occurred.Throughout the whole process,a high resolution digital camera was used to record the deformation of the speckles ata frame rate of 24fps.Simultaneously,the load information for calculating the engineering stress was recorded by the universal testing machine at a rate of $_ { 1 0 \ H z }$ .The experimental setup is shown in Fig. 4.

![](images/20967d20ed5ff9a51a882434e58ee6fe5ee0b135a90dd7e63a12129e2464ff0b.jpg)  
Fig.3.A clamped specimen with black and white speckles.

After the tensile tests,a MATLAB script (The MathWorks,Natick, MA USA) was used to convert the DIC video to images at a sampling rate of 1Ofps for the purposes of synchronizing with the load/stress data.The images were subsequently processed using a DIC data processing system (VIC-2D,Correlated solutions,Inc.,Irmo,SC,USA） to compute the averaged axial and transverse strains atan area of interest over the entire gauge length.The resulted strains were synchronized with the stress in another MATLAB script for obtaining the mechanical properties of the 316L stainless steel.

name: 2020 - Computational Materials Science - Wang et al. - Experimental characterization and micromechanical-statistical modeling of 316L st-part-13
fileName: 2020 - Computational Materials Science - Wang et al. - Experimental characterization and micromechanical-statistical modeling of 316L st.md
content:
![](images/f1804f71a54093be108156d6bef6308be87a2883d324212f3ba44115117d3ca0.jpg)  
Fig.4.Experimental setup for the tensile tests.A light source was applied to ensure the specimen was sufficiently and uniformly illuminated.

To evaluate the consistency of the SLM process,statistical analysis were conducted on the resulted mechanical properties.For each parameter set, the mean,standard deviation and coefficient of variations of the mechanical properties of the three specimens were analyzed to evaluate the scattering of the statistical data.

name: 2020 - Computational Materials Science - Wang et al. - Experimental characterization and micromechanical-statistical modeling of 316L st-part-14
fileName: 2020 - Computational Materials Science - Wang et al. - Experimental characterization and micromechanical-statistical modeling of 316L st.md
content: Destructive testing itself is a time-consuming and expensive process to study the effects of the internal defects on the mechanical properties of the SLM products,especially when there are multiple process parameters to be investigated.Here we propose a micromechanical model with statistical considerations,where the quantitative pore characteristics from the XCT analysis are taken into account, to predict the effective mechanical properties,particularly the elastic properties,of the 316L stainless steel. The proposed model is also generally applicable to the other additively manufactured materials provided that the pore characteristics are quantitatively known from the XCT characterization.

name: 2020 - Computational Materials Science - Wang et al. - Experimental characterization and micromechanical-statistical modeling of 316L st-part-15
fileName: 2020 - Computational Materials Science - Wang et al. - Experimental characterization and micromechanical-statistical modeling of 316L st.md
content: Representative volume element (RVE),a popular micromechanical technique for estimating the macroscopic behavior of composites consisting of microscale inhomogeneities such as pores or fibers [29,30] embedding in a matrix,was adopted to model the SLM processed SS316L.There are numerous possibilities to identify an RVE from the large population of pores characterized by the XCT analysis.A simple identification is to take a portion of the matrix containing one single pore as the representation,assuming that all the pores have the same geometry and are uniformly distributed in the specimen.This identification method is popularly adopted in the literature (see,for example, [31,30]),however,it is inadequate to cover the detailed pore characteristics such as spatial distributions and size variations in the micromechanical analysis.
summary: 3.1. Representative volume elements based on quantitative XCT analysis - Part 1/4

name: 2020 - Computational Materials Science - Wang et al. - Experimental characterization and micromechanical-statistical modeling of 316L st-part-16
fileName: 2020 - Computational Materials Science - Wang et al. - Experimental characterization and micromechanical-statistical modeling of 316L st.md
content: For more realistic micromechanical modeling,here we adopt a statistical identification of the RVE to take into account the quantitative pore details from the XCT analysis.As illustrated in Fig.5,the 316L stainless steel was regarded consisting of an array of periodically repeated RVEs.Each RVE was modeled as a square elastic matrix containing $N _ { E }$ pores with the sizes following the statistical distribution of the actual pore sizes from the XCT quantification.More details of the size selections for the $N _ { E }$ pores are given in Section 4.3.The shape of the pores was assumed to be circular considering that the pore sizes were characterized by measuring the circumscribed sphere of each pore in the XCT analysis. Once the sizes of the $N _ { E }$ pores were determined, the pores were randomly distributed within the RVE while the distances between the adjacent pores were not allowed to be smaller than a specific value.For such an RVE,the geometrical details vary with only the spatial coordinates $\mathbf { X }$ and $\mathbf { y }$ and the porosity is defined as the total area of the pores over the area of the entire square.A MATLAB script was coded for realizing the geometrical configuration of the RVEs.
summary: 3.1. Representative volume elements based on quantitative XCT analysis - Part 2/4

name: 2020 - Computational Materials Science - Wang et al. - Experimental characterization and micromechanical-statistical modeling of 316L st-part-17
fileName: 2020 - Computational Materials Science - Wang et al. - Experimental characterization and micromechanical-statistical modeling of 316L st.md
content:
To estimate the effective properties,a unidirectional tension was applied on the RVE along the $\mathbf { X }$ -axis for the micromechanical analysis. Since the RVEs were regarded as periodically repeated in the SS316L material,periodic boundary conditions were applied to the RVE model to ensure that the shape at two opposite boundaries must remain the same and the tractions at the two opposite boundaries must be continuous [32,33].A commercial finite element analysis package (ABAQUS,Simulia, Providence,RI) together with a Python script (Python Software Foundation,Wilmington,Delaware,USA) was adopted to facilitate the micromechanical analysis.The Young's modulus of the elastic matrix was taken as l85GPa as given in the data sheet of the SS316L powder provided by EOS GmbH.However, the Poisson's ratio was not provided in the data sheet.We took its value as O.3 which was widely givenas the Poisson's ratio of the SLM processed 3l6L stainless steel [34-36].The pores were modeled as extremely weak solids with the elastic properties much smaller than the SS316L matrix.Thatis,the values of their Young's modulus (GPa) and Poisson's ratio were taken as 0.0000o1.Six-node plane stress elements CPS6M were used to mesh the RVE and the grid sensitivity study was carried out to verify the mesh convergence by using seed sizes O.025,0.05 and O.1.The effective elastic properties were estimated by using the homogenized stresses $\bar { \sigma } _ { i j }$ and strains $\bar { \varepsilon } _ { i j }$ over the whole RVE (with the volume denoted by $V _ { E } )$ ， which were calculated respectively by

$$
\bar { \sigma } _ { i j } = \frac { 1 } { V _ { E } } \int _ { V _ { E } } \sigma _ { i j } d V _ { E }
$$

and

$$
\bar { \varepsilon } _ { i j } = \frac { 1 } { V _ { E } } \int _ { V _ { E } } \varepsilon _ { i j } d V _ { E }
$$
summary: 3.1. Representative volume elements based on quantitative XCT analysis - Part 3/4

name: 2020 - Computational Materials Science - Wang et al. - Experimental characterization and micromechanical-statistical modeling of 316L st-part-18
fileName: 2020 - Computational Materials Science - Wang et al. - Experimental characterization and micromechanical-statistical modeling of 316L st.md
content: where $\sigma _ { i j }$ and $\varepsilon _ { i j }$ denote respectively the spatially variable stress and strain components in the RVE.More specifically,the effective Young's modulus was calculated by dividing the homogenized axial stress over the corresponding axial strain along the $\mathbf { X }$ direction and the effective Poisson's ratio calculated by using the homogenized transverse and axial strains.
summary: 3.1. Representative volume elements based on quantitative XCT analysis - Part 4/4

name: 2020 - Computational Materials Science - Wang et al. - Experimental characterization and micromechanical-statistical modeling of 316L st-part-19
fileName: 2020 - Computational Materials Science - Wang et al. - Experimental characterization and micromechanical-statistical modeling of 316L st.md
content:
In the present study,the number of pores involved in the XCT analysis of each tensile specimen reaches 1.8 million.The concept of statistics is adopted to ensure that the numerical predictions using the RVE model are accurate sufficiently in inferring the elastic properties of the SS316L specimens containing such a huge number of pores.

![](images/16ba1de7f9ecf489e93844baf5798055cbdb30ff500a11c9a417c999a4ed3e8c.jpg)  
Fig.5.Arepresentative volume element containing randomly distributed pores and its equivalent homogeneous solid.

Here the 'population'refers to the elastic properties of tensile specimens (fabricated using a given SLM parameter set) containing a vast amount of pores.For a statistical analysis,we built a sample of $n _ { r }$ RVE realizations (that is, $n _ { r }$ is the sample size) to infer the effective elastic properties in the population.The statistical technique presented by [37,38] was closely followed here to select a sample size $n _ { r }$ sufficiently large for representing the population.

The Central Limit Theorem [39] pointed out that the mean value $\mu$ of the population can be inferred by the sample mean $\bar { x }$ and standard deviation $s _ { x }$ via

$$
\hat { x } - 2 . 5 8 \frac { s _ { x } } { \sqrt { N _ { x } } } \leqslant \mu \leqslant \bar { x } + 2 . 5 8 \frac { s _ { x } } { \sqrt { N _ { x } } } ,
$$

with a $9 9 \%$ confidence interval for a sample size $N _ { x }$ . At the same time, the difference between the mean value $\mu$ of the population and the one $\bar { x }$ of the sample is strictly limited to be within a specified error ∈,that is,

$$
| ( \mu - \bar { x } ) / \bar { x } | \leqslant \epsilon ,
$$

thus the number of RVE realizations $n _ { r }$ needs satisfy

$$
n _ { r } \geqslant ( 2 . 5 8 \frac { s _ { x } } { \bar { x } \in } ) ^ { 2 } ,
$$

name: 2020 - Computational Materials Science - Wang et al. - Experimental characterization and micromechanical-statistical modeling of 316L st-part-20
fileName: 2020 - Computational Materials Science - Wang et al. - Experimental characterization and micromechanical-statistical modeling of 316L st.md
content: which was used to determine the minimum number of RVE realizations, ensuring that the error between the inferred population mean and the sample mean of the elastic properties falls in the specified error.

name: 2020 - Computational Materials Science - Wang et al. - Experimental characterization and micromechanical-statistical modeling of 316L st-part-21
fileName: 2020 - Computational Materials Science - Wang et al. - Experimental characterization and micromechanical-statistical modeling of 316L st.md

name: 2020 - Computational Materials Science - Wang et al. - Experimental characterization and micromechanical-statistical modeling of 316L st-part-22
fileName: 2020 - Computational Materials Science - Wang et al. - Experimental characterization and micromechanical-statistical modeling of 316L st.md
content:
The results for the quantitative pore characteristics analyzed by the XCT technique are presented in this section.

The first group of the results is the pore size distributions which are the most important pore features for the present study.The XCT analysis shows that the detected pores have a wide variety of sizes ranging from $1 4 . 7 \mu \mathrm { m }$ to $1 . 2 \mathrm { m m }$ across the microscopic and macroscopic world and the smallest pore population in a single specimen is 919,672.To capture the broad size distribution for such huge population of pores, we divided the range of the pore sizes into $N _ { i n t }$ intervals and plotted the frequency polygon to capture the number of pores in each intervals. Considering that the size distribution may be dependent on the number of the pore size intervals,various values of $N _ { i n t }$ were taken to divide the full range of the pore sizes. Figs. 6 and 7 present the frequency polygon of the pore sizes for $N _ { i n t } = 6 0$ ,120,240 and 480 for two representative specimens processed by the low (Set A) and high (Set C) level of the energy input. Since the plots for the pore sizes larger than $0 . 1 \ \mathrm { m m }$ are almost visually overlapping with the horizontal axis,we only present the frequency polygon for the pore sizes ranging from $0 . 0 1 4 7 \ \mathrm { m m }$ to $0 . 1 \ \mathrm { m m }$ .Note that the ordinate of each data point ona single polyline denotes the number of pores located in the pore size intervals between the abscissas of the previous and current points.Take the polyline for 60 intervals in Fig.6 as an example.The data point at the pore size $0 . 0 3 4 7 ~ \mathrm { { m m } }$ indicates that there are 918,096 pores with sizes between $0 . 0 1 4 7 ~ \mathrm { m m }$ and $0 . 0 3 4 7 ~ \mathrm { { m m } }$

name: 2020 - Computational Materials Science - Wang et al. - Experimental characterization and micromechanical-statistical modeling of 316L st-part-23
fileName: 2020 - Computational Materials Science - Wang et al. - Experimental characterization and micromechanical-statistical modeling of 316L st.md
content:
It is observed that the polylines are getting converged as the full pore size range is discretized into more intervals.The plots for 960 intervals,although not presented,are almost overlapping with the polylines for 48O intervals.This is as expected from the basic statistics knowledge.Moreover,the profiles of the pore frequency polygon for the Set A and Set C specimens are generally similar although the number of pores in each size intervals in Set A is much larger than the corresponding number of pores in Set C.

![](images/589174ff8b68ca821f0b59487f6e4db041262d5e979e62fd0fedddad35aa0626.jpg)  
Fig.6.Pore size distribution for a representative specimen in Set A processed by the low energy input expressed in terms of frequency polygon.The plots for pore size larger than $0 . 1 \ \mathrm { m m }$ are not presented since they are visually overlapped with the horizontal axis.

![](images/4ea33e27e0b5f10cb0acb3dd27eb1a609dccbccefc9a7f3848aeadc6fb4b36b1.jpg)  
Fig.7.Pore size distribution for a representative specimen in Set C processed by the high energy input expressed in terms of frequency polygon.The plots for pore size larger than $0 . 1 \ \mathrm { m m }$ are not presented since they are visually overlapped with the horizontal axis.

![](images/85f7cc7533a97643dce433ac7e04ac62655363933031c9d38f389cae38fdb050.jpg)  
Fig.8.Relative frequency of representative specimens in Sets A and C.

name: 2020 - Computational Materials Science - Wang et al. - Experimental characterization and micromechanical-statistical modeling of 316L st-part-24
fileName: 2020 - Computational Materials Science - Wang et al. - Experimental characterization and micromechanical-statistical modeling of 316L st.md
content:
To beter understand the pore size distributions of the specimens fabricated by the low and high energy input, Fig.8 plots the relative frequency of the pore sizes divided into 48o intervals for Sets Aand C. It is interesting to find that although the number of pores in each pore size interval is different for the specimens fabricated by the low and high energy input, the relative frequency of the pore sizes for the two energy levels is generally very close to each other for the pore sizes smaller than $0 . 0 4 \mathrm { ~ m m }$ .However, there is some discrepancy of relative frequency shown between the two energy levels for larger pores.This seems to suggest that the pore size distribution for the low and high energy input specimens may be quite similar for the smaller pores but may have a different story for the larger pores. Table 3 A compact form of relative frequency of the pore sizes for the four sets of specimens.

name: 2020 - Computational Materials Science - Wang et al. - Experimental characterization and micromechanical-statistical modeling of 316L st-part-25
fileName: 2020 - Computational Materials Science - Wang et al. - Experimental characterization and micromechanical-statistical modeling of 316L st.md
content:
Fig.8 has demonstrated a good visualization for the size distribution of the relatively small pores,however,it does not capture clearly the distribution of the larger pore sizes due to their low relative frequency. For further understanding the stories of the larger pore sizes,we categorized the full range of the pore sizes into five groups,the relative frequency of which were calculated by summing up the relative frequencies of the pores in the corresponding intervals in Fig.8.The resulted relative frequency for the five groups of pore sizes is given in Table 3.Also included are the corresponding data for the specimens in Sets B and D.

Table 3 shows that all the four sets of specimens have very similar relative frequency of the pores with the sizes smaller than $0 . 0 7 4 7 \mathrm { \ m m }$ However, the specimens processed with the low energy input are apparently observed to have much more pores with large sizes ranging from $0 . 0 7 4 7 \ \mathrm { m m }$ to $1 . 2 \ \mathrm { m m }$ ,comparing to those specimens processed with the high energy input.The major difference occurs in the pore size group in $\mathbf { 0 . 1 1 5 \ m m }$ ， $1 . 2 \ \mathrm { m m } ]$ ，where the relative frequency of the pores in the Set A specimen is about 2.6 times of the corresponding relative frequency in the Set C specimen. The difference between the relative frequency of the pores in Set B and Set D specimens is even more obvious- there are quite some pores in the Set B specimen having the sizes larger than $0 . 1 1 5 ~ \mathrm { m m }$ whereas such large pores appear to be rarely observed in the Set D specimen.

name: 2020 - Computational Materials Science - Wang et al. - Experimental characterization and micromechanical-statistical modeling of 316L st-part-26
fileName: 2020 - Computational Materials Science - Wang et al. - Experimental characterization and micromechanical-statistical modeling of 316L st.md
content:
The analysis above on the pore size distributions may explain well the porosity given in Table 4 by the XCT characterizations for the four sets of tensile specimens.It is observed that the specimens fabricated by the low energy input, containing more pores greater than $0 . 1 1 5 ~ \mathrm { m m }$ exhibit obviously higher porosity. This may be as expected considering that the porosity is intrinsically dominated by the presence of the larger pores.For a better correlation between the porosity and the larger pores,the number density (defined as the number of pores divided by the total volume under investigation） and relative frequency for the pores above $0 . 1 1 5 ~ \mathrm { m m }$ are also included in Table 4.

The pore size analysis in Tables 3 and 4 can be well visualized by mapping the three dimensional XCT images to transverse,sagittal and coronal planes as illustrated in Fig.9.Figs.1O and 11 respectively present the pore characteristics for the specimens fabricated using the low and high energy input at the transverse and coronal planes.For all the four sets of specimens,it is observed that there are numerous pores of nearly spherical shape having the sizes below $0 . 1 1 5 \mathrm { m m }$ 、As pointed out by [4O],these small pores generally tend to be formed at a low scanning speed due to the gases trapped within the melting pool or the pores evolved from the powder feedstock.

Table 4 Porosity analysis for the four sets of specimens.Also included are the number density and relative frequency of the large pores of sizes above $0 . 1 1 5 ~ \mathrm { m m }$

![](images/835e73f54c12654767a5fd06db009cc893aa7624ac499af8c49909e5a2619c3c.jpg) Fig.9.An illustration of transverse,sagittal and coronal planes in the three dimensional XCT image. On the contrary,the large pores with the sizes above $0 . 1 1 5 \mathrm { m m }$ are observed to have irregular shape in Fig.1O (a) and (c).They are usually generated due to a rapid scanning and solidification where the gaps cannot be completed filled with the molten metal [41].With the scanning speed decreases from $2 1 6 6 \ \mathrm { m m } / s$ (Set A) to $5 4 1 . 5 \ \mathrm { m m } / s$ (Set C),itis obvious that the irregular pores in Fig.11 (a) are significantly reduced compared to Fig.1O (c),whereas the amount of spherical pores increases.This is also well demonstrated by the values of the relative frequency for Set A and Set C in Table 3.The above observations agree well with the conclusions in [40].

name: 2020 - Computational Materials Science - Wang et al. - Experimental characterization and micromechanical-statistical modeling of 316L st-part-28
fileName: 2020 - Computational Materials Science - Wang et al. - Experimental characterization and micromechanical-statistical modeling of 316L st.md
content:
The large pores with the size above $0 . 1 1 5 \mathrm { m m }$ are also observed in Figs.1O (b) and (d). These pores are found in irregular shape too, however,some of them have the spatial locations in linear pattern. They may evidence the lack of fusion caused by the large hatch distance in the laser scanning [16].When the hatch distance decreases from $1 8 0 ~ { \mu \mathrm { m } }$ (Set B) to $4 5 ~ { \mu \mathrm { m } }$ (Set D),the large irregular pores are almost observed to disappear in Fig.11 (b) compared to Fig.1O (d).This is also reflected in Table 3 that the relative frequency for the pores above $0 . 1 1 5 ~ \mathrm { m m }$ in the Set B specimen is $1 . 6 4 \%$ ,however the corresponding relative frequency in the Set D specimen is only $0 . 0 2 \%$

For better comparing the porosity of the specimens processed using the low and high energy input, the three dimensional XCT images for Set Aand Set C are presented in Fig.l2 and the ones for Set Band Set D are shown in Fig. 13.

The mechanical properties characterized for the four sets of SS316L tensile specimens are presented in Table 5 in terms of their mean and standard deviation from the statistical analysis.Correspondingly, the plots of stress-strain curves are shown in Fig.14,and the plots of the transverse strain versus the axial strain are presented in Fig.15.

As may be expected, the specimens processed using the high energy input (Sets C and D) present better mechanical performance in terms of the linear properties,ultimate strength and ductility compared to those by the low energy input (Sets A and B).If we pay closer attention to the two specimen sets within each level of the energy input, it is found that the two parameter sets (A and B) for the low energy input give rise to quite similar material properties.However, the specimens processed by Set D demonstrate obviously better material properties than those by Set C although the two sets share the same energy input.Especially, the ductility of the Set D specimens is much better the other three specimens.

content:
This can be explained in relation to the relative frequency of the large pores with the sizes over $0 . 1 1 5 \ \mathrm { m m }$ in Table 3.As reported in [23],the existence of the large pores gives rise to the stress concentration around the pores,which contributes significantly to a decrease in the ductility.Our Set D specimen is observed to have the lowest relative frequency of the large pores over $0 . 1 1 5 ~ \mathrm { m m }$ diameter, giving rise to a relativelyuniformly distributed state of stresses around the pores,therefore exhibits the best ductility.On comparison,the specimens processed by Sets A and B present relatively higher percentage of the large pores,which may induce stronger stress concentration surrounding the pores,such that their ductility is the worst among the

four sets of specimens.

The statistical variations of the mechanical properties for the three tensile specimens are quantified in Table 5. It is shown that the consistency in most of the mechanical properties are acceptable,however, the variation of the fracture strain is relatively severe.The coefficient of variations for the fracture strain reaches $1 8 . 6 \%$ which occurs in the specimens fabricated by the fastest scanning speed (Set A).Such large inconsistency in the ductility may be caused by the positional variations of the large pores in the different specimens.This indicates that the part-to-part repeatability for the SLM process needs to be further improved in terms of the ductility and the internal defects.

fileName: 2020 - Computational Materials Science - Wang et al. - Experimental characterization and micromechanical-statistical modeling of 316L st.md
content: Prediction results of the mechanical properties using the proposed micromechanical model are presented in this section. Firstly, the RVEs are identified by determining the number of pores required for homogenizing the elastic properties as well as the number of RVE realizations for proper statistical analysis.Subsequently,the effects of the pore size distribution and the distance between the pores on the predicted mechanical properties are investigated.At the same time,the predicted results are benchmarked with two existing analytical solutions as well as the experimental characterization given in Section 4.2.

content:
To ensure the proposed micromechanical model is reliable in predicting the mechanical properties of the SLM processed SS316L,a fundamental step is to identify appropriate RVEs with two important parameters: the number of pores $N _ { E }$ and the number of realizations $n _ { r }$ for the statistical analysis.On one hand,the number of pores in each RVE is required to be sufficiently large to capture the homogenized properties of the RVE.The number of realizations also needs to be adequate to ensure the sample for the statistical analysis is large enough asa reliable reflection of the statistical characteristics of the whole population.On the other hand,both the two numbers should be as small as possible for economic computation. To construct an RVE using the actual pore size distributions from the XCT analysis,the pore sizes in the RVE were selected following the steps below: · Step 1: Divide the full range of the pore sizes in a specific specimen into 48o intervals and calculate the relative frequency for the pore sizes (the same process acquiring the data in Fig. 8); · Step 2: Take an initial number of pores $N _ { i n i }$ in the RVE and calculate the rounded number of pores in each size interval by following the ![](images/8b0087b66b43b30e55681418e4ae12f523273b84155dffdbee5b8b6568f38b97.jpg) Fig3.ut small hatch distance).
