name: 2020 - J. Manufacturing Processes - Tian et al. - Numerical analysis of powder bed generation and single track forming for selective las-part-1
fileName: 2020 - J. Manufacturing Processes - Tian et al. - Numerical analysis of powder bed generation and single track forming for selective las.md
content:
Yunfu Tianab,Lijun Yanga,b\*, Dejin Zhaoab,Yiming Huangab\*,Jiajing an

a SchoolofMaterials Scienceand Enginering,Tianjin University,Tianjin30o350,China bTianjinKeyboratoryofdncedJoingechologyanjino50in College ofElectromechanical Engineering, Qingdao Universityof Scienceand Technology,Qingdao,266o42,China

# ARTICLEINFO


# ABSTRACT
Keywords:   
Selective laser melting   
Track morphology   
Balling defect   
Distortion defect   
Porosity defect

The discrete element method (DEM) and the finite volume method (FVM) were used to build a 3D numerical model to simulate the selective laser melting process(SLM).The Marangoni efect and the recoil pressure were incorporated in the model.Experiments for the single track were performed for verification.The numerical results indicated that melt tracks with diferent morphologies were formed when the same linear energy density (LED) was applied.The formation mechanism of the melt track defects including balling,porosity and distortion were analyzed. It was found that the balling defect was concluded to be resulted by insuficient energy input incapable of melting the substrate.The distortion defect originated from thecombined effect of the random distribution of powder particles and the Marangoni efect.In the keyhole-mode laser melting proces,the unsteady behavior of the molten pool and keyhole led to the porosity defect.
summary: Numerical analysis of powder bed generation and single track forming for selective laser melting of SS316L stainless steel

name: 2020 - J. Manufacturing Processes - Tian et al. - Numerical analysis of powder bed generation and single track forming for selective las-part-2
fileName: 2020 - J. Manufacturing Processes - Tian et al. - Numerical analysis of powder bed generation and single track forming for selective las.md
content: Compared with the traditional manufacturing methods,metal additive manufacturing (AM) with the advantages such as high flexibility, fewer process cycles and the possibility of manufacturing the parts with complex shapes,has received considerable attention from modern manufacturing filed [1,2].Selective laser melting (SLM) is one of the representative additive manufacturing technologies,which has a series of dominant advantages such as no structural restrictions and high formation precision and high efficiency [3].During the SLM process, the powder particles are spread by the roller or the blade layer-by-layer firstly,the laser beam subsequently melts the metal particles to manufacture the desired parts with the guidance of computer-aided design (CAD）model [4,5].However,many defects like balling,distortion, porosity or poor surface quality may be encountered during the SLM process,which is detrimental to the mechanical performance and surface roughness.Therefore,it requires a further understanding of the formation mechanism of defects and the influence of process parameters on the morphology.

name: 2020 - J. Manufacturing Processes - Tian et al. - Numerical analysis of powder bed generation and single track forming for selective las-part-3
fileName: 2020 - J. Manufacturing Processes - Tian et al. - Numerical analysis of powder bed generation and single track forming for selective las.md
content: Notice that a number of deposition parameters have the influences on the quality of the fabricated parts [6],among which laser power, scanning speed,particle size distribution (PSD) and powder bed thickness play dominant roles in the surface morphology and properties of the components.In order to study the influence of process parameters, experimental efforts have been taken to understand the complex thermophysical interaction processes from the perspective of the powder bed generation process [7,8], process parameters [9],common defects [10]. Dursun et al. [11] analyzed the effects of laser power and scanning speed on the surface characteristics of SLM parts.According to their study,detrimental defects,discontinuity,pores and cracks on the surfaces could be generated at a higher scanning speed.Gong et al.[12] focused on the defect formation mechanism during the powder bed fusion processes.Their study indicated that the energy input had a significant effect on defect generation. The mentioned researches provide an improvement in understanding SLM formation.However, the scientific understanding of the complex relationship between process parameters discussed above and the final products is incomplete.Relying solely on the trial-error method to find the appropriate process parameters during the SLM experiments is time-consuming and costly. Furthermore,figuring out the multiple complicated physical phenomena of the SLM process is challenging through the experimental analysis [13]. Therefore, numerical simulation can be a valid tool for enhancing the physical understanding of the SLM process.

name: 2020 - J. Manufacturing Processes - Tian et al. - Numerical analysis of powder bed generation and single track forming for selective las-part-4
fileName: 2020 - J. Manufacturing Processes - Tian et al. - Numerical analysis of powder bed generation and single track forming for selective las.md
content: Over the years, massive researches have focused on the morphology and the formation mechanism of defects using a mesoscopic model at the powder scale. Qiu et al.[1O] established a powder-scale model closely mapping interfacial forces such as surface tension,Marangoni force and recoil pressure.Their study revealed that increased powder bed thickness contributed to the possibility of the presence of porosity.It should be noted that the regularly packed powder bed differed from the actual power bed in terms of particle size distribution and particle spatial distribution. Therefore, modelling the powder bed generation process as close to the actual condition as possble is a premise before establishing a powder-scale SLM model based on the computational fluid dynamic (CFD) method. The powder spreading process mainly involves particle size distribution and powder bed distribution.Due to the presence of issues mentioned,the discrete element method (DEM) is always adopted to simulate the powder bed spreading process.Lee and Zhang [14] adopted the discrete element method (DEM) and the finite volume method (FVM) to research the influences of laser power, scanning speed and powder particle distribution on the molten pool.Their study implied that a faster scanning speed and a lower laser power led to the balling defect. Khairallah et al.[15] proposed a relatively comprehensive model considering the recoil pressure and the Marangoni effect to explore the formation mechanism of common defects during the laser powder bed fusion process.Their model expounded the formation mechanism of spattering,denudation,pore defect. Furthermore,their study revealed the significant effect of the recoil pressure and the Marangoni effect. Yan et al.[16] built a multi-physics field model to identify the formation mechanism of single/multiple-track defects during the EBSM process.

name: 2020 - J. Manufacturing Processes - Tian et al. - Numerical analysis of powder bed generation and single track forming for selective las-part-5
fileName: 2020 - J. Manufacturing Processes - Tian et al. - Numerical analysis of powder bed generation and single track forming for selective las.md
content:
They found that the energy input and the powder bed thickness significantly affected the presence of the balling defect,and the powder size distribution and powder bed thickness were two pivotal process parameters for the single melt track nonuniformity. Qian et al.[17] investigated the influence of process parameters on surface morphology. They found that scanning speed was a critical parameter which was closely related to the dimension of the molten pool and surface morphology.Le et al.[18] developed a physics-based computational fluid dynamics (CFD) model with the application of the ray-tracing technique.Their model demonstrated that the unstable behavior of the molten pool and keyhole accounted for the porosity defect. Most of the aforementioned numerical models mainly concentrate on investigating the influence of various parameters.The formation mechanism of defects during the SLM process has been the focus of intense study over the past several years.However, the comprehensive understanding of the formation mechanism of defects and the influence of process parameters on the forming quality is still lacking.

In this work,the powder spreading process of powder bed based on the discrete element (DEM) method was applied to generate a powder bed.A computational fluid dynamics (CFD) model, in which the recoil pressure and the Marangoni effect were considered,was developed to investigate the formation mechanism of common defects and analyze the forming quality of the single melt track.Meanwhile, corresponding experiments were conducted for the fabrication of melt tracks to validate the numerical model. This paper is expected to provide the guidance for reducing or eliminating common defects during the SLM process.

name: 2020 - J. Manufacturing Processes - Tian et al. - Numerical analysis of powder bed generation and single track forming for selective las-part-6

name: 2020 - J. Manufacturing Processes - Tian et al. - Numerical analysis of powder bed generation and single track forming for selective las-part-7
fileName: 2020 - J. Manufacturing Processes - Tian et al. - Numerical analysis of powder bed generation and single track forming for selective las.md
content:
The DEM software YADE in this work was utilized to simulate the powder bed generation process of $3 1 6 \mathrm { ~ L ~ }$ stainless powder particles.A powder bed was formed by discrete metal particles instead of treating the powder bed as an equivalent region.Fig.1 shows a snapshot of the powder bed generation process.According to the SEM image in Fig.2(a), the individual powder particle can be considered as spherical in good approximation.The particle size distribution was considered to follow the experimental measurement, the particle sizes were found to follow Gaussian distribution with D10,D50,and D90 of 7,22 and $4 0 ~ { \mu \mathrm { m } }$ in diameter,respectively.Fig.2(b) shows the particle size distribution used in the simulation. The simulation of powder bed generation process could mainly be divided into two steps: firstly,a collection of powder particles dropped vertically onto the plate to form a particle pile; secondly,the blade moved along the plate at a specified speed, some particles were pushed into the building chamber to form the powder bed used to manufacture the parts,and others fell into the container.

In the powder bed generation process,the particles modelled as discrete entities update their physical states and motions determined by Newton's second law.The contact forces between spherical powder particles can be decoupled into the normal and tangential force.In the normal direction,a contact model with the non-linear elastic HertzMindlin algorithm is utilized to figure the elastic normal contact force [19],and the damping force is added artificially to solve dissipation of kinetic energy [2O,21]. The elastic normal contact force and damping force can be expressed by the following equations:

![](images/d9b6a187fae2bdb82296f3d34ca57e0bcee284066708e7fab095991bcc207f14.jpg)  
Fig.1.The snapshot of powder bed generation process.
summary: 2.1. Modelling of powder bed generation process - Part 1/3

$$
\begin{array} { l } { { \displaystyle F _ { c } ^ { n } = K _ { n } u _ { n } = \frac { 4 } { 3 } E ^ { * } \sqrt { R ^ { * } } u _ { n } ^ { \frac { 3 } { 2 } } , } } \\ { { \displaystyle F _ { d } ^ { n } = - \sqrt { \frac { 2 0 } { 3 } } \Big ( \mathrm { l n } \sigma \Big / \sqrt { \pi ^ { 2 } + \mathrm { l n } ^ { 2 } \sigma } \Big ) ( m ^ { * } E ^ { * } \sqrt { R ^ { * } u _ { n } } ) ^ { \frac { 1 } { 2 } } , } } \end{array}
$$

where $u _ { n }$ is the overlap between the contacting particles in the normal direction, $K _ { n }$ is the effective stiffness in the normal direction, $E ^ { * } , m ^ { * }$ and $R ^ { * }$ are the equivalent Young's Modulus,mass and radius respectively. $\sigma$ is the restitution coefficient.In the tangential direction,the Mindlin no micro-slip solution is adopted to account for elastic contact force [19]. The elastic contact force can be described by the following equation:

$$
\begin{array} { r } { F _ { e } ^ { t } = K _ { t } u _ { t } = 8 G ^ { * } \sqrt { R ^ { * } u _ { n } } u _ { t } , } \end{array}
$$

The formulation of damping force in the tangential direction is expressed as follows [20,21]:

$$
F _ { d } ^ { n } = - \sqrt { \frac { 8 0 } { 3 } } \Big ( \mathrm { l n } \sigma \Big / \sqrt { \pi ^ { 2 } + \mathrm { l n } ^ { 2 } \sigma } \Big ) ( m ^ { * } G ^ { * } \sqrt { R ^ { * } u _ { n } } ) ^ { \frac { 1 } { 2 } } ,
$$

where $K _ { t } , u _ { t }$ are the effective stiffness and overlap between the particles in the tangential direction respectively. $G ^ { * }$ is the equivalent shear modulus.Once the tangential slide motion occurs,the shear force is calculated using the Mohr-Coulomb model:

$$
F _ { c } ^ { t } = \mu F _ { c } ^ { n } ,
$$

where $\mu$ is the coefficient of friction.
summary: 2.1. Modelling of powder bed generation process - Part 2/3

name: 2020 - J. Manufacturing Processes - Tian et al. - Numerical analysis of powder bed generation and single track forming for selective las-part-9
fileName: 2020 - J. Manufacturing Processes - Tian et al. - Numerical analysis of powder bed generation and single track forming for selective las.md
content:
As a typical cohesion force,the Van der Waals force can not be neglected due to its great effect on the movement of particles whose sizes are less than $1 0 0 ~ { \mu \mathrm { m } }$ 、Hence, the DMT cohesion model is implemented in the DEM simulation algorithm[22].The Van der Waals force can be given by the following equation:

$$
F _ { \nu } = 4 \pi R ^ { * } \zeta ,
$$

where $\zeta$ is surface energy density per unit area.

In the present model,to ensure numerical stability,a safety factor of 0.3 is added into the algorithm which is used to calculate the time step of the simulation which can be expressed as [23]:

$$
t = \partial A t _ { c r } = 0 . 3 R \sqrt { \frac { \rho ^ { * } } { E } } _ { m i n }
$$

where $R _ { m i n }$ is the minimum radius of generated powders, $\rho ^ { * }$ and $E$ represent the density and Young's modulus of the $3 1 6 \mathrm { ~ L ~ }$ materials, respectively.Notice that the diversity of the morphology of powder and the cohesion force between sphere and blade are not taken into account

in this model.

The parameters of the powder bed used during the simulation are summarized in Table 1.Fig.3 shows the powder bed distribution after the accomplishment of the powder bed generation process.The height of the building chamber represented the thickness of the powder bed.In this work, the thickness of the powder bed was adopted to $5 0 ~ { \mu \mathrm { m } }$

content: A CFD model was set up and implemented in the CFD software FLOW-3D using the customized subroutines.In the model,several assumptions or simplifications are considered for simplicity:(1) The melt within the molten pool is assumed to be incompressible Newtonian fluid; (2) The region where the solid and liquid phases coexist is assumed to be a mushy zone;(3) The mass loss due to the metal evaporation is not considered.

fileName: 2020 - J. Manufacturing Processes - Tian et al. - Numerical analysis of powder bed generation and single track forming for selective las.md
content:
To identify the dynamic flow inside the molten pool, the conservation equations of mass,momentum and energy were given by the following equations [25,26]: Mass conservation equation: $$ \nabla \cdot ( \rho \overrightarrow { \nu } ) = 0 , $$ Momentum conservation equation: $$ \partial \rho \frac { \overrightarrow { \nu } } { \partial { t } } + \nabla ( \rho \overrightarrow { \nu } \otimes \overrightarrow { \nu } ) = - \nabla p + \rho \overrightarrow { g } + \overrightarrow { f _ { B } } + \mu _ { T } \nabla ^ { 2 } \overrightarrow { \nu } - K \overrightarrow { \nu } , $$ Energy conservation equation: $$ \frac { \partial \rho h } { \partial t } + \nabla ( \rho \overrightarrow { \nu } h ) = \nabla \cdot ( k \nabla T ) + R _ { E S O R } , $$ where $\overrightarrow { \nu }$ is the velocity of the molten pool, $\mu _ { T }$ denotes the viscosity of the liquid material, $t$ is the time, $p$ is the pressure, $\overrightarrow { g }$ represents the gravitational acceleration, $T$ is the fluid temperature, $h$ is enthalpy, $\rho$ Table 1 Parameters used in DEM simulation [24].

name: 2020 - J. Manufacturing Processes - Tian et al. - Numerical analysis of powder bed generation and single track forming for selective las-part-12
fileName: 2020 - J. Manufacturing Processes - Tian et al. - Numerical analysis of powder bed generation and single track forming for selective las.md
content:
$$
\overrightarrow { f _ { B } } = \rho g \beta ( T - T _ { r e f } ) ,
$$

where $\beta$ is the thermal expansion coefficient, $T _ { r e f }$ is the reference temperature.In this work,the region where the liquid and solid phases coexist is treated as the mushy zone.When liquid metal flow moves through the mushy zone,the flow is considered as though it is in porous media.

$$
K = C \frac { F _ { s } ^ { 2 } } { \left( 1 - F _ { s } \right) ^ { 3 } + B } ,
$$

here, $C$ is a constant representing mushy zone morphology, $F _ { S }$ denotes the solid fraction,and $B$ is a small constant used to avoid division by zero.

The volume of fluid (VOF) method [14] is applied to capture the free surface, the VOF equation can be expressed as:

$$
\frac { \partial V _ { F } } { \partial t } + \boldsymbol { \nabla } ( \overrightarrow { \nu } \cdot V _ { F } ) = 0 ,
$$

where $V _ { F }$ represents the metallic volume fraction within the cell.When $V _ { F } = 1$ ,it means that a cellis full of fluid,whereas $V _ { F } = 0$ corresponds to a cell that contains no fluid.Values in between indicate the free surface exists in this cell.

name: 2020 - J. Manufacturing Processes - Tian et al. - Numerical analysis of powder bed generation and single track forming for selective las-part-13
fileName: 2020 - J. Manufacturing Processes - Tian et al. - Numerical analysis of powder bed generation and single track forming for selective las.md
content:
One of the main driving forces is the Marangoni force caused by the variation of surface tension. The surface tension of the liquid metal can be expressed as a linear function of temperature [14]:

$$
\gamma = \gamma _ { 0 } + \frac { d \gamma } { d T } ( T - T _ { m } ) ,
$$

where $\gamma$ is the surface tension, $\gamma _ { 0 }$ is the surface tension at the melting temperature, $\frac { d \gamma } { d T }$ is the temperature coeficient of surface tension.

During the SLM process,the recoil pressure was exerted on the molten pool when it reached or exceeded the evaporation point of SS316 $\mathbf { L } ,$ affecting the morphology and properties of the fabricated parts.The recoil pressure is given by the equation [27]:

$$
P _ { R } = 0 . 5 4 P _ { 0 } \mathrm { e x p } ( L _ { \nu } \frac { T - T _ { b } } { R T T _ { b } } ) ,
$$

where $P _ { 0 }$ represents the atmospheric pressure, $L _ { \nu }$ is the latent heat of evaporation, $T _ { b }$ is the boiling temperature, $R$ denotes the gas constant.

The laser beam power density is assumed to approximately follow Gaussian distribution.During the laser scanning process,the laser beam moves along the positive direction of $\mathbf { X }$ -axis at a constant scanning speed, and hence the laser beam power density can be expressed as:

$$
q = \frac { 2 A P } { \pi R _ { b } ^ { 2 } } \mathrm { e x p } [ - 2 \frac { \left( x - \nu t - x _ { 0 } \right) ^ { 2 } + \left( y - y _ { 0 } \right) ^ { 2 } } { R _ { b } ^ { 2 } } ] ,
$$

where $A$ is the laser absorption of the powder bed, $P$ represents the laser power, $R _ { b }$ denotes the radius of the laser beam, $\nu$ is the scanning speed. $( x _ { 0 } , y _ { 0 } )$ represents the original position of the laser beam center. The radius of the laser beam $R _ { b }$ is adopted to $4 0 ~ { \mu \mathrm { m } }$

fileName: 2020 - J. Manufacturing Processes - Tian et al. - Numerical analysis of powder bed generation and single track forming for selective las.md
content:
The convection and radiation are considered on every surface,and evaporation can not be neglected for the surface of the molten pool. Hence,the energy balance on the surface of the molten pool can be given as:

$$
k \frac { \partial T } { \partial  \overrightarrow { n } } = q - h _ { c } ( T - T _ { 0 } ) - \sigma _ { 0 } \varepsilon \big ( T ^ { 4 } - T _ { 0 } ^ { 4 } \big ) - q _ { e v a p } ,
$$

where $h _ { c }$ is the convective heat transfer coeficient, $T _ { 0 }$ is the ambient temperature, $\sigma _ { 0 }$ represents the Stefan-Boltzmann constant, $\varepsilon$ is the emissivity. $q _ { e v a p }$ is the heat loss due to evaporation and can be expressed by the equation [28]:

$$
q _ { e \nu a p } = w _ { 0 } L _ { \nu } = e x p \bigg ( 2 . 5 2 + 6 . 1 2 1 - { \frac { 1 8 8 3 6 } { T } } - 0 . 5 \log T \bigg ) L _ { \nu }
$$

where $\omega _ { 0 }$ is the evaporation rate.

name: 2020 - J. Manufacturing Processes - Tian et al. - Numerical analysis of powder bed generation and single track forming for selective las-part-15
fileName: 2020 - J. Manufacturing Processes - Tian et al. - Numerical analysis of powder bed generation and single track forming for selective las.md
content:
Based on the mentioned theoretical model in Section 2.1,the powder bed generation process of $^ { 3 1 6 \mathrm { ~ L ~ } }$ stainless powder particles was simulated.Subsequently, the powder bed was imported into FLOW-3D in the form of STL format to build the CFD model.Fig.4 shows a schematic description of the simulation domain (the length of $1 1 0 0 \mu \mathrm { m }$ ,the width of $3 0 0 \mu \mathrm { m } .$ ,and the height of $2 3 0 ~ { \mu \mathrm { m } } )$ .The thickness of the powder bed and the height of the substrate were $5 0 \mu \mathrm { m }$ and $1 5 0 \mu \mathrm { m } .$ ,respectively.A regular grid with a uniform size of $5 \mu \mathrm { m }$ was adopted to mesh the whole computational domain, the time step was set to be $1 \times 1 0 ^ { - 8 } s$ .In this study，the explicit method was used to solve the convection,heat transfer and surface tension,and the GMERS implicit method was used to solve the pressure.A fixed monitoring point A(as shown in Fig.4) was set to record the molten pool temperature variation during the SLM process. $3 1 6 \mathrm { ~ L ~ }$ stainless steel was selected as the material whose thermophysical properties of SS316 L [4,25,29] used in the simulation are

Y. Tian et al.

![](images/a4396781abfef15edab01db1274bb60cbbf1d7f37001c0e27548e40522dbd459.jpg)  
Fig.4. Schematic description of the simulation domain.

shown in Table 2.

In the present work,different combined process parameters were taken into the calculation to analyze the influence of process parameters on the forming quality of the single melt track,as listed in Table 3. The combined process parameters were divided into two categories: group A had the same linear energy density (LED),and laser power increased proportionally with scanning speed; group B had a constant laser power whereas scanning speed increased, resulting in a corresponding decrease in the energy input.

content: In order to validate the numerical model, single-track SLM experiments were conducted.The single melt track was fabricated by an EOSINT M 28O with an ytterbium fiber laser as the energy source.The gas-atomized $3 1 6 \mathrm { ~ L ~ }$ powders with approximately spherical shape were used in the experiments,the particle size distribution is shown in Fig.2. The thickness of the powder bed is $5 0 ~ { \mu \mathrm { m } }$ ,and the laser spot size is 80 μm.

content:
As shown in Fig.5, there existed differences in the forming quality of the single melt track obtained under different combined process parameters. The simulation results indicated that the forming quality of the single melt track varied even if the same linear energy density (LED) was applied.As illustrated in Fig.5(a),the balling defect occurred, the discontinuous track with poor surface morphology was formed in the calculation scheme A1.When laser power and laser scanning speed increased to $3 0 \mathrm { W }$ and $1 0 0 \mathrm { m m } / s$ respectively, the single melt track was distorted.The formation mechanism of the distortion defect and the ballng defect will be detailly discussed in Section 3.2 and Section 3.3, respectively.Fig.5(c) shows the straight morphology of the single melt track in the calculation scheme A3.The dimension of the molten pool in Fig.5(a) was very small,which was approximately equivalent to the diameter of the laser beam $( 8 0 ~ \mu \mathrm { m } )$ .Additionally, the increase in the length of the molten pool was more obvious than the change of the width,which accounted for the transformation from the circular shape to the comet-like shape of the molten pool.

name: 2020 - J. Manufacturing Processes - Tian et al. - Numerical analysis of powder bed generation and single track forming for selective las-part-20
fileName: 2020 - J. Manufacturing Processes - Tian et al. - Numerical analysis of powder bed generation and single track forming for selective las.md
content:
Fig.6 shows the temperature fields of the powder bed on the X-Z plane in the calculation scheme A1,A2 and A3.In Fig.6(a),the penetration depth of the molten pool was not large enough,and many voids still existed between particles and the substrate.This poor bonding between the powder bed and the substrate can lead to bad mechanical properties of as-built parts.Additionally,the irregular undulations of the melt track were also obvious.The penetration depth generated in calculation scheme A2(Fig. 6(b)) was deeper than that in the calculation scheme A1 (Fig. 6(a)), the melt volume of the substrate increased,and the number of voids decreased obviously.As laser power and scanning speed increased,a flat surface was obtained as shown in Fig.6(c).The penetration depth of the melting substrate also increased,all of the voids were filled with the liquid metal,forming a sound bonding.According to the simulation results,the isotherm curves became slender with the variation of simulation parameters,the isotherm curves were denser at the forepart of the molten pool.

In order to distinguish the diverse laser melting process,the temperature variation of the molten pool (point A,as illustrated in Fig.4) was investigated, Fig.7 shows the temperature-time curves of a fixed monitoring point A at different parameters.

content:
In the calculation scheme A1,the peak temperature of A was $2 0 6 9 \mathrm { K } ,$ exceeding the melting temperature represented by the dashed line (Fig. 7(a)). At $\mathbf { t } = 3 . 6 \ \mathrm { m s }$ ,the fixed location began to be heated.At the range of $3 . 6 \mathrm { m } s { - 6 . 5 \mathrm { m } s }$ ,the slope of the T-t curve was small,indicating it experienced a slow heating process.The laser energy was not directly irradiated to A,but the heat conduction between powder particles took place.When t was at the range of $6 . 5 ~ \mathrm { m s } { - 7 . 7 ~ \mathrm { m s } }$ ,the laser beam interacted with powder particle,and A was heated to the peak temperature sharply.The heating rate was approximately $1 . 2 5 7 \times 1 0 ^ { 6 } ~ \mathrm { K } / s$ in this process.When the laser beam moved away from the fixed point, the temperature of the molten pool decreased rapidly.At $\mathrm { t } = 8 . 7 ~ \mathrm { m s }$ ，the temperature of the molten pool decreased to 1697 K,the slope of the curve was changed slightly due to the latent heat of melting,and the cooling rate of A was $\bar { 3 . 3 6 \times 1 0 ^ { 5 } \mathrm { K } / s }$ in this process.

The $T _ { m a x }$ in the T-t curve was $2 4 7 2 \mathrm { K }$ ，surpassing the peak temperature obtained at the simulation condition of $\mathbf { P } = 3 0$ W and $\mathbf { v } = 1 0 0 \mathrm { m m } / $ s (Fig. 7(b)). At $\mathbf { t } = 3 . 3 ~ \mathrm { m s }$ ,due to the higher scanning speed, the laser beam began to heat the point A.It was heated to the maximum temperature after O.67 ms,the heating rate and cooling rate were $2 . 8 6 1 \times$ $\bar { 1 } 0 ^ { 6 } \mathrm { K } / s$ $8 . 7 1 \times 1 0 ^ { 5 } \mathrm { K } / s$ ,respectively.
summary: 3.1．Morphology and thermal behavior of single melt track - Part 4/5

name: 2020 - J. Manufacturing Processes - Tian et al. - Numerical analysis of powder bed generation and single track forming for selective las-part-22
fileName: 2020 - J. Manufacturing Processes - Tian et al. - Numerical analysis of powder bed generation and single track forming for selective las.md
content:
As shown in Fig.7(c),when the power and scanning speed increased continuously, the peak temperature of A increased to 2957 K,which was nearly the evaporation temperature of the material.The heating rate of $6 . 9 4 8 \times 1 0 ^ { 6 } \mathrm { K } / s$ and cooling rate of $2 . 4 4 8 \times 1 0 ^ { 6 } \mathrm { K } / s$ were obtained.

Based on the simulation results,it is clear that the peak temperature, the heating rate and cooling rate tend to increase when laser power and scanning speed within the same linear energy density (LED) increase in the same proportion to keep an invariable heat input.By definition, the identical linear energy density (LED) merely indicates that the same amount of energy is applied on a certain scanning distance.It can be useful to understand the differences from the perspective of the variation of energy dissipation [3O].The energy dissipation time is affected bythe interaction time between laser energyand material.Ata higher laser scanning speed,the energy dissipation time is shorter,which accounts for the differences under different combinations of laser power and scanning speed within a constant LED.
summary: 3.1．Morphology and thermal behavior of single melt track - Part 5/5

name: 2020 - J. Manufacturing Processes - Tian et al. - Numerical analysis of powder bed generation and single track forming for selective las-part-23
fileName: 2020 - J. Manufacturing Processes - Tian et al. - Numerical analysis of powder bed generation and single track forming for selective las.md
content:
Fig.8(a)-(h) and Fig.8(i) shows the top views of simulation results at different times and the experimental result $( \mathrm { P } = 3 0 \mathrm { W }$ $\mathbf { v } = 1 0 0 \mathrm { m m } / s )$ ， respectively.The red box in Fig.8(a) is the scanning track of the laser beam.The laser beam energy follows Gaussian distribution,so the energy density is relatively higher in the central region of the laser beam. As a result, the particles located in this area could reach the melting temperature to form the molten pool firstly.When the energy source moved forwards along the positive direction of the $\mathbf { X }$ -axis,the particles on the scanning track were continuously heated to form the molten pool. Owing to the random distribution of metal particles in the powder bed and Gaussan distribution of powder size,the particles in the periphery of the scanning track were randomly distributed.The small particles near the laser spot were melted completely,forminga relatively straight track,even if the low LED was applied.However, the energy acting on the particles was inadequate to completely melt the large particles.

![](images/8741a8c619b51b0085b6711e59be22b90df0308e10376720f032a079d85fa425.jpg)  
Fig.7.Temperature-time curves of fixed monitoring point A at different parameters: (a) calculation scheme A1; (b) calculation scheme A2; (c) calculation scheme A3.

name: 2020 - J. Manufacturing Processes - Tian et al. - Numerical analysis of powder bed generation and single track forming for selective las-part-24
fileName: 2020 - J. Manufacturing Processes - Tian et al. - Numerical analysis of powder bed generation and single track forming for selective las.md
content: Consequently,the unsteady morphology was formed inevitably.The partially melted metal particles maintained close contact with the scanning track when the molten pool solidified,which increased the unevenness of the melt track (Fig.8(b)-(c)).At $\mathbf { t } = 3 . 6 ~ \mathrm { m s }$ ,the molten pool deflected from the laser scanning path,this region corresponded to region 1 marked by the red dotted line in Fig.8(a).Region1 was composed of particles with small sizes,these small powders were melted to form the molten pool firstly. On the left side of the molten pool along the laser scanning direction,the partially melted particles were dragged into the molten pool by the surface tension.This area consisting of larger powders became vacant and the melt track deflected to the right side.As the laser moved to region 2 where the size of metal particles was relatively smaller,the molten pool was stretched and deflected again (as shown in Fig.8(e)).The molten pool formed the twisted track in regions 3 and 4,respectively (as shown in Fig.8(f)-(g)).
summary: 3.2. The formation mechanism of distortion defect - Part 2/3

name: 2020 - J. Manufacturing Processes - Tian et al. - Numerical analysis of powder bed generation and single track forming for selective las-part-25
fileName: 2020 - J. Manufacturing Processes - Tian et al. - Numerical analysis of powder bed generation and single track forming for selective las.md
content: It could be found from Fig.8(a)-(i) that when the laser energy density was low, the random distribution of powder particles on the scanning track had a significant influence on the molten pool.The cause of the distortion defect can be concluded in the following perspectives.The spatial arrangement of powder particles in the layer is random,and small metal particles can be completely melted with less heat.The substrate below the small particle aggregation region is prone to be melted,the partially melted larger particles in the single melt track are dragged into the molten pool for the effect of the surface tension. On the otherhand,the temperature of partially melted large particles in the periphery of the laser beam is relatively low,resulting in the large surface tension gradient between the molten pool and the partially melted particles.The molten pool is distorted under the Marangoni effect.Based on the results,itis demonstrated that the random distribution of powder particles on the scanning track is important for the development of the distortion defect. Due to the random distribution at the scanning track edges of powder particles with different sizes,itis diffcult to obtain a completely straight melt track without the distortion defect.Therefore, it is suggested that the distortion phenomenon can be improved by appropriately reducing powder particle size.
summary: 3.2. The formation mechanism of distortion defect - Part 3/3

name: 2020 - J. Manufacturing Processes - Tian et al. - Numerical analysis of powder bed generation and single track forming for selective las-part-26
fileName: 2020 - J. Manufacturing Processes - Tian et al. - Numerical analysis of powder bed generation and single track forming for selective las.md
content:
According to Refs.[11,l2],the energy input hasa significant effect on the forming quality of melt tracks. Therefore,the efects of the energy input on forming quality would be discussed in this section.Based on the simulation schemes,group B had a constant laser power of $1 5 0 ~ \mathrm { W }$ ,and four different scanning speeds were chosen. Group B was applied to investigate the effects of the energy input on the forming quality of the single melt track.

The surface morphology of the single melt track obtained from simulation (calculation scheme B4) and the experiment is illustrated in Fig.9.The result of the simulation agreed well with that of the experiment.A discontinuous track with the balling defect was formed in the calculation scheme B4 (150 W, $1 3 0 0 \mathrm { m m } / s $ ). Due to the low heat input, there were still a large number of voids between the melt track and the substrate,which led to bad connectivity between the melt track and the substrate (Fig. 9(b)). The balling phenomenon occurs commonly during the SLM process when the inappropriate parameters are utilized, causing the poor bonding between layers,low density of parts and even damaging to the blade when the height of the ball is higher than designed layer thickness [31].
summary: 3.3.Effects of energy input on forming quality - Part 1/5

name: 2020 - J. Manufacturing Processes - Tian et al. - Numerical analysis of powder bed generation and single track forming for selective las-part-27
fileName: 2020 - J. Manufacturing Processes - Tian et al. - Numerical analysis of powder bed generation and single track forming for selective las.md
content:
To further understand the forming process of the balling defect, Fig.lO illustrates the simulation results of the temperature field in the calculation scheme B4 at different times.The molten pool directly below the laser beam was unstable,and the rear end was quickly disconnected from the front end, forming the balling defect.As shown in Fig.10(b), due to the non-uniformity of the powder bed,a small void appeared in the middle of the molten pool.As the laser moved forwards,the gap continuously increased,as shown in Fig.1O(c).The melt track was completely broken and divided into two parts,and the rear end formed a ball (Fig.1O(d)). The formation of void and its expansion were caused by a strong backward flow driven by the surface tension caused by the temperature gradient.Discontinuous characters of the melt track could be recognized in the periphery of the melt track (Fig.10(e)-(f)).

![](images/40f16b6cfaa11061b12c72c41439ef59b2edec99de8a5a27ca10b88a3dc4d4b7.jpg)  
Fig.8.Simulated and experimental results of the distorted track $( \mathrm { P } = 3 0 ~ \mathrm { W }$ $\mathbf { v } = 1 0 0 \mathrm { m m } / s ,$ : (a)-(h) simulation results at different times,(i) experimental result

![](images/7a1f90aed501b8901688d61cf5dbe76333b33949eb02ba608c4c42631bc4c98e.jpg)  
Fig.9.Simulated and experimental results of calculation scheme B4: (a) 3-dimensional view; (b)sectional view $( \mathtt { Y } = 1 5 0 \mu \mathrm { m } )$ ; (c) corresponding experimental result

![](images/0025d6b174fb6a40fc442fe34e16de08a60df16d58e9211c104646c1ed3c464c.jpg)  
Fig.10.The formation process of the balling defect in calculation scheme B4.

name: 2020 - J. Manufacturing Processes - Tian et al. - Numerical analysis of powder bed generation and single track forming for selective las-part-28
fileName: 2020 - J. Manufacturing Processes - Tian et al. - Numerical analysis of powder bed generation and single track forming for selective las.md
content:
Based on the above discussion, the cause of the balling defect can be summarized.Insuficient energy input is incapable of melting the substrate below the powder bed.When the substrate below the powder particles is melted,the wetting behavioris beneficial for the spreading of the melted particles on the substrate,contributing to the sound bonding between the solidified track and the substrate [16,25].According to the analysis above,the issue of insufficient melting of the substrate below the powder bed is responsible for the balling defect.The effective approach of diminishing the balling defect is to provide sufficient energy input.Additionally,a thinner powder bed composed of particles with smaller sizes can be used to ensure a well metallurgical bonding between the melted particles and the substrate.It is noted that suficient energy input can ensure powder particles fully fused and bonded with the previous layer,avoiding the possibility of interlayer defects.

For the same powder bed, the surface quality of the melt track in the calculation scheme B3 (150 W, $1 0 0 0 \mathrm { m m } / s \mathrm { \Omega }$ was improved,a continuous but nonuniform melt track was formed, as illustrated in Fig.11.As can be seen in Fig.1l(a),spatter was generated due to the instability of the molten pool under the interaction of the Marangoni effect and the recoil pressure.Another issue was the occurrence of the denudation zone. In the calculation scheme B2 (150 W, $6 0 0 \mathrm { m m } / s $ ,witha higher heat input than that in the calculation scheme B3 or the calculation scheme B4, the melt track was even and straight,as shown in Fig.12. Under the combined effects of the Marangoni force and the recoil pressure,a larger depth was generated.A perfect wetting effect between the molten metal and the substrate was obtained to avoid the occurrence of the balling effect.
summary: 3.3.Effects of energy input on forming quality - Part 3/5

name: 2020 - J. Manufacturing Processes - Tian et al. - Numerical analysis of powder bed generation and single track forming for selective las-part-29
fileName: 2020 - J. Manufacturing Processes - Tian et al. - Numerical analysis of powder bed generation and single track forming for selective las.md
content:
Finally,the keyhole-mode laser melting occurred when the laser scanning speed further decreased to $2 0 0 \ \mathrm { m m } / s$ .The collapse of the keyhole is responsible for the appearance of the porosity,and the formation mechanism of porosity is similar to that of deep penetration laser welding [32]. The flow pattern of the melt within the molten pool was strongly influenced by the interaction between the surface tension and the recoil pressure and other factors [25].Therefore,the flow of the melt within the molten pool exhibited unstable dynamic behavior,leading to the porosity defect.

The forming process of the pores in the keyhole-mode laser melting process is shown in Fig.l3.The melt flowed randomly on the front of the keyhole wall.At the rear of the molten pool, the flow of molten metal was very complex and unstable.The flow direction of the melt is shown in the white line segment in Fig.13(b).The melt flowed downward near the surface of the rear wall of the keyhole while the melt at the rear area of the keyhole flowed upward along the fusion line,resulting in a clockwise vortex at the rear area of the molten pool. Such melt flow patterns mainly caused by the recoil pressure and the surface tension were also observed in the laser welding simulation [32,33]. The flow field signed by the black arrows indicated that the fluid velocity near the keyhole was more drastic than that of other parts of the molten pool, revealing the melt near the keyhole flowed with a strong and unstable flow pattern.Due to the melt backflow,a hump was formed on the rear wall of the keyhole.The severe fluctuation and instability of the keyhole caused the collapse of the hump,and the pore was generated at the bottom of the keyhole,as shown in Fig.l3(c)-(e).A hump collapsed again so that a pore formed again (Fig.l3(f)).Notably, the gas pores rapped in the solidified metal led to the residual pores.
summary: 3.3.Effects of energy input on forming quality - Part 4/5

Fig.11.Simulated and experimental results of calculation scheme B3: (a) 3-dimensional view; (b)sectional view $( \mathrm { Y } = 1 5 0 ~ \mu \mathrm { m } )$ ； (c） corresponding experi mental result.

![](images/a34769d312c3de29dd3d97e48282c7729ae289dc2f88b7a60ff9186636220e3b.jpg)  
Fig.12.Simulated and experimental resultsof calculation scheme B2: (a) 3-dimensional view; (b) sectional view $( \mathrm { Y } = 1 5 0 ~ \mu \mathrm { m } )$ ; (c) corresponding expel mental result.

![](images/c6cfe343284f5a7cbbcf42a902343f1837679418c801f3aa61e998d2ebe31273.jpg)  
Fig.13.The forming process of the pores in calculation scheme B1.

Based on the numerical results,the formation of the pore is closely related to the dynamic behavior of the keyhole in the keyhole-mode laser melting process.Different combination of laser power and scanning speed will result in different behavior of the molten pool.The simulation results indicate that the pore is formed due to the dynamic behavior of the keyhole when the process parameters resulting in high energy input is applied. Consequently,appropriate energy input plays an essential role in alleviating the porosity defect.
summary: 3.3.Effects of energy input on forming quality - Part 5/5

name: 2020 - J. Manufacturing Processes - Tian et al. - Numerical analysis of powder bed generation and single track forming for selective las-part-31
fileName: 2020 - J. Manufacturing Processes - Tian et al. - Numerical analysis of powder bed generation and single track forming for selective las.md
content:
In this paper,a DEM based model was built to simulate the powder bed generation process and a 3D numerical model was established to investigate the forming quality of melt tracks and the relevant formation mechanism of track defects.The numerical model was validated by the experiments.The main conclusions can be drawn as follows:

(1）Three different types of melt tracks:balling,distortion,continuous,were observed in simulation results with a constant LED. The peak temperature,heating rate and cooling rate of the molten pool had an increasing tendency with increasing laser power and scanning speed.   
(2) The random distribution of powder particles in the scanning path and the Marangoni effect contributed to the distortion defect.   
(3) The occurrence of the balling defect was caused by insufficient energy input incapable of melting the substrate when the high scanning speed was used.The keyhole collapse led to the porosity defect in the keyhole-mode laser melting process.The dynamic behavior of keyhole and the molten pool was strongly associated with the porosity defect.

name: 2020 - Materials Science and Engineering A - Agrawal, Meric de Bellefon, Thoma - High-throughput experimentation for microstructural des-part-1
fileName: 2020 - Materials Science and Engineering A - Agrawal, Meric de Bellefon, Thoma - High-throughput experimentation for microstructural des.md
content:
Ankur Kumar Agrawala,b, Gabriel Meric de Bellefon a,b, Dan Thoma a,b,\*

aDepartment of Materials Science and Engineering, UW-Madison,Madison, 53706,USA bGraingersieforieigUoiso

# ARTICLEINFO
summary: High-throughput experimentation for microstructural design in additively manufactured 316L stainless steel

name: 2020 - Materials Science and Engineering A - Agrawal, Meric de Bellefon, Thoma - High-throughput experimentation for microstructural des-part-2
fileName: 2020 - Materials Science and Engineering A - Agrawal, Meric de Bellefon, Thoma - High-throughput experimentation for microstructural des.md
content:
# ABSTRACT
Keywords:   
Additive manufacturing   
Selective laser melting   
316L stainless steel   
High-throughput experiments   
Processing maps

In the present study,a combination of high-throughput (HT)and low-throughput (LT) techniques was used to rapidly determine the processing window and generate processing maps for Selective Laser Melting (SLM) of 316L stainless steel.The HT method includes the fabrication of hundreds of hex nut-shaped specimens,each processed with a unique combination of laser power,scanning speed,and hatch spacing.An easily removable scaffolding permited rapid sample extraction from the base plate,thus saving machining cost and time.Hardness and immersion density measurements were used for HT characterization to identify a processng window for maximum strength and density.Within the defined processing window,a low-throughput (LT) microstructural interrogation of specimens were performed.The microstructural analysis included quantification at various length scales (i.e. grains size and morphology,texture,primary dendritearm spacing,and melt pool geometry analysis). Microstructure-based processng maps as a function of volumetric energy density were generated.The combination of HT and LT methods produced a predictive relationship between hardnessand primary dendrite arm spacing using a Hal-Petch relationship.A model is proposed to explain the dependence of microstructure on the melt pool geometry.The HT method can be applied for the microstructural design of SLM-fabricated components in other alloys.

# 1．Introduction

name: 2020 - Materials Science and Engineering A - Agrawal, Meric de Bellefon, Thoma - High-throughput experimentation for microstructural des-part-3
fileName: 2020 - Materials Science and Engineering A - Agrawal, Meric de Bellefon, Thoma - High-throughput experimentation for microstructural des.md
content: Additive manufacturing (AM) is a process to fabricate components through the layer-by-layer deposition of materials.Examples of metal powder AM techniques include selective laser melting (SLM),directed energy deposition (DED),and electron beam melting (EBM) [1]. The underlying principle behind these processes is to introduce material in powder or wire form and melt them using a high energy source such as a laser or electron beam. Over the past decade,the SLM process has gained high interest especially among energy,defense,and aerospace industries [2].The SLM process enables the printing of complex geometries with the potential for lower cost and minimizing material waste [2,3]. However, SLM parts often contain processing defects such as porosity, inclusions,residual stress,and anisotropic properties.The defect concentration,microstructure,and property anisotropy depend upon processing conditions such as laser power, scanning speed, hatch spacing, and layer thickness [1,2,4].As a consequence of processing defects, qualification and certification of fabricated parts can be challenging [5] and limit the use of metal AM parts.To fully exploit the SLM process,it is necessary to design, predict, and control the microstructural development in viable processing ranges.
summary: 1.1. Challenges and opportunities in additive manufacturing - Part 1/4

name: 2020 - Materials Science and Engineering A - Agrawal, Meric de Bellefon, Thoma - High-throughput experimentation for microstructural des-part-4
fileName: 2020 - Materials Science and Engineering A - Agrawal, Meric de Bellefon, Thoma - High-throughput experimentation for microstructural des.md
content: Processing ranges in SLMare bounded by the challenge to fabricate a defect-free,fully dense component.Many studies [6-9] have focused on pore characterization and how these defects form during AM processing. Pores due to localized lack-of-fusion are commonly observed in AM parts where insufficient input energy results in weak bonding between the layers [lO].Ina study by Mukherjee etal.[11] a normalized heat-input parameter (non-dimensional number) showed a linear dependence with the amount of lack-of-fusion defects.Conversely,keyholing occurs due to excessively high energy input [l2].These solidification defects can lead to catastrophic failure.For example,failure analysis ofadditively manufactured 316L SS specimens showed the initiation of cracks at the fabrication-induced pores and defects during tensile testing [13].In as-fabricated AM parts,defect morphologies,which can vary from spherical pores to high aspect ratio cracks,can also impact failure. For example,accelerated crack initiation was observed in the specimens having lack-of-fusion defects during a high-cycle fatigue testing, whereas a minimal effect was observed in specimens having small equiaxed pores [14].
summary: 1.1. Challenges and opportunities in additive manufacturing - Part 2/4

name: 2020 - Materials Science and Engineering A - Agrawal, Meric de Bellefon, Thoma - High-throughput experimentation for microstructural des-part-5
fileName: 2020 - Materials Science and Engineering A - Agrawal, Meric de Bellefon, Thoma - High-throughput experimentation for microstructural des.md
content: Another challenge in the SLM process is the ability to predict and control the microstructure.Solidification microstructures are considered complex because of the moving localized heat source that overlaps with existing fusion tracks [5,15].In addition,the moving heat source thermally affects prior layers asa function of spatial and temporal processing conditions.The solidification microstructural features depend mainly on the melt pool size and solidification conditions (i.e., thermal gradient (G) and solidification rate (R)) [6].High thermal gradients and high cooling rates associated with the metal AM process result in the formation of microstructures consisting of high dislocations densities,low angle grain boundaries, sub-granular cellular structures, andcrystallographictexture[4].Microstructuralanalysisof SLM-fabricated 316L SS shows the presence of columnar grains and cellular-dendritic structures [l6] with a cellular spacing increasing with the energy input [17].Transmission Electron Microscopy (TEM) analyses of SLM 316L SS show the presence of dislocation networks in the cell boundaries region [4,l8],which could be effective in blocking the motion of dislocations.In addition,epitaxial grain growth can occur multiple deposition layers,resulting in microstructures textured along the building direction.A study by Bertoli et al.[19] showed that crystallographic texture is strongly related to the melt pool geometry and hatch spacing.
summary: 1.1. Challenges and opportunities in additive manufacturing - Part 3/4

name: 2020 - Materials Science and Engineering A - Agrawal, Meric de Bellefon, Thoma - High-throughput experimentation for microstructural des-part-6
fileName: 2020 - Materials Science and Engineering A - Agrawal, Meric de Bellefon, Thoma - High-throughput experimentation for microstructural des.md
content: When processing conditions are well selected,as-fabricated AM316L SS can show higher strength and ductility as compared to wrought 316L SS [2O].The main factors attributed to a strength increase are the cellular dendritic structure,grain size,and dislocation density [18,21, 22].The increase in ductility was attributed to a higher propensity for deformation twinning [4,23,24].AM 316L SS also showed excellent fatigue strength and fatigue crack growth threshold values as compared to wrought materials,primarily due to high yield strength to tensile strength ratios [25,26].However, the columnar grain and crystallographic texture in the build direction can often lead to anisotropic properties.For example,in 304L SS higher ductility was observed along the transverse direction,as compared to building direction,while,both directions showed similar tensile strength [27].
summary: 1.1. Challenges and opportunities in additive manufacturing - Part 4/4

name: 2020 - Materials Science and Engineering A - Agrawal, Meric de Bellefon, Thoma - High-throughput experimentation for microstructural des-part-7
fileName: 2020 - Materials Science and Engineering A - Agrawal, Meric de Bellefon, Thoma - High-throughput experimentation for microstructural des.md
content:
Metal AM processing with SLM is controlled by at least 100 process variables [28].Of these variables,laser speed,laser power,and hatch spacing are the more common and easily adjusted ones.Selecting the adapted variables for a given material,powder feedstock [29],and application can be challenging and time-consuming and often relies on trial and error.

High-throughput (HT) experiments may permit faster rates of design of experiments (DOE),particularly when guided with a fundamental premise [30,31].Large datasets obtained from HT experiments can be used as training sets for various machine learning algorithms [32,33] and can be used to predict the process parameter ranges.Ren et al. [34] have demonstrated the combined use of HTand machine learning for the discovery of metallic glasses.Specifically,forAM,givena known set of process parameters corresponding to specific material,HT can allow a systematic interrogation of processing parameter variations.Moreover, the interdependence of the parameters can be developed to rapidly define correlations not available in existing models.Recent studies [35, 36] using an automated HT tensile test were performed to evaluate the effects of processing parameters on the mechanical behavior of AM 316L SS.Other studies [37] have focused on HT process control via in-situ monitoring of the melt pool. To expand the AM techniques to other alloy systems,HT experiments are needed to quickly fabricate,characterize,and identify the appropriate processing window, especially since there are a large number of processing variables in the SLM technique.

name: 2020 - Materials Science and Engineering A - Agrawal, Meric de Bellefon, Thoma - High-throughput experimentation for microstructural des-part-8
fileName: 2020 - Materials Science and Engineering A - Agrawal, Meric de Bellefon, Thoma - High-throughput experimentation for microstructural des.md
content:
Power-Velocity (PV) processing maps are a powerful way to visualize the effects of AM processing parameters on microstructure and performance.Processing maps for SLM techniques have been systematically used by Beuth et al.[38] where different regions of defects (i.e., lack-of-fusion and keyholing) were mapped at different laser power and scanning speed combinations.These maps provide useful information about the defect population and processing window to fabricate full density specimens.A few other recent studies [39,4O] have also extended this idea and constructed processing maps for different alloy systems using experimental and computational techniques. Processing maps for welding,deformation, other manufacturing techniques were previously developed to guide users about the optimum processing conditions.However,most of these studies have focused on defects at different processng conditions,and there is a lack of understanding about microstructure evolutions at these conditions.

The novelty of the current work lies in using high-throughput fabrication and characterization techniques to quickly analyze SLMfabricated 316L SS.These techniques allowed the identification of the processing bounds within a reasonable time frame of 2-3 days. Following the HT synthesis and characterization,low-throughput (LT) microstructural investigations on key specimens were performed to define the critical microstructural featuresand to generate microstructure-based processing maps.This study will provide insights into the microstructural evolution and microstructural design strategies for SLM-fabricated parts.The new methodology can be applied to other alloy systems for rapid processing parameter discovery.

name: 2020 - Materials Science and Engineering A - Agrawal, Meric de Bellefon, Thoma - High-throughput experimentation for microstructural des-part-9
fileName: 2020 - Materials Science and Engineering A - Agrawal, Meric de Bellefon, Thoma - High-throughput experimentation for microstructural des.md
content:
316L SS feedstock powder were procured from EOS GmbH, Germany.The powder particles were spherical in shape.The particle size range was $1 5 { \ - } 4 0 \ \mu \mathrm { m }$ as provided by the supplier.The chemical composition of the powder as measured using plasma emission spectroscopy is shown in Table 1.Wrought 316L SS plates were used as the substrate material. Build plates were thoroughly cleaned using ethanol prior to fabrication.

316L SS specimens were additively manufactured using the EOs M290 system.A 4oo W Ytterbium fiber laser with a wavelength of 1060 nm and a beam diameter of $1 0 0 \mu \mathrm { m }$ was used as the energy source.Build plates were preheated to $8 0 ~ ^ { \circ } \mathrm { C } ,$ ，and an inert argon atmosphere was maintained during the fabrication process.A set of hex nut-shaped specimens,each having a width of $3 . 1 7 ~ \mathrm { m m }$ (1/8th in.)and a height of $3 . 0 \ \mathrm { m m }$ ，was fabricated at different processing conditions.These specimens were deposited over a $3 . 0 \ \mathrm { m m }$ porous support structure for easy removal from the build plate as shown in Fig.1.In the current study,the effects of the most influential parameters were studied,i.e., laser power (7O-28o W),laser scanning speed( $\mathrm { 6 0 0 { - } 7 0 0 0 ~ m / s ) }$ ，and hatch spacing $( 0 . 0 7 { - } 0 . 3 6 \mathrm { m m } )$ ). All the other processing parameters were kept constant such as layer height $= 0 . 0 2 \mathrm { m m }$ ,build plate temperature $= 8 0 ^ { \circ } C$ ,stripe thickness $= 5 \mathrm { m m }$ ,etc.The porous support structure was fabricated using the factory's default processng conditions.In addition, a volumetric energy density(VED) parameter was used to compare the combined effects of these parameters.VED $\mathrm { ( J / m m ^ { 3 } ) }$ signifies the amount of input energy into the melt pool and is defined by the equation:

$$
V E D = \frac { l _ { p } } { \nu _ { s } \times h \times t }
$$

name: 2020 - Materials Science and Engineering A - Agrawal, Meric de Bellefon, Thoma - High-throughput experimentation for microstructural des-part-10
fileName: 2020 - Materials Science and Engineering A - Agrawal, Meric de Bellefon, Thoma - High-throughput experimentation for microstructural des.md
content:
where $l _ { p }$ is laser power (W), $\nu _ { s }$ is laser scanning speed $\mathrm { ( m m / s ) }$ _， $h$ is hatch spacing (mm),and t is nominal layer thickness (mm). The hex nut sample morphology developed for this investigation offered three advantages fora HT synthesis and evaluation.First,the specimens were quickly removed with a socket wrench.Next, removing the specimens by applying a torque resulted in minimal residue support structure on the sample,thus requiring no additional machining.Finally, the hex nut's flat surface permitted HT hardness investigations.A total of 425 hex nut specimens covering a wide range of VED $\left( 5 { - } 1 6 0 \mathrm { J } / \mathrm { m m } ^ { 3 } \right)$ were fabricated. Table 1 Chemical composition of the 316L SS powder.

![](images/a5731cca0c1497b34f800c2944302a649ec3c7795f3d9186a3b460f5fd5fc26e.jpg) Fig.1.Schematic diagram of the hex nut geometry and a picture of the 316L Ss hex nuts fabricated at different power and velocity combinations using an EOS M290.

name: 2020 - Materials Science and Engineering A - Agrawal, Meric de Bellefon, Thoma - High-throughput experimentation for microstructural des-part-11
fileName: 2020 - Materials Science and Engineering A - Agrawal, Meric de Bellefon, Thoma - High-throughput experimentation for microstructural des.md
content: HT hardness and density measurements on all 425 hex nut specimens were performed.Hardness measurements were performed using the Rockwell A method,where a load of 6O Kgf was applied fora dwell time of $_ { 1 5 s }$ 、All the indents were made on the center of the side surface (xz plane) to maintain consistency.At least five indents were made on each specimen (as-fabricated surface) to get the average hardness measurements.An immersion density measurement method was used based on the Archimedes principle [41] using a FluorinertTM FC-40 solution (density $= 1 . 8 6 \mathrm { g / c c } )$ .An ASTM Standard B962[42] was followed while measuring the density.The relative density $( \% )$ was calculated with respect to wrought 316L SS alloy (density $= 8 . 0 ~ \mathrm { g / c m ^ { 3 } } )$ [43]. Specimens with the highest density and hardness values were chosen forLTdetailed microstructural characterization.

name: 2020 - Materials Science and Engineering A - Agrawal, Meric de Bellefon, Thoma - High-throughput experimentation for microstructural des-part-12
fileName: 2020 - Materials Science and Engineering A - Agrawal, Meric de Bellefon, Thoma - High-throughput experimentation for microstructural des.md
content:
Based on the results of the HT study,seven LT specimens were selected,as detailed in 3.2.1. The seven specimens were sectioned along the build direction and cold mounted using an epoxy resin to study the planar and the cross-sectional surface (as defined in Fig.1).Planar surfaces were ground to the approximate depth of $_ { 1 \mathrm { m m } }$ from the bottom surface,and this depth was uniform for all of the specimens.A conventional metallographic practice involving mechanical grinding and polishing was used to prepare these specimens for further analysis.Final polishing was performed using a $0 . 5 \mathrm { - } \mu \mathrm { m }$ alumina and $0 . 0 5 \mathrm { - } \mu \mathrm { m }$ colloidal silica solution.Prior to microscopy,specimens were cleaned and rinsed using isopropanol. Electron backscatter diffraction (EBSD) mapping of planar surfaces was carried out ina FEI Helios G4 High-Resolution FEGSEM.An accelerating voltage of $3 0 \mathrm { k V }$ and a current of 51 nA was used to collect EBSD data form the $^ \mathrm { ~ 1 ~ } \times \mathrm { ~ 1 ~ }$ mm region with a step size of $1 ~ { \mu \mathrm { m } }$

EBSD data was analyzed using the MATLAB based MTex toolbox, in particular to calculate grain sizes and textures.To calculate a grain size, grain boundaries having a misorientation greater than $5 ^ { \circ }$ were mapped. Smaller grains (i.e., total grain area $< 2 0 \ \mu \mathrm { m } ^ { 2 } )$ were removed from the analysis.The grain size was calculated by measuring the largestdistance (in pixels) within each grain.Non-weighted number average provided the average grain size value.For texture analysis,the‘odfl' function was used to calculate the orientations of each pixels.A reconstruction of these datasets using the ‘plotIPDF’ function was done to generate IPF maps with the build direction as a reference direction.

name: 2020 - Materials Science and Engineering A - Agrawal, Meric de Bellefon, Thoma - High-throughput experimentation for microstructural des-part-13
fileName: 2020 - Materials Science and Engineering A - Agrawal, Meric de Bellefon, Thoma - High-throughput experimentation for microstructural des.md
content: Similar metallographic preparation and electrochemical etching were performed for the cross-sectional surfaces. Electrochemical etching of the 316L SS was done using a $0 . 1 \mathrm { ~ M ~ }$ oxalic acid solution operated at $5 . 5 \mathrm { m V }$ to reveal grain boundaries and dendrites. Chemical etching using ferric chloride solution was used (i.e., $5 \mathrm { \textrm { g F e C l } } _ { 3 }$ $2 0 \ \mathrm { m l }$ HCl, $8 0 ~ \mathrm { m l }$ ethanol) to reveal the melt pool boundaries.Optical microscopy (OM) and Scanning Electron Microscopy (SEM) of cross-sectional surfaces were carried out ina Keyence VHX-50OO and a ZEISS LEO 1530 FEGSEM respectively.An accelerating voltage of $5 \ \mathrm { k V }$ was used to collect the SEM images.SEM and optical image analysis were performed using ImageJ software,in particular for dendrite analysis.

name: 2020 - Materials Science and Engineering A - Agrawal, Meric de Bellefon, Thoma - High-throughput experimentation for microstructural des-part-14
fileName: 2020 - Materials Science and Engineering A - Agrawal, Meric de Bellefon, Thoma - High-throughput experimentation for microstructural des.md
content:
# 3.1．High-throughput characterization


# 3.1.1.Density measurements
Immersion-based density measurements of the hex nut specimens as a function of VED are shown in Fig.2a.In the lower VED range of 5-70 $\mathrm { J } / \mathrm { m m } ^ { 3 }$ ,the density of the specimen increases from $7 5 \%$ to $9 8 . 5 \%$ with increasing VED.A linear dependence of density with energy density suggests the presence of lack-of-fusion type defects in these specimens [11]. In the VED range of $\mathrm { 5 - 2 0 ~ J / m m ^ { 3 } }$ ,few specimens showed relatively higher densities than the rest of the specimens.In these specimens, open pores were observed (Fig. 2a) suggesting misleading density measurements,and thus those data points were treated as outliers.The presence of open pores in the unfused specimens is probably due to extremely low laser power or very high scanning speed values.A saturation point in the density was observed at $7 0 \mathrm { \ J / m m ^ { 3 } }$ which might be related to the lack-of-fusion offset.In the VED range of $7 0 { - } 1 5 0 \ \mathrm { J / m m ^ { 3 } }$ ,a similar and constant density was observed.The maximum density recorded was $7 . 9 0 \ : { \mathrm { g / c c } }$ (i.e., $9 9 \%$ dense as compared to wrought 316L SS).The actual specimen density may have some deviation due to surface roughness effects.

name: 2020 - Materials Science and Engineering A - Agrawal, Meric de Bellefon, Thoma - High-throughput experimentation for microstructural des-part-15
fileName: 2020 - Materials Science and Engineering A - Agrawal, Meric de Bellefon, Thoma - High-throughput experimentation for microstructural des.md
content:
# 3.1.2.Hardness measurements
Average hardness measurements of the hex nut specimens are shown in Fig.2b.Similar to density,the specimen's hardness increases with VED before reaching a maximum value of 5o.1 HRA.Both density and hardness measurement showed a peak in the similar VED value suggestinga lack-of-fusion offset to be around $\mathrm { V E D } \approx 7 0 ~ \mathrm { J / m m } ^ { 3 }$ .Almost all the specimens in the lower VED,i.e.,below $2 0 \mathrm { \ J / m m ^ { 3 } }$ ，showed a negative hardness value.The negative value stems from the material being too soft for the HRA scale measurement.The HRA scale is effective in measuring the hardness between 112 and 513 HV and if hardness is below $1 1 2 \mathrm { H V }$ ,Rockwell B or F scale should be used. Since most of the specimens were in the range of the HRA scale,only the HRA scale was used for consistency.A drop in the hardness from 50.1 to 39.95 HRA was observed in the VED ranging from 70 to $1 5 0 \mathrm { J / m m ^ { 3 } }$ .The observed linear relationship between hardness and VED was obtained within the processing regime of $\mathrm { V E D } = 7 0 { - } 1 5 0 \ \mathrm { J } / \mathrm { m m } ^ { 3 }$ can be expressed by:

![](images/7c40b2fb31dac8d732a76614c2a3c945a7fefd4651496d8388f12663dc729e88.jpg)  
Fig.2.(a) High-throughput density measurement using Archimedes principle. Inset showing a SEM image of as-fab specimens (unpolished,bottom surface) having open pores. (b) High-throughput hardness measurement using a Rockwell indention.

$$
H R A = 5 3 . 3 - 0 . 0 5 5 \times V E D
$$

A p-value of $4 . 9 \times 1 0 ^ { - 2 4 }$ suggests the data to be statistically significant,despite an R-square value of O.424.Above $1 5 0 \mathrm { ~ J / m m ^ { 3 } }$ ，the average hardness values had increased scatter.

name: 2020 - Materials Science and Engineering A - Agrawal, Meric de Bellefon, Thoma - High-throughput experimentation for microstructural des-part-16
fileName: 2020 - Materials Science and Engineering A - Agrawal, Meric de Bellefon, Thoma - High-throughput experimentation for microstructural des.md
content:
SEM images of the defects and pores from different regions of the HT measurements are shown in Fig.3.Ata very high energy density sample $\mathrm { ( V E D = 2 1 2 . 1 \ J / m m ^ { 3 } ) }$ keyholing defects were observed (Fig.3a). The keyholes were about $2 0 { - } 5 0 ~ { \mu \mathrm { m } }$ in size and had a spherical morphology. These defects were randomly distributed within the specimens and easy to find. The amount of keyhole pores was less prominent (but roughly the same size) as the VED approached $1 5 0 \mathrm { J / m m ^ { 3 } }$ .Within the boundary regions of the LT study (i.e., $\mathrm { V E D } = 7 0 { - } 1 5 0 \ \mathrm { J / m m ^ { 3 } } )$ relatively dense specimens were obtained.These specimens $\mathrm { ( V E D ~ = ~ 1 1 3 . 6 ~ \ J / m m ^ { 3 } ) }$ showed pores in sub-micron size ranges (not clearly visible in Fig.3b) and are potentially confused with inclusion pull-out. The specimens at lower energy density $\mathrm { ( V E D ~ = ~ } 4 1 . 9 \mathrm { ~ J / m m } ^ { 3 } \mathrm { ) }$ i.e.，below the lower boundary region $\scriptstyle ( < 7 0 \ J / { \mathrm { m m } } ^ { 3 } )$ showed various characteristics of lackof-fusion,processing cracks,and un-melted powders.(Fig.3c).These defects have a high aspect ratio,and many have sharp edges. Overall, the defects and pores investigation showed a good correlation with the HT measurements.

# 3.2.Low-throughput microstructural characterization

# 3.2.1. Specimens selection for low-throughput microstructural characterization
In the regime of constant density and hardness (i.e., $\mathrm { V E D } = 7 0 ~ \mathrm { J } /$ $\mathrm { m m } ^ { 3 }$ and $1 5 0 \mathrm { ~ J / m m } ^ { 3 }$ ,seven specimens were selected for LT microstructural characterization as shown in Fig.4a and b.All of the specimens were made using the same hatch spacing $( 0 . 1 1 \mathrm { m m } )$ and the same layer thickness $( 0 . 0 2 \mathrm { m m } )$ ,but different laser power and scanning speed listed in Table 2 and located in the PV maps in Fig.4c.All specimens were considered free of lack-of-fusion or keyholing defects,as the relative density was close to $9 9 \%$

content:
EBSD maps and inversed pole figure (IPF) plots of the S3,S4,and S5 specimen's planar surfaces are shown in Fig.5.From EBSD maps,it was observed that many grains had an irregular,elongated shape.In each specimen, the variation in grain size from 10 to $5 0 \mu \mathrm { m }$ was observed. The average values of the grain size calculated from EBSD maps were compared among all seven specimens (see Table 2).As the energy density increases from 69.9 to $1 5 1 . 5 \ \mathrm { J / m m ^ { 3 } }$ ，an increase in average grain size from 23.05 to $3 5 . 0 7 \mu \mathrm { m }$ was observed.

In addition,the texture of the specimens also varied with VED (Fig.5). At a lower VED of $6 9 . 9 \mathrm { J / m m ^ { 3 } }$ ,a random texture was observed. With increasing VEDs,specimens showed a texture towards (11O) and (100) plane with respect to the build direction (more green and red color grains).These specimens showed an IPF intensity of ${ \approx } 2$ ,which means twice the number of grains were oriented towards (11O) plane than that of completely random texture.Also,in these specimens,none of the grains were oriented towards (111) plane.A similar variation in average grain size and texture with VED was observed for the rest of the specimens at different laser power (Table 2).

The cross-sectional SEM images of the S3, S4,and S5 specimens are shown in Fig.7a-c.Specimens were aligned such that the build direction points upwards,and the SEM images were taken at a similar height in the build direction to maintain consistency. Grain boundaries (white boundaries) in each of the images were manually drawn. For each grain, longitudinal length and transverse length were measured.By analyzing multiple images from each processing condition，statistically,the average grain aspect ratio was calculated.At lower energy densities of $6 9 . 9 ~ \mathrm { J / m m ^ { 3 } }$ ，more spherical grains were observed. The average grain aspect ratio was around $2 . 9 8 \pm 0 . 6 1$ . As the energy density increased to $1 5 1 . 5 \mathrm { J / m m ^ { 3 } }$ , the average grain aspect ratio also increased from $2 . 9 8 \pm$ 0.61 to $5 . 1 6 \pm 2 . 5 1$ .Interestingly,an increase in the average grain aspect ratio was accompanied by a simultaneous increase in both longitudinal length and transverse length. Qualitatively,both SEM analysis (crosssectional surface) and EBSD analysis (planar surface) showed an increase in grain size with an increase in energy density.

content:
# 3.2.4. Primary dendrite arm spacing
The dendritic structure of the S3,S4,and S5 specimens is shown in Fig.7d-f. In SLM components, the solidification structures vary along the z-direction owing to the variation in cooling rates.For comparison, specimens were aligned in the building direction and the various SEM images were captured ata similar z-height in each specimen.Also,images of dendrites were captured along the center of the melt pool to minimize the influences of heat affected zones.In each specimen,a similar dendritic morphology was observed suggesting similar solidification conditions at the solid-liquid interface.The distance between the dendrites was measured only for the cases in which the dendrites were long (the distance remains constant along the longitudinal direction) ensuring the dendrites were perpendicular to the surface.Multiple measurements (i.e.,15-2O per specimen） for primary dendrite arm spacing were performed.At lower energy densities of $6 9 . 9 ~ \mathrm { J / m m ^ { 3 } }$ ,the average primary dendrite arm spacing measurement was $0 . 3 9 \pm \ : 0 . 0 3$ $\mu \mathrm { m }$ .As the energy density increased to $1 5 1 . 5 ~ \mathrm { J / m m ^ { 3 } }$ ,the average primary dendrite arm spacing increased by around $4 3 \%$ from $0 . 3 9 \pm \ : 0 . 0 3$ $\mu \mathrm { m }$ to $0 . 5 6 \pm 0 . 0 4 \mu \mathrm { m }$

A linear relation between primary dendrite arm spacing and VED based on the regression analysis (R-square $= 0 . 9 5$ $\mathbf { p }$ -value $= 1 . 9 \mathrm { e } { - 4 } \mathrm { \check { \ : } }$ is shown in Fig.8.The equation to predict the PDAS $\left( \mu \mathrm { { m } } \right)$ in the VED regime of $7 0 { - } 1 5 0 \mathrm { ~ J / m m } ^ { \bar { 3 } }$ can be given by:

$$
P D A S = 0 . 2 6 - \ 0 . 0 0 1 9 \times V E D
$$

content:
# 3.2.5. Melt pool geometry
Melt pool boundaries of the S3, S4,and S5 specimens are shown in Fig.9. Successive overlapping of the melt pool is apparent in all of the specimens.The overlapping pools are essential for good bonding between the layers and fabricating fully dense components. Some of the layers have a long streak of the melt pool due to the orientation effects (hatch rotation of $6 7 ^ { \circ }$ ).A detailed measurement of the melt pool dimensions was difficult due to the orientation effects and the overlapping melt pools.The width and depth of some of the melt pool,especially at the top few layers,were easier to trace,and these values were used for analysis.

Dependence of the melt pool dimensions with energy density is shown in Fig.10.Ata lower VED of $6 9 . 3 ~ \mathrm { J / m m ^ { 3 } }$ ,a shallower melt pool was observed with a more conical morphology.The average width and depth of the melt pool was around $1 1 0 . 2 2 \pm 8 . 0 4 \mu \mathrm { m }$ and $6 3 . 4 5 \pm 1 1 . 1 9$ $\mu \mathrm { m }$ ,respectively.The width of the melt pool was similar to the laser beam diameter $( \approx 1 0 0 ~ \mu \mathrm { m } )$ .As the energy density increased,the melt pool became deeper and had a semi-spherical morphology.At a VED of $1 5 1 . 5 \ \mathrm { J / m m ^ { 3 } }$ ,the average width and the depth of the melt pool was around $1 3 3 . 7 0 \pm 1 0 . 8 4 ~ \mu \mathrm { m }$ and $9 0 . 9 5 \pm 1 0 . 3 2 \mu \mathrm { m }$ ,respectively.The variation in melt pool depth with energy density has also been reported in prior studies [44].

![](images/3fe9160557efd632b1cd78ee209afe57c848db00bfe1d9ef9214352bee7699a2.jpg)  
Fig.8.Regression analysis of primary dendrite arm spacing with volumetric energy density of the S1-S7 specimens.

# 3.3. Microstructure maps

name: 2020 - Materials Science and Engineering A - Agrawal, Meric de Bellefon, Thoma - High-throughput experimentation for microstructural des-part-24
