name: 2021 - Progress in AM - Kladovasilakis et al. - Impact of metal additive manufacturing parameters on the powder bed fusion and direct en-part-10
fileName: 2021 - Progress in AM - Kladovasilakis et al. - Impact of metal additive manufacturing parameters on the powder bed fusion and direct en.md
content:
# 2.2 Part orientation
One parameter that is completely controlled by the user of the metal 3D printer and affects the properties of the final component is the object's orientation inside the building chamber. In 2013,according to ASTM and International Organization for Standardization (ISO),a standardization was enacted regarding both the terminology and the printing orientations of all AM technologies [23].A coordinate system is defined with the $X$ -axis parallel to the front side of the machine, $Z$ -axis in the vertical direction and the $Y .$ -axis is perpendicular to the other two,and the positive direction is determined by the rule of the right hand. Figure 4 shows the graphical representation of tensile and fatigue test specimens accompanied by three capital letters $( X , Y , Z )$ ，which code the print orientation [24]. In particular, the first letter represents the axis that is parallel to the specimen's biggest dimension. In the same manner, the second letter is defined based on the next biggest dimension of the part [25]. The build orientation influences the overall quality of the object, i.e.surface quality, dimensional accuracy and mechanical behavior,as it willbe discussed in the next section. In general, the surface quality and the dimensional accuracy are depended mainly on the build orientation and the geometry of the component, as complex geometries tend to lead to lower quality [26].Additionally,mechanical behavior is primary influenced by the anisotropy effect that is created due to the build orientation of the product inside the build chamber of the AM machine [25,27].

![](images/7c86a362c5d334daae102578e2e8fc37ae720b6e4c762db17152df8281219f8f.jpg)  
Fig.4 Graphical representation of main orientations for tensile and fatigue test specimens

name: 2021 - Progress in AM - Kladovasilakis et al. - Impact of metal additive manufacturing parameters on the powder bed fusion and direct en-part-11
fileName: 2021 - Progress in AM - Kladovasilakis et al. - Impact of metal additive manufacturing parameters on the powder bed fusion and direct en.md
content:
Depending on the applied metal AM process,various process-related parameters affect the quality of the produced part.For metal AM processes,such as PBF and DED, the majority of the parameters that influence the procedure are common and are generally affected by the energy source configuration [18,28]. These process-related parameters are exhibited in Table 4 [29].

However, there are some parameters that affect each AM process individually and are distinctive in these two metal AM techniques.More specifically, in PBF process: hatching distance: the distance between the centers of the laser beams in two consecutive laser paths. Overlap percentage: the percentage of an area that is scanned by a consecutive laser path from a previous laser path.Energy density: the energy that is absorbed by a region of the powder bed and affects the overburden and the unmelt raw material resulting to diverse qualities on the final product. The energy density is measured in units per volume and is computed by the Eq. 1 [28]. The parameter $E$ represents the energy density, $P$ is the power of laser beam, $V$ is the laser speed, $h$ describes the hatching distance and $\delta$ is the layer height.

$$
E = \frac { P } { V \cdot h \cdot \delta } \Big ( \frac { \mathrm { ~ J ~ } } { \mathrm { m m } ^ { 3 } } \Big ) ,
$$

Figure 5 graphically illustrates the effect of the laser beam and the effective laser beam diameter on the above-mentioned factors in PBF methods.Moreover, the paths that are scanned by the laser beam, as well the formation of hatching distance and the creation of overlapping regions between two consecutive passes of the laser beam are exhibited.

name: 2021 - Progress in AM - Kladovasilakis et al. - Impact of metal additive manufacturing parameters on the powder bed fusion and direct en-part-12
fileName: 2021 - Progress in AM - Kladovasilakis et al. - Impact of metal additive manufacturing parameters on the powder bed fusion and direct en.md
content:
In DED procedures, there are a few additional factors that need to be taken into account concerning the nozzle's and wire's configuration,and are documented in Table 5.Material feed rate in DED process represents the mass of the feedstock material that is extracted from the nozzle per unit of time [30]. In case of using powder as the feedstock material, feeding rate is directly related to the speed of the carrier gas, the geometry of the nozzle and the properties of the powder [18,31]. An increased print speed is the outcome of high material feed rates which lead in a rapid construction of the product, but could potentially result to the reduced quality of the final object as explained in the next section [32, 33]. Finally, it should be noted that the wire-DED method offers the additional advantage of the lack of hazardous powder's environment. Table 4 Machine's parameters for metal AM
ParametersDescription
Laser speed/scan speedLaser beam scanning speed
Laser powerPower of laser to melt the metal
Spot size/beam sizeDiameter of the laser beam
Focus offsetFocus offset of laser beam
Layer heightHeight of each deposition of materials
TemperatureTemperature of the building chamber and building plate
![](images/787795f4a8e8985ff69dcf589863769b7f0220542d4e712a3a146ead4c6b286a.jpg) Fig.5 Graphical illustration of laser beam parameters

name: 2021 - Progress in AM - Kladovasilakis et al. - Impact of metal additive manufacturing parameters on the powder bed fusion and direct en-part-13
fileName: 2021 - Progress in AM - Kladovasilakis et al. - Impact of metal additive manufacturing parameters on the powder bed fusion and direct en.md
content:
# 2.4 Infill patterns In metal AM processes,it is feasible to produce solid parts or fabricate objects with a specific infll pattern. The lattice structures (infil pattern) are internal structure of a part and composes one of the main advantages of AM technology. Specific infill patterns reduce the relative density of the manufactured part resulting the minimization of the production lead time, the reduction of the feedstock material consumption and could lead in the fabrication of lightweight and structurally optimized products. Therefore, many engineers and designers prefer to apply specific internal structures, commonly named as lattice structures. However, lattice structures affect the integrity of the part, especially in terms of mechanical performance due to the size effect [34-37]. More specifically the size, the geometry and the relative density of each unit cell in a lattice structure possess severe impacts on the mechanical behavior of the manufactured component. Nowadays,research focuses on employing diverse lattice structures to identify each contribution and impact on the product's mechanical behavior.Figure 6 illustrates various lattice structures types applied in metal AM processes and their classification [35]. Table 5 Nozzle and wire parameters
ParametersDescription
Wire diameterDiameter of the applied wire
Feed rateExtracted mass of the raw material per unit of time
Feeding (clad) angleAngle between the nozzle and the building plate
Nozzle orientationThe orientation of material extrusion nozzle

name: 2021 - Progress in AM - Kladovasilakis et al. - Impact of metal additive manufacturing parameters on the powder bed fusion and direct en-part-14
fileName: 2021 - Progress in AM - Kladovasilakis et al. - Impact of metal additive manufacturing parameters on the powder bed fusion and direct en.md
content:
# 2.5 Post-processing procedures
Similarly to traditional manufacturing operations, metal components created via an AM procedure could be subjected to post-processing procedures. These procedures are usually the same as those applied in machining or die cast methods,i.e. heat treatments (aging,annealing etc.),hot isostatic pressing (HIP),polishing and shot peening.Postprocessing techniques could enhance the surface quality and the mechanical properties of a metal additively manufactured part, such as the tensile strength,hardness etc.[38-40]. However, metal parts should undergo different post-processing procedures depending on their applications.Mechanical polishing and electropolishing are employed for optimizing the external surfaces of an object.In general, the utilization of various heat treatments is suggested to optimize a specific mechanical property,achieving that way the desired mechanical performance of the printed component.

# 3 Impact of process parameters in metal AM
In the previous section, the parameters that affect the metal AM procedures and possess a direct impact on the quality of the product (i.e.on surface roughness, dimensional accuracy and mechanical behaviour) were discussed. Investigating their effect composes a fundamental step in improving and optimizing the metal AM technologies.In this frame, many studies have explored various approaches to enhance the quality of additively manufactured metal parts investigating the process parameters through experimental procedures and statistical analyses. In the next paragraphs,the results and the findings of these studies are presented and categorized to summarize the research background and identify possible research gaps.
summary: 2.5 Post-processing procedures, 3 Impact of process parameters in metal AM

name: 2021 - Progress in AM - Kladovasilakis et al. - Impact of metal additive manufacturing parameters on the powder bed fusion and direct en-part-15
fileName: 2021 - Progress in AM - Kladovasilakis et al. - Impact of metal additive manufacturing parameters on the powder bed fusion and direct en.md
content: PBF and powder-feed DED processes present the same typical values for roughness average $( R _ { \mathrm { a } } )$ , which ranges between 10 and $2 0 ~ { \mu \mathrm { m } }$ . However, the surface roughness for wirefeed DED procedures is significantly higher reaching up to $2 0 0 \mu \mathrm { m }$ [32]. Studies have shown that the powder properties exhibit a dominant impact on the developed surface roughness,dimensional accuracy and mechanical properties of metal AM products [17]. In particular, the PSD and the apparent density are reported to compose major factors on the surface quality [41-44]. In those studies,specimens with various powder's properties were created and the asprinted surface roughness was measured using laser scanning microscope (LSM), X-ray micro-tomography (XMT) and profilometers.The results exhibited that a wide and fine PSD lead in better quality of the external surface.The finer particles are able to fill the holes between coarser particles resulting to lower values of the surface roughness.More specifically,according to Spierings et al. [41,42], it is possible to achieve $R _ { \mathrm { a } } = 4 ~ { \mu \mathrm { m } }$ for aluminium alloy AlSil $0 \mathrm { M g }$ in case of employing the appropriate manufacturing conditions,build orientation and feedstock material properties (PSD,apparent density).Furthermore,sharp particles with irregular shapes could cause low apparent density and coarser PSD,resulting to an adversely effect on the surface roughness and thus producing reduced surface finish [44]. Additionally,wider powders usually develop low flowability,which could affect other properties of an additively manufactured like its mechanical properties due to the creation of internal building flaws [17].Hereupon,a reasonable trade-off between PSD and flowability rates should be considered to manufacture high quality metal components with decreased internal build flaws and high surface finish.

name: 2021 - Progress in AM - Kladovasilakis et al. - Impact of metal additive manufacturing parameters on the powder bed fusion and direct en-part-16
fileName: 2021 - Progress in AM - Kladovasilakis et al. - Impact of metal additive manufacturing parameters on the powder bed fusion and direct en.md
content:
![](images/0347d26b4eadfd73e673f187bc96680aaee18d8461db542984f3a2c7ac04897f.jpg)  
Fig.6 Types and classification of cellular materials [35]

In general,DED procedures possess inferior surface quality compared to powder-feed procedures.In particular, there are many articles which declare that the surface roughness could rise even up to ten times higher [31,45]. As mentioned in Table 5, the feeding orientation and feeding angle are two essential factors that affect the quality of a printed part.According to existing studies,among the three different possible nozzle's orientations in DED technology, which are shown in Fig.7, the one that results to the best surface finish is the front feeding,followed by the side and the back (rear) feeding [32,33,45, 46]. It is worth noting that in case of powder-feed DED process, the same trend is observed [18]. The range of the feeding angle depends from the combination of the feeding orientation and some geometrical restrictions due to the energy beam as illustrated schematically in Fig.7.More specifically, in case of the front feeding orientation, the angle ranges between $1 0 ^ { \circ }$ to $7 5 ^ { \circ }$ in contrast with the back-feeding orientation which varies between $1 0 5 ^ { \circ } { }$ to $1 7 5 ^ { \circ }$ [47]. According to Syed et al. [47], the best surface quality is obtained in situations where the front feeding orientation and a feeding angle between $2 0 ^ { \circ }$ to $6 0 ^ { \circ }$ are employed, due to the minimization of adhesion's discontinuous of the material on the already printed object, known as rippling effect.

![](images/b36b5a24d8aa995606e186eb438b211d37d50d0fdf9a30a8c14ef74d3d7ed0de.jpg)  
Fig.7 Graphical layout of nozzle parameters and possible nozzle's orientation

name: 2021 - Progress in AM - Kladovasilakis et al. - Impact of metal additive manufacturing parameters on the powder bed fusion and direct en-part-17
fileName: 2021 - Progress in AM - Kladovasilakis et al. - Impact of metal additive manufacturing parameters on the powder bed fusion and direct en.md
content: Print orientation is one of the major parameters that affect surface quality, dimensional accuracy and the mechanical properties of a metal AM part.Many researchers have examined the relationship between the build orientation and the surface quality. Early studies focused on the geometrical characteristics of the 3D model in relation to the print orientation as well as the layer height, suggesting that the geometry with the lowest inclinations to the building direction coupled with low layer heights could produce the optimum results in terms of surface roughness [48-5O].Recent studies have shown that the surface roughness varies depending on the print orientation [26, 51, 52]. According to Simonelli et al. [53], the roughness on the surfaces that are parallel to the building direction could be three times deteriorated compared to other surfaces of the object. Therefore,the effect of the print orientation inside the build chamber should be taken into consideration to achieve the optimum results on the external surfaces of the part.

name: 2021 - Progress in AM - Kladovasilakis et al. - Impact of metal additive manufacturing parameters on the powder bed fusion and direct en-part-18
fileName: 2021 - Progress in AM - Kladovasilakis et al. - Impact of metal additive manufacturing parameters on the powder bed fusion and direct en.md
content: Applying proper printing strategies and adjusting the 3D printer-configured parameters, it is feasible to achieve quite low surface roughness (up to $4 ~ { \mu \mathrm { m } }$ for aluminium alloy $\mathrm { A l S i 1 0 M g } ^ { \mathrm { \dag } }$ [41,42]. In particular, existing studies have shown that the process-related parameters that possess significant influence on the surface finish are layer thickness,hatching distance,laser power,laser beam diameter, laser beam focus and laser speed [54-61]. Calignano et al. [29] employed Taguchi methods utilizing fractional factorial experiments (FFE) and concluded that the energy density possesses a narrow influence on the surface quality. However,the parameters that effect the energy density maintain individually high impact on the surface roughness [56, 58]. Fotovvati et al. [6O] clearly declares that low layer thickness induces high surface quality.It must be mentioned that there are other process-related parameters affecting two major phenomena that are directly related to the surface finish: the molten pools and the surface tension of the molten feedstock material. Applying proper laser power coupled with low hatching distance could potentially result in the creation of a uniform molten pool, producing that way flatten surfaces. Additionally, the utilization of high scan speeds can produce sufficient diffusion of the thermal energy shrinking the size of molten pool, hence the development of uniform melt pools is achieved, reducing that way the surface roughness [55,59]. On the other hand,according to Abd-Elghany and Bourell [54] in situations where the power of the laser is too high or the speed is too low,the intense surface tension of the molten pool combined with the balling effect could generate poor surface quality, especially on the top surface and the free side surfaces.Calignano et al.

name: 2021 - Progress in AM - Kladovasilakis et al. - Impact of metal additive manufacturing parameters on the powder bed fusion and direct en-part-19
fileName: 2021 - Progress in AM - Kladovasilakis et al. - Impact of metal additive manufacturing parameters on the powder bed fusion and direct en.md
content:
[29] applied analysis of variance (ANOVA) to examine the influence of process-related parameters on the surface finish and the results showed that the scan speed possesses the most dominant impact. Furthermore,according to the Attarzadeh et al. [61] applying high energy density (above $6 0 \mathrm { ~ J } / \mathrm { m m } ^ { 3 }$ ） coupled with high laser power, small hatching distance,small layer height and relatively high scan speed could decline the roughness on the in-plane surface below $4 \mu \mathrm { m }$ for Ti6Al4V samples fabricated with DMLS process. Gond et al. [62] and Lee et al. [63] investigated the influence of the laser beam diameter and the focus offset on the developed size of the molten pool. These studies indicate that an effcient thermal energy diffusion could be obtained via the regulation of the size of the molten pools by employing the appropriate laser beam diameter and suficient focus offset.

Post-processing procedures that enhance the surface roughness in AM procedures are mainly the polishing and coating process [39, 64, 65]. According to Mower et al. [40], typical values of average roughness in DMLS and DED specimens are greater than $1 0 ~ { \mu \mathrm { m } }$ for soft alloys (i.e.

aluminium alloys $\mathbf { A l S i l 0 M g } ^ { \mathrm { ~ } }$ ） and greater than $1 5 ~ { \mu \mathrm { m } }$ for hard alloys (i.e. Ti6Al4V, SS316L, SS17-4PH etc.) [39, 59]. In addition, through the utilization of mechanical polishing, which causes the removal of high spots and also smooths the surface voids, it is possible to achieve roughness up to $R _ { \mathrm { a } } = 1 . 1 ~ { \mu \mathrm { m } }$ [56]. In high-strength alloys (such as Ti6Al4V, SS316L, SS17-4PH), the roughness reduction is restricted and could reach up $3 0 \%$ of the as printed value. Finally, the electropolishing process is suggested only on soft alloys,like the AlSi1oMg alloy, and retains less effciency compared to the mechanical polishing [40].

name: 2021 - Progress in AM - Kladovasilakis et al. - Impact of metal additive manufacturing parameters on the powder bed fusion and direct en-part-20
fileName: 2021 - Progress in AM - Kladovasilakis et al. - Impact of metal additive manufacturing parameters on the powder bed fusion and direct en.md
content: The present sub-section reviews how metal AM processrelated parameters influence the surface roughness and documents the approaches that could be utilized to minimize it. It is evident that the surface finish is also affected by the feedstock material itself as soft alloys (i.e. AlSi10Mg etc.) achieve better surface quality than hard alloys (i.e.Ti6Al4V, SS316L, SS17-4PH etc.).Table 6 summarizes all the investigated parameters and their contribution to the surface roughness of a metal additively manufactured product.

name: 2021 - Progress in AM - Kladovasilakis et al. - Impact of metal additive manufacturing parameters on the powder bed fusion and direct en-part-21
fileName: 2021 - Progress in AM - Kladovasilakis et al. - Impact of metal additive manufacturing parameters on the powder bed fusion and direct en.md
content:
In general, dimensional accuracy is higher in powder-feed AM processes compared to wire-feed. According to Vock et al. [17] and Badrossamay [66], fine powder coupled with wide PSD could fill the voids which are created on the surface of the printed part along to the coarse powder [54] and lead in a better accuracy of the final metal component. Typical values for the dimensional accuracy for the powder feed processes range between O.03 and $0 . 1 \mathrm { m m }$ [67-70]. On the other hand, in wire-feed DED procedures, the dimensional accuracy is lower presenting typical values beyond $0 . 2 \mathrm { m m }$ due to the higher applied feed rates of the technology [32, 33, 71].

Table 6 Process parameters and their influence in surface roughness

name: 2021 - Progress in AM - Kladovasilakis et al. - Impact of metal additive manufacturing parameters on the powder bed fusion and direct en-part-22
fileName: 2021 - Progress in AM - Kladovasilakis et al. - Impact of metal additive manufacturing parameters on the powder bed fusion and direct en.md
content:
ParametersPositive influence in surface roughness
Feedstock material
PowderFine and wide PSD, high apparent density,low feed rate [17,30, 41-44]
WireFront-feed,20o-60° nozzle angle,low feed rate [31, 32, 45–47]
OrientationSimpler geometries, low slopes to build orientation [26, 48-53]
Machines parameters
Scan speedHighly significant, higher than the mean [29, 54-61] value
Laser powerSignificant, slightly lower than mean value
Layer heightSignificant, as low as possible
Hatching distanceSignificant,as low as possible
Focus offsetFocus slightly offset and medium range beam [62, 63]
Laser beam diameter
Energy densityLess significant, requirements for mean value [29,59, 61]
Post-processing procedures
Mechanical polishingHighly significant, reduce more than 30% [39, 40, 64, 65]
ElectropolishingLess significant,only affect soft metals (like AlSi10Mg)[40]

name: 2021 - Progress in AM - Kladovasilakis et al. - Impact of metal additive manufacturing parameters on the powder bed fusion and direct en-part-23
fileName: 2021 - Progress in AM - Kladovasilakis et al. - Impact of metal additive manufacturing parameters on the powder bed fusion and direct en.md
content: Print orientation affects the dimensional accuracy of the manufactured part; thus,the physical dimensions of the printed part could be either smaller or larger compared to the nominal 3D model [72]. One of the major reasons that constitutes to this behavioris the shrinkage effect that takes place in all AM procedures which involve the melting of the feedstock material. More specifically, studies have shown that the shrinkage phenomenon is anisotropic, so the influence on the dimensional accuracy is strongly depended on the print orientation [26]. Depending on the geometry of the product, alternating the print orientation could result to higher dimensional accuracy. Delgado et al.[51] and Ratnadeep et al. [73] concluded that the dimensional error at all the external surfaces is influenced by the applied build direction.According to their studies, in situations where the build direction varies from $0 ^ { \circ }$ to $9 0 ^ { \circ }$ , the dimensional error is significantly reduced in some surfaces (i.e.surfaces printed perpendicular to the build direction),while the other surfaces follow the opposite trend.

name: 2021 - Progress in AM - Kladovasilakis et al. - Impact of metal additive manufacturing parameters on the powder bed fusion and direct en-part-24
fileName: 2021 - Progress in AM - Kladovasilakis et al. - Impact of metal additive manufacturing parameters on the powder bed fusion and direct en.md
content: The main process-related parameters that affect the dimensional accuracy of metal AM procedures are the laser power and the scanning speed. According to Tang et al. [74] and Fotovvati et al.[75], the thickness of the individual layer and the hatching distance possess a mild effect in terms of dimensional accuracy; nevertheless,a slightly improvement of the accuracy is observed in situations where these parameters are increased to a certain extent. Charles et al. [76] and Zhang et al.[77] declare that as the laser power increases the accuracy tends to decrease and in case of employing high scan speeds,the dimensional accuracy could be enhanced to some extent. Studies have shown that high scan speeds and low laser power create small melting pools resulting to weaker shrinkage effects, thus the dimensional accuracy is relatively higher.Table 7 summarizes all the process-related parameters that affect the dimensional accuracy of a metal AM object.

name: 2021 - Progress in AM - Kladovasilakis et al. - Impact of metal additive manufacturing parameters on the powder bed fusion and direct en-part-25
fileName: 2021 - Progress in AM - Kladovasilakis et al. - Impact of metal additive manufacturing parameters on the powder bed fusion and direct en.md
content:
The mechanical behavior of a component can be inspected from many aspects,such as tensile strength,toughness, ductility,hardness and fatigue strength.The main objective of metal AM processes is to produce,among others, components with advanced mechanical properties for various applications.Therefore, it is necessary to optimize the AM process to fabricate metal components with high mechanical performance.

The influence of the feedstock material is the primary concern in all metal AM processes; thus,there is a plethora of studies that examine the impact of the feedstock material on the mechanical properties of an additively manufactured part. According to Ziegelmeier et al. [44] and Liu et al. [78], mechanical behavior is mainly affected by the flowability, which is a bulk property of the powder. High flowability improves the part's relative density, fills the voids and avoids the generation of internal building flaws;hence it leads in the increase of the tensile strength,the enhancement of ultimate tensile strength,hardness and elongation at break.Besides the fact that flowability is affected by a series of variables as it is presented in Fig. 3, there are mainly two powder properties that have been deeply examined though the existing literature due to their severe impact on flowability, namely the PSD and the bulk density. Indicatively, narrow PSD and high bulk density result to an increased flowability [17]. In addition,the quality of the powder depends on the percentage of the recycled powder in the feedstock material mixture.

Table7 Process parameters and their influence in dimensional accuracy

name: 2021 - Progress in AM - Kladovasilakis et al. - Impact of metal additive manufacturing parameters on the powder bed fusion and direct en-part-26
fileName: 2021 - Progress in AM - Kladovasilakis et al. - Impact of metal additive manufacturing parameters on the powder bed fusion and direct en.md
content:
ParametersImpact on dimensional accuracy
Feedstock material
PowderLow and wide PSD and low feed rate lead to high accuracy (0.03-0.1 mm) [17,35,66-70]
WireLow accuracy (above 0.2 mm) even with low feed rates [32, 33, 71]
OrientationLeads to low accuracy in specific surfaces [26, 51, 70, 73]
Machines parameters
Scan speed Laser powerHigh speed and low laser power lead to high accuracy [74-77]
Layer heightLayer height and hatching distance small impact
Hatching distanceon accuracy, the higher the better [74,75]
Strondl et al. [79] employed SLM methods using titanium and nickel alloys (i.e.Ti-6Al-4V) as feedstock material and concluded that in case where the percentage of recycled powder is high, i.e. $9 5 \%$ of the whole mixture,the tensile strength is not considerable affected; but its impact on the ductility and toughness of the material is significant. On the other hand,in the wire-feed processes the mechanical properties of the produced part depend mainly on the parameters of the 3D printer, such as feding orientation and the feeding rate [47].

name: 2021 - Progress in AM - Kladovasilakis et al. - Impact of metal additive manufacturing parameters on the powder bed fusion and direct en-part-27
fileName: 2021 - Progress in AM - Kladovasilakis et al. - Impact of metal additive manufacturing parameters on the powder bed fusion and direct en.md
content: Anisotropy influences a variety of orientation-dependent physical and mechanical properties of a metal AM printed part. Anisotropy is calculated as a percentage between the value of the same property (physical or mechanical) in two different directions,the reference and the examined one [80].According to existing literature,anisotropy exists in all metal AM parts,but some metal AM methods exhibit less anisotropy behavior compared to others [25].In EBM and powder-feed DED processes the effect of anisotropy is mild and mainly affects the ductility, while the effect on tensile strength is negligible.On the other hand, SLM and DMLS procedures are strongly influenced by anisotropy regardless the mechanical properties of the employed material.Print orientation affects the mechanical behavior of a specimen produced via the SLM method in terms of reducing the tensile strength and increasing the ductility [53, 81]. More specifically,anisotropy results to notable deviations in tensile strength depending on the printing direction [27], which could reach up $2 5 \%$ reduction compared to the reference value [82]. In EBM and powder-feed DED processes this difference is limited presenting almost $1 0 \%$ decrease compared to the reference one [83, 84]. Anisotropy phenomena occurs in these AM techniques due to the facilitation of crack propagation in different directions. According to Seifi et al. [85], crack propagation follows the direction of the print course and could potentially lead even in the failure of the product. In addition, the fatigue properties of the product exhibit diverse mechanical performance along the horizontal and the vertical build directions. The fatigue properties of SLM parts are more severely afected from anisotropy phenomena compared to EBM and powder-feed DED procedures [24]. Furthermore, Jain et al.

name: 2021 - Progress in AM - Kladovasilakis et al. - Impact of metal additive manufacturing parameters on the powder bed fusion and direct en-part-28
fileName: 2021 - Progress in AM - Kladovasilakis et al. - Impact of metal additive manufacturing parameters on the powder bed fusion and direct en.md
content: [86] has developed an algorithm to calculate the optimum print orientation taking into account the effect of the anisotropy on the manufactured specimens. In wire-feed DED,the build orientation is essential in terms of mechanical performance, where anisotropy could potentially exceed $1 0 \%$ concerning the tensile strength in horizontal and vertical direction [87].

name: 2021 - Progress in AM - Kladovasilakis et al. - Impact of metal additive manufacturing parameters on the powder bed fusion and direct en-part-29
fileName: 2021 - Progress in AM - Kladovasilakis et al. - Impact of metal additive manufacturing parameters on the powder bed fusion and direct en.md
content:
Mechanical properties,such as structural strength and hardness are mainly influenced by the relative density of the part's internal structure.Relative density of metal AM products is always less than $1 0 0 \%$ reducing the integrity on the mechanical properties of the object. This is mainly due to the presence of voids and entrapped gases within the structure,which are created during the metal AM process. Relative density is primary influenced by the following printing parameters: laser power, scan speed, hatching distance,layer thickness and energy density [88]. There are two major different mechanisms that create discontinuities: lack of fusion and keyholing [62]. Lack of fusion of the feedstock material may occur in situations where the molten pool has not adequate penetrated into the previously deposited layer and has failed to fully melt the feedstock material, resulting to the welding of unmelted particles on the last printed surface.Their removal from the coater could create a pit on the surface as illustrated in Fig. 8a. The second mechanism occurs when excessive energy source is applied on the feedstock material leading in the formation of regions with entrapped gases or Vapor in the internal structure of the product, i.e.keyholing as shown in Fig.8b.Mukherjee et al. [89, 90] showed that there is a relation between the two mechanisms and are strongly dependent on the applied material.More specifically, the materials that exhibit extensive thermal strain and distortion,like Ti6Al4V and AlSi10M, are more vulnerable at keyholing defects and composition changes due to the development of metal vapors; however, they minimize defects such as lack of fusion. On the other hand, the materials that are resistant at thermal strain and form small molten pools,like SS316 and Inconel 625,are most susceptible to lack of fusion defects.

![](images/69517f9aad05a626891881876373962488929c817d2cc9e223c5c0971d0a8210.jpg)  
Fig.8 Graphical illustration of void creation in PBF

name: 2021 - Progress in AM - Kladovasilakis et al. - Impact of metal additive manufacturing parameters on the powder bed fusion and direct en-part-30
fileName: 2021 - Progress in AM - Kladovasilakis et al. - Impact of metal additive manufacturing parameters on the powder bed fusion and direct en.md
content:
Various studies have applied Taguchi and one-factor-at-atime (OFAT) methods to examine the effect of each processrelated parameter on the mechanical performance of a metal AM part. These studies have shown that the influence of hatching distance and layer thickness on the relative density present the same trend and it is exhibited in Fig. 9a, b correspondingly; the smaller these values are,the higher is the relative density of the fabricated part due to the concentration of the energy density [28, 60, 88]. Moreover, other process-related parameters,such as laser power and scan speed, possess a more complex relationship to the creation of defects in the part's structure.More specifically, depending on the feedstock material, there are optimum printing conditions that result to a maximum relative density [28, 55]. Consequently,as shown in the qualitative diagrams concerning the laser power and scan speed in Fig. 9c, d correspondingly,a plateau is created in which a certain value of the highest relative density could be achieved [62, 88]. According to Ghayoor et al. [55], in case of employing appropriate printing conditions with SS 3O4L as construction material, it is possible to achieve up to $9 9 \%$ relative density providing remarkable tensile strength. Liverani et al. [91] concluded that a relative density of $9 8 \%$ coupled with proper build orientation could lead in producing metal AM components with fatigue strength properties close to the reference bulk one. Finally, Georgilas et al. [92] exhibited that matching proper powder properties, such as Hausner ratio and PSD with suitable process parameters (energy density,laser power etc.) is possible to reach a relative density up to $9 9 . 8 4 \%$ for Inconel 718 specimens.

![](images/9507fa98297a8ebbfaecd83f95f5e50027c5f6baf21be0eb698f92bd2557dbbd.jpg)  
Fig.9 Typical trends of relative density for: a hatching distance; b layer thickness; c scan speed; d laser power

name: 2021 - Progress in AM - Kladovasilakis et al. - Impact of metal additive manufacturing parameters on the powder bed fusion and direct en-part-31
fileName: 2021 - Progress in AM - Kladovasilakis et al. - Impact of metal additive manufacturing parameters on the powder bed fusion and direct en.md
content: In DED procedures, three process-related parameters affect mainly the mechanical properties of an additively manufactured part.These parameters are the scan speed, the laser power and the feed rate (both for wire-feed or powder-feed).As in the case of the PBF method, the mechanical performance of parts created via DED techniques are affected by their relative density. Combinations of the feed rate and laser power generate defects within the internal structure, such as keyholing and regions with lack of fusion [93]. According to Prasad et al. [3O] high feed rates on powder-feed DED lead in undesired phenomena such as spatter formation and boiling effect resulting to low catchment effciency and increase of porosity. Figure 1O [18] exhibits a detailed map of the relationships between feed rate and defects depending on the heat input for a variety of feedstock materials.In particular, in situations where the feed rate is high, the energy source is unable to completely melt the material resulting in the creation of defects due to lack of fusion phenomena. Contrarily, when the feed rate is low, the material receives an excessive amount of energy which provokes defects due to the keyholing effect. Furthermore, according to Wang et al. [94] and Zhang et al. [95], the reduction of the laser power in DED processes results in an increase of hardness and tensile strength. This enhancement is obtained due to the faster cooling rates of the printed layer, so according to the Hall-Petch formula and the effect of grain boundary strengthening [96, 97], the size of the grains inside the microstructure of the material is refined leading in the improvement of the mechanical properties of the product.

name: 2021 - Progress in AM - Kladovasilakis et al. - Impact of metal additive manufacturing parameters on the powder bed fusion and direct en-part-32
fileName: 2021 - Progress in AM - Kladovasilakis et al. - Impact of metal additive manufacturing parameters on the powder bed fusion and direct en.md
content:
In [94, 95], OFAT methods showed that as the scan speed increases,the thermal energy is absorbed by the feedstock material in a shorter amount of time, thus there is a reduction of the molten pool size and an increment of the cooling rates resulting to the increase of the hardness and strength in metal additively manufactured components.

![](images/bfdcdd0e729e87155e2681e7140b44a38412e16a0af4e5444d28345a9878ecca.jpg)  
Fig.10 Diagram of dependency of defects with feed rate and energy input [18]

As documented in previous paragraphs, the mechanical properties of an additively manufactured part deteriorate as its relative density decreases.Nevertheless,metal AM is also applied for the fabrication of low-density products, such as light-weight parts and objects with high porosity $( \rho _ { \mathrm { r e l a t i v e } } < 6 0 \% )$ [34]. This practice could be achieved by employing lattice structures for the internal structure of the part,as shown in Fig. 6.However, utilizing these structures could result in a strong reduction of the mechanical properties.According to Gibson et al. [34], this deterioration follows the equation of a scaling law:

$$
\Phi _ { \mathrm { l a t t i c e } } = \Phi _ { \mathrm { s o l i d } } \cdot C \cdot \left( \rho _ { \mathrm { r e l a t i v e } } \right) ^ { n } ,
$$

name: 2021 - Progress in AM - Kladovasilakis et al. - Impact of metal additive manufacturing parameters on the powder bed fusion and direct en-part-33
fileName: 2021 - Progress in AM - Kladovasilakis et al. - Impact of metal additive manufacturing parameters on the powder bed fusion and direct en.md
content:
$\boldsymbol { \varPhi } _ { \mathrm { l a t t i c e } }$ and $\boldsymbol { \phi } _ { \mathrm { s o l i d } }$ are the values of a mechanical property with lattice and solid structure correspondingly. Furthermore, $\rho _ { \mathrm { r e l a t i v e } }$ is the relative density of the object, $C$ and $n$ are variables influenced by the selected internal geometry (lattice structures). Depending on the applied lattice structure,the variables $C$ and $n$ are adjusted to alternate their impact on the mechanical properties of the printed product. Recent research suggests that lattice structures that possess the smaller influence on the mechanical behavior of an AM part are the triply periodic minimal surfaces(TPMS), followed by the truss-based structures (textile)and finally the

2D lattice structures (honeycombs and prismatic),which present strong anisotropy phenomena [36, 37, 98, 99].

name: 2021 - Progress in AM - Kladovasilakis et al. - Impact of metal additive manufacturing parameters on the powder bed fusion and direct en-part-34
fileName: 2021 - Progress in AM - Kladovasilakis et al. - Impact of metal additive manufacturing parameters on the powder bed fusion and direct en.md
content: Metal AM components are used in highly demanding applications, such as aerospace and automotive, thus it is essential to meet specific requirements regarding their mechanical performance.To accomplish this task, metal AM parts undergo post-processing procedures.The most common procedures are heat treatments (homogenization, aging,annealing),hot isostatic pressing(HIP) and shot peening. In their comprehensive review,Liu and Shin [100] pointed out the necessity of post-processing procedures to minimize the internal defects and enhance the mechanical properties of a Ti6Al4V product using DED or PBF techniques. Moreover, according to Pal et al. [59] and Popovich et al. [101], proper heat treatment (aging, homogenization) enhances both strength properties and hardness.Ma et al. [102] deduced that excessive heat treatment or special heat treatment (annealing) may result in a slight decrease of the tensile properties and hardness;however,it enhances the ductility as well the fatigue properties of the product. Furthermore,the HIP process improves the ductility of the printed objects and enhances the fatigue strength,while also reducing significantly the porosity leading in a noticeable reduction of mechanical anisotropies [39,40,103,104]. Considering the studies of Molaei et al.[1O3] and Sanaei et al. [104], AM parts that undergo post-processing procedures to reduce their surface roughness, such as machining, exhibit increased fatigue and cycling loading strength. This behavior occurs due to the extinction of defects on the surfaces of the part that could lead to a crack initiation. Finally, according to Sanz et al. [38], the post-processing procedure of shot peening could result in a relief of the internal stresses improving that way the mechanical properties of the printed part.

name: 2021 - Progress in AM - Kladovasilakis et al. - Impact of metal additive manufacturing parameters on the powder bed fusion and direct en-part-35
fileName: 2021 - Progress in AM - Kladovasilakis et al. - Impact of metal additive manufacturing parameters on the powder bed fusion and direct en.md
content:
A plethora of parameters affect the metal AM processes in terms of the quality of the final printed part. The quality of a product depends mainly on its mechanical behaviour, dimensional accuracy and surface quality. During the last decade,many studies have been focused on examining the process parameters that affect the metal AM procedures to produce high quality components.However, there is still no optimal direction to produce metal AM parts,so researchers investigate trade-off scenarios between various parameters.

Metal parts produced via AM procedures demonstrate anisotropy,so post-processing procedures are used to enhance the part's quality. The utilization of heat treatments (i.e.HIP) reduces but does not eliminate the anisotropy effect in metal AM process.Therefore,it is essential to develop mathematical and artificial intelligence (AI) models that would calculate the optimum build orientation depending on the product's application diminishing the anisotropyphenomena.

The detection of defects in metal PBF methods has been the subject of many researches over the last years. These studies mainly focus on the process-related parameters (layer thickness,hatching distance,laser power, scan speed, energy density) and the types of defects they generate.While the influence of various parameters has been analysed and verified by numerous research articles, there is still no systematic work on real time quality control methods of metal AM procedures. Therefore, in situ monitoring and intervention methods should be developed to improve the reliability and the eficiency of metal AM technology.

name: 2021 - Progress in AM - Kladovasilakis et al. - Impact of metal additive manufacturing parameters on the powder bed fusion and direct en-part-36
fileName: 2021 - Progress in AM - Kladovasilakis et al. - Impact of metal additive manufacturing parameters on the powder bed fusion and direct en.md
content:
DED technology composes one of the first metal AM techniques that were utilized in real case applications due to the existing technical background in welding technology. Various studies have focused on improving process parameters selection,which possess a direct impact on the manufactured products.However,a new field of research is being carried out aiming to the optimization of metal AM technology.Hybrid AM is a method that combines the DED method with traditional CNC machining techniques. Hybrid AM is a promising technique that targets to accent the advanced mechanical properties of a metal component produced by DED process along with the high quality and the accuracy of CNC machining [105].

There is a strong interest, both in industry and research, into the utilization of lattice structures as infill patterns on metal AM components for structural optimization,i.e. for maximum structural strength with minimal mass. During the last decade, plenty of complex lattice structures have been inspected due to the improvement of computer-aided design (CAD） and computer-aided engineering (CAE) software tools.However, there is a research gap on the utilization of advanced lattice geometries (such as TPMS) in metal AM procedures and the experimental data concerning their impact on the mechanical behavior of a product is limited.In addition,a narrow number of materials have been examined with these geometries, thus there is a paucity of research regarding the types of materials that could be used in high technology industries,such as Inconel alloys,titanium alloys and other superalloys.Finally, it is suggested to examine hybrid lattice structures to optimize the mechanical properties of a metal AM object [106].

name: 2021 - Progress in AM - Kladovasilakis et al. - Impact of metal additive manufacturing parameters on the powder bed fusion and direct en-part-37
fileName: 2021 - Progress in AM - Kladovasilakis et al. - Impact of metal additive manufacturing parameters on the powder bed fusion and direct en.md
content:
# 5 Summary
This paper presents a review for the most applicable metal AM processes as well the existing research in the identification and the optimization of process-parameters that influence the metal AM parts.Numerous articles were considered which investigate the capabilities to improve the quality of AM process taking into account the feedstock material, print orientation,printing conditions,infill patterns and post-processing procedures.These studies utilized a variety of statistical tools and experimental methods to identify the effect of each factor on the final quality of the AM component. The most essential findings were collected,classified and evaluated according to the type of influence on the quality of the product, which namely are dimensional accuracy,surface quality and mechanical behaviour. In addition, the present article constitutes to the declaration of a process map of the categories that affect metal AM through the combination of the existing literature to facilitate research and development for industrial applications.Finally, the review paper exhibits the progress in metal AM procedures,but also points out several fields of study that need thorough investigations and improvements to overcome existing challenges and limitations of the AM technology.

Acknowledgements We acknowledge support of this work by the project “Intelligent kαt Automated Systems for enabling the Design, Simulation and Development of Integrated Processes and Products— ODYSSEAS"(MIS 5002462)which is implemented under the “Action for the Strategic Development on the Research and Technological Sector",funded by the Operational Programme "Competitiveness,Entrepreneurship and Innovation"(NSRF 2014-2020) and co-financed by Greece and the European Union (European Regional Development Fund).

Funding Not applicable.

Availability of data and material Not applicable.

Code availability Not applicable.

name: 2022 - Int. J. Advanced Manufacturing Technology - Wang, Liang - Prediction of molten pool height, contact angle, and balling occurrence-part-1
fileName: 2022 - Int. J. Advanced Manufacturing Technology - Wang, Liang - Prediction of molten pool height, contact angle, and balling occurrence.md
content:
Wenjia Wang1 $\cdot$ Steven Y. Liang1

Received: 18 October 2021/Accepted: 21 December 2021 /Published online: 19 January 2022   
$\circledcirc$ The Author(s),under exclusive licence to Springer-Verlag London Ltd.,partof Springer Nature 2022
summary: Prediction of molten pool height, contact angle,and balling occurrence in laser powder bed fusion

name: 2022 - Int. J. Advanced Manufacturing Technology - Wang, Liang - Prediction of molten pool height, contact angle, and balling occurrence-part-2
fileName: 2022 - Int. J. Advanced Manufacturing Technology - Wang, Liang - Prediction of molten pool height, contact angle, and balling occurrence.md
content:
# Abstract
In this work,ananalytical modeling method is proposed for the predictionof molten pool height,contact angle,and balling occurrence in laser powder bedfusion (LPBF) metal additive manufacturing. A closed-form temperature prediction model is employed tocalculate the temperature distribution during melting proces.The width and length of molten pool,and width of powder consumed band are then determined by comparingthe temperature profile with the melting point of the material.The shapeof thesolidifedcapof the moltenpool is assumed tobeasegmentalcylinder.Per this assmption and mass conservation,the molten pool height,contact angle,and diameter ofthecylindrical cap are then determined through geometricalrelationships.Theoccurrences ofballing defect are then predictedbycheckingthe stabilityconditionofscan tracks under different processconditions.The predictedresultsof moltenpool width,height,and contact angle are compared with experimentalresultsofTi6Al4V,Inconel625 inLPBF,andshowacceptableaccuracy.The predictionsofballingoccurrence areconsistent with most experimental observations of SS316L.The sensitivities ofcontact angle to processconditions are discused.Inlightof thefactthat thetemperature profilesarecalculatedbaseduponsolutions inclosed form,the presented computations of moltenpool geometric characteristics and ballng ocurrence do notuseany numerical iterations,which makes the proposed analytical modeling method computationally eficient. Thus,the proposed modeling method can be a fast and acceptable tool for the study of molten pool geometry and stability of single tracks in LPBF.

Keywords Laser powder bed fusion $\cdot$ Analytical modeling $\cdot$ Molten pool height $\cdot$ Contact angle $\cdot$ Balling occurrence

name: 2022 - Int. J. Advanced Manufacturing Technology - Wang, Liang - Prediction of molten pool height, contact angle, and balling occurrence-part-3
fileName: 2022 - Int. J. Advanced Manufacturing Technology - Wang, Liang - Prediction of molten pool height, contact angle, and balling occurrence.md
content:
Laser powder bed fusion (LPBF) additive manufacturing can fabricate complex metallic products directly from digital models,which is quite superior when compared with other traditional manufacturing techniques,such as machining, casting,and rolling[1].However,defects often exist in the final products of LPBF,which will deteriorate their quality. Balling is a common process-induced defect in LPBF. It represents the phenomenon that the molten pool of a scan track breaks into plenty of individual spherical droplets [2]. It will cause high part porosity and undesired surface roughness, thus has detrimental effects on the mechanical performance of the products.As discussed in[3,4], the onset of balling phenomenon is related to the size and geometry of the molten pool in single tracks.Thus, it is necessary to have a better understanding of the molten pool geometric characteristics including height, width,and contact angle,so that to better infer the occurrence of balling and to optimize the process conditions for the fabrication of balling-free products.

Experimental investigations, numerical simulations, and analytical modeling are three main methods to study the characteristics of LPBF process. Experimental techniques can help the researchers monitor the in situ melting process of the metal powders,observe the formation of processinduced defects,and measure the properties of final products [5-8]. For example,Cunningham et al.[1] observed the formation process of vapor depression depth in LPBF by using a high-speed X-ray image technique.The correlation between vapor depression depth and process conditions was studied. Wang et al. [3] used a roughness meter to measure the roughness of upper layer surface in LPBF and employed

name: 2022 - Int. J. Advanced Manufacturing Technology - Wang, Liang - Prediction of molten pool height, contact angle, and balling occurrence-part-4
fileName: 2022 - Int. J. Advanced Manufacturing Technology - Wang, Liang - Prediction of molten pool height, contact angle, and balling occurrence.md
content: Archimedean method to measure the part porosity. The sensitivity of roughness and porosity to energy density was discussed. Li et al. [9] employed scanning electron microscope (SEM) to investigate the morphology of single scan tracks and microstructure of final products under different process conditions. It was found that the balling tendency has increasing trends with the increase of scan speed and layer thickness.However, it will decrease when the laser power increases.The effects of oxygen content and surface remelting on the balling characteristics were also studied based on the experimental observations. Bertoli et al. [8] also investigated the effects of process conditions on the surface morphology and balling tendency of single scan tracks. The observed sensitivity of balling tendency to laser power and scan speed was consistent with the conclusions in [9]. Guo et al. [10] employed SEM to observe the morphology of the powder material and used optical microscope (OM) to study the surface morphology and wetting characteristics of the single tracks. The discontinuity, humping,and balling behaviors of tracks were observed. The OM was also widely used to observe the geometry of molten pool cross-sections and obtain the information of molten height, width,depth, and contact angle [1O-12]. Although experimental study can help the researchers understand the physics in LPBF process and has provided significant amount of valuable data, the high cost of experimental equipment and complex operations for measurements will hinder the further application of these experimental techniques.

name: 2022 - Int. J. Advanced Manufacturing Technology - Wang, Liang - Prediction of molten pool height, contact angle, and balling occurrence-part-5
fileName: 2022 - Int. J. Advanced Manufacturing Technology - Wang, Liang - Prediction of molten pool height, contact angle, and balling occurrence.md
content: Numerical simulations do not need expensive equipment or complex operations,and they are very convenient to conduct; thus, more and more numerical models have been developed by researchers to simulate the LPBF process. Tian et al. [13] developed a three-dimensional numerical model to simulate the formation of single tracks in LPBF,with the consideration of recoil pressure and Marangoni effect.The discrete element method was employed to simulate the packing of powder material.Based on the simulated results, the development mechanisms of process-induced defects such as balling and porosity were discussed. Tang et al.[14] proposed a computational fluid dynamic-based model for the simulation of melting and solidification in LPBF process. The powder bed packing pattern was also generated by a discrete element method. The mechanism of the formation of porosity was analyzed based on the simulations. Tang et al. [15] also used computational fluid dynamics and discrete element method to simulate the single-track printing in LPBF. The mechanism of humping formation was analyzed, and effects of different forces such as surface tension and recoil pressure on the formation of humping were also discussed.Khairallah et al.[16] developed a three-dimensional model for the simulation of melting process in LPBF. The laser ray-tracing model was included in the simulation process.The formation mechanisms of pores,denudation,and spatter were revealed. Ge et al. [17] proposed a numerical model to study the characteristics of molten pool and scan track morphology. The laser ray-tracing method was also employed in the simulation. The discontinuity and balling defect in scan tracks were both predicted by the numerical model and the predictions agreed well with the experimental observations.However, the main disadvantage of these numerical models is the low computational efficiency, which will significantly increase the computational cost [14].

name: 2022 - Int. J. Advanced Manufacturing Technology - Wang, Liang - Prediction of molten pool height, contact angle, and balling occurrence-part-6
fileName: 2022 - Int. J. Advanced Manufacturing Technology - Wang, Liang - Prediction of molten pool height, contact angle, and balling occurrence.md
content: Analytical modeling has high computational efficiency because it does not resort to iteration-based numerical computations.There have been plenty of physics-based analytical models proposed in the literature for the study of LPBF process. Ning et al. [18], Tang et al. [19], Wang et al. [20], and Promoppatum et al. [21] all employed the Rosenthal equation to calculate the temperature profile and obtain the information of molten pool size and shape in LPBF.Based on the validation against experimental measurements of molten pool size [18] and comparison with finite elementbased simulations [21], the analytical Rosenthal equation shows acceptable predictive accuracy and low computational cost.To consider the effects of heat loss at part boundaries,Ning et al. [18] combined a heat sink solution and the Rosenthal model together based on the principle of superposition.The predictions of molten pool size were better when considering the boundary effects.Vastola et al. [22] proposed a 2D model for the prediction of keyhole-induced porosity in LPBF.Wang et al.[3] presented an analytical expression of upper surface roughness for the uni-directional scan strategy in LPBF, based on the assumption of cylindrical molten pool transverse cross-section. Yadroitsev et al. [4] developed a stability condition for segmental cylinder based on the theory ofPlateau-Rayleigh instability,which could be used to determine the threshold of balling defect in LPBF.However, there have few complete analytical models proposed in the literature which can correlate the molten pool height, contact angle,and balling behavior directly with the process parameters such as laser power, scan speed and layer thickness,and material properties.

name: 2022 - Int. J. Advanced Manufacturing Technology - Wang, Liang - Prediction of molten pool height, contact angle, and balling occurrence-part-7
fileName: 2022 - Int. J. Advanced Manufacturing Technology - Wang, Liang - Prediction of molten pool height, contact angle, and balling occurrence.md
content: In this paper, a physics-based analytical model is presented to relate the molten pool height, contact angle,and balling occurrence to the process parameters and material properties in LPBF. The molten pool width, molten pool length,and width of powder consumed band are predicted first by a moving point heat source model of the temperature field in melting process,with given process conditions and material properties.Based on the principle of mass conservation and assumption of a cylindrical cap profile of molten pool, further molten pool geometric characteristics including the molten pool height, the contact angle,and diameter of cap profle are then calculated by geometrical relationships.With the obtained molten pool length and contact angle,the stability conditions of scan tracks under different process conditions are checked and the balling occurrences are discussed based on the results of contact angles and indicator values. The predicted results of molten pool width, height,and contact angles are compared with the experimental data of $\mathrm { I n } 6 2 5$ and Ti6Al4V.316L stainless steel is chosen as the material to experimentally validate the prediction of balling occurrence. The sensitivity of contact angle to process conditions is also analyzed.

name: 2022 - Int. J. Advanced Manufacturing Technology - Wang, Liang - Prediction of molten pool height, contact angle, and balling occurrence-part-8
fileName: 2022 - Int. J. Advanced Manufacturing Technology - Wang, Liang - Prediction of molten pool height, contact angle, and balling occurrence.md
content:
An analytical modeling strategy,followed by experimental validation, is proposed in this work for the prediction of molten pool height, contact angle,and balling occurrence in LPBF.An analytical moving point heat source model is employed for the calculation of temperature distribution in the melting process of LPBF,as shown in the top diagram of Fig.1. The heat source model was developed based on the assumptions of semi-infinite medium,temperatureindependent material properties,and steady state [23]. It can be expressed as

$$
\theta _ { \mathrm { p o i n t } } ( x , y , z ) = \frac { P \eta } { 2 \pi K R \big ( T _ { m } - T _ { 0 } \big ) } \mathrm { e x p } ( \frac { - V ( R + x ) } { 2 \kappa } )
$$

![](images/ff158dcf00eb29b5edc22666826c40e3eb0525a930951dfec2f3c2da993bf1cd.jpg)  
Fig.1 Schematic of the molten pool in melting process (top) and after solidification (bottom). $W _ { 0 }$ represents the width of powder consumed band.W denotes the molten pool width. $d$ represents the molten pool depth (also called re-melted depth). $h$ is the molten pool height. $L$ represents the layer thickness. $\Phi = \Phi _ { 1 } = \Phi _ { 2 }$ represents the contact angle.The portion of molten pool above the substrate is made of newly melted powder material, while the portion in the substrate represents the remelted zone of the substrate

name: 2022 - Int. J. Advanced Manufacturing Technology - Wang, Liang - Prediction of molten pool height, contact angle, and balling occurrence-part-9
fileName: 2022 - Int. J. Advanced Manufacturing Technology - Wang, Liang - Prediction of molten pool height, contact angle, and balling occurrence.md
content: In this equation, $\theta _ { \mathrm { p o i n t } } ( x , y , z ) = ( T - T _ { o } ) / ( T _ { m } - T _ { o } )$ represents the dimensionless temperature with $T _ { m }$ and $T _ { o }$ denote the melting point and initial temperature, respectively. $x$ represents the laser scanning direction, $y$ denotes the transverse direction, and $z$ is the build direction. $P$ and $V$ represent the laser power and scan speed of the LPBF process. $\eta$ represents the laser absorptivity. $K$ ,and $\kappa$ represent the thermal conductivity and diffusivity of the material, respectively. The value of $\kappa$ can be calculated with given $K$ ,density $\rho$ ， and specific heat $\boldsymbol { \underline { c } } _ { p }$ through the relationship $\kappa = K / \rho \mathrm { c } _ { \mathrm { p } }$ $R = \sqrt { x ^ { 2 } + y ^ { 2 } + z ^ { 2 } }$ is the distance of the calculation point to the laser source. After comparing the obtained temperature profile with the melting point of the material, the width of powder consumed band $W _ { 0 }$ , the width $W$ ,and length $L _ { m }$ of molten pool can be obtained. The predictive accuracy of the moving point heat source model for the prediction of molten pool length and width of powder consumed band in typical conduction melting mode has been verified in the literature [18, 19, 21].

name: 2022 - Int. J. Advanced Manufacturing Technology - Wang, Liang - Prediction of molten pool height, contact angle, and balling occurrence-part-10
fileName: 2022 - Int. J. Advanced Manufacturing Technology - Wang, Liang - Prediction of molten pool height, contact angle, and balling occurrence.md
content:
In the solidification process, due to the effects of surface tension and elimination of void in powder bed, the liquid metal above the substrate (or previous layer) will shrink and solidify into a cap shape,as shown in the bottom diagram of Fig. 1. In this study,the cap is assumed to be a segmental cylinder; thus,the cap cross-section is part of a circle. This assumption has been widely adopted in the literature to describe the shape of the cap profile,because it resembles most experimentally observed cap shape in typical conduction melting mode [3, 4]. Due to principle of mass conservation, the mass of newly melted powders in the melting process is equal to the mass in the solidified cap assuming that solidified cap reaches a full density, which can be expressed as

$A _ { 2 } = A _ { 1 } \times$ packing densification of powderbed where $A _ { 1 }$ represents the cross-section of newly melted powders with void inside, which can be obtained by image analysis of the temperature distribution calculated from the thermal model. $A _ { 2 }$ denotes the cross-section of solid cap with no void.Based on the mass conservation and the assumption of circular cap geometry, the molten pool height $h$ ,contact angle $\Phi$ ,and diameter of circular cap $D$ can be determined after solving the following simultaneous equations

$$
D \bullet \mathrm { s i n } \Phi = W
$$

$$
\mathrm { A } _ { 2 } = \Phi \bullet \frac { D ^ { 2 } } { 4 } - \frac { W } { 2 } \bullet ( \frac { D } { 2 } - h )
$$

$$
\displaystyle \cos \Phi = { \frac { ( D - 2 h ) } { D } }
$$

name: 2022 - Int. J. Advanced Manufacturing Technology - Wang, Liang - Prediction of molten pool height, contact angle, and balling occurrence-part-11
fileName: 2022 - Int. J. Advanced Manufacturing Technology - Wang, Liang - Prediction of molten pool height, contact angle, and balling occurrence.md
content:
The balling occurrence is then predicted by checking the stability condition of a segmental cylindrical scan track.As discussed by Yadroitsev et al. in [4], if the contact angle of a single track is below $9 0 ^ { \circ }$ , then no balling will occur. If the contact angle is over $9 0 ^ { \circ }$ , then the indicator value needs to be calculated so that to determine whether balling will appear. The formula to calculate the indicator value is expressed as $$ \mathsf { e } = \frac { \pi \bullet D } { L _ { m } } - \sqrt { 2 } \sqrt { \frac { \Phi ( 1 + \cos 2 \Phi ) - \sin 2 \Phi } { 2 \Phi ( 2 + \cos 2 \Phi ) - 3 \sin 2 \Phi } } $$ Table 1 Material properties [19,27,28]

Balling defect willoccur if the indicator value is negative; it will not appear if the indicator value is positive [4].

name: 2022 - Int. J. Advanced Manufacturing Technology - Wang, Liang - Prediction of molten pool height, contact angle, and balling occurrence-part-12
fileName: 2022 - Int. J. Advanced Manufacturing Technology - Wang, Liang - Prediction of molten pool height, contact angle, and balling occurrence.md
content: In this paper, the molten pool height, width and length, width of powder consumed band, contact angle,and balling occurrence under various process conditions are predicted by a physics-based analytical modeling method. Documented experimental measurements of In625 [12] are compared to analytical predictions to validate the modeling of molten pool width,height,and contact angle.In [12],a lab-developed LPBF equipment was utilized to conduct multiple single-track experiments, which employed a Quasi-CW Ytterbium fiber laser to melt the $\mathrm { I n } 6 2 5$ powders.The laser spot diameter was $7 2 \mu \mathrm { m }$ . An optical microscope was employed to observe the transverse cross sections of the molten pool. Table 1 shows the material properties of $\mathrm { I n } 6 2 5$ at the middle temperature of room temperature $( 2 5 ~ ^ { \circ } \mathrm { C } )$ and melting point.Table 2 shows the process conditions for LPBF of $\mathrm { I n } 6 2 5$ . To further verify the predictive accuracy of the proposed analytical method for different materials,the predictions of molten pool width and height are compared with the documented experimental measurements of Ti6Al4V in LPBF [24]. The single-track experiments in [24] were performed by using a Concept Laser M2 LPBF equipment. The laser spot size $( D 4 \sigma )$ of that equipment was $5 4 ~ { \mu \mathrm { m } }$ . The material properties of Ti6Al4V at room temperature are also shown in Table 1. The process conditions for Ti6Al4V are shown in Table 3.SS316L is selected for the validation for balling occurrence prediction.In [9],a lab-developed LPBF system was used to fabricate plenty of single tracks using SS316L powders [9]. The power source used was a 2Oo-W fiber laser. A Quanta 2Oo scanning electron microscope was employed to observe the surface morphology of the fabricated single tracks and analyzed the balling behavior.The material properties of SS316L at room temperature are also shown in Table 1.

content:

Based on the study in the literature,the laser absorptivity can be affected by many parameters in LPBF,including laser spot size,distance from laser source to powder bed, surface roughness of powder layer,and layer thickness [25,26]. The values of laser absorptivity used in this study have been reported in the literature,as shown in Table 1. The packing densifications of the common powders in LPBF are related to the powder size distribution, and they are usually in the range of 20 to $7 0 \%$ [12]. In this study, the packing densifications for $\mathrm { I n } 6 2 5$ , Ti6Al4V, and SS316L are assumed to be $3 0 \%$ ， $7 0 \%$ ,and $5 0 \%$ ,respectively. The initial temperature $T _ { 0 }$ is $2 0 ~ ^ { \circ } \mathrm { C }$ for all the simulations in this work,as stated in [9, 12,24]. In addition, it should be noted that all the process conditions studied in this paper are typical conduction mode,as observed through experiments in [9, 12, 24].

![](images/67a2317ef6eb7a93b2931a8e9600244471af0baa2a9181ad754b9deb0b0035eb.jpg)

name: 2022 - Int. J. Advanced Manufacturing Technology - Wang, Liang - Prediction of molten pool height, contact angle, and balling occurrence-part-15
fileName: 2022 - Int. J. Advanced Manufacturing Technology - Wang, Liang - Prediction of molten pool height, contact angle, and balling occurrence.md
content:
The comparison between predictions and experimental data of Inconel 625 and Ti6Al4V are shown in Figs.2,3,and 4 and Figs.6 and 7.It can be observed that the predicted results of molten pool width, height, and contact angle all show good agreement with experimental measurements for most cases.For some cases,the deviations between predictions and measurements are big.The occurrence of these deviations can be explained by many reasons because the melting and solidification processes in LPBF are affected by many process parameters.For example,the laser spot size can affect the coefficient of laser absorption and the geometry of vapor depression,which will then affect the formation of molten pool. The content of gas atmosphere in the LPBF equipment will affect the solidification and surface morphology of molten pools [9]. The powder size distribution and packing pattern will affect the powder bed density and material properties,which will then affect the heat transfer during the melting process [27]. Thus,the ignorance of these parameters in the proposed model will induce some deviations to experimental results.Calculated results of width of powder consumed band of $\mathrm { I n } 6 2 5$ and Ti6Al4V and the predicted results of contact angle of Ti6Al4V are shown in Figs.5,8,and 9, respectively.

![](images/7c338e4236b7c6cb111ccf2eb829c09dbceb6ff6306feecf117c0e2b5d21f798.jpg)

name: 2022 - Int. J. Advanced Manufacturing Technology - Wang, Liang - Prediction of molten pool height, contact angle, and balling occurrence-part-16
fileName: 2022 - Int. J. Advanced Manufacturing Technology - Wang, Liang - Prediction of molten pool height, contact angle, and balling occurrence.md
content: The calculated results of molten pool length,contact angle,diameter of cylindrical cap profile,and indicator value of SS316L are shown in Figs.10,11, 12,13, and 14. The experimental observed surface morphologies of SS316L under the same process conditions are shown in Fig.13(Track 1 to 8) and Fig.14 (Track 9 to 11) [9]. From Table 4 and Fig.11, it can be found that the contact angle has a positive relationship with scan speed and a negative relationship with laser power. As discussed in [3], balling defect will not appear when the contact angle is below $9 0 ^ { \circ }$ , so the indicator values for Tracks 1,2, 3,4, 10,and 11 are not calculated. When the contact angle is above $9 0 ^ { \circ }$ , the stability condition of a scan track needs to be checked to determine whether balling defect will occur. From the calculations in Fig.13,when the scan speed is over $3 5 0 ~ \mathrm { m m / s }$ , the indicator values are negative,which means that the stability conditions are not fulfilled and thus obvious balling will appear in Tracks 6,7,and 8.In the experimental observations shown in Fig.13, the scan track broke into plenty of individual drops when the scan speed was over $3 5 0 ~ \mathrm { m m / s }$ and the number of drops in a scan track showed an increasing trend with the scan speed [9].In other words,balling defect appeared when the scan speed was over $3 5 0 \ \mathrm { m m / s }$ and the severity of balling increased with the scan speed [9]. Thus,the predictions of balling occurrence for Tracks 1 to 8 are consistent with the experimental observations.For Track 9, the calculated indicator value (O.O8) is positive,which means the stability condition of this track is fulfilled and thus no balling should occur. However,as shown in Fig.14,obvious balling appeared when the laser power was 11O W.

name: 2022 - Int. J. Advanced Manufacturing Technology - Wang, Liang - Prediction of molten pool height, contact angle, and balling occurrence-part-17
fileName: 2022 - Int. J. Advanced Manufacturing Technology - Wang, Liang - Prediction of molten pool height, contact angle, and balling occurrence.md
content:
This difference between prediction and experimental observation may be caused by the prediction error in the thermal modeling process,which may be induced by the ignorance of temperature-dependent material properties and assumption of a constant laser absorptivity.For Tracks 10 and 11, no balling will happen according to the small contact angles,which is consistent with experimental observations in Fig. 14.

![](images/0b51e88e3cd08d0c57bbc398d7935adb8b075f498a9e33e22b0e48d0e17038cf.jpg)  
Fig.10 Predictions of molten pool length of SS316L

![](images/77e88ce73fe8fd5150c50ced3a075160971f248491d77f344a051f4544f2cd80.jpg)  
Fig.12 Predictions of diameter of cylindrical cap of SS316L

![](images/b0349d04e06d4ee86c7cf0a9d3b9c1694375eca0179efe8efabc2e41bc8b209b.jpg)  
Fig.13 SEM photos of scan tracks(Tracks 1 to 8) of SS316L under different scan speeds [9]. The bottom two coordinates show the calculated contact angles and indicator values for the scan tracks

The proposed analytical modeling method has shown acceptable accuracy for the prediction of molten pool width, height, contact angle,and balling occurrence. In addition, no numerical iterations are adopted in the proposed method, which will make it computationally efficient. The computational time of the proposed method is less than $2 \mathrm { m i n }$ when running on a personal laptop with a $3 . 4 \mathrm { - G H z }$ Intel i5 processer and Windows operating system.In contrast, the developed numerical model in [17] for the prediction of molten pool and surface morphology needs around $1 0 0 \mathrm { { h } }$ when running on a computer with an Intel i7-87o0 processor. Thus,the presented analytical method can be a promising tool for the study of characteristics of molten pools and balling defect in LPBF.

name: 2022 - Int. J. Advanced Manufacturing Technology - Wang, Liang - Prediction of molten pool height, contact angle, and balling occurrence-part-18
fileName: 2022 - Int. J. Advanced Manufacturing Technology - Wang, Liang - Prediction of molten pool height, contact angle, and balling occurrence.md
content:
![](images/55c25c12a4b11de601c49519d9746d329ab775a28740c135018eabbc5feb5936.jpg)  
Fig.14 SEM photos of scan tracks (Tracks 9 to 11) of SS316L under different laser powers [9]. The bottom two coordinates show the calculated contact angles and indicator values for the scan tracks

The predictions of molten pool height,width,and contact angle are compared with experimental measurements of Inconel 625 and Ti6Al4V and show good agreement with experimental results.The contact angle shows a positive relationship with the scan speed and a negative relationship with the laser power.The predictions of balling occurrence under different process conditions are validated against the experimental observations of 316L stainless steel in LPBF and are consistent with experimental observations for most scan tracks.The proposed analytical strategy has shown its ability to correlate the molten pool geometric characteristics and onset of balling phenomenon directly with process parameters and material properties.In addition, it is computationally efficient because no numerical iterations are included in this model. The acceptable predictive accuracy and low computational cost are the primary advantages of the proposed method, which will make it a useful tool for the study of molten pool characteristics and balling defects in laser powder bed fusion.

content:
Ethics approval Not applicable.
