name: 2023 - Int. J. Heat and Mass Transfer - Yao et al. - The essential role of initial powder bed state in selective laser melting of 316 L-part-3
fileName: 2023 - Int. J. Heat and Mass Transfer - Yao et al. - The essential role of initial powder bed state in selective laser melting of 316 L.md
content: Understanding the esential role of initial powder bed states (e.g.,structure and temperature) in the printing process is crucial to obtain high-quality components in powder-bed-based aditive manufacturing.In this article, a 3D high-fidelity model which considered the Marangoni efects and recoil pressure was established based on the computational fluid dynamics (CFD) approach to simulate the printing process of $3 1 6 \mathrm { ~ L ~ }$ stainless steel through selective laser melting (SLM).The influences of powder bed structure and temperature on the macroand microscopic characteristics of the molten layer during printing were comprehensively investigated.On this basis,corresponding mechanisms were analyzed. Results show that the developed numerical model can vividly reproduce the SLM process of $^ { 3 1 6 \mathrm { ~ L ~ } }$ stainless steel.With the increase of powder bed thickness from $3 2 . 0 2 ~ { \mu \mathrm { m } }$ $( H _ { \mathrm { { s p r e a d i n g } } } { = } 2 ~ D 9 0$ and $V _ { \mathrm { s p r e a d i n g } } { = } 0 . 2 ~ \mathrm { m } / s ,$ to $4 0 . 6 5 ~ { \mu \mathrm { m } }$ $( H _ { \mathrm { s p r e a d i n g } } { = } 2 D ^ { \mathsf { C } }$ 90and $V _ { \mathrm { s p r e a d i n g } } { = } 0 . 0 1 \ \mathrm { m } / s )$ ,the height of the molten layer will increase from 16.37 to $3 2 . 8 6 \mu \mathrm { m }$ ,the depth will decrease from $2 1 . 6 9 \mu \mathrm { m }$ to $1 0 . 5 2 \mu \mathrm { m } ,$ and the width will decrease from 100.67 to $9 4 . 9 4 ~ \mu \mathrm { m }$ Meanwhile,this will make the fluctuation of the depth (CV) increase from O.31 to O.85.When the initial temperature increases from $3 0 0 \mathrm { K }$ to $7 7 3 . 1 5 \mathrm { K }$ ,the height, depth and width of the molten layer increase by $3 . 8 8 ~ \mu \mathrm { m }$ $1 2 . 6 8 ~ { \mu \mathrm { m } }$ and $1 7 . 3 7 ~ { \mu \mathrm { m } }$ ,respectively.In this case,the CV is reduced from 0.34 to 0.23,implying the improvement of the molten layer quality.

name: 2023 - Int. J. Heat and Mass Transfer - Yao et al. - The essential role of initial powder bed state in selective laser melting of 316 L-part-4
fileName: 2023 - Int. J. Heat and Mass Transfer - Yao et al. - The essential role of initial powder bed state in selective laser melting of 316 L.md
content: Under the current laser parameters,the defects such as warping,pores,faults,and balling induced bythe insuficient melting in the thick powder bed can to a certain extent be reduced or even eliminated using the high initial temperature.The melting pool collapse will occur in a thin powder bed,the resultant entrained bubble defect in the molten layer can also be properly avoided by the high initial temperature.However,a special groove structure will appear due to excessive energy input.During multi-track melting,the rough surface,irregular molten layer and the pores between the molten tracks are likely to occur due to the insuficient energy input,these problems can be properly solved by employinga high initial temperature.

name: 2023 - Int. J. Heat and Mass Transfer - Yao et al. - The essential role of initial powder bed state in selective laser melting of 316 L-part-5
fileName: 2023 - Int. J. Heat and Mass Transfer - Yao et al. - The essential role of initial powder bed state in selective laser melting of 316 L.md
content: As one of the most frequently utilized additive manufacturing techniques [1],selective laser melting (SLM,also known as 3D printing) employs high-energy laser beam as the heat source to melt metal powder and produce parts with desired geometry and properties ina layered stack mode [2,3].Due to its high flexibility,no mold and structural restrictions,ithas been widely used in the fields of aerospace,automobile and medical appliances,etc.[4-6].As a crucial step in selective laser melting,the melting process will directly afect and determine the quality and performance of the printed products [7,8].

name: 2023 - Int. J. Heat and Mass Transfer - Yao et al. - The essential role of initial powder bed state in selective laser melting of 316 L-part-6
fileName: 2023 - Int. J. Heat and Mass Transfer - Yao et al. - The essential role of initial powder bed state in selective laser melting of 316 L.md
content: Currently,understanding the physical mechanisms and microscopic behaviors during SLM is always the researchers'main concern. Some researchers directly observed and investigated the complex molten pool variations or pore behaviors during the melting process through physical experiments by using high-energy X-ray imaging technology [9-12]. Even though the physical experiments are very intuitive and straightforward, the unavoidable disadvantages (e.g.,expensive devices, laborious operations, and difficulties for in-situ monitoring/characterization) restricted its further development 13].In comparison,numerical simulation is an appropriate alternative to overcome the problems in physical experiments because it can easily capture the dynamic information during printing from particulate scale and provide valuable solutions for actual process through optimization of results from systematic parametric studies.For example,Khairallah et al.[14] built a three-dimensional powder-scale model to reveal the mechanism of pore defects,material spattering (sparking),and denudation zones.Bayat et al. [8] analyzed the formation,evolution and disappearance of keyhole and keyhole-induced porosities along with their initiating mechanisms,during single track laser-based powder bed fusion.Wei etal.[4] studied the formation and evolution of inter-track voids in different heat input conditions.Khairallah etal.[1] discovered new spatter-induced defect formation mechanisms that depend on the scan strategy and competition between laser shadowing and expulsion. Gu et al.[15] investigated various phenomena including balling effect, keyhole depression,and insufficient fusion between layers are investigated with different laser energy inputs.Li et al.[16] analyzed the keyhole life cycle including formation and drilling,fluctuation,and disappearance.

name: 2023 - Int. J. Heat and Mass Transfer - Yao et al. - The essential role of initial powder bed state in selective laser melting of 316 L-part-7
fileName: 2023 - Int. J. Heat and Mass Transfer - Yao et al. - The essential role of initial powder bed state in selective laser melting of 316 L.md
content: These studies provide a new research perspective for the formation and mechanism of various behaviors in the melting process, such as internal pores,interlayer pores,molten layer morphology,and molten pool behavior,which demonstrates the necessity and significance of establishing an effective and proper numerical model in studying the powder bed melting process.

name: 2023 - Int. J. Heat and Mass Transfer - Yao et al. - The essential role of initial powder bed state in selective laser melting of 316 L-part-8
fileName: 2023 - Int. J. Heat and Mass Transfer - Yao et al. - The essential role of initial powder bed state in selective laser melting of 316 L.md
content: The variations in macro- and microscopic behaviors during melting are closely related to the process of SLM.Hence,researchers have conducted extensive researches on laser processing (i.e.,the effects of operating factors on the melting process).In this aspect, Gao et al.[17] discussed the effect of non-spherical particles on packing density, molten pool dynamics and melt track dimensions.Cao [18] investigated the influences of particle size distribution,powder bed compactness,and lamination thickness on SLM single-pass formation. And the influence of energy density on the single track formation and porosity development was investigated in detail [19-21].Gu et al.[22] discussed the influence of powder particle size on the melting and solidification characteristics of selective laser melting.It has been evidenced that the powder bed state has a great influence on the subsequent molten pool behavior and the properties of the final parts [23-25],while the essential role of the initial state (i.e.,initial structural state and temperature) of the powder bed in the subsequent melting process is not clear enough. Especially for the SLM 3D printing of 316 L stainless steel (abbreviated by 316 L) powder,much less work in this regard was found. Generally,following problems or research gaps are still existed and yet to be solved: (1) How do the initial structure and temperature of the powder beds affect the macro-and microscopic characteristics (including formation and prediction of defects) of the molten layer? (2) What is the quantitative correlation between them?(3) What are the underlying mechanisms? (4) What is the best resolution for improvement?

name: 2023 - Int. J. Heat and Mass Transfer - Yao et al. - The essential role of initial powder bed state in selective laser melting of 316 L-part-9
fileName: 2023 - Int. J. Heat and Mass Transfer - Yao et al. - The essential role of initial powder bed state in selective laser melting of 316 L.md
content: In this paper,the whole SLM process (including powder spreading and partial melting) of $3 1 6 \mathrm { ~ L ~ }$ powder was numerically reproduced. Firstly,the spreading of $3 1 6 \mathrm { ~ L ~ }$ powder was realized and visualized by discrete element method (DEM) used in our previous work [26,27]. Then,a computational fluid dynamics (CFD) model that considering the Marangoni effects and recoil pressure was established and validated to simulate the melting process of each powder layer. On this basis, the influences of powder bed structure and temperature on the macroscopic morphology (i.e.,width,height,and depth of each molten track) and microscopic behavior (i.e.,defects) of the molten layer were systematicallyinvestigated.Finally,the underlying mechanisms were analyzed and corresponding solutions were provided.The obtained highlighted results are of paramount theoretical and practical significance for in-depth insights on the melting process of SLM 3D printing and improving the quality of the molten layer as well as the performance of final products.

name: 2023 - Int. J. Heat and Mass Transfer - Yao et al. - The essential role of initial powder bed state in selective laser melting of 316 L-part-10
fileName: 2023 - Int. J. Heat and Mass Transfer - Yao et al. - The essential role of initial powder bed state in selective laser melting of 316 L.md

name: 2023 - Int. J. Heat and Mass Transfer - Yao et al. - The essential role of initial powder bed state in selective laser melting of 316 L-part-11
fileName: 2023 - Int. J. Heat and Mass Transfer - Yao et al. - The essential role of initial powder bed state in selective laser melting of 316 L.md
content:
# 2.1.DEM model for powder spreading
Before printing, the spreading of 316 L powder was reproduced by

DEM modeling.For abbreviation, only some main governing equations used in DEMare listed.For details,the readers can refer to our previous publications [26,27].In DEM simulation, the translational motion and rotational motion of each particle are governed by Newton's second law [28,29]:

$$
\begin{array} { l } { { m _ { i } \displaystyle \frac { d \nu _ { i } } { d t } = F _ { i } + m _ { i } g } } \\ { { \displaystyle } } \\ { { I _ { i } \displaystyle \frac { d \omega _ { i } } { d t } = T _ { i } } } \end{array}
$$

where $m _ { i } , \pmb { \nu } _ { i } , \pmb { \omega } _ { i }$ and $I _ { i }$ are the mass, translational velocity,angular velocity,and movement of inertia,respectively; $F _ { i }$ and $T _ { i }$ represent the total force and the total torque acting on the particle i.Hertz-Mindlin contact model is utilized to describe the elastic contact force and the cohesive force is calculated by the JKR model [3O].The normal contact force between particles can be expressed by:

$$
F _ { n } = \frac { 4 E ^ { * } } { 3 R ^ { * } } r ^ { 3 } - 4 \sqrt { \pi r ^ { 3 } \gamma E ^ { * } }
$$

where $\gamma , E ^ { * }$ and $R ^ { * }$ are the surface energy,the equivalent Young's modulus and the equivalent contact radius,respectively. The contact radius $r$ in Eq. (3) can be obtained from the expression of normal overlap $\alpha$

$$
\alpha = r ^ { 2 } / R ^ { * } - \sqrt { \frac { 2 \pi \gamma r } { E ^ { * } } }
$$

name: 2023 - Int. J. Heat and Mass Transfer - Yao et al. - The essential role of initial powder bed state in selective laser melting of 316 L-part-12
fileName: 2023 - Int. J. Heat and Mass Transfer - Yao et al. - The essential role of initial powder bed state in selective laser melting of 316 L.md
content:
The CFD model is established based on the following assumptions: (i) the fluids involved were regarded as the incompressible Newtonian fluids with laminar flow; (ii) the thermal expansion of the melted materials was not considered; (ii) the mass loss due to vaporization was not included in the model; (iv) the buoyant force was ignored [31]. In addition,since the solid particles were assumed to be incapable of movement during the simulation, the denudation of the powder layer near the molten pool was not considered.

The simulation of the powder melting process is performed based on mass,momentum and energy conservation equations [32],given by:

Mass:

$$
\nabla \cdot ( \rho \overrightarrow { \nu } ) = 0
$$

Momentum:

$$
\frac { \partial } { \partial t } ( \rho \overrightarrow { \nu } ) + \nabla \cdot ( \rho \overrightarrow { \nu } \otimes \overrightarrow { \nu } ^ { \prime } ) = \nabla \cdot ( \mu \nabla \overrightarrow { \nu } ^ { \prime } ) - \nabla p + \rho \overrightarrow { g } ^ { \prime }
$$

Energy:

$$
\frac { \partial } { \partial t } ( \rho h ) + \boldsymbol { \nabla \cdot } ( \rho \boldsymbol { \overrightarrow { \nu } } h ) = \boldsymbol { q } + \boldsymbol { \nabla \cdot } ( k \boldsymbol { \nabla } T )
$$

where $\overrightarrow { \nu }$ and $\overrightarrow { g }$ are the velocity vector and gravitational acceleration vector,respectively.trepresents time; $p$ is the pressure; $\rho$ is the density; $\mu$ is the average viscosity; $q$ is the Gaussian heat source; $h$ is the enthalpy; $k$ is the thermal conductivity; and $T$ is the temperature. $h$ can be obtained by [32]:

$$
\begin{array} { l } { \displaystyle h = c T + ( 1 - f _ { s } ) L } \\ { \displaystyle } \\ { f _ { s } = \frac { T - T _ { s } } { T _ { l } - T _ { s } } } \end{array}
$$
summary: 2.2. CFD model for powder melting - Part 1/3

name: 2023 - Int. J. Heat and Mass Transfer - Yao et al. - The essential role of initial powder bed state in selective laser melting of 316 L-part-13
fileName: 2023 - Int. J. Heat and Mass Transfer - Yao et al. - The essential role of initial powder bed state in selective laser melting of 316 L.md
content:
where $c$ and $L$ are the specific heat and latent heat of melting,respectively.The solid phase fraction $f _ { s }$ is assumed to be a linear interpolation of the temperature during the phase transition range between the solidus temperature $T _ { s }$ and liquidus temperature $T _ { l }$

The volume of fluid (VOF) method is used to track the free surface boundary of the molten pool [18,32,33].The volume ratio factor of metal phase $F$ is defined to indicate the volume fraction of metal phase at different positions.The value of $F$ is between O and1,where $F = 0$ means the grid is completely occupied by the gas phase,and $F = 1$ means it is occupied by the metal phase.The equation governing the law of $F$ is the volume ratio equation (VOF algorithm) [15]:

$$
\frac { \partial F } { \partial t } + \boldsymbol { \nabla } \mathbf { \cdot } ( \overrightarrow { \mathbf { \nabla } \nu } F ) = 0
$$

Marangoni effect, usually caused by the gradients of temperature and solute concentration,has an important impact on the flow behavior of the molten pool [34].The relationship between surface tension difference and temperature gradient can be described as [19,35]:

$$
\sigma = \sigma _ { 0 } - \frac { d \sigma } { d T } ( T - T _ { 0 } )
$$

where $\textstyle { \frac { d \sigma } { d T } }$ is the coeficient of surface tension with temperature change rate, $\sigma _ { 0 }$ is the surface tension coeficient at the reference temperature $T _ { 0 }$

Once the temperature exceeds a certain value,evaporation is prone to occur,which results in the generation of evaporation recoil pressure. The evaporation heat loss can be calculated by [22]:

$$
q _ { e \nu a p } = \frac { 0 . 8 2 L _ { \nu } m } { \sqrt { 2 \pi m k _ { B } T } } P _ { 0 } \mathrm { e x p } \left( \frac { L _ { \nu } m ( T - T _ { \nu } ) } { k _ { B } T T _ { \nu } } \right)
$$
summary: 2.2. CFD model for powder melting - Part 2/3

name: 2023 - Int. J. Heat and Mass Transfer - Yao et al. - The essential role of initial powder bed state in selective laser melting of 316 L-part-14
fileName: 2023 - Int. J. Heat and Mass Transfer - Yao et al. - The essential role of initial powder bed state in selective laser melting of 316 L.md
content:
where: $P _ { 0 }$ is the ambient pressure; $L _ { \nu }$ is the latent heat of vaporization; $m$ is the molecular mass; $k _ { B }$ is the Boltzmann constant; $T _ { \nu }$ is the gasification temperature; and $T$ is the temperature of liquid metal. The recoil pressure on the free surface can be calculated by [17,20]:

$$
P _ { \nu } = 0 . 5 4 P _ { 0 } \mathrm { e x p } \left( \frac { L _ { \nu } m } { k _ { B } } \left( \frac { T - T _ { \nu } } { T T _ { \nu } } \right) \right)
$$

In the present work,a moving laser heat source with Gaussian distribution is utilized during melting [18,36,37]:

$$
q _ { l a s e r } = \frac { 2 \eta P _ { l a s e r } } { \pi R ^ { 2 } } \exp \biggl ( - \frac { 2 r ^ { 2 } } { R ^ { 2 } } \biggr )
$$

where: $P _ { l a s e r }$ is the laser power; $R$ is the laser spot radius; $r$ is the distance to the central line of the laser spot; and $\eta$ is the power absorptivity rate.
summary: 2.2. CFD model for powder melting - Part 3/3

name: 2023 - Int. J. Heat and Mass Transfer - Yao et al. - The essential role of initial powder bed state in selective laser melting of 316 L-part-15
fileName: 2023 - Int. J. Heat and Mass Transfer - Yao et al. - The essential role of initial powder bed state in selective laser melting of 316 L.md
content: Fig.1 shows the whole procedure of SLM reproduced by numerical simulation.Firstly,the spreading process of $3 1 6 \mathrm { L }$ powder was simulated by the DEM method as shown in Fig.1(a).The size distribution of the actual $3 1 6 \mathrm { ~ L ~ }$ powder is $2 0 \mathrm { - } 8 5 ~ \mu \mathrm { m }$ $( D 1 0 { = } 3 1 ~ \mu \mathrm { m }$ $D 5 0 { = } 4 5 ~ { \mu \mathrm { m } }$ $D 9 0 { = } 6 5$ $\mu \mathrm { m } )$ as illustrated in Fig.Al,and the corresponding contact parameters are listed in Table A1 in Appendix.In powder spreading simulations, the gap height between the blade and substrate was set to be fixed (i.e., 2 D90);different blade velocities (i.e.,0.01,0.05,0.1,0.15, $0 . 2 \ : \mathrm { m } / s \dot { }$ were set to obtain different powder bed structures.It should be noted that since the spreading of 316 L powder has been successfully reproduced in our previous work [26],the powder beds with different structures therein were directly adopted in this study.

name: 2023 - Int. J. Heat and Mass Transfer - Yao et al. - The essential role of initial powder bed state in selective laser melting of 316 L-part-16
fileName: 2023 - Int. J. Heat and Mass Transfer - Yao et al. - The essential role of initial powder bed state in selective laser melting of 316 L.md
content: Secondly,the powder beds with different structures obtained from Fig.1(a) were used for subsequent CFD simulations.Here,in powder bed melting process (Fig.l(b)),the laser heat source loading and recoil pressure loading were realized by our homemade code.And FLOW-3D was used to solve all the governing equations.More details of simulation process are given in Section A.2 of the Appendix.In CFD simulation, the mesh size used in all cases is $5 \mu \mathrm { m }$ ,which has been proven to be effective in others’work [15,32,38,39].Boundary conditions for all the surfaces were considered as continuative (zero normal derivative).The powders and the substrate are set to be the same material.And the gas phase is not involved.The high-temperature physical properties of $3 1 6 \mathrm { L }$ powder and simulation parameters are shown in Table 1.These parameters are all from previous researches [18,20,3l,4O]. It should be noted that the average thicknesses of powder beds 1-5 in Table 1 are 40.65,34.88,34.35,33.41,and $3 2 . 0 2 \mu \mathrm { m }$ ,respectively.

Appendix.Firstly，Fig.2(b） gives the comparison of molten layer cross-sectional morphologies obtained from current simulations and previous experiments. Clearly,satisfactory agreement can be observed; especially, both the depth and the width of the molten layers are very comparable.Secondly,the macroscopic morphologies of the molten layers from both current numerical simulations and others’physical experiments under different conditions were also compared as shown in Figs.2(c) and (d),where good consistency can be demonstrated. In addition, the molten pool characteristics occurred during printing under different conditions were compared and shown in Figs. 2(e) and (f). One can find that the features of depression and keyhole from both studies are very comparable.On this basis,similar width of the molten layers in the two cases as presented in Fig.2(g) is also identified.Above analyses all prove that the established numerical model as well as the utilized materials parameters for $3 1 6 \mathrm { L }$ powder are valid and appropriate,which can guarantee the accuracy of the subsequent simulations.

name: 2023 - Int. J. Heat and Mass Transfer - Yao et al. - The essential role of initial powder bed state in selective laser melting of 316 L-part-19
fileName: 2023 - Int. J. Heat and Mass Transfer - Yao et al. - The essential role of initial powder bed state in selective laser melting of 316 L.md
content: The computational domain with the size of $1 2 0 0 ~ { \mu \mathrm { m } } \times 4 0 0 ~ { \mu \mathrm { m } } \times$ $3 0 0 \mu \mathrm { m }$ as shown in Fig.3 is used for the single-track melting simulation. The initial temperatures are all set to be $3 0 0 ~ \mathrm { K }$ while investigating the effect of the powder bed structure on the melting.During scanning, the laser starts from the position of $1 0 0 \mu \mathrm { m }$ in the left side and moves toward the $+ X$ direction along the central axis.The movement is stopped after $1 0 0 0 \mu \mathrm { m }$ .The total computation time is $1 . 5 \mathrm { m } s \mathrm { _ { \ell } }$ ,including1 ms for laser working and $0 . 5 ~ \mathrm { m s }$ for cooling.A systematic description of the laser scanning process is given in Section A.4 of the Appendix.

name: 2023 - Int. J. Heat and Mass Transfer - Yao et al. - The essential role of initial powder bed state in selective laser melting of 316 L-part-20
fileName: 2023 - Int. J. Heat and Mass Transfer - Yao et al. - The essential role of initial powder bed state in selective laser melting of 316 L.md
content: To reveal the influences of powder bed structure and temperature on the molten layer quality,the macroscopic morphologies and corresponding height,depth,and width of the molten layers (average values and fluctuations) obtained under different conditions were shown in Figs.4 and 5,respectively.It needs to note that the height and depth of the molten layer are measured from the surface of the substrate.
summary: 3.1.Effects of powder bed structure and temperature on the macroscopic morphology of the molten layer - Part 1/6

name: 2023 - Int. J. Heat and Mass Transfer - Yao et al. - The essential role of initial powder bed state in selective laser melting of 316 L-part-21
fileName: 2023 - Int. J. Heat and Mass Transfer - Yao et al. - The essential role of initial powder bed state in selective laser melting of 316 L.md
content: From Fig.4(a) one can find that when the powder bed is thick (e.g., powder bed 1),the shape of the molten layer fluctuates significantly, and the height and depth of the molten pool vary obviously.The entire molten layer can even be divided into three separate sections,and many parts are not melted [18].When the thickness of the powder bed is moderate (e.g.,powder beds 3 and 4),the morphology of the molten layeris not seriously fluctuated,and the internal pores are not likely to occur.When the powder bed is very thin and the number of particles is small(e.g.,powder bed 5),the fluctuation of the molten layer increases slightly,which is caused by the large difference of powder bed quality in early spreading stage [26].Moreover,due to the large cavities formed between particles in the powder bed,the laser even directly acts on the substrate,which reduces the utilization rate of energy to a certain extent [22].Accordingly,the variations of molten layer characteristics can be quantitatively reflected in Figs. 5(a)-(c). As can be seen that increasing the powder bed thickness from $3 2 . 0 2 \mu \mathrm { m }$ to $4 0 . 6 5 ~ { \mu \mathrm { m } }$ can increase the molten layer height from $1 6 . 3 7 \mu \mathrm { m }$ to $3 2 . 8 6 \mu \mathrm { m }$ .The thick powder layer will make it difficult for the laser energy to penetrate and transfer to the lower region; in this case,most of the melted part is from the powder layerabove the substrate[18],resulting ina higher heightof the molten layer.In addition,the depth of the molten layer from thick powder bed also becomes smaller due to the small energy transfer.For example, the molten layer depth of powder bed1is only $1 0 . 5 2 \mu \mathrm { m }$ .In comparison,the powder bed structure has litte efect on the width of the molten layer.
summary: 3.1.Effects of powder bed structure and temperature on the macroscopic morphology of the molten layer - Part 2/6

name: 2023 - Int. J. Heat and Mass Transfer - Yao et al. - The essential role of initial powder bed state in selective laser melting of 316 L-part-22
fileName: 2023 - Int. J. Heat and Mass Transfer - Yao et al. - The essential role of initial powder bed state in selective laser melting of 316 L.md
content:
To further explore the influence of powder bed structure on the molten pool morphology,the coefficient of variations (CV) of the molten layer height,depth and width under different conditions are calculated by:

$$
C V = { \frac { X _ { \mathrm { s t } } } { \overline { { X } } } }
$$
summary: 3.1.Effects of powder bed structure and temperature on the macroscopic morphology of the molten layer - Part 3/6

name: 2023 - Int. J. Heat and Mass Transfer - Yao et al. - The essential role of initial powder bed state in selective laser melting of 316 L-part-23
fileName: 2023 - Int. J. Heat and Mass Transfer - Yao et al. - The essential role of initial powder bed state in selective laser melting of 316 L.md
content: where $X _ { \mathrm { s t } }$ is the standard deviation of $X$ and $\overline { { X } }$ is the average value. $X$ represents the molten pool height,depth and width,respectively.A larger CV indicates the more serious fluctuation of the molten layer. The fluctuations of CV in Figs.5(a)-(c) indicate that increasing powder bed thickness will result in a decrease of the $C V$ of molten layer depth from 0.85 to O.31,implying a more uniform depth evolution.The upper surface of the molten layer is significantly affected by the powder bed structure.The fluctuation of the upper surface is extremely complicated due to the complexity of the structure.In addition,the height of the molten layer increases with powder bed thickness.Therefore,the CV of the molten layer height does not show obvious trend, so as to the CV of the molten layer width.For the molten layer depth,when the thickness of the powder bed is reduced (from Powder beds 1 to 4),the powder bed is decreased from 3-4 layers of particles to one layer of particles.The energy transfer path changes from the particle-particle-substrate mode to a simple particle-substrate mode.Complex particle-particle contacts result in high molten layer depth fluctuations for thick powder beds. Therefore,the CV of the molten layer depth becomes smaller with the decrease of the powder bed thickness.As the powder bed becomes thinner (Powder bed 5),the involved cavities between the particles become larger;in this case,the particle distribution becomes more uneven,which leads to the increase of the CV of the molten layer depth. Combining with Fig.4(a),one can find that the quality of the molten layer of powder bed 4is more optimal under current laser conditions. Therefore,powder bed 4is selected for investigating the influence of powder bed temperature in the following sections.
summary: 3.1.Effects of powder bed structure and temperature on the macroscopic morphology of the molten layer - Part 4/6

name: 2023 - Int. J. Heat and Mass Transfer - Yao et al. - The essential role of initial powder bed state in selective laser melting of 316 L-part-24
fileName: 2023 - Int. J. Heat and Mass Transfer - Yao et al. - The essential role of initial powder bed state in selective laser melting of 316 L.md
content: Fig.4(b) shows the macroscopic morphologies of molten layers obtained from different initial temperatures.As indicated that no obvious defects can be observed in each molten layer.With the increase of initial temperature,the area (red region in Fig.4(c)) of the molten layer expands obviously.From the average values in Figs.5(d)-(f),one can find that when the initial temperature increases from $3 0 0 \mathrm { K }$ to 773.15K, the height, depth and width of the molten layer are increased by $3 . 8 8 ~  { \mu \mathrm { m } }$ $1 2 . 6 8 \mu \mathrm { m }$ and $1 7 . 3 7 \mu \mathrm { m }$ ,respectively,which can be inextricably linked with the conclusion in Fig.A3(b) in Appendix.A high initial temperature can increase the energy contained in the molten pool so that the maximum temperature therein will be increased [41],which will increase the melted particles and substrate area [25].From the CV evolution in Figs.5(d)-(f),one can find similar effect as the powder bed structure;i.e.,only the effects of initial temperature on the molten pool depth are monotonic.Here,the CV of the molten pool depth decreases from 0.34 to 0.23 with the increase of the initial temperature,indicating that the fluctuation of the depth becomes smaller and the quality of the molten layer becomes better.Under the same initial structure,the shapes of the molten layers obtained from different temperatures are basically similar.However, the incrementof the molten pool at diferent parts caused by the high initial temperature is not consistent due to the complexity of the powder bed structures.Therefore,the CV of the molten layer height and width does not show obvious monotonic trend. For the depth of the molten layer,the high thermal conductivity caused by the high initial temperature reduces the heat difference between different parts,and the fluctuation of the molten depth caused by the powder bed is reduced,so the CVof the molten layer depth decreases.
summary: 3.1.Effects of powder bed structure and temperature on the macroscopic morphology of the molten layer - Part 5/6

Fig.2.Model validation.
summary: 3.1.Effects of powder bed structure and temperature on the macroscopic morphology of the molten layer - Part 6/6

name: 2023 - Int. J. Heat and Mass Transfer - Yao et al. - The essential role of initial powder bed state in selective laser melting of 316 L-part-26
fileName: 2023 - Int. J. Heat and Mass Transfer - Yao et al. - The essential role of initial powder bed state in selective laser melting of 316 L.md
content: Inaddition to the aforementioned analysis of macroscopic characteristics,the microscopic features of the molten layers are also very important to reveal related dynamics and mechanisms.Fig.6(a) shows the molten layer morphologies of the thick powder bed (Powder bed 1) under two different initial temperatures. Clearly,there are many defects in the molten layer when the initial temperature is $3 0 0 \mathrm { K } ,$ where the typical features are mainly located in the three positions“i-ii" marked by the dotted box.The formation process of these microscopic defects isanalyzed in detail,as depicted in Figs.6(b)-(d).It is worth mentioning that the red and black dashed circles in the figure are the initial and final states of the selected key analysis zones.And the corresponding positions are marked with yellow arrows to describe the evolution of the molten pool conveniently in this duration.From Fig.6 (b) one can find that when the laser is irradiated on the surface of the powder bed $\left( 0 . 0 0 { - } 0 . 0 3 \mathrm { m s } \right)$ ,the top particles are melted rapidly.At this moment, the energy of the laser cannot be transferred to the downward particles,which makes them not properly melted.At $0 . 0 6 \mathrm { m s }$ ,the central region of the laser shifts to the right and part of the lower particles are melted due to the energy transfer.When the laser moves away from this position $( 0 . 1 2 \mathrm { - } 0 . 1 5 \mathrm { m } s )$ ,the molten pool gradually cools.At $0 . 1 8 \mathrm { m s }$ it is completely solidified and a special-shaped “edge warping"structure is formed.Similar features can be observed in others’work [43].The initial position of the laser scanning path and the thick powder bed are the main reasons for this phenomenon.The laser action time in the initial position is shorter than that on the powder in other parts,so the input energy is less.

name: 2023 - Int. J. Heat and Mass Transfer - Yao et al. - The essential role of initial powder bed state in selective laser melting of 316 L-part-27
fileName: 2023 - Int. J. Heat and Mass Transfer - Yao et al. - The essential role of initial powder bed state in selective laser melting of 316 L.md
content:
In addition, the powder bed here is thicker with the thickness about 3-4 particle diameters $( \approx 1 . 5 ~ D 9 0 )$ .The energy of the laser cannot be quickly transferred to the lower part. Therefore, the particles in the upper layer are completely melted while those in the lower layer are partially melted; this phenomenon can also be observed in literature [18].

![](images/4e6d842d0e2ba549798b67285159306adda684481db7bac665f28d88b5645c30.jpg)  
Fig.3.Computational domain.

The microscopic behavior of the molten pool in Fig.6(c) is similar to that in Fig.6(b).At the initial moment $( 0 . 3 3 ~ \mathrm { m } s )$ ,the powder bed thickness in target zone (red dashed circle) is large.During laser scanning( $0 . 3 6 { - } 0 . 4 5 \mathrm { m s } )$ ,the powder is gradually melted from top to bottom, while the substrate is always unmelted due to the insufficient heat transfer. The unmelted substrate results in worse connection between the front and rear molten metal liquid.In addition,the melted metal tends to aggregate together to form balling due to the surface tension rather than uniformly spread on the substrate [32,44].Therefore,a discontinued structure of the molten layer appears here at $0 . 4 8 \mathrm { m s }$ .The molten pool behavior in Fig.6(d) is similar to that in Fig.6(c).The difference lies in that the defect is caused by large particles.The target large particle is gradually melted during the laser scanning (O.54-0.63 ms).The substrate below the large particle is not melted,so the discontinuity and balling defects occur here [18,22].Additionally, pores are formed either,which is also caused by the larger upper particles and their impedance on laser penetration [45].

name: 2023 - Int. J. Heat and Mass Transfer - Yao et al. - The essential role of initial powder bed state in selective laser melting of 316 L-part-28
fileName: 2023 - Int. J. Heat and Mass Transfer - Yao et al. - The essential role of initial powder bed state in selective laser melting of 316 L.md
content: The right panel of Fig.6(a) shows the morphology of the molten layer when the initial temperature is $7 7 3 . 1 5 \mathrm { K } .$ One can find that many microscopic defects (e.g.,faults,balling,pores) caused by insufficient laser energy or uneven energy input have been significantly reduced, and the values such as the depth of the molten layer have also been notably increased.Aforementioned results indicate that a high initial temperature that can increase the energy retained in the molten pool is the main reason for the quality improvement.Therefore,under current laser conditions,the thickness of the powder bed should not be too high and the number of large particles should be small to obtain better quality of the molten layer. Otherwise,microscopic defects such as edge warping,faults, balling,and pores are prone to appear in the molten layer.The high initial temperature can alleviate the generation of these defects to a certain extent.

name: 2023 - Int. J. Heat and Mass Transfer - Yao et al. - The essential role of initial powder bed state in selective laser melting of 316 L-part-29
fileName: 2023 - Int. J. Heat and Mass Transfer - Yao et al. - The essential role of initial powder bed state in selective laser melting of 316 L.md
content:
Fig.7(a) shows the molten layer morphologies of thin powder beds (i.e.,Powder bed 5) at different initial temperatures (i.e., $3 0 0 ~ \mathrm { K }$ and 773.15 K). Similar to Fig.6, three special positions “i-iii"are selected and marked in Fig. 7(a). Detailed analyses are conducted for these positions,as shown in Figs.7(b)-(d).It should be noted that the white dotted line at the position “ii"in Fig.7(a) represents the cross section, and“x"represents the coordinate position in the X direction of the cross section.Unlike the thick powder bed, there will be obvious depression generated during the melting process of the thin powder bed,as depicted in Fig.7(b).This is mainly caused by the small thickness of the powder bed.The laser directly melts the powder in the active zone until the heat energy is transferred to the substrate,and then visible depressions appear in the molten pool under the action of vapor recoil [21].In addition,new defects (entrained bubbles) appeared in the molten pool due to the effect of molten pool depression (tiny keyhole),as shown in the black dotted circle in Fig.7(b),which is different from the porosity due to the insufficient energy in Fig.6.At O.45 ms, there is only one layer of particles in the target zone (red dashed zone).Under the action of laser energy $( 0 . 4 5 { - } 0 . 5 4 ~ \mathrm { m s } )$ ,the particles are completely melted,and the underneath substrate is also melted and dented. $\mathrm { \ t { 0 . 5 7 - 0 . 6 0 } } \mathrm { m } s$ ,the generated bubbles are mixed into the molten pool due to the influence of the recoil pressure,the Marangoni effect,and the unstable fluctuation of the molten pool. These bubbles will be retained in the molten layer because of the fast melting and solidification [7,40].

![](images/cfd6366c6e78f53977e559256cc10a8ecf4fb1cd73c38d7660c7b16c65028b6f.jpg)  
Fig.4.Morphologies of the molten layers under different conditions.

name: 2023 - Int. J. Heat and Mass Transfer - Yao et al. - The essential role of initial powder bed state in selective laser melting of 316 L-part-30
fileName: 2023 - Int. J. Heat and Mass Transfer - Yao et al. - The essential role of initial powder bed state in selective laser melting of 316 L.md
content:
![](images/1e8c93d792a29cd0cc01b892e2f12c3905f3e1eafb9b9e7ddaf3c98f753f145b.jpg)  
Fig.5.Effects of powder bed structure and temperature on the height, width and depth of the molten layers.

The microscopic defects in Fig.7(c) are similar to those in Fig. 6(c). The thick particle bed and large particle size in the target region (red dotted line) induce the substrate not fully melted during the laser scanning process,leading to pores appearing here.The right panel of Fig.7(a) shows the morphology of the molten layer at an initial temperature of 773.15 K. One can find that the entrained bubbles and pores are distinctly reduced at high initial temperature.The high initial temperature slows down the solidification rate of the molten pool,allowing more time for the bubbles to escape [7].This is the main reason for the reduction of entrained bubbles.Also,large energy input can contribute to the reduction of pores in Fig.7(c).

name: 2023 - Int. J. Heat and Mass Transfer - Yao et al. - The essential role of initial powder bed state in selective laser melting of 316 L-part-31
fileName: 2023 - Int. J. Heat and Mass Transfer - Yao et al. - The essential role of initial powder bed state in selective laser melting of 316 L.md
content:
Nonetheless,high initial temperature is not always beneficial in the melting process of thin powder beds,as shown in Fig.7(d).In this figure, the morphologies of the four cross-sections in Fig.7(a) are indicated, where the black rectangular dashed box shows the melting process of the Ll cross-section.In addition to the two grooves in Ll,the melting process of Ll is similar to that in Fig.4(c).The same phenomenon can also be observed in L2.The formation of grooves is mainly caused by the loose powder bed and high initial temperature,which will lead to the formation of a larger molten pool and depression $\left( 0 . 6 0 \mathrm { \ m s } \right)$ on the substrate.After the laser leaves,the molten pool is backfilled upward under the surface tension,and finally cools and solidifies to form a bulge.Then, the grooves are formed between the bulge and both edges. Similar features can be observed in others'experiments [25] and simulations [35].When the initial temperature is $3 0 0 ~ \mathrm { K } ,$ both the molten pool and the recoil depression are smaller,which makes the backfill force such as surface tension smaller,so no bulges and grooves are formed in L1'and L2'.

![](images/672dae6886eef3b63cbb9ead4eb7ebb0a544907e96412d357372821ecc816252.jpg)  
Fig.6.Microscopic behaviors during melting in thick powder beds.

![](images/4674c7ef7f5672eb2f9d0ea6cbe464f34d66456222f3e458caf1145331cc96e3.jpg)  
Fig.7.Microscopic behaviors during melting in thin powder beds.

name: 2023 - Int. J. Heat and Mass Transfer - Yao et al. - The essential role of initial powder bed state in selective laser melting of 316 L-part-32
fileName: 2023 - Int. J. Heat and Mass Transfer - Yao et al. - The essential role of initial powder bed state in selective laser melting of 316 L.md
content:
In addition to the microscopic defects inside the molten layer, the defects formed between the molten layers are also the research focus.In this section, the multi-track melting processes of powder bed 4 are simulated,as plotted in Fig.8.The first subfigure in Fig.8(a) shows the computational domain used for the 6-track melting simulation,and its size is $1 2 0 0 ~ { \mu \mathrm { m } } \times 6 0 0 ~ { \mu \mathrm { m } } \times 3 0 0 ~ { \mu \mathrm { m } }$ .The remaining three subfigures show the melting process of the powder layer at different moments.It should be noted that only the 3-track melting process is given here.It is found that during multi-track melting,the printed region can provide preheating to the powder bed to be melted [46,47].Fig.8(b) depicts the final morphologies of the 6-track molten layers,in which the upper and lower panels are the morphologies at the initial temperatures of $3 0 0 ~ \mathrm { K }$ and $7 7 3 . 1 5 \ \mathrm { K } .$ ,respectively.From the top view of the upper panel one can find that the surfaces of the 6-track molten layers are relatively rough.The three cross sections (Ll-L3) indicate that there are many pores at the junction between the molten layers.These pores are mainly caused by insuficient energy input. The junction between the two molten layers isat the edge of the laser energy,and the temperature in this region is lower [4,48]. Therefore,defects similar to those in Fig. 6(c) are prone to occur.When the initial temperature is higher (e.g.,773.15 K),one can find that the surfaces of the 6-track molten layers become smoother.And the quality of the entire molten layer is noticeably better.

![](images/0d190b164d012e8ae7a9fcf2dc756eb00f81b454c3c5077914efd9cf7ae04716.jpg)  
Fig.8.Defects in multi-track melting process.

name: 2023 - Int. J. Heat and Mass Transfer - Yao et al. - The essential role of initial powder bed state in selective laser melting of 316 L-part-33
fileName: 2023 - Int. J. Heat and Mass Transfer - Yao et al. - The essential role of initial powder bed state in selective laser melting of 316 L.md
content: In addition,pores at the junction between the molten layers are also visibly reduced or even disappeared. Both internal and surface quality improvements can be ascribed to the sufficient energy induced by the high initial temperature.

name: 2023 - Int. J. Heat and Mass Transfer - Yao et al. - The essential role of initial powder bed state in selective laser melting of 316 L-part-34
fileName: 2023 - Int. J. Heat and Mass Transfer - Yao et al. - The essential role of initial powder bed state in selective laser melting of 316 L.md
content: In this paper,the melting process of SLM316 L stainless steel powder was numerically simulated by computational fluid dynamics method. The reliability of the simulations was firstly verified by others'experiments and simulations.Afterwards,the influences of powder bed structure and temperature on the macro-and microscopic characteristics of the molten layers during printing were comprehensively investigated. Corresponding mechanisms and solutions were provided. Following conclusions can be drawn.

name: 2023 - Int. J. Heat and Mass Transfer - Yao et al. - The essential role of initial powder bed state in selective laser melting of 316 L-part-35
fileName: 2023 - Int. J. Heat and Mass Transfer - Yao et al. - The essential role of initial powder bed state in selective laser melting of 316 L.md
content:
1.A three-dimensional high-fidelity model was successfully established to simulate the printing process of $3 1 6 \mathrm { ~ L ~ }$ stainless steel in SLM. Almost all the physical fundamentals like melting,solidification, vapor recoil,and energy transfer were involved in the model.   
2.With the increase of powder bed thickness from $3 2 . 0 2 ~ \mu \mathrm { m }$ $( H _ { \mathrm { { s p r e a d i n g } } } { = } 2 D 9 0$ and $V _ { \mathrm { s p r e a d i n g } } { = } 0 . 2 ~ \mathrm { m } / s )$ to $4 0 . 6 5 \mu \mathrm { m }$ $( H _ { \mathrm { { s p r e a d i n g } } } { = } 2$ $D 9 0$ and $V _ { \mathrm { s p r e a d i n g } } { = } 0 . 0 1 \ \mathrm { m } / s .$ ),the height of the molten layer will increase from 16.37 to $3 2 . 8 6 \mu \mathrm { m }$ ,the depth will decrease from 21.69 $\mu \mathrm { m }$ to $1 0 . 5 2 ~ { \mu \mathrm { m } } ,$ and the width will also decrease from 1oo.67 to $9 4 . 9 4 \mu \mathrm { m }$ .Meanwhile,this will make the fluctuation CV of the depth increase from 0.31 to O.85,but its effect on the fluctuation of the height and width is not obvious.   
3.When the initial temperature of the powder bed increases from $3 0 0 \mathrm { K }$ to $7 7 3 . 1 5 \mathrm { K } ,$ the maximum temperature at the measuring point increases from $1 9 0 0 . 3 4 \mathrm { K }$ to $2 5 1 0 . 6 \mathrm { K } ,$ and the height, depth and width of the molten layer are increased by $3 . 8 8 ~ { \mu \mathrm { m } }$ $1 2 . 6 8 ~ { \mu \mathrm { m } }$ and 17.37 $\mu \mathrm { m }$ ，respectively.Meanwhile,the CV fluctuation of the depth is reduced from 0.34 to 0.23.

name: 2023 - Int. J. Heat and Mass Transfer - Yao et al. - The essential role of initial powder bed state in selective laser melting of 316 L-part-36
fileName: 2023 - Int. J. Heat and Mass Transfer - Yao et al. - The essential role of initial powder bed state in selective laser melting of 316 L.md
content:
4. Under the current laser process parameters,edge warping, pores, faults and balling defects caused by insufficient energy are prone to occur in the thick powder bed melting. The high initial temperature can reduce or even eliminate these defects to a certain extent. During the melting process of the thin powder bed， new defect (e.g., entrained bubbles) may appear,which can also be reduced by the high initial temperature.It should be noted that special grooves will be formed in the molten layer due to excessive energy input.During the 6-track melting process,the surface roughness,the irregularity of the molten layer,and the pores between layers due to insufficient energy are likely to occur.A high initial temperature can significantly improve the surface quality of the molten layer and reduce the pores between layers. 5.When the laser power is $2 0 0 ~ \mathrm { W }$ ,the scanning velocity is $_ { 1 \textrm { m } / s }$ ,and the laser size is $8 0 \mu \mathrm { m }$ ,the best molten layer quality can be obtained by using powder bed 4 (i.e., $H _ { \mathrm { s p r e a d i n g } } { = } 2 D 9 0$ and $V _ { \mathrm { s p r e a d i n g } } { = } 0 . 1 5 \mathrm { m } /$ s)as the initial powder bed structure.The initial temperature of $7 7 3 . 1 5 \mathrm { K }$ can significantly improve the quality of the molten layer.

These new findings can further enhance the insight into powder melting process,which will not only reveal the powder melting regimes from particulate scale,but also provide valuable references for the selection of process parameters and process optimization in the real AM process.

# ARTICLEINFO
summary: Powder sheet additive manufacturing of multi-material structures: Experimental and computational characterizations

name: 2024 - Composites Part B Engineering - Zhang et al. - Powder sheet additive manufacturing of multi-material structures Experimental and-part-2
fileName: 2024 - Composites Part B Engineering - Zhang et al. - Powder sheet additive manufacturing of multi-material structures Experimental and.md
content:
# ABSTRACT
Handling Editor: Dr Hao Wang

Keywords:   
Powder sheet additive manufacturing   
Multi-material structures   
Manufacturability   
Defect control   
Thermo-mechanical simulation

Selective laser melting (SLM)of multi-material structures (MMs) is of significance because it allws for bespoke structural innovation and high-accuracy process tailoring.However,most of the currently developed loose powder-based SLM techniques for MMS are limited by the long changeover time and potential crosscontamination between materials.To address these issues,a novel Metal Additive Manufacturing using Powder Sheets (MAPS) technique is proposed for printing MMS within a single process. It utilizes flexible powder sheets as the feedstock material,which are composed of metal powder-polymer binder composites.The printability of MMS by MAPS is assssed through the fabrication of three-phase SS304-IN718-Ss304 composites with increased geometric dimensions on the S316 baseplates.The effects of part size on the evolution of the meltpool morphologyand the formation of defects during MAPS are investigated by experimental characterizations and computational modeling.The results show that when fabricating larger MMs,the use of alonger scanvector easily leads todefects suchas lack-of-fusion porosity,ballingand cracks.This is due to the longer duration of inter-hatch cooling time,the reduced amount of thermal accumulation and the higher degree of residual streses.By adopting an island scanning strategy,a defect-free large-size MMS with variationsof chemical composition, microstructure and microhardness is successfully printed by MAPs.The proposed MAPS method offers a new solution for producing high-quality MMs.

name: 2024 - Composites Part B Engineering - Zhang et al. - Powder sheet additive manufacturing of multi-material structures Experimental and-part-3
fileName: 2024 - Composites Part B Engineering - Zhang et al. - Powder sheet additive manufacturing of multi-material structures Experimental and.md
content: Multi-material structures (MMS) are characterized by spatial variations in materials and thus vary in their functionality and characteristic properties along the thickness or length direction [1-3]. This is contrary to homogeneous single-material components.As a revolutionary and novel composite material,MMS is of great interest in a variety of industrial applications,including the aerospace,biomedical and automobile sectors [4-6].For the wider uptake of MMS,many advanced manufacturing methods have been developed.Wang et al.[7] synthesized multilayer composite Ti/TiN coatings with different composite periods by a plasma-enhanced ion plating technique.Feng et al.[8] achieved a functionally graded WC-Co/Ni composite and 41O stainless steel via diffusion bonding.However, these conventional techniques are typically used for the preparation of thin films,limiting the design freedom and size of MMS.

name: 2024 - Composites Part B Engineering - Zhang et al. - Powder sheet additive manufacturing of multi-material structures Experimental and-part-4
fileName: 2024 - Composites Part B Engineering - Zhang et al. - Powder sheet additive manufacturing of multi-material structures Experimental and.md
content:
Additive manufacturing (AM) of MMS has attracted extensive attention due to its capabilities to fabricate arbitrarily complex geometries or customized components [9-l2].As one of the most commonly used AM methods,directed energy deposition (DED) has become an important approach for manufacturing metallic MMS parts due to its convenience in changing the feedstock materials [13-16]. Shan et al. numerically and experimentally investigated the effect of the composition gradient on the mechanical behavior of DED-processed MMS composed of austenitic and ferritic steels [17].Li et al.established a multi-physics,multi-material thermal fluid model and predicted the material composition gradients and the geometry of SS316/IN718 MMs during the DED fabrication process.This work was also experimentally validated [18].Adomako et al.explored the influence of the deposition sequence of different materials and the laser power on the multi-layered materials of Ti6Al4V,vanadium and $1 7 { - } 4 \mathrm { P H }$ stainless steel in DED[19]. Although it demonstrates a high deposition efficiency,DED fails to manufacture complex structures with fine features due to its low fabrication accuracy (i.e.spatial resolution) [20].

Sheet lamination or laminated object manufacturing (LOM) is a method for MMS by bonding metal foils feedstock using techniques such as laser,electron beam,or ultrasonics [2l-23]. Obielodan et al. fabricated Ti/Al3003 composites using LOM and a $6 1 . 7 7 \ \%$ increase in the load capability was experimentally measured on the dual-material structure compared to thatof the single Al3oo3 material [24].However,LOMhas limitations,as it requires an additional milling tool or laser to cut the feedstock into the desired geometry at each layer and difficulties in recycling the removed material.In addition,LOMis limited to fabricating 2D MMS with the material transitions along only the build direction [25].

name: 2024 - Composites Part B Engineering - Zhang et al. - Powder sheet additive manufacturing of multi-material structures Experimental and-part-5
fileName: 2024 - Composites Part B Engineering - Zhang et al. - Powder sheet additive manufacturing of multi-material structures Experimental and.md
content:
Unlike DED or LOM,the selective laser melting (SLM) technique enables the fabrication of high-precision metal components because it employs a finely focused laser beam (e.g.diameter of ${ \sim } 1 0 0 ~ \mu \mathrm { m } )$ asthe heat source [26-28].However,most of the currently commercialized SLM systems are specifically designed for printing single-material components;printing MMS by SLM has not been widely investigated or implemented thus far [29-31].

With the urgent demand for complex MMS,new SLM methods for manufacturing MMS are being developed rapidly.Wei etal.developed a roller-assisted multiple powders feeding system for building multiple metallic materials including 316L stainless steel (SS316),IN718 Nibased alloy and $\operatorname { C u l 0 5 n }$ copper alloy in a single SLM printer [32]. Wen et al.invented a powder-feeding method by dividing spaces for feeding different metal particles and achieved the SLM fabrication of large-scale CoCrMo-IN718 components with variations of mechanical properties and chemical compositions [33].Wang et al.printed a layered TiB2/Ti6Al4V biological structure using a multi-material SLM platform where different materials are fed via separate grooves [34].

Even though these newly developed SLM systems can be used to accomplish the manufacturing of MMs,it is challenging to separate different powder particles for recycling after the SLMbuild-up [35-37]. Moreover,a long pause is often required for the replacement of material from one powder to another[35].Therefore,one of the key objectives of this work is to develop a new SLM technique for printing MMS with a maximum material utilization,a lower risk of cross-contamination of feedstock materials and improved productivity.

name: 2024 - Composites Part B Engineering - Zhang et al. - Powder sheet additive manufacturing of multi-material structures Experimental and-part-6
fileName: 2024 - Composites Part B Engineering - Zhang et al. - Powder sheet additive manufacturing of multi-material structures Experimental and.md
content: Regarding the SLM printing of MMs,the inter-process parameters involved are considered to primarily affect the quality and in-service performance of the final metal depositions.For instance,when two distinct metallic powders are used to fabricate sandwich-like MMS,the dissimilarmaterial properties,especiallyat their interface,can yielda more complex fusion zone (e.g.a different melt-pool morphology) and a more intense mechanical response (e.g.a larger residual stresses), compared to the deposition of single-material [38,39].Therefore, the fabrication of MMS is prone to generate undesirable defects such as lack of fusion (LOF),balling,porosity and cracks,hereby weakening the bonding strength between two materials [30,40,41].However, these potential defects may be reduced or eliminated by optimizing the process parameters such as the energy density of the laser input, the scanning sequence,or the geometry of MMS [41-43].For example,Chen et al.investigated the formation of interfacial defects between SS316L and CuSnlO and found that depositing copper on steel results in reduced cracking compared to the reverse deposition sequence [44].Even so, more efforts need to be devoted to investigating the effect of the AM variables,such as the inter-hatch cooling time (i.e.the time interval after finishing the fabrication of a hatch,prior to the manufacturing of the next hatch),since they are responsible for the temperature evolution and the final performance of MMs.

name: 2024 - Composites Part B Engineering - Zhang et al. - Powder sheet additive manufacturing of multi-material structures Experimental and-part-7
fileName: 2024 - Composites Part B Engineering - Zhang et al. - Powder sheet additive manufacturing of multi-material structures Experimental and.md
content:
To provide some guidance for practical SLM printing and process optimization, the scientific community is developing computational tools to model the thermo-mechanical evolution of MMS.Gu et al. developed a multi-physics modelling framework for predicting the evolution of the melt-pool and the formation of tracks in multi-track, multi-layer and multi-material SLM[45].Using a Computational Fluid Dynamics (CFD) simulation, Tan et al.predicted the thermal behavior and velocity field of the melt-pool at the interfacial zone during SLMof 300 maraging steel on bulk 4Crl3 stainless steel [2].Also,Yao et al. investigated the physical mechanism of mixing elements caused by circulating flow with CFD [46].The results showed that the prediction of building MMS is more challenging than simulating the deposition of single-material, due to the heterogeneous property structures that are intrinsic to MMS.

Steel-nickel alloy is an increasingly attractive advanced material that has advantages in obtaining MMS with remarkable property-blending capabilities,well-suited for demanding environments characterized by high temperatures and corrosive conditions.Its applications include power plant,aerospace,and oil refining [47,48].

In this study,an innovative printing technology, namely,Metal Additive Manufacturing using Powder Sheets (MAPS),is developed for printing MMS parts.To assess the printability of MAPS,a number of investigations are carried out.Firstly,three MMS parts of 3o4L stainless steel (SS304)-IN718-SS304 with increased deposition size are printed by using a $9 0 ^ { \circ }$ rotation scanning pattern.Secondly,the formation mechanisms of different defects (i.e.LOF,porosity,balling and crack) are systematically analyzed by experimental characterizations in conjunction with thermo-mechanical simulations.Lastly,a large-scale defectfree MMS part is completely manufactured and characterized by using the optimum MAPS process configurations.

name: 2024 - Composites Part B Engineering - Zhang et al. - Powder sheet additive manufacturing of multi-material structures Experimental and-part-8
fileName: 2024 - Composites Part B Engineering - Zhang et al. - Powder sheet additive manufacturing of multi-material structures Experimental and.md
content: The study is structured as follows:Section 2 provides a detailed description of the experimental campaign,including the introduction of MAPS,the preparation of the powder sheets,the fabrication of MMS using MAPS and the subsequent material characterizations. Section 3 introduces the computational model employed to predict the thermomechanical behavior of MMS during the MAPS process.Section 4 presents the experimental results,which covers the characterization of the powder sheets feedstock,the metallurgical quality and the mechanical properties of the MMs.Section 5 analyzes the formation mechanisms of different defects and provides an optimized solution.Finally, Section 6 concludes this study.

name: 2024 - Composites Part B Engineering - Zhang et al. - Powder sheet additive manufacturing of multi-material structures Experimental and-part-9

name: 2024 - Composites Part B Engineering - Zhang et al. - Powder sheet additive manufacturing of multi-material structures Experimental and-part-10
fileName: 2024 - Composites Part B Engineering - Zhang et al. - Powder sheet additive manufacturing of multi-material structures Experimental and.md
content:
Fig.1 shows the powder sheet fabrication process and the workflow of the proposed MAPS method [49].MAPS is a modified AM process that combines concepts of both SLM and LOM.Different from the currently commercialized SLM systems that use loose metal powder as the raw material,MAPS adoptsa flexible powder sheetas feedstock.Herein,the metal particles are tightly connected together by the polymer binder while maintaining flexibility of the powder sheet,hence allowing its incorporation with the material roller distribution system.When the laser beam is activated,the polymer binder is evaporated as the temperature surpasses its boiling point (e.g.PCL of $2 3 7 ^ { \circ } \mathrm { C }$ ,while the metal powder is sintered.Hence,no debinding process is required during the MAPS process.

The MAPS for MMS operates according to the following procedure: (i)A thin powder sheet,which is tightened to remain flat,is firstly placed on the substrate by rotating the rollers (Fig.1). (i) A high-energy laser beam traces out the specific cross-section of the designed geometry according to the user-defined scanning sequence.(iii) The fabrication platform is lowered to fit a new piece of powder sheet for the next layer. (iv) The steps (i)-(ii) are repeated until completion of the multi-layer deposition of the first material (e.g. SS3o4). (v) For the deposition of the second material,the current powder sheet is removed from the rollers and the new rolled material is replaced.After this,the printing chamber is purged until the oxygen level is below $0 . 2 ~ \%$ for the MAPS printing.(vi) The above processes (i)-(v) are repeated until finishing the build-up of the entire MMS.

![](images/857e7a7ff19204b870b7199a8597aa93549dfb103069e782f2101cb77337cff7.jpg)  
Fig.1.Illustration of the powder sheet fabrication process (a) and the workflow of MAPS (b).

Compared to the traditional SLM technique, the crucial advantages of the MAPS manufacturing of MMS are as follows.

name: 2024 - Composites Part B Engineering - Zhang et al. - Powder sheet additive manufacturing of multi-material structures Experimental and-part-12
fileName: 2024 - Composites Part B Engineering - Zhang et al. - Powder sheet additive manufacturing of multi-material structures Experimental and.md
content:
The powder sheets are prepared using a solvent casting method (Fig.la) by mixing metal particles with polycaprolactone (PCL $\mathrm { ( C _ { 6 } H _ { 1 0 } O _ { 2 } ) _ { n } ) }$ and $\mathrm { C H C l } _ { 3 }$ solvent [49,50]．Specifically,the PCL $\mathrm { . C H C l _ { 3 } }$ solvent is prepared firstlyby fully dissolving PCL pellets in $\mathrm { C H C L } _ { 3 }$ . Then, the gas-atomized metal powder is mixed with the PCL- $\mathrm { C H C l } _ { 3 }$ solvent to form a metal-polymer-solvent mixture.The mixture is poured on a flexible Teflon sheet.In doing so,designed thickness (i.e.theory thickness),of the mixture is laid down by moving the Teflon belt while also fixing the doctor blade.Following the full evaporation of the $\mathrm { C H C L } _ { 3 }$ solvent from the mixture,the mixed metal powder and PCL polymer solidify to become a flexible metal-polymer composite film.Finally, the solidified metal-polymer composite powder sheet is peeled off from the Teflon sheet.

Fig.2 shows the virgin SS304 (Carpenter Additive,powder size of $1 5 { \sim } 4 5 \mu \mathrm { m } )$ and IN718 (Hoganäs, $1 5 { - } 4 5 \mu \mathrm { m } )$ powders used for preparing their respective powder sheets，including SEM observation for morphology and the corresponding powder size distribution.In this study, SS3O4 and IN718 Ni-based alloys are chosen due to their similar thermophysical properties.Such similarities are beneficial for effectively lowering the interfacial stresses between materials.Both SS304 and IN718 particlesare highly spherical and there is a marginal $2 . 3 7 \%$ difference in the average particle diameter size between SS304 (29.50 $\mu \mathrm { m } )$ and IN718 $( 3 0 . 2 0 ~ \mu \mathrm { m } )$ . Table 1 lists the chemical compositions of the SS3o4 and IN718 powders and the content of each chemical element.
summary: 2.2. Preparation of the powder sheets - Part 1/2

name: 2024 - Composites Part B Engineering - Zhang et al. - Powder sheet additive manufacturing of multi-material structures Experimental and-part-13
fileName: 2024 - Composites Part B Engineering - Zhang et al. - Powder sheet additive manufacturing of multi-material structures Experimental and.md
content:
Fig.3 shows the overallview and SEMobservations at the top surface and cross-section of the SS304 and IN718 powder sheets.A high metal content is achieved in both powder sheets.The gaps between adjacent metal particles are filled with the PCL polymer binder that connects the metal particles tightly together.The thickness of the SS3O4 and IN718 powder sheets is $1 3 2 \pm 1 7 { \mu \mathrm { m } }$ and $1 2 2 \pm 1 1 { \mu \mathrm { m } }$ ,respectively,measured bya Laserliner apparatus.The packing densities of the SS304 $( 5 2 . 8 3 \pm$ $4 . 0 2 \ \% )$ and IN718 $( 5 2 . 0 2 \pm 3 . 9 3 \ : \% )$ powder sheets are close to each other.The packing density of the powder sheet is calculated using bulk density and material density analyses,according to Ref.[51]. Specifically,the bulk density of the powder sheet can be calculated using its weight (mass) and volume:

$$
\rho _ { b } = \frac { M } { V }
$$

where $M$ for mass and $V$ for volume of the powder sheet. The material density of the powder sheet is calculated by:

$$
\rho _ { p } = \rho _ { m } \times \varphi _ { m } + \rho _ { p } \times \varphi _ { p }
$$

where $\rho _ { m }$ is the density of metal material, $\varphi _ { m }$ is the weight percentage of metal material, $\rho _ { p }$ is the density of polymer and $\varphi _ { m }$ is the weight percentage of polymer within the powder sheet.The packing density of the powder sheet can be calculated as:

$$
\eta = \frac { \rho _ { b } } { \rho _ { m } }
$$

IN718-SS304 MMS parts are printed by using a MAPS machine adapted froma commercialized Realizer SLM5o.The MAPS system is equipped with a CW (modulated) fibre laser beam with a Gaussian distributed profile and a positive pressure argon atmosphere to prevent the occurrence of oxidation during the printing process.Table 2 lists the process parameters applied for the MAPS printing of MMs.

name: 2024 - Composites Part B Engineering - Zhang et al. - Powder sheet additive manufacturing of multi-material structures Experimental and-part-15
fileName: 2024 - Composites Part B Engineering - Zhang et al. - Powder sheet additive manufacturing of multi-material structures Experimental and.md
content:
To investigate the printability of MMS by MAPS,three square plates with different sizes are designed: $5 \times 5 \times 1 . 2 \mathrm { m m } ^ { 3 }$ (Case-1), $1 0 \times 1 0 \times$ $1 . 2 \mathrm { m m } ^ { 3 }$ (Case-2), and $2 0 \times 2 0 \times 1 . 2 \mathrm { m m } ^ { 3 }$ (Case-3), as shown in Fig. 4. During MAPS of MMS,three square SS304 blocks,each of a 2O-layer thickness,are firstly deposited on the same SS3l6 substrate using a $9 0 ^ { \circ }$ rotation scanning strategy.Next,a 2O-layer IN718 matrix at the middle section and another 2O-layer SS3o4 at the top section are printed sequentially.In MAPS,the transition from finishing the printing of the first material to beginning the printing of the secondary material takes a $1 0 { \cdot } \mathrm { m i n }$ interval. This includes $5 \ \mathrm { m i n }$ to change the feedstock on the roller and another $5 \ \mathrm { m i n }$ to purge the oxygen level in the printing chamber to below $0 . 2 4 \%$ .In contrast, this process can take a number of hours or days in SLM.This is one of the key advantages of MAPS over SLM. The end result is three 60-layer sandwich-like MMS parts being printed,as shown in Fig. 5a.

It can be seen from Fig.5a that using the $9 0 ^ { \circ }$ rotation scanning strategy generates a relatively smooth top surface of the small (Case-1) and medium (Case-2) MMS samples,but a poor surface quality is obtained for the large MMS sample (Case-3).For comparative purposes and in an effort to optimize the MAPS printing process,an island scanning strategy with a $9 0 ^ { \circ }$ staggered rotation (Fig.4d) is used to re-print the large-scale MMS sample (Case-4),as shown in Fig.5b.

name: 2024 - Composites Part B Engineering - Zhang et al. - Powder sheet additive manufacturing of multi-material structures Experimental and-part-16
fileName: 2024 - Composites Part B Engineering - Zhang et al. - Powder sheet additive manufacturing of multi-material structures Experimental and.md
content:
To determine the content of the metal powders in the SS304 and IN718 powder sheets and the thermal decomposition performance of the PCL polymer binder,thermogravimetric analysis(TGA) is carried out under a nitrogen environment. Such an atmosphere represents the same conditions as during the MAPS printing process.During TGA,the powder sheets are heated from $3 0 ~ ^ { \circ } \mathrm { C }$ to $8 0 0 ~ ^ { \circ } \mathrm { C }$ at a rate of $1 0 ~ { ^ \circ } \mathrm { C } / \mathrm { m i n }$ .To check the quality of the internal metallurgy and the occurrence of potential defects within the builds, the four MAPS-manufactured MMS parts are sectioned firstly by wire electric discharge machining (Excetek V440G EDM).This operation is carried out along the middle of the depositions,as shown in Fig.5.The sectioned samples are then mounted with conductive resin and subsequently polished to form a mirror finish for the purpose of conducting optical microscopy (OM).Based on the cross-section OMof the polished samples,the area fraction porosity of the MMS parts is measured by using ImageJ software.The relative porosity is calculated as the percentage of the pixels of pores over the total number of pixels of the OM image,following the method in Ref.[52].The chemical composition of the MMS samples printed by MAPS is characterized by energy-dispersive X-ray spectroscopy (EDX) analysis.The microhardness is measured with $\mathrm { H V } _ { 0 . 5 }$ along the build direction of MMs.For the microstructural analysis along the cross-section of the samples,the polished MMS samples are electrochemically etched using a reagent of $6 9 ~ \%$ nitric acid and $3 1 ~ \%$ water while applying a 2 V DC current [53].A scanning electron microscope (SEM) is used for microstructural characterizations of the etched samples.

Table 2 Process parameters used for printing MMS by MAPS.

name: 2024 - Composites Part B Engineering - Zhang et al. - Powder sheet additive manufacturing of multi-material structures Experimental and-part-18
fileName: 2024 - Composites Part B Engineering - Zhang et al. - Powder sheet additive manufacturing of multi-material structures Experimental and.md
content:
To better understand the formation mechanism of defects in the MAPS process of MMS,a coupled thermo-mechanical finite element (FE) model for AMis adopted to predict the evolution of the temperature field and the stress response.The staggered thermo-mechanical coupled simulation is carried out as follows:(i)a transient thermal analysis is solved firstly for each time step and then (ii)a stress analysis is conducted using the calculated temperature results from (i).A uniformly distributed volumetric heat source model is used to simulate the laser energy input. The key heat loss mechanisms in the thermal analysis consist of conduction,convection and radiation.A thermo-elastic-viscoplastic constitutive model is used to predict the residual stresses of the printed MMs builds.The birth-death element technique is adopted to simulate the metal deposition during MAPS by gradually activating the elements according to the user-defined scanning strategy.More details of this computational model, the governing equation and related experimental validations can be found in the previous papers [54-56].

Fig.6 shows the FE meshes of three different-sized MMS parts, consisting of the SS316 substrate, the bottom and top SS304 layers and the middle IN718 layer. Table 3 lists the numbers of hexahedral elements and nodes involved in simulating the different square plates (Fig.6).To save computational time while preserving a high prediction accuracy,five physical layers are virtually grouped into one in the simulation.Thus,the size of the FE meshes is set as $0 . 2 \times 0 . 2 \times 0 . 1 \mathrm { m m } ^ { 3 }$ for the builds and coarse meshes are used for the substrates.

name: 2024 - Composites Part B Engineering - Zhang et al. - Powder sheet additive manufacturing of multi-material structures Experimental and-part-19
fileName: 2024 - Composites Part B Engineering - Zhang et al. - Powder sheet additive manufacturing of multi-material structures Experimental and.md
content: Fig.7 shows the temperature-dependent thermodynamic properties of SS316 (substrate)，SS304 and IN718 [57-59] used in the thermo-mechanical simulation.Poisson's ratio for SS316,SS304 and IN718 is 0.24,0.25 and 0.32, respectively.To simulate the MAPS process of metallic MMS,the heat transfer coefficients (HTC) for convection and radiation are 1 $5 ~ { \textrm W } / ( { \textrm m } ^ { 2 } { \cdot } ^ { \circ } { \textrm C } )$ and 0.7,respectively [6O]．The absorption of the laser radiation is O.45 [6O] and the ambient temperature is fixed at $2 0 ~ ^ { \circ } \mathrm { C }$ for all simulations.The mechanical boundary conditions used in the stress analysis are the same as the actual experimental setups: the central area at the bottom surface of the substrate is mechanically restrained [27].
