content:
# 4.1.Powder sheet characterization
Fig.8 shows the degradation performance of the SS3o4 and IN718 powder sheets.The TGA curves include three periods: the initial stage, the following polymer degradation and the final stabilization. The PCL polymer binder gradually degrades when the temperature reaches $2 0 0 ~ ^ { \circ } \mathrm { C }$ 、The different degradation temperatures for these two powder sheets are due to the unequal distributions of metal particles and PCL polymer binder in the powder sheets (Fig.2),as well as the difference in packing densities of the powder sheets.When the temperature is higher than $4 0 0 ~ ^ { \circ } \mathrm { C }$ ，the TGA curves keep steady,showing that all the PCL binder has been fully degraded and only metal powder remains.The TGA results also illustrate that the powder content of SS304 and IN718 in the sheets is of $9 5 . 8 6 ~ \%$ and $9 5 . 6 5 ~ \%$ by net weight, respectively.

name: 2024 - Composites Part B Engineering - Zhang et al. - Powder sheet additive manufacturing of multi-material structures Experimental and-part-21
fileName: 2024 - Composites Part B Engineering - Zhang et al. - Powder sheet additive manufacturing of multi-material structures Experimental and.md
content:
Fig.9 compares the densifications and cross-section SEM images of the MAPS-printed MMS with different geometric dimensions.Note that the relative density of the metal depositions decreases with the increase in the size of the builds.The small MMS bulk (Case-1) achieves the highest densification of $9 9 . 8 6 ~ \%$ ，while the lowest relative density of $8 9 . 9 8 ~ \%$ is produced in the large MMS bulk (Case-3),printed by using the $9 0 ^ { \circ }$ rotation scanning strategy.

Three kinds of defects are observed in the relatively large MMS parts fabricated with the $9 0 ^ { \circ }$ rotation scanning strategy (Fig. 9b): cracking,

![](images/fc3cdd1a5467736403a8c46bd820c9a1c6e3541c75467a03027d1c6c59686b5c.jpg)  
Fig.4.Building strategies used for printing the SS304-IN718-SS304 MMs with diferent geometric sizes by (a-c) $9 0 ^ { \circ }$ rotation scanning strategy and (d) island scan strategy.

![](images/93767f9aea6db4faf0e13b4874e1a6bad1498f0a370f131c93f8ca7902f91882.jpg)  
Fig.5.Square SS304-IN718-Ss304 MMS plates with diferent sizes fabricated by MAPS with the building strategies of (a) $9 0 ^ { \circ }$ rotation scanning and (b) island scanning strategy.

LOF and balling.In detail, both the medium (Case-2) and large (Case-3) MMS components yield visible macro-cracks with a length of over 300 $\mu \mathrm { m }$ . The growth direction of the cracks is mainly along the build direction while a small crack ( ${ \sim } 5 0 \mu \mathrm { m }$ long) is formed in the powder bed direction (Fig. 9c). The second category of defects is LOF porosity, occurring in the Case-2 and Case-3.In-particular,Case-2 yields a Ushaped LOF pipe with a cross-section diameter of over $5 0 ~ { \mu \mathrm { m } }$ The baling phenomenon also occurs at the top surface of the large MMs build (see Fig. 5a and 9c).
summary: 4.2.Effect of the MAPS parameters on densification and defects - Part 1/2

name: 2024 - Composites Part B Engineering - Zhang et al. - Powder sheet additive manufacturing of multi-material structures Experimental and-part-22
fileName: 2024 - Composites Part B Engineering - Zhang et al. - Powder sheet additive manufacturing of multi-material structures Experimental and.md
content: In general, the larger the dimension of the MMS parts,the higher the risk of generating defects.With the increase of the MMS size,the scanvector is lengthened to fill the actual cross-section of the component. This can lead to non-uniform temperature fields and large residual stresses in the MMS manufactured by MAPS.Thereby,an alternative island scanning strategy with shortened scan-vectors (e.g. less than 7 mm) in each individual sub-zone is considered for printing large MMs parts (Fig. 4d). Consequently,a large-scale defect-free MMS component (Case-4) with a high relative density of $9 9 . 7 0 \%$ is successfully built by MAPS,as shown in Fig. 5b and 9d.
summary: 4.2.Effect of the MAPS parameters on densification and defects - Part 2/2

Fig.10 shows the overall cross-section and the EDX mapping results of the large SS304- IN718-SS304 MMS (Case-4) built with the island scanning strategy.It can be seen from Fig.1Oa that, notwithstanding the fact of different material properties between SS3o4 and IN718,the printing of a nearly fully dense (a relative density of $9 9 . 7 0 \%$ MMSbuild is realized.Fig.Ob shows the metallurgically bonded interfaces between SS3o4 and IN718 along the build direction,regardless of the printing sequence of the two materials.Although the chemical composition dramatically changes at the transition interfaces (Fig.10c), no cracks or other defects are observed.In addition,the average layerthickness of the deposited SS304 (at the top section) and IN718 (in the middle) is $2 1 . 5 4 \mu \mathrm { m }$ and $1 5 . 2 9 \mu \mathrm { m }$ ,respectively,yielding a $2 9 . 0 2 \%$ reduction due to the different thermophysical properties (e.g.density) and thicknesses of powder sheets between SS304 and IN718 (Figs.3 and 7). ![](images/f378d4666921b27493195c4682c136f23ea7befc5e4ea81ab592d569c23121cd.jpg) Fig.6.FE mesh models of three square-bulks with diferent dimensions: (a) $5 \times 5 \times 1 . 2 \mathrm { m m } ^ { 3 }$ (b) $1 0 \times 1 0 \times 1 . 2 \mathrm { m m } ^ { 3 }$ (c) $2 0 \times 2 0 \times 1 . 2 \mathrm { m m } ^ { 3 }$ For the $2 0 \times 2 0 \times 1 . 2$ $\mathrm { m i n } ^ { 3 }$ MMS, $9 0 ^ { \circ }$ rotation and island scanning strategies were used. content:
Fig.lla shows the line EDX analysis of Case-4 with a significant variation in the chemical compositions along the build direction.When printing the composition gradient material zone (CGZ),the deposition of the secondary material (e.g.IN718) on SS304 inevitably leads to the remelting of the previously solidified SS3o4,generating a new matrix of composition (i.e.intermetallic dilution area) [61].Thus,the CGZ from IN718 to SS3o4,or vice versa,presents a gradual variation in the chemical composition and shows a certain thickness corresponding to the intermixed fusion zone of Fe and Ni.For the optimized Case-4, the thickness of CGZ1 $\mathrm { ( I N 7 1 8 \to S S 3 0 4 ) }$ ）and CGZ2 $\mathrm { \Delta } \mathrm { S S 3 0 4 }  \mathrm { I N } 7 1 8$ is measured as $4 0 ~ { \mu \mathrm { m } }$ and $2 0 ~ { \mu \mathrm { m } }$ ,respectively.

![](images/af7ca93132985492ba5f5a4af16611c0bf7ccd736e2940cd281fee25c18ee032.jpg)  
Fig.7.Temperature-dependent material properties of SS316, SS304 and IN718 [57-59].

![](images/4bcf44658d74a39a286a5160f60c602f973e9c591f93b5a7eec206cd51419b52.jpg)  
Fig.8.TGA analysis of the SS304 and IN718 powder sheets.

Fig.llb shows the variation of microhardness of the Case-4 specimen measured along the build direction.The microhardness remarkably varies in the three different matrices.The microhardness is 381.20 $\pm 1 5 \mathrm { H V } _ { 0 . 5 }$ at the bottom SS3o4 layersand gradually increases across the SS304- IN718 CGZ until reaching a peak of $4 1 1 . 1 5 \pm 1 \mathrm { { H V } } _ { 0 . 5 }$ at the middle IN718 region. Then, it gradually decreases to $3 4 4 . 4 5 \pm 2 0 \mathrm { H V } _ { 0 . 5 }$ at the top section of the SS3o4 layers.This result is in accordance with the previous SLM studies [62,63].

Fig.l2 shows the cross-section microstructural evolution from the bottom to the top of the Case-4 sample.The microstructures,and especially the sub-grain sizes,change significantly along the building direction.The bottom SS3o4 layers are made of coarse cellular subgrains with sizes of ${ \sim } 2 \mu \mathrm { m }$ ,as shown in Fig.12f. When depositing IN718 on the SS3o4 layers,the sub-grains are pronouncedly refined and a dense reticulation is generated at this CGZ (see Fig.l2e).With the continuous deposition of the IN718 layers,fine flocculent dendrites with a size of less than $1 \mu \mathrm { m }$ are formed,as shown in Fig.12d.Furthermore, the sub-grains are coarsened when the deposited materials are switched from IN718 to SS304 (Fig.12c). Lastly,visible cellular microstructures are generated at the top SS3o4 layers,as shown in Fig.12b.

name: 2024 - Composites Part B Engineering - Zhang et al. - Powder sheet additive manufacturing of multi-material structures Experimental and-part-26
fileName: 2024 - Composites Part B Engineering - Zhang et al. - Powder sheet additive manufacturing of multi-material structures Experimental and.md
content:
In this section,the formation mechanisms of diverse defects presented in the printed MMS parts are analyzed in detail by combining the

FE thermo-mechanical simulation with the experimental observations. Based on the understanding of thermal and stress evolution during the MAPS process of MMS,a control strategy for preventing such defects is also proposed and assessed.

name: 2024 - Composites Part B Engineering - Zhang et al. - Powder sheet additive manufacturing of multi-material structures Experimental and-part-27
fileName: 2024 - Composites Part B Engineering - Zhang et al. - Powder sheet additive manufacturing of multi-material structures Experimental and.md
content:
The LOF defects in SLMare normally characterized by a non-sintered region and improper fusion between adjacent tracks or layers,as shown in Fig.9b and c.This is due to insufficient energy input [64]. In this work,different lengths of the scan-vector are used for printing the three different-sized MMS components,although each component is otherwise manufactured under the same printing conditions (Fig. 4a-c). This is assumed to be the reason for the generation of LOF and balling defects during the MAPS process.To assess this and to avoid the remelting effect of multi-layer deposition on the observation and measurement of the melt-pool, three new single-layer SS304 samples with increased horizontal dimensions of $5 \times 5 ~ \mathrm { m m } ^ { 2 }$ $1 0 \times 1 0 ~ \mathrm { m m } ^ { 2 }$ and $2 0 \times 2 0 ~ \mathrm { m m ^ { 2 } }$ are manufactured on SS316 substrate by MAPS with the $9 0 ^ { \circ }$ rotation scanning strategy (Fig.4a-c).This approach is the same as that which was carried out for the previous multi-layer MMS parts (Fig.5).

The printed single-layer specimens are sectioned firstly along the center of the build.The obtained cross-sections,which are perpendicular to the scanning direction,are presented in Fig.13a-c.The profile of the melt-pool and the overlapping between adjoining tracks are plainly visible.On the right side of these figures,the melt-pool morphologies predicted byFE thermal analysisare also displayed.Fig.13d compares the predicted and measured width and depth of the melt-pool for the three cases.A noticeable agreement between simulations and experiments is achieved.Once calibrated,the computational model is employed to analyze the thermo-mechanical behavior during the MAPS process of multi-layer MMS.
summary: 5.1.Formation mechanisms of LOF and balling in MMS - Part 1/5

name: 2024 - Composites Part B Engineering - Zhang et al. - Powder sheet additive manufacturing of multi-material structures Experimental and-part-28
fileName: 2024 - Composites Part B Engineering - Zhang et al. - Powder sheet additive manufacturing of multi-material structures Experimental and.md
content:
The melt-pool width and depth pronouncedly decrease with the increase of the scan-vector length used for building larger MMS parts (Fig.13). When the part size increases from $5 \times 5 \mathrm { m m } ^ { 2 }$ to $2 0 \times 2 0 \mathrm { m m } ^ { 2 }$ the width and depth of the melt-pool are reduced by $1 7 . 3 ~ \%$ (from 162 $\mu \mathrm { m }$ to $1 3 4 \mu \mathrm { m } )$ and $2 0 . 9 \%$ (from $6 7 \mu \mathrm { m }$ to $5 3 \mu \mathrm { m } )$ ,respectively. This is explained as follows: the longer scan-vector is subjected to the prolonging of the interval cooling time between adjacent tracks.Thus, this significantly diminishes the thermal accumulation,reducing the melt

pool size.
summary: 5.1.Formation mechanisms of LOF and balling in MMS - Part 2/5

name: 2024 - Composites Part B Engineering - Zhang et al. - Powder sheet additive manufacturing of multi-material structures Experimental and-part-29
fileName: 2024 - Composites Part B Engineering - Zhang et al. - Powder sheet additive manufacturing of multi-material structures Experimental and.md
content: To further prove this,the evolution of the temperature field in the MAPS processes of the four designed MMS geometries (Fig.5a） is simulated by the thermal model.Fig.14 shows the thermal histories at three different deposition heights (i.e. $0 . 2 \mathrm { m m }$ $0 . 6 \mathrm { m m }$ and $1 . 0 \mathrm { m m }$ in the center of the builds.The grey and yellow backgrounds correspond to the deposition layers of SS304 and IN718,respectively.It can be observed that with the increase of the part size (and also the length of scan-vector), the peak temperature declines (Fig.14a-c). For instance, when printing the middle IN718 layers,the magnitude of peak temperature decreases by $9 . 4 ~ \%$ from $2 3 5 4 ~ ^ { \circ } \mathrm { C }$ (for Case-1) to $2 1 3 3 ^ { \circ } \mathrm { C }$ (for Case-3),as shown in Fig.14a and c.This indicates that using longer scan tracks prolongs the interval time between tracks and allows for sufficient cooling,accelerating the heat loss through the lower substrate or the previous metal deposition.As the geometric dimension of MMS increases,variations in the thermal history during the MAPS printing process can significantly influence the degradation behavior of the polymer.Therefore,the metal powder embedded in the sheets is insufficiently sintered during the MAPS processing of the large MMS components.As a result, LOF defects are produced (Fig.9b and c).
summary: 5.1.Formation mechanisms of LOF and balling in MMS - Part 3/5

name: 2024 - Composites Part B Engineering - Zhang et al. - Powder sheet additive manufacturing of multi-material structures Experimental and-part-30
fileName: 2024 - Composites Part B Engineering - Zhang et al. - Powder sheet additive manufacturing of multi-material structures Experimental and.md
content:
Apart from the LOF defect, the large MMS part also presents a balling phenomenon (Fig.5c),which may further cause discontinuous tracks, porosity,poor inter-line bonding,or even delamination [64].The formation of balling is induced by the lack of wetting between the solid particles and the underlying substrate [65,66].Essentially,wettability is closely related to the melt-pool morphology,significantly affected by the printing parameters.In this work,the longer scan-vector used for building the large MMS part yields a smaller melt-pool accompanied by poor wettability (Fig.13)and, thus, the occurrence of the balling defect (Fig. 9c).

![](images/a1b61aa96f1b0b0707ab5ee1f8130ab4065d7d3aa7fd794963516762f05c1ff2.jpg)

name: 2024 - Composites Part B Engineering - Zhang et al. - Powder sheet additive manufacturing of multi-material structures Experimental and-part-31
fileName: 2024 - Composites Part B Engineering - Zhang et al. - Powder sheet additive manufacturing of multi-material structures Experimental and.md
content: Based on the above analysis regarding the formations of LOF and balling,it is possible to prevent their occurrence by improving the metallurgical sintering during the MAPS process. One strategy is to utilize a relatively higher energy density to increase both the size and the wettability of the melt-pool.However,this may cause higher residual stresses and potential warping and cracking.This is explained by the fact that,the larger the melt-pool dimensions are,the more significant are the thermal deformations [67].An alternative feasible solution is to optimize the scanning strategy by shortening the length of scan-vector, as used in MAPS of the small MMS part (Case-1).According to this, the MAPS fabrication of a large-scale $( 2 0 \times 2 0 \times 1 . 2 ~ \mathrm { m m } ^ { 3 } )$ MMS part is accompanied by adopting an optimized island scanning strategy,as shown in Fig.5b.The metallurgical quality of both the single-phase matrices and CGZ is remarkable (Fig.9d), thanks to achieving sufficient heat accumulation during the MAPS printing (see Fig.14d).
summary: 5.1.Formation mechanisms of LOF and balling in MMS - Part 5/5

name: 2024 - Composites Part B Engineering - Zhang et al. - Powder sheet additive manufacturing of multi-material structures Experimental and-part-32
fileName: 2024 - Composites Part B Engineering - Zhang et al. - Powder sheet additive manufacturing of multi-material structures Experimental and.md
content:
In this section,the formation of cracks observed in the moderate and large MMS (Fig.9b and c) is numerically investigated by the FE structural analysis.These cracks are induced by the intrinsic thermal stresses occurring during the MAPS process for MMS.A previous study has illustrated that both large thermal gradients and the strong mechanical constraints from stiff substrates (or previously deposited layers) in AM are responsible for the formation of residual stress [68].However, the unique characteristics of both the composite materials and the MAPS technique used in this work significantly increase the complexity of the mechanical response.

Therefore,the MAPS printing process of MMS is numerically simulated to further comprehend the generation of the residual stresses. Fig.15 compares the evolution of the Von Mises stresses at three different building heights in the center of the MMS builds.With the increase of the MMS size,the Von Mises stresses pronouncedly increase, which proves that the size effect plays a crucial role in the mechanical behavior of MMS.This is because the larger the structure is in size, the longer the inter-hatch cooling time will be.This results in a reduction of thermal accumulation,consequently contributing to higher thermal stresses and cracks in the as-built MMS parts (Fig.9b and c).

Nevertheless，when the island scanning strategy isused for manufacturing the large-scale MMS part, the residual stresses at the center of the build are mitigated (Fig.15c and d).
summary: 5.2.Formation mechanism of cracks in MMS - Part 1/3

name: 2024 - Composites Part B Engineering - Zhang et al. - Powder sheet additive manufacturing of multi-material structures Experimental and-part-33
fileName: 2024 - Composites Part B Engineering - Zhang et al. - Powder sheet additive manufacturing of multi-material structures Experimental and.md
content:
Fig.l6 shows the contour-fills of the residual Von Mises stresses in the different MMS components.The specific residual stress distributions in the building direction at the center of four different MMS builds are presented in Fig.17.It can be seen that with the increase of the component size (or the scan-vector length） when utilizing the $9 0 ^ { \circ }$ rotation scanning strategy,the residual stresses are dramatically accumulated in the MMS build. This is especially the case at the middle IN718 layers due to their high yield stress.These results are in line with the previous SLM report [69].

Remarkably, the use of island scanning with a $9 0 ^ { \circ }$ staggered rotation disrupts the continuity of the residual stress distribution,which effectively mitigates stress concentration,as shown in Fig.16d.Although the resulting stress reduction is limited (e.g. ${ \sim } 1 0 ~ \% )$ ,this strategy successfully prevents the occurrence of cracking defects.This is largely due to the elimination of metallurgical defects,which are typically the most susceptible areas for crack initiation under high thermal stresses.

name: 2024 - Composites Part B Engineering - Zhang et al. - Powder sheet additive manufacturing of multi-material structures Experimental and-part-34
fileName: 2024 - Composites Part B Engineering - Zhang et al. - Powder sheet additive manufacturing of multi-material structures Experimental and.md
content: The successful production of large-scale defect-free MMS using the MAPS method can be primarily attributed to the careful control of the thermal history and the resulting residual stress.As the scanning length increases, issues such as LOF and balling occur due to insufficient energy input resulting from reduced energy accumulation.This study also delves into the formation mechanisms of cracks,which are influenced by longer inter-hatch cooling times leading to a higher residual stress and, consequently,the formation of cracks.Details have been presented in Sections 5.1 and 5.2. The insights gained from this study hold the potential to optimize the printing configurations for large-scale functional MMS.
summary: 5.2.Formation mechanism of cracks in MMS - Part 3/3

name: 2024 - Composites Part B Engineering - Zhang et al. - Powder sheet additive manufacturing of multi-material structures Experimental and-part-35
fileName: 2024 - Composites Part B Engineering - Zhang et al. - Powder sheet additive manufacturing of multi-material structures Experimental and.md
content:
In this work,a novel MAPS method is proposed for printing metallic MMS parts.Its capability is systematically evaluated by varying the MMS dimensions and scanning strategies.The mechanisms for chemical composition transition,crystal growth,interfacial bonding and formation of defects are investigated by both experimental characterizations and computational modelling.Optimized MAPS configurations for fabricating high-quality MMS parts are provided.The main conclusions are as follows.

1） The MAPS simplifies the common loose powder SLM processes and improves the fabrication eficiency for MMs.Importantly,it can avoid potential cross-contamination between different feedstock materials,this being especially beneficial for recycling materials. Additionally,the polymer binder used to secure the metal powder within the powder sheets is degraded during the MAPS melting

name: 2024 - Composites Part B Engineering - Zhang et al. - Powder sheet additive manufacturing of multi-material structures Experimental and-part-36
fileName: 2024 - Composites Part B Engineering - Zhang et al. - Powder sheet additive manufacturing of multi-material structures Experimental and.md
content:
process.   
2)When using the $9 0 ^ { \circ }$ rotation scanning strategy to print square MMS plates,metallurgical defects such as LOF and balling phenomenon are more likely to occur as the part dimensions increase and the scanvector becomes longer. This is because as the part size increases, the inter-hatch cooling time and heat loss also increase,leading to a reduction in the size of the melt-pool and thus to the generation of defects.   
3) The predicted thermo-mechanical results of MMS illustrate that a large residual stress concentration occurs at the interface of dissimilar matrices.The larger the MMS deposition, the higher both the residual stresses and the risk of cracking (mechanical defects) are. Specifically,the longer scan-vector used for building larger MMS results in larger residual stresses.   
4) Based on the experimental and numerical analyses,an island scanning strategy is proposed for preventing both metallurgical and mechanical defects.By using the optimized process parameters,a large-scale defect-free SS304-IN718-SS304 MMS component is successfully printed by MAPS.Variations in chemical composition, microhardness and microstructure along the build direction and a good interfacial metallurgical bonding are achieved in the MAPSprocessed MMS part.

name: 2024 - J. Alloys and Compounds - Jeyaprakash et al. - Effect of microstructural evolution during melt pool formation on nano-mechanical-part-1
fileName: 2024 - J. Alloys and Compounds - Jeyaprakash et al. - Effect of microstructural evolution during melt pool formation on nano-mechanical.md
content:
N. Jeyaprakasha\*, M. Saravana Kumarb, Che-Hua Yangb, Yanhai Chenga, N. Radhika, S. Sivasankaran d

# ARTICLEINFO

summary: Effect of microstructural evolution during melt pool formation on nano-mechanical properties in LPBF based SS316L parts

name: 2024 - J. Alloys and Compounds - Jeyaprakash et al. - Effect of microstructural evolution during melt pool formation on nano-mechanical-part-2
fileName: 2024 - J. Alloys and Compounds - Jeyaprakash et al. - Effect of microstructural evolution during melt pool formation on nano-mechanical.md
content:
# ABSTRACT
Laser Powder Bed Fusion (LPBF) based SS316L parts have a wide range of industrial applications,mainly due to their high strength and good structural integrity.However,there is alack of nano-mechanical studies related to microstructural evolution.The SS3l6L cubes were examined for grain orientation and phase transformation with the help of OMand FESEM with EDX analysis.Cellular and columnar grains were substantiated by FESEM with EDX.Further,the δ ferrite and $\gamma$ austenite phases occurrence was evident in XRD analysis.The orientation of grains was further examined through EBSD analysis.The microstructural transformation was substantiated by mapping based on modulus. Cellular grains showed a maximum hardness of 6 Gpa,whereas the transverse columnar grains displayed a minimum elastic modulus of 105.8 GPa.Nano-wear and scratch analysis predicted the functions caused by the occurrence of celllar dendritic microstructure,and the topographic wear and scratch tracks confirmed the soft nature of transverse columnar grains by forming more pile-up of materials. Strain Rate Sensitivity (SRS)of the SS316L specimens was analysed based on three diferent strain rates (4.1 $\times 1 0 ^ { - 5 } \ s ^ { - 1 }$ $2 . 0 8 \times 1 0 ^ { - 4 } \ s ^ { - 1 }$ and $3 . 3 \times 1 0 ^ { - 4 } \ s ^ { - 1 } )$ . It was concluded that the LPBFed SS316L parts possessed a negative strain rate.In contrast,the simultaneous attainment of maximum Ultimate Tensile Strength (UTS)and ductility was possible in the quasi-static strain rate.

name: 2024 - J. Alloys and Compounds - Jeyaprakash et al. - Effect of microstructural evolution during melt pool formation on nano-mechanical-part-3
fileName: 2024 - J. Alloys and Compounds - Jeyaprakash et al. - Effect of microstructural evolution during melt pool formation on nano-mechanical.md
content: The Rapid prototyping-based LPBF technique is a member of the additive manufacturing (AM) technology,which has gained popularity in recent years due to its capacity to reduce material waste and shorten lead times [1].This routine has been frequently used to investigate the high temperatures working metals such as Ti6Al4V, SS316L, SS304L and Inconel IN718,allowing the direct fabrication of metal objects with incredibly complex interior structures [2].Due to the rapid cooling rates used during the LPBF process,the specimens are linked with fine grains and high dislocation density [3].The grain formations during the LPBF process stimulate the mechanical properties [4].Even without post-processing treatment, the fabricated parts have enhanced elongation and strength [5].

name: 2024 - J. Alloys and Compounds - Jeyaprakash et al. - Effect of microstructural evolution during melt pool formation on nano-mechanical-part-4
fileName: 2024 - J. Alloys and Compounds - Jeyaprakash et al. - Effect of microstructural evolution during melt pool formation on nano-mechanical.md
content: Afew researchers investigated the microstructural development of LPBFed SS316L parts in detail. Yuji Sato et al. examined the spattering effect while printing SS316L parts.By using a high-resolution camera, they have tracked the spattering caused by the irradiation of the laser and have enhanced the dimensional accuracy,surface roughness and surface finishes by reducing the spattering behaviour on the printed surface by controlling the laser power [6].Few researcher works on electric field intensity to enhance their microstructure.Zhang et al. showed that the electric field intensity had the greatest influence on the atomic diffusion [7].Michal et al. investigated the tension and torsion behaviour of the vertical and horizontal-oriented SS316L printed parts. Theyused finite element analysis for applying Von Mises criterion and Hill criterion to compare the lord-deformation result. They have also compared the conventionally processed Ss316L with the printed SS316L concerning ductility of the parts.They concluded that the machined parts significantly reduced their ductility [8].The phase transformation has the significant contribution in microstructural characteristics which was proven by Xin et al.[9] and Kuang etal.[1O]. Kumaran et al. studied the residual stress during the combined direct energy deposition and powder bed fusion. They have stated that the residual stresses may be compressive or tensile,leading to fatigue cracks.So,they have insisted on analyzing the residual stress of the LPBF SS3l6L substrate before performing the direct energy deposition [11].Similarly,thermal protection performance of the components can also be improved by performing atmospheric plasma spraying technique [l2].Meet et al. associated the possessions of LPBFed SS316L and MS300 maraging steel with the conventional manufacturing process.They have found that MS30O maraging steel has the maximum tensile strength compared with SS316L and the conventional method.

name: 2024 - J. Alloys and Compounds - Jeyaprakash et al. - Effect of microstructural evolution during melt pool formation on nano-mechanical-part-5
fileName: 2024 - J. Alloys and Compounds - Jeyaprakash et al. - Effect of microstructural evolution during melt pool formation on nano-mechanical.md
content: On the contrary, SS316L showed more hardness compared with the Ms3oo maraging steel and conventionalmethod[13]．Esmaeilpouretal．investigatedthe high-temperature flow behavior of SLM-based SS316L.They have performed the hot compression and strain rate sensitivity analysis.Moreover,a single-layer Artificial Neural Network (ANN) model was adopted to track the strain-hardening portion and the flow softening behavior of the material [14].Similarly,in anotherresearch,they have engaged Johnson-Cook and Arrhenius-type constructive models.However,as it was unable to predict the flow hardening or softening behaviour and levels of strength at various strain rates and temperatures.They adapted an artificial neural network model,which was more accurate compared with the constructive models [15].

name: 2024 - J. Alloys and Compounds - Jeyaprakash et al. - Effect of microstructural evolution during melt pool formation on nano-mechanical-part-6
fileName: 2024 - J. Alloys and Compounds - Jeyaprakash et al. - Effect of microstructural evolution during melt pool formation on nano-mechanical.md
content: A few research was carried out to analyze the effect of LPBF process parameters.Jae et al.analysed the impact of laser power, scanning speed and energy density on the creep performance of the LPBFed SS316L parts.Similarly,the build direction of the printed parts was also studied based on the creep performance. They have found that the energy density was an essential parameter for enhancing the creep life. Moreover they have confirmed that the vertically oriented parts possessed longer creep life than the horizontally oriented parts [16]. The mechanical characteristics of the fabricated parts was influenced by the phase transformation during the manufacturing process and that was proved by Xu et al. [17] and Wang et al.[18]. Zhiheng et al. found out that,reducing the spot diameter,powder size and laser beam,it was possible to get a better surface without defects and also with dimensional accuracy.To investigate this interaction of attributes， they adopted single-track development in SS316L steel. They also noted some double-crest morphology due to the fine spot size which led to recoil pressure gradient [19]. Pawel et al.emphasized the influence of relative density on the mechanical attributes of different lattice structures made from Ss316L.They have adopted different stud diameters to change the relative density which had a predominant influence on the deformation movements of the printed parts.However, they have concluded that the latice structure with high relative density displayed more performance in stretching， while the lattice structure with lower relative density showed increased performance in bending [2O]. Binqi et al. predicted the porosity during the melt pool formation during SS316L and Ti-6Al-4 V. Many defects such as lack of fusion,keyhole formations and pore formation were analysed using the CFD simulations.

name: 2024 - J. Alloys and Compounds - Jeyaprakash et al. - Effect of microstructural evolution during melt pool formation on nano-mechanical-part-7
fileName: 2024 - J. Alloys and Compounds - Jeyaprakash et al. - Effect of microstructural evolution during melt pool formation on nano-mechanical.md
content:
They compared the analytical model with the experimentally observed data，conforming that analytical modelling was the effective tool for producing defect-free components [3]. Philipp et al. focused on the process interruption in the static tensile properties of the SS316L and hybrid parts.They have stated that process interruption occurred at the weakened zone of the printed parts.However,it is not possble for the occurrence of failure exactly in the interruption zone all the time,which was proven by testing on the hybrid parts [21]. According to Abbasi etal., the existence of fine grains $( < 2 0 ~ \mu \mathrm { m } )$ across the printed microstructure was taken into account as proof that dynamic recrystallization occurred during the SLM process [22]. Armin Habibiyan et al. performed a hybrid aditive manufacturing process by adopting open forge (Ampliforge) after completing the additive manufacturing process They have concluded that by adopting this hybrid process, it is possible to obtain a homogenous microstructure without anisotropy of properties [23].

These surveys confirm that there needs to be more nano-mechanical studies in terms of microstructural evolution during the melt pool formation.Hence,the prime novelty of this study is to examine the formation of cellular and columnar grains on the printed SS316L and their influence over the nano-level properties.Nano-scratch and wear were implemented on five different regions in the printed SS316L parts to examine the effect of microstructural evolution.Similarly, SRS investigation for the SS316L specimens was also performed to investigate the simultaneous attainment of strength and ductility.

name: 2024 - J. Alloys and Compounds - Jeyaprakash et al. - Effect of microstructural evolution during melt pool formation on nano-mechanical-part-8
fileName: 2024 - J. Alloys and Compounds - Jeyaprakash et al. - Effect of microstructural evolution during melt pool formation on nano-mechanical.md
content:
# 2．Materials and methods


# 2.1．Elemental proportion
Stainless steel powder particles were used to print the LPBFed SS316L parts.Particles of SS316L powder with a minimum purity of $9 9 . 9 \%$ by weight. The spherical shaped particles and their corresponding composition of elements were confirmed during the morphology analysis using SEM with EDAX.The particle size distribution was analysed using the Image J software shown in the Fig.1(a-c).The major composition of Fe,Cr and Ni elements confirmed the SS316L powder particles.The size of the spherical-shaped particles was in a range from $1 5 \mu \mathrm { m }$ to $4 5 \mu \mathrm { m }$ So,the average particle size of the SS316L powder was $2 6 . 5 \mu \mathrm { m }$ .Table1 displays the elemental composition of SS316L powder particles.

# 2.2. LPBF process
The EOSINT M280 machine was adopted for printing the coupons. The SS316L parts were designed depending on the printing process parameters specified by the manufacturer. The LPBF parameters adopted were 30o W laser power, 0.13 hatch spacing, $1 4 5 0 \mathrm { m m } / s$ scanning speed and $5 0 \mu \mathrm { m }$ layer thickness.Moreover, $2 0 0 ~ ^ { \circ } \mathrm { C }$ of printing bed temperature was sustained for the effective printing of parts.Argon gas was placed inside the printing chamber to prevent any reactions.The extra steel powder particles were gathered in the collector unit. The printing began as soon as the oxygen content reached the minimum parts.Fig.2 demonstrates the representation process of making SS316L parts.Table 2 displays the process settings selected for printing the LPBFed SS316L.

name: 2024 - J. Alloys and Compounds - Jeyaprakash et al. - Effect of microstructural evolution during melt pool formation on nano-mechanical-part-9
fileName: 2024 - J. Alloys and Compounds - Jeyaprakash et al. - Effect of microstructural evolution during melt pool formation on nano-mechanical.md
content: Wire Electric Discharge Machining (WEDM) was used to section the SS316L specimens,which were then cut into $\mathbf { 2 } \times 2 \mathbf { x } 2 ~ \mathrm { c m } ^ { 3 }$ squares for microstructural examination.The specimens were hot mounted with Bakelite powders,polished with different grits of emery sheets ranging from 4Oo to 3ooo grit,and then cloth polished with alumina particles in the double disc polishing machine.Kallings solution( $_ { 2 g }$ Cupric Chloride, $4 0 { - } 8 0 ~ \mathrm { m l }$ Methanol, $4 0 ~ \mathrm { m l }$ Water and $4 0 ~ \mathrm { m l }$ Hydrochloric acid) was used as the etchant and swab etching method was used.The distinct phases in the printed SS316L parts were examined using the PANalytical X'Pert PRO diffractometer.The morphology of the LPBFed SS316L parts was examined.The microstructure of the printed items was examined with an Optical Microscope (OM) (OLYMPUS SZX16).Advanced characterization methods were applied,including Transmission Electron Microscope (TEM)-(JEM-21OO F),Electron Beam Scattered Diffraction (EBSD) and Field Emission Scanning Electron Microscopy (FE-SEM) - (JOEL 7900 F).

name: 2024 - J. Alloys and Compounds - Jeyaprakash et al. - Effect of microstructural evolution during melt pool formation on nano-mechanical-part-10
fileName: 2024 - J. Alloys and Compounds - Jeyaprakash et al. - Effect of microstructural evolution during melt pool formation on nano-mechanical.md
content:
The nanohardness test was carried out using the ASTM E 2546 [24] to determine the nano-level indentation resistance on the LPBFed SS316L parts.The mapping was performed by applying a constant force of $2 8 0 0 \mu \mathrm { N }$ in the designated area.The corner cube indenter tip was used for the nanowear examination.At a distance of $1 0 \mu \mathrm { m }$ ，sliding was executed three times in a single track with a load of $7 0 0 0 ~ \mu \mathrm { N }$ .Then, utilizing topographic photos, the surface topographies were examined. The nano-scratch test was conducted similarly,except for the load condition.The tensile test was conducted by the ASTME8 standard [25]. The Tinios Olsen computerized model of the Universal Testing Machine (H50KL) was used to determine the SRS.Three strain rates were used to test the tensile performance $( 4 . 1 \times 1 0 ^ { - 5 } \ s ^ { - 1 }$ ， $2 . 0 8 \times 1 0 ^ { - 4 } \ s ^ { - 1 }$ and $3 . 3 \times 1 0 ^ { - 4 } \ : s ^ { - 1 } )$ . The selected strain rates are quasi-static with minimum ranges to examine their high sensitivity toward strain rates.Moreover, these fixed quasi-static strain rates aid in understanding and comparing the results of nano-level mechanical properties such as nano-hardness, nano-wear and nano-scratch.The UTS was scrutinized according to the SRS,and the fracture process was analyzed using the FESEM images taken from the fractured SS316L parts. ![](images/f69fb96768c043b1d8e63e185969a3b0afc8bbd4f1c8b2f02435a4642b187190.jpg) 'ig.1.(a)Powder morphology of SS316L powder,(b) Particle size distribution chartand (c)EDXresults of SS316L po Table 1 Elemental composition of SS316L powder particles.

name: 2024 - J. Alloys and Compounds - Jeyaprakash et al. - Effect of microstructural evolution during melt pool formation on nano-mechanical-part-12
fileName: 2024 - J. Alloys and Compounds - Jeyaprakash et al. - Effect of microstructural evolution during melt pool formation on nano-mechanical.md
content:
# 3.1． XRD analysis
The X-Ray Diffraction analysis confirms the occurrence of $\gamma$ austenite and a small trace of δ ferrite.Fig.3 shows the phase identification of SS316L powder and as-built SS316L parts.The magnified view of small trace of δ ferrite was presented in Fig.3(b). Zhongji Sun et al. [26], Won-Sang Shin et al.[27] and Wakshum M. Tucho et al.[28] observed a similar small trace of δ ferrite peaks on(11O) crystal plane.The predominant diffraction peaks with crystal planes (111),(2oo),(220) and (311） confirmed the $\gamma$ austenite phases of the LPBFed SS316 parts. However,compared with SS316L powder and as-built parts,there was no major phase transformation.A similar observation was made by Won-Sang Shin et al. [27]. The melt pool formation did not posess enough temperature for the complete transformation of the ferrite phase to the austenite phase,because the ferrite phase could withstand high temperatures.Moreover,the retained partial quantity of the ferrite phase helped to strengthen the soft austenite phase.He etal.stated that the occurrence of the BCC matrix phase enhances the strength of the material [29].The formation of δ ferrite phase also contributes to nano level fluctuation of properties.Moreover,the soft austenitic matrix was meant to be strengthened by the retained δ phase.

name: 2024 - J. Alloys and Compounds - Jeyaprakash et al. - Effect of microstructural evolution during melt pool formation on nano-mechanical-part-13
fileName: 2024 - J. Alloys and Compounds - Jeyaprakash et al. - Effect of microstructural evolution during melt pool formation on nano-mechanical.md
content: Understanding the melting process and examining faults in connection to process parameters was made possible by studying the morphology of the LPBFed SS316L parts.Fig.4 Shows the OM images of the printed SS316L parts from which it is evident that the microstructures are in a micron scale. From these OM images, the overlapping of melt pool boundaries which is recognized by semi-circular shape and tracks perpendicular to the build direction are obvious. However,a few micropores and spattering effects were noted.It is conceivable that the partial melting of the bigger particles in the coarse and raw powders led to binding problems [3O].The SEM analysis in Fig. 5(a-e) shows that, there are two different microstructures,cellular dendrite structure and transverse columnar elongated structure.A similar observation was made by Yusuf etal. [31]. These microstructures were mainly induced by the higher cooling rate of the LPBF process which attributed to the fast solidification process.The cellular dendritic structure created islands of small cellular grains scattered among the columnar grains, which contributed to the hardening effect and lower ductility of the tensile specimens.There were islands of tiny cellular subgrains and transverse columnar subgrains.At the several nucleation sites along the boundary, these islands of small subgrains could be detected [32].This finding is seen in Fig.5(b)and Fig.5(c). It's interesting to note that,as shown in Fig. 5(c), the grains appears normally to the curvature of the fusion lines and that the fusion line does not prevent the expansion of the grains.The columnar grains generally form towards the edge of the melt pool in the direction of the heat flow,which is parallel to the fusion line. Wang et al.[33] examined the relationship between the direction of the columnar grains and the crystal orientation in order to determine the reason of diversity in the direction of the grains'development in the melt pool.

name: 2024 - J. Alloys and Compounds - Jeyaprakash et al. - Effect of microstructural evolution during melt pool formation on nano-mechanical-part-14
fileName: 2024 - J. Alloys and Compounds - Jeyaprakash et al. - Effect of microstructural evolution during melt pool formation on nano-mechanical.md
content:
Marangoni flow,which results in convincing fluid flow and heat transfer within a melt pool,can potentially alter the heat flux's direction.This caused the columnar grains’growth orientation to change from its natural orientation,forcing it to follow the fusion line. This characteristic is evident in Fig.5(d).Likewise,re-melting during the overlap of melt pools significantly affected the grains normal to the fusion line,by restricting nucleation during solidification in the previously melted region. The presence of austenite phase along the melt pool formation was further investigated in the TEM analysis which has a considerable role in nano-wear and scratch analysis.

![](images/64a57fb3151cfadd64962d7ade4be7dc28f5a7ed4cdb0d25ccec507630296a70.jpg)  
Fig. 3.Phase analysis of LPBFed SS316L parts (a) and magnified view of b (b).

![](images/881c5341f98b17f7dc0ce17551fa6bf77f65f6b289db38fd16e42faea960da9e.jpg)  
ig. 4.OM images of LPBFed SS316L parts: (a) Overlapped Melt pools and (b) Spatering ffec

name: 2024 - J. Alloys and Compounds - Jeyaprakash et al. - Effect of microstructural evolution during melt pool formation on nano-mechanical-part-15
fileName: 2024 - J. Alloys and Compounds - Jeyaprakash et al. - Effect of microstructural evolution during melt pool formation on nano-mechanical.md
content:
The results of EBSD phase analysis in Fig.6(a-b),show the mixed structure of transverse columnar and cellular arrangement of grains.The EBSD image was taken in the Inverse Pole Figure-Z direction. The Fig. 6 (a-d) displays the Pole Figure and Inverse Pole Figure.Itwas difficult to index the smaller grain structure that resulted from the transverse columnar structure's fused area.This intricate grain structure distribution was due to the LPBF technique which possessed a faster cooling rate [34].These fine grain structures along with the fused regions had an essential role in the strengthening mechanism and also aided in reducing the ductility of the printed SS316L [35].The orientation of grains was analyzed based on the IPFs.The analysis verified that the transverse columnar grain structures were oriented in the direction of $< 1 0 1 >$ ， indicating that the crystal cubes of the surface-textured normal are mostly orientated in that direction.The formation mechanism of grain structures is often described in terms of compositional variations and the supercooling theory [36]. The cellular grain structure was caused by an increased thermal gradient and decreased growth velocity. Similarly, the columnar structure was caused by the decreased thermal gradient and increased growth velocity.As previously stated,LPBFed materials were more severely strained at faster heating and cooling processes [37]. As a result, LPBFed materials that experience faster heating and cooling processes are supposed to cause more dislocation networks than conventionally manufactured metals with relatively slower heating and cooling processes.

![](images/1350fc939c009d900e9fef9f3e00daa0b12cb8175334c0d11ea8a59075316254.jpg)  
Fig6.Es inverse pole figures.

name: 2024 - J. Alloys and Compounds - Jeyaprakash et al. - Effect of microstructural evolution during melt pool formation on nano-mechanical-part-16
fileName: 2024 - J. Alloys and Compounds - Jeyaprakash et al. - Effect of microstructural evolution during melt pool formation on nano-mechanical.md
content: In the literature,the micron-sized grain development mechanism was investigated.According to Sames etal.[38],gradation in thermal stress has the ability to regulate and anticipate grain shapes. However, there is no experimental and theoretical supporting evidence justifying the grain formation mechanism prediction based on the thermal gradient and growth velocity. Sub-grain microstructure development by the LPBF process was characterized by a high density of dislocation networks and sometimes segregation of heavier elements. Consequently, precipitate formation may result from these dislocations close to the recently established boundary,which may stop heavier components from diffusing farther [32].

name: 2024 - J. Alloys and Compounds - Jeyaprakash et al. - Effect of microstructural evolution during melt pool formation on nano-mechanical-part-17
fileName: 2024 - J. Alloys and Compounds - Jeyaprakash et al. - Effect of microstructural evolution during melt pool formation on nano-mechanical.md
content:
# 3.4. TEM analysis
TEM analysis also confirmed the presence $\gamma$ austenite phase.Previously, these $\gamma$ austenite phase and δ ferrite phase were confirmed by the XRD results by the indication of major peaks of $\gamma$ austenite phase and small traces of δ ferrite phase at the corresponding intensity.The formation of cellular grain structure and transverse columnar structure was noted in the FESEM analysis during the microstructural investigation. With the help of TEM analysis, $\gamma$ austenite phase was investigated in detail, which is shown in Fig.7.The observed $\gamma$ austenite phase was also one of the predominant factors in influencing the nano-level tribological performance of the printed parts.Zhongji Sun et al.observed the irregular shaped ferrites [26] and stated that the occurrence of δ ferrite phase causes twisted dense dislocations.This characteristic had more influential effects on the wear and tensile performance. Fig.7(b) shows the Selected Area Electron Diffraction (SAED) of $\gamma$ austenite phase and the obtained SAED of $\gamma$ austenite phase was similar to the observation made by Zhongji Sun et al.[26].In Fig.7(a),the grain boundary is shown by two different contrasts.The occurrence of δ ferrite phase which was confirmed in the XRD was due to the ability to withstand the high temperature.Moreover,due to the rapid cooling rate of the LPBF technique,there was no sufficient time for the complete transformation of the ferrite to austenite phase.So,the limited S ferrite phase which was confirmed in the XRD attributed to the strengthening of the soft FCC

![](images/0b9988b1e2dba299a9283ef21b609a7de8bb1cec6f4c8d9f0ad2db21c199d49c.jpg)  
Fig.7.TEM images of LPBFed SS316L: (a)Bright field image and (b) Selected Area Electron Difraction (SAED) pattern.

austenite phase.

name: 2024 - J. Alloys and Compounds - Jeyaprakash et al. - Effect of microstructural evolution during melt pool formation on nano-mechanical-part-18
fileName: 2024 - J. Alloys and Compounds - Jeyaprakash et al. - Effect of microstructural evolution during melt pool formation on nano-mechanical.md
content:
The LPBFed SS316L specimens were inspected by applying a load of $2 8 0 0 ~ \mu \mathrm { N }$ for $_ { 1 5 s }$ which helped in the attainment of effective load.The indentation was removed as soon as the indent reached the maximum load.The nano-indentation test was performed at five different regions on the surface of the LPBFed SS316L parts,and their corresponding 3D topographic images with force versus displacement curves were examined (Fig.8(a-b)).It was observed that there was an absence of a smooth curve with multiple pop-in effects.The mapping was obtained by executing the indentation procedure over 3oo times in a defined region of $2 0 \times 2 0 ~ \mu \mathrm { m }$ ,as depicted in Fig.8(c-d).

![](images/c57c7212863a013fea5c44183a3d52c8e2f17c0e554f3aebb6ff6763ae7060e8.jpg)  
Fig.8.Nanohardness testing of SS316L with a load of $2 8 0 0 \mu \mathrm { N } ;$ (a) Indented regions, (b) nano-indentation profile,(c-d) hardnessand reduced modulus mapping

name: 2024 - J. Alloys and Compounds - Jeyaprakash et al. - Effect of microstructural evolution during melt pool formation on nano-mechanical-part-19
fileName: 2024 - J. Alloys and Compounds - Jeyaprakash et al. - Effect of microstructural evolution during melt pool formation on nano-mechanical.md
content: In some regions, the smooth curve was observed,due to the presence of transverse columnar grains.The occurrence of pop-in effects was due to the presence of cellular grains with a high resistance towards the indentation effect. On the other hand,imperfections like the balling effect and micro-pores can also cause pop-in effects.Therefore,it can be said that the pop-in effects,which served as a counterbalance to the indentation effects,were caused by the existence of cellular grain structure and the creation of defects [39].The stress state of nano-indentation is more complex than the uniaxial deformation condition.The red-coloured region in the hardness and reduced modulus mapping represents the strong cellular grains which possess a maximum hardness value of 6 GPa and a maximum reduced modulus of 22o GPa. Similarly,the yellow-coloured region shows the columnar transverse grains which represent the lessened modulus and nanohardness.So,the nominal nano-hardness value of $3 . 7 \ : \mathrm { G P a }$ with reduced modulus of 162.5 GPa was obtained in the LPBFed SS316L parts.

name: 2024 - J. Alloys and Compounds - Jeyaprakash et al. - Effect of microstructural evolution during melt pool formation on nano-mechanical-part-20
fileName: 2024 - J. Alloys and Compounds - Jeyaprakash et al. - Effect of microstructural evolution during melt pool formation on nano-mechanical.md
content:
The hardness values may also be impacted by microstructural flaws such as voids,balling,spattering and micro-pores.The use of optimal process settings helped get rid of the microstructural flaws [16].However,the laser's $3 0 0 \mathrm { ~ W ~ }$ power,the layers’ $5 0 \mu \mathrm { m }$ thickness and the hatches’ $0 . 1 3 \mathrm { m m }$ spacing in this study，all worked to lessen the microstructural flaws,as demonstrated by the microstructural analysis. However,a very few microstructural defects such as micro pores, segregated particles were observed during the OM analysis in the Fig. 4 and these defects also fluctuates the indentation effects.The mapping images substantiated the non-uniform formation of grains by the appearance of irregular red-coloured dots. Similarly,the yellow coloured region reflects the lack of resistance toward the indentation effects,primarily due to the soft nature of the austenite phase.

In terms of grain structure,the cellular grain structure showed improved hardness and resistance towards elastic deformation because of the strong structural integrity,and the transverse columnar structure displayed reduced hardness values which represented the absence of obstacles towards the indentation effects as well as lack of resistance towards elastic deformation [4O].The formation of the ferrite phase severely constrained the dislocation mobility.Furthermore,strain hardening occurred during the nano-hardness testing because of the increased dislocation density.Due to the numerous indentation at the designated area,the creep behaviour was noticed.Because this phenomenon causes some instability,it impacts hardness values [16].

name: 2024 - J. Alloys and Compounds - Jeyaprakash et al. - Effect of microstructural evolution during melt pool formation on nano-mechanical-part-21
fileName: 2024 - J. Alloys and Compounds - Jeyaprakash et al. - Effect of microstructural evolution during melt pool formation on nano-mechanical.md
content: The scratch and wear analyses were performed on the LPBFed SS316L parts to examine their resistance towards the plowing action. The 3D topographic images of the worn-out regions were examined for the depth of material removal,as shown in Fig.9(a-d).In this study, the horizontally printed SS316L parts were taken into account, because, the horizontal orientation exhibits greater wear resistance than parts with a vertical orientation [4l].For the scratch test,a load of $2 0 0 0 \mu \mathrm { N }$ was applied on the slider which slided ata distance of $1 0 \mu \mathrm { m }$ in five different regions at an interval of $5 \mu \mathrm { m }$ .Similarly,for the wear test,a load of $7 0 0 0 \mu \mathrm { N }$ was applied on the slider which slided ata distance of $1 0 ~ { \mu \mathrm { m } }$ in five different regions at an interval of $5 \mu \mathrm { m }$ .It was discovered that there was a plastic deformation at the beginning of the process.However, significant resistance toward the sliding action was observed during the testing.

name: 2024 - J. Alloys and Compounds - Jeyaprakash et al. - Effect of microstructural evolution during melt pool formation on nano-mechanical-part-22
fileName: 2024 - J. Alloys and Compounds - Jeyaprakash et al. - Effect of microstructural evolution during melt pool formation on nano-mechanical.md
content: The maximum worn-out depth of around —95 nm was observed on the wear tracks 1 and 3.This maximum worn-out depth was attained after three consecutive wear cycles.However,a deep plowing that indicated the removal of materials was seen after the third cycle.The spatial representation of the wear trails made this procedure very evident.Additionally,it was observed that there wasa fluctuation in the worn-out depth.These fluctuations are mostly brought on by the presence of a fusion of a cellular and columnar grains and microstructural flaws [28].Siqi et al.investigated the creep behaviour during the indentation testing. They noticed that, there is no tertiary stage [42]. Moreover, the microstructural evolution during the manufacturing process has a key role in influencing the mechanical properties and that was proven by Chen et al.[43] and Deng et al.[44].The pile-up of debris along the edges of the wear tracks also confirmed their resistance to plastic deformation [45].Based on the observation of the pile-up of materials around the edges,wear tracks1 and 3 possessed the maximum pile-up of around $1 1 5 . 9 5 \ : \mathrm { n m }$ .This observation confirmed the maximum removal of materials due to the presence of transverse columnar grains in that region [46].But,in the wear tracks 2,4 and 5,there was no noteworthy pile-up of materials around $4 5 . 5 9 \mathrm { n m }$ .This characteristic represented the occurrence of cellular grain structure,which reduced the material removal rate.This observation confirmed that the formation of cellular grain structure during the melt pool formation had a predominant resistance towards the wear and scratch effects.However, the noted pile-up of materials around the edges in the wear analysis was higher compared with the scratch analysis,since the load adopted during the testing was higher.Also the number of the repetitive cycles was more.Moreover,the scratch test was analysed only to understand the surface morphology.

name: 2024 - J. Alloys and Compounds - Jeyaprakash et al. - Effect of microstructural evolution during melt pool formation on nano-mechanical-part-23
fileName: 2024 - J. Alloys and Compounds - Jeyaprakash et al. - Effect of microstructural evolution during melt pool formation on nano-mechanical.md
content:
So,it did not require any higher load or repetitive cycles for investigation.As seen in Fig.1O (a-e),the lack of resistance to the plowing action caused the plowing duration to decrease consistently for each subsequent wear cycle.The consequence of the pile-up of more materials was also due to the ductile nature which was due to the presence of a soft austenite phase.

![](images/4ded51976d3fb257802006cd7f229aa254e3eb43cd647c6a207c914f2cefbd1d.jpg)  
Fig.9.Nanaalsed)adaiao wear track (c-d) SPM images displaying scratch and wear track length.

The maximum depth and pile-up on the surface were observed to be $- 2 8 . 2 3 \ : \mathrm { n m }$ and $5 1 . 1 6 \ \mathrm { n m }$ which was lower than the nano-wear analysis.Since the used loading value was lower than the wear analysis.This maximum removal rate was due to the occurrence of elongated grain boundaries.The presence of cellular and columnar grains were confirmed during the microstructural analysis which played a key role in providing resistance to scratch.The occurrence of cellular grains created high resistance to scratch and caused the minimum worn-out depth of $- 1 . 7 7 \ : \mathrm { n m }$ with a minimum pile-up of materials around $2 4 . 7 0 \ \mathrm { n m }$

On analyzing the scratch mechanism, the nano-indenter first penetrated the SS3l6L surface.Then, the sling action was performed after attaining a certain depth and that sliding action experienced fluctuations in their flow path. The lateral load fluctuated in the early plowing operation,but afterward,as shown in Fig.1O (al-el),it exhibited a smooth and consistent removal of materials.These fluctuations were due to the different grain boundary orientations.Local fractures,cracks or bends in the nano-indenter tips may happen due to such characteristics.

![](images/6d1c966154cbc4e719328ed01942986d45b7a7bb96077c8af31733e6cdcad2f0.jpg)  
ig

name: 2024 - J. Alloys and Compounds - Jeyaprakash et al. - Effect of microstructural evolution during melt pool formation on nano-mechanical-part-24
fileName: 2024 - J. Alloys and Compounds - Jeyaprakash et al. - Effect of microstructural evolution during melt pool formation on nano-mechanical.md
content: The SRS of the SS316L specimen was studied by performing the tensile test with three quasi-static strain rates $( \mathrm { E 1 } { : } \bar { 4 } . 1 \times 1 0 ^ { - 5 } \ \mathsf { s } ^ { - 1 }$ ， ${ \tt E } 2 { : } 2 . 0 8 \times 1 0 ^ { - 4 } \ s ^ { - 1 }$ and $\bar { \mathrm { E 3 } } { \cdot } 3 . 3 \times 1 0 ^ { - 4 } \ s ^ { - 1 } )$ .Fig.11 displays the engineering SS curves of the SS316L specimens.LPBFed SS316L tensile specimens before and after fracture are shown in Fig.l2. Results of the SRS analysis showed that the minimum SR of $4 . 1 \times 1 0 ^ { - 5 } s ^ { - 1 }$ possessed an enhanced tensile strength of $5 2 0 \mathrm { M P a }$ in addition with improved ductility, which was confirmed by the maximum elongation percentage of $3 7 \%$ .The observed strain rate sensitivity results display the negative strain rates.The negative strain rates represent that the tensile strength decreases with an increase in the Strain rates which was due to the increase in resistance to plastic deformation.Moreover, it was witnessed that,when the strain rate decreases,the tensile strength increases and the failure strain correspondingly decreases.This process was the result of strain hardening and heat softening working together.The elongated columnar grains in the LPBFed SS316L components were the cause of the ductile behaviour shown in the lower SRS analysis. Therefore, by adopting a reduced strain rate,this quasi-static situation induced the elastic nature.Furthermore,the dislocation motions were limited by the grains’cellular structure.Similarly,these cellular structured grains acted as the hindrance for the cracks propagation by arresting the interruptions. Subsequently,the higher SR led to the early failure in which the crack propagation reached the various stress-concentrated regions especially in the fusion lines [47]. It was clear that localization and necking followed softening.

name: 2024 - J. Alloys and Compounds - Jeyaprakash et al. - Effect of microstructural evolution during melt pool formation on nano-mechanical-part-25
fileName: 2024 - J. Alloys and Compounds - Jeyaprakash et al. - Effect of microstructural evolution during melt pool formation on nano-mechanical.md
content: However,as the strain rate increased, the behaviour changed from ductile to brittle,which in turn caused the elongation to drop.This resulted from the faster dislocation speed. During the higher strain rates,the stress concentration was higher in the defect region such as the balling effect and pores formation.So the propagation of cracks follows the defects formation which appears to be a brittle zone.The similar crack propagation along the stress field was experience by Fu et al.[48].The formation of dimples was visible when the strain rate was slow and constant,as seen in Fig.l2(a), because localization and necking both of which were brought on by the $4 . 1 \times 1 0 { - } 5 \ { s } ^ { - 1 }$ slow and steady strain rate caused the progressive dislocation movement. However,defect formation also plays a significant role in the fracture mechanics.Because the defect region acts as the stress-concentrated region in which the defect region initiates the crack propagation [49].

name: 2024 - J. Alloys and Compounds - Jeyaprakash et al. - Effect of microstructural evolution during melt pool formation on nano-mechanical-part-26
fileName: 2024 - J. Alloys and Compounds - Jeyaprakash et al. - Effect of microstructural evolution during melt pool formation on nano-mechanical.md
content:
The stress-concentrated area along the interface was where the fracture first appeared. Unmelted particles in the middle of consecutive were noted as shown in Fig.12 (b).These defect region might have operated as areas of concentrated stress,causing cracks,especially under high strain rate conditions.When the strain rate was multiplied by 5, cracks started to spread quickly. The emergence of cleavage facets denotes the brittle fracture and the evidence for the rapid propagation of cracks [5O].The presence of cellular grains contributed to the printed SS316L components'enhanced tensile strength at a lower strain rate by acting as a barrier to the propagation of fractures.However,when the strain rate increased,the stress concentration in the cellular grains increased and the cohesive force supplied by the columnar and cellular grains decreased relative to the applied tensile force.Similar to the originalcrack， thesubordinatecracksalsobegan atthe stress-concentrated region and traveled towards the initial crack that starts at the microstructural flaws.As a result, cracks spread quickly and clues to brittle fracture [Fig.12 (c)]. The Orowan process was reflected in this crack propagation phenomenon.It was also discovered that transgranular dimple rupture was triggered by keyholes {{{Fig.13}}}.

![](images/3809561a8712bac7dd0c2c5f46f9b34d287f7ee07224f5d12085b017348c297b.jpg)  
Fig.11.Stress-strain curve for LPBFed SS316L tensile specimens under various strain rates: $\operatorname { E 1 } { : 4 . 1 } \times 1 0 { - 5 } \ : s ^ { - 1 }$ ， $\mathtt { E 2 } { \cdot } 2 . 0 8 \times 1 0 ^ { - 4 } \ s { \cdot } 1$ $\mathrm { E } 3 { : } 3 . 3 \times 1 0 ^ { - 4 } \ : s ^ { - 1 }$

name: 2024 - J. Alloys and Compounds - Jeyaprakash et al. - Effect of microstructural evolution during melt pool formation on nano-mechanical-part-27
fileName: 2024 - J. Alloys and Compounds - Jeyaprakash et al. - Effect of microstructural evolution during melt pool formation on nano-mechanical.md
content: This investigation adopted the LPBF technique to print the SS316L parts.These fabricated parts were examined for microstructural orientation which was influenced during the melt pool formation.The effect of microstructural characteristics was examined.The conclusions drawn from the results are listed below:

name: 2024 - J. Alloys and Compounds - Jeyaprakash et al. - Effect of microstructural evolution during melt pool formation on nano-mechanical-part-28
fileName: 2024 - J. Alloys and Compounds - Jeyaprakash et al. - Effect of microstructural evolution during melt pool formation on nano-mechanical.md
content:
·The occurrence of ferrite phase at the crystal plane of (1lO) and austenite phase at the crystal planes of(111),(2oO),(22O)and(111) was confirmed by all the XRD results. The microstructural investigation revealed two types of grain orientations namely,the cellular dendrite structure and the transverse columnar elongated structure. Another interesting observation was that the grains looked orientated normally to the fusion lines' curvature and that the fusion line did not inhibit the growth of the grains.   
· The TEM analysis witnessed the occurrence of $\gamma$ austenite and EBSD analysis revealed the cellular and columnar grains and also confirmed the transverse columnar grain structures were oriented towards the $< 1 0 1 >$ direction.Moreover, due to the rapid cooling rate of the LPBF technique,there was no sufficient time to attain a homogenous microstructure.   
·The nano-hardness results reveal that the presence of a red-coloured region in the hardness and reduced modulus mapping represents the cellular grain structure which possesses a maximum hardness value of 6 GPa and a maximum reduced modulus of 22o GPa. Similarly, the yellow-coloured region shows the transverse columnar grain structure reflecting the minimum hardness and reduced modulus of $1 . 4 \ : \mathrm { G P a }$ and $1 0 5 . 8 \mathrm { G P a }$   
·Nanowear track 1 and 3 possessed a maximum pile-up of around $1 1 5 . 9 5 \mathrm { n m }$ ，This observation confirmed the maximum removal of materials,due to the presence of transverse columnar grains in that region. But,in the wear tracks 2,4 and 5,there was not any noteworthy pile-up of materials;it was around $4 5 . 5 9 \mathrm { n m }$ and endorsed the presence of the strong cellular grain structure.In the nanoscratch analysis,the minimum depth and pile-up of the worn-out surface was observed to be $\mathbf { - 2 8 . 2 3 n m }$ and $5 1 . 1 6 \ \mathrm { n m }$ which was lower than the nano-wear analysis.

# ARTICLEINFO
summary: The influence of deformation affected region on microstructure and mechanical property of 316L fabricated by hybrid additive-subtractive manufacturing

name: 2024 - J. Manufacturing Processes - Xu et al. - The influence of deformation affected region on microstructure and mechanical property o-part-2
fileName: 2024 - J. Manufacturing Processes - Xu et al. - The influence of deformation affected region on microstructure and mechanical property o.md
content:
# ABSTRACT
Keywords:   
316L stainless steel   
Hybrid additive-subtractive manufacturing   
Deformation-affected region   
Hardness   
Microstructure   
Mechanical property

The hybrid of additive manufacturing and subtractive manufacturing is promising in producing high-quality and high-accuracy parts made of hard-to-machine metallc materials with complex geometries.However,few studies have been conducted to analyze the influence of responses from subtractive manufacturing,especially the plastic deformation region induced by mechanical cutting,on the folowing additive manufacturing processes.This paper comprehensively investigates the impact of finishing miling on the mechanical properties and quality of 316L fabricated by hybrid additive-subtractive manufacturing.The whole manufacturing processconsisted of a two-stage micro selective laser melting $\mu { \mathrm { S L M } }$ process with three scanning speeds and one finishing milling process.Typical machining responses including phase，cuting force,surface roughness at different manufacturing stages were analyzed; the mechanisms of how the deformation-affected region induced in subtractive manufacturing process afects the microstructure,hardnes,and mechanical properties after the secondstage additive manufacturing were explored.Fine grains were formed after the second-stage $\mu { \mathrm { S L M } }$ in the connected region,because of the lower $\scriptstyle { \mathrm { G } } / { \mathrm { R } }$ ratio and the higher ${ \bf G } \times { \bf R }$ value,whereas the hardness in this region was lower than the bulk material consisting of coarse grains,caused by the thermal softening effect induced in mechanicalcutting.The elongation rate was increased due to the existence of the grain-boundary-rich connected region.

name: 2024 - J. Manufacturing Processes - Xu et al. - The influence of deformation affected region on microstructure and mechanical property o-part-3
fileName: 2024 - J. Manufacturing Processes - Xu et al. - The influence of deformation affected region on microstructure and mechanical property o.md
content: Additive manufacturing (AM) is a promising method in near-netshape fabrication of components made of hard-to-machine metals (e. g.,titanium alloys and nickel-based super alloys) with complex geometries [1]. Selective laser melting (SLM),electron beam melting (EBM), wire-arc additive manufacturing (WAAM) and direct energy deposition (DED) are the typical methods in additive manufacturing of metallic products [2].However,extensive post-processing is often required owing to the inaccurate geometric dimension and poor surface quality of the additively manufactured components [3]. For example, the surface roughness Ra of the parts fabricated by DED can be up to $6 0 ~ { \mu \mathrm { m } }$ due to the melting/reconsolidating of powders [4]; whereas in SLM,the powder spatter and balling effect during the melting/reconsolidating process may lead to defects such as pores and cracks,which eventually undermine the surface integrity of the products [5]. The severe spatter and balling on the solidified layer can also cause uneven distribution of powders on the powder bed or even the scraping-off of the powder, resulting in the termination of the printing process. Consequently,the coarse surfaces of the additively manufactured parts need to be machined during the post-processing process.This step is crucial and indispensable in ensuring the quality of the final products.

name: 2024 - J. Manufacturing Processes - Xu et al. - The influence of deformation affected region on microstructure and mechanical property o-part-4
fileName: 2024 - J. Manufacturing Processes - Xu et al. - The influence of deformation affected region on microstructure and mechanical property o.md
content: The advancement of additive-subtractive manufacturing (ASM) through specifically designed machine tools enables the synthesis of AM and conventional subtractive manufacturing (SM). This synthetization harnesses the strengths of both techniques,offering heightened flexibility,enhanced machining efficiency,and improved dimensional accuracy [6].The ASM can be divided into two categories [7]: sequential additive-subtractive manufacturing (SASM) and hybrid additivesubtractive manufacturing (HASM). In SASM, components are initially produced using additive manufacturing to achieve near-net-shape, followed by finish cutting processes such as turning and milling to meet surface roughness and dimensional requirements.On the other hand,in the HAsM process,machining operations are alternatively conducted and are integrated in the additive manufacturing process. One of the primary goals is to eliminate severely deteriorated surfaces and ensure the continuity of subsequent printing.
