name: 2024 - J. Manufacturing Processes - Xu et al. - The influence of deformation affected region on microstructure and mechanical property o-part-6
fileName: 2024 - J. Manufacturing Processes - Xu et al. - The influence of deformation affected region on microstructure and mechanical property o.md
content: The current studies on ASM are mainly focused on the processing window of additive manufacturing and its effects on the machinability of the printed workpieces such as cuttng force, temperature,surface roughness and tool wear [8] in comparison with wrought, forged or cast materials. Salvi et al.[9] compared the machinability of IN625 fabricated by AM and wrought,and found that wrought IN625 consumed more power than AMed IN625 due to the higher tool wear rate. The higher thermal conductivity of AMed IN625 resulted in a $1 9 1 . 5 5 \ \%$ increase in tool life.In the studies of Kallel et al.[1O,11],Ti6Al4V fabricated by direct metal deposition (DMD) was finished by high speed milling. Compared with its wrought counterparts,the DMDed material resulted in a $1 0 { - } 4 0 ~ \%$ increase in cutting forces and higher roughness because of the more significant ploughing and rubbing effects.In the study of Val et al. [12], it was found that the surface roughness of Invar 36 fabricated by WAAM after milling was lower, compared with that of the wrought material.However, the milling forces were higher in the machining of the WAAMed workpiece due to the higher hardness. Montevecchi et al.[13] compared cutting forces in the milling of AISIH13 materials fabricated by laser engineered net shaping (LENS), WAAM and the as-received workpiece.The hardness of WAAM and LENS are 55 HRC and 59 HRC,which were significantly higher than that of the wrought parts (19 HRC).Therefore,the cutting forces and cutting coefficients show a general increase when machining the AMed workpieces,indicating the poor machinability of AM parts. Ding et al. [14] found that the angle and width of tearing streaks of chips in milling DEDed 316L was wider because the improved mechanical properties limited the plastic deformation of the workpiece material.Bai et al.[15] conducted a study on the machinability of DEDed ASTM A131 stainless steel.

name: 2024 - J. Manufacturing Processes - Xu et al. - The influence of deformation affected region on microstructure and mechanical property o-part-7
fileName: 2024 - J. Manufacturing Processes - Xu et al. - The influence of deformation affected region on microstructure and mechanical property o.md
content: It was found the boundaries of the melt pools hinders the plastic deformation of the workpiece materials,leading to higher cutting force. Bonaiti et al.[16] found that as the hardness of DEDed Ti6Al4V increases, the milling force gradually increases,and the DEDed workpieces are more prone to generate serrated chips,compared with conventional forged materials.Oyelola et al.[17] utilized heat treatments to homogenize the microstructure of DEDed Ti6Al4V，enhancing the machinability.The results presented the $4 0 \%$ reduction in cutting forces in the beta condition and a $2 4 ~ \%$ reduction in the alpha condition at a low machining speed of $5 0 \ \mathrm { m / m i n }$ ，whereas the compressive stress on the machined surface exhibited a $2 2 ~ \%$ increase. Guo et al. [18] investigated the cutting of AMed 316L and found that the cuting responses were influenced by cutting directions.The anisotropy of the dendritic microstructure in the printing direction caused higher hardness than that in the scanning direction, therefore,the cutting forces were larger when cutting along the printing direction.Alonso et al.[19] investigated the machinability of Inconel 718 made of WAAM. They found that higher cutting speeds $( \ge 6 0 \ \mathrm { m / m i n } )$ were preferred,contributing to better surface roughness and lower torque of the main spindle.Additionally,milling along the torch's travel direction demonstrated better dimensional tolerance values and lower cutting torques compared to machining in the building direction.Lizzul et al.[2O] investigated the influence of $\alpha$ -grain boundaries (αGB) on the development of tool wear in micro-milling AMed Ti6Al4V.

name: 2024 - J. Manufacturing Processes - Xu et al. - The influence of deformation affected region on microstructure and mechanical property o-part-8
fileName: 2024 - J. Manufacturing Processes - Xu et al. - The influence of deformation affected region on microstructure and mechanical property o.md
content: It was found that the tool life decreased gradually to $4 0 ~ \%$ when the inclination angle of the αGB layer was increased from $0 ^ { \circ }$ to $9 0 ^ { \circ }$ because the αGB layers represented a discontinuity of the microstructure and a weak point that eased the development of cracks caused by the cutting force [21].Bordinassi etal.[22] found that the higher laser energy density in the AM process led to longer cooling time of the melt pool, resulting in reduced residual stress. In the following cutting process,the residual stress transitioned from compressive to tensile states due to elevated cutting temperature.

name: 2024 - J. Manufacturing Processes - Xu et al. - The influence of deformation affected region on microstructure and mechanical property o-part-9
fileName: 2024 - J. Manufacturing Processes - Xu et al. - The influence of deformation affected region on microstructure and mechanical property o.md
content: Although the machinability of alloys fabricated by different AM methods has been comprehensively investigated from different aspects, most of the findings were made based on SASM.The role of mechanical cutting in HASM and the influence induced by conventional cutting on the quality of parts after the completion of the entire HASM process are seldomly explored.The quality of the machined surface and the deformation affected region beneath the machined surface can influence the subsequent AM process.Specifically,the roughness of the machined surface due to the ploughing effect or the surface defects such as dimples and scratches caused by the plucking of insufficiently-melted materials could impact the bedding of the powder,and eventually affect the quality of the printed parts.In the cutting process,the deformationaffected region,which comprises hardening and softening regions,are formed by the high temperature and workpiece distortion.Near the machined surface,the hardness is significantly higher than that of the bulk workpiece.This high hardness is attributed to the nanoscale grain refinement which is the result of severe plastic deformation at low cutting speeds or phase transformation at high cutting speeds [23]. Underneath the hardening region lies the softening area,where the impact of thermal softening outweighs work hardening.In this area, the elongation of the grains could be found,and the hardness in this area was lower than that of the bulk material [24].

name: 2024 - J. Manufacturing Processes - Xu et al. - The influence of deformation affected region on microstructure and mechanical property o-part-10
fileName: 2024 - J. Manufacturing Processes - Xu et al. - The influence of deformation affected region on microstructure and mechanical property o.md
content: Currently,there are limited studies on the influences of surface roughness and deformation-affected region on the quality of ASMed parts.Rotella et al.[25] investigated the affected regions in cutting Ti6Al4V alloy fabricated by EBM and Direct Metal Laser Sintering (DMLS).The thickness of the regions increased with the increase of cutting speed,and the affected layer thickness of the EBMed partswas the largest, followed by the DMLSed parts when compared with the wrought workpiece.Dang et al. [26] analyzed the deformation regions formed in drilling DMLSed Ti6Al4V.Similar to the results of Rotella et al.,it was found that the thickness of the metamorphic layer was larger at higher spindle speeds because the ploughing-pulling effect of the cuting tool was significant at higher cuting speeds,and secondary shear plastic deformation was induced beneath the machined surface [27].Studies of influences of the deformation-affected region on the following AM processes are scarce.In the study of Chen etal. [28],finish milling was applied during the gas tungsten arc welding (GTAW)of TC4, and it was found that the hardness increased at the regions used to be the hardening zones.This phenomenon was explained by the formation of smaller $\beta$ grains and the increased proportion of $\leq 1 5 \mu \mathrm { m } \alpha$ grains in the following AM process,and this grain refinement also improved the ultimate strength of the HASMed material. Similar mechanism was revealed in the study of Ren et al.[29], which was about manufacturing Inconel 738 by hybrid SLM and high-speed milling.The experimental results show that the mix of slender and fine grains was found at the AM/ SM interface,which relieved the residual stress induced by the highspeed milling.Lee et al.[3O] investigated the influence of part deformation on residual stress in HASMed SS316L by using finite element method.

name: 2024 - J. Manufacturing Processes - Xu et al. - The influence of deformation affected region on microstructure and mechanical property o-part-11
fileName: 2024 - J. Manufacturing Processes - Xu et al. - The influence of deformation affected region on microstructure and mechanical property o.md
content:
Thay discovered that the part exhibited a pattern of tensilecompression alternation,which was attributed to the combination of deposit shrinkage,solid constraint,and stress balancing due to the subtractive manufacturing.However,work hardening and phase transformation were neglected in the modelling process.He et al.[31] manufactured 316L stainless steel thin-wall through HASM,and found that there was a significant tensile stress at the junction of AM and SM. The stress first decreased and then increased with the ongoing of the HASM.In addition， the compressive stress generated by milling balanced the initial residual tensile stress of the AM. Gong et al. [32] discovered that the high density and fine grains of the HASMed material were the primary factors contributing to the increases in hardness, tensile strength,and ductility.

From above studies,it can be summarized that the coupled influence of additive manufacturing and subtractive manufacturing on the cuting responses and overall mechanical properties is still limited,and the fundamental mechanism on the evolution of the microstructures HASMed materials needs to be analyzed in-deep to further expand the knowledge on HASM.In this study,316L stainless steel was manufactured by a hybrid approach which combines a two-stage micro selective laser melting $\mathbf { ( \mu S L M ) }$ and a finish milling process.In addition to the conventional machining responses which include phases,surface morphology and cutting forces,the effects of work hardening on the evolution of microstructure,hardness,and mechanical properties at the re-AMed regions were investigated. The findings of this study will not only contribute insights into the fundamental aspects of additivesubtractive manufacturing,but also provide essential knowledge for the optimal integration of additive manufacturing and conventional cutting processes in industrial applications.

name: 2024 - J. Manufacturing Processes - Xu et al. - The influence of deformation affected region on microstructure and mechanical property o-part-12
fileName: 2024 - J. Manufacturing Processes - Xu et al. - The influence of deformation affected region on microstructure and mechanical property o.md
content: The fabrication of the HASMed 316L was through an additivesubtractive-additive manufacturing process to investigate the evolution of phases, micromorphology and mechanical properties at different manufacturing stages.The scheme of the entire manufacturing process is presented in Fig.1. Specifically, the workpieces were printed via the $\mu { \bf S L M }$ to a certain height, then the top layer of the printed workpiece was removed by finish milling; after the milling process, the second-stage $\mu { \bf S L M }$ process continued,and the workpiece was eventually printed to the designed geometry. The $\mu { \bf S L M }$ used in the experiments is a threedimensional SLM machine (HANS M1oO),which can provide a laser power of up to $5 0 0 \mathrm { W }$ and a laser beam with the spot diameter of $2 5 \mu \mathrm { m }$ During the SLM process,the printing chamber was protected by circulating argon gas,and the fraction of oxygen was maintained below 1000 ppm in order to limit the large-scale spattering and uneven melt pool due to the excessive oxidation. The raw powder used in $\mu { \bf S L M }$ was gasatomized 316L spherical particles with an average particle size of around $1 5 \ \mu \mathrm { m } ,$ 、as shown in Fig.2.The chemical composition of the powder,obtained through Energy Dispersive Spectrometer (EDS),is shown in Fig.2b.Before the experiment, the powder was dried in a vacuum furnace at ${ \bf 1 1 0 ^ { \circ } C } , \quad$ , ensuring the good fluidity of the powder and reducing spattering in the bedding of $\mu { \mathrm { S L M } }$ .Fig.3 illustrates the laser scanning strategy.The powder within the powder bed was melted by the scanning of the laser beam along the Xaxis,and the scanning direction turned anti-clockwise by $9 0 ^ { \circ }$ in printing the following layer to reduce the deformation caused by thermal stres. SLM parameters including laser power,scanning speed, hatch spacing and thickness per layer are listed in Table 1.
summary: 2. The ASHM process for manufacturing 316L - Part 1/5

name: 2024 - J. Manufacturing Processes - Xu et al. - The influence of deformation affected region on microstructure and mechanical property o-part-14
fileName: 2024 - J. Manufacturing Processes - Xu et al. - The influence of deformation affected region on microstructure and mechanical property o.md
content:
For each type of sample,two workpieces of different dimensions were fabricated: the cross sectional area of $2 0 \ \mathrm { m m } \times 2 0 \ \mathrm { m m }$ and the height of $5 0 \mathrm { m m }$ in the printing direction; the cross sectional area of 20 $\mathrm { m m } \times 5 0 \mathrm { m m }$ and the height of $2 0 ~ \mathrm { m m }$ in the printing direction.After the height of the workpiece reached $2 5 \mathrm { m m }$ and $1 0 \mathrm { m m }$ ,respectively,a $1 \mathrm { m m }$ -thick layer on the top surface was removed by milling using the finishing cutting parameters shown in Table 2 in order to eliminate splatters and spheroidization.The milling experiment was conducted on a CNC milling machine (VDL-6ooA) using a $3 \mathrm { m m }$ three-flute flat end mill with AlTiN coating. Cutting forces were measured via a three-axis piezoelectric dynamometer (YDl5-II)，and the morphology and roughness of the top surface before/after milling were characterized by the laser confocal microscope (KEYENCE-VHX-7OoO).Ra,which was the average of five-time measurements at randomly-selected positions,was used to quantify the surface roughness for every sample.After the milling process,the parts were additively manufactured into the designed dimensions with the same parameters listed in Table 1,and then machined into the dog-bone shape of standard tensile test specimens by wire EDM (WEDM) for tension testing. These specimens were tested in tension along the printing direction and perpendicular to the printing direction (Fig.4),respectively,to investigate the influences of the deformation-affected region on the mechanical properties of the materials in different directions.

The characterization of the microstructure was implemented on the processed samples.The workpieces machined by $\mu { \mathrm { S L M } }$ ,SASM,HASM were sliced via WEDM.The cross sections were ground by metallographic sandpaper,and polished with alumina abrasives on a polishing machine for5 min into the mirror-like finish.Then,the polished surfaces were etched in aqua regia solution (the mix of HCl and HNO3 with the 3:1 volume fraction),5 s per sample,and were cleaned by water and industrial ethanol $( \geq 9 5 \% )$ to prevent the influence of water gloss during drying. The microstructure was observed using a field emission scanning electron microscope (Hitachi UHR FE-SEM SU8OoO).The software Image-pro plus (IPP) was used to evaluate dimensions of the melt pools in SEM images.The hardness at different regions was measured with a micro-Vickers hardness tester (HVS-1oooA),and the measurements were implemented at the load of $0 . 2 \mathrm { k g }$ with the dwell time of $_ { 1 5 s }$

name: 2024 - J. Manufacturing Processes - Xu et al. - The influence of deformation affected region on microstructure and mechanical property o-part-17
fileName: 2024 - J. Manufacturing Processes - Xu et al. - The influence of deformation affected region on microstructure and mechanical property o.md
content:
3.1. Conventional machining responses after different machining stages

Fig.5 shows the morphology of the top surface after the first-stage $\mu \mathrm { S L M }$ process and the subsequent milling process.It is obvious that the surface after $\mu { \bf S L M }$ was uneven due to unmelted powders and the splatter of spheroidization.Spheroidization is the solidification of metal powder into a spherical shape under the action of surface tension during melting,or the splashing of liquid metal into unmelted powder,and the splatter of spheroidization can be caused by the lateral shielding gas flow,melt pool fluctuations,and the vapor recoil pressure.The blow of the internal vapor is the main driving force for the occurrence of splatter during the SLM processes. Under the irradiation of the high-energy laser, the 316L metal powder uniformly reaches the melting point of temperature $\mathrm { T } _ { \mathrm { m } } ,$ and forms the melt pools.The excessive energy inevitably causes the powder to rapidly reach the boiling point $\mathrm { T _ { b } }$ and generates 316L metal vapor or plasma plume [34].As shown in Figs. 5(a) to (c), the surface splatter significantly decreases with the increase of scanning speed.This is because,at scanning speeds of $8 0 0 \ \mathrm { m m } / s$ and $9 0 0 \ \mathrm { m m } / s ,$ the speed of the moving melt pool could exceed the speed of the splatter, thus trapping the droplets within the melt pool [35].However, the energy absorption at a higher scanning speed was insuficient, which aggravates the unmelted powders on the machined surface,as can be seen in Figs. 5(b) and (c).

name: 2024 - J. Manufacturing Processes - Xu et al. - The influence of deformation affected region on microstructure and mechanical property o-part-18
fileName: 2024 - J. Manufacturing Processes - Xu et al. - The influence of deformation affected region on microstructure and mechanical property o.md
content: After milling,the surface quality has been significantlyimproved due to the removal of the unmelted powders and spherical solidification, as indicated by the significantly reduced surface roughness which are $2 \mu \mathrm m$ to $3 ~ \mu \mathrm { m }$ ,as shown in Fig.6(b).However,voids were found on the machined surface,and it was the major defects aftermilling,attributable to the flaws during the first-stage $\mu { \mathrm { S L M } }$ process.Additionally, the distribution of voids varies with different scanning speeds.At the scanning speeds of $7 0 0 \ \mathrm { m m } / s$ and $9 0 0 \ \mathrm { m m } / s$ ,more internal voids are presented, as shown in Figs.5(d) and (f).This occurs because excessive heat within the melted pool tends to be accumulated at the lower scanning speeds, making it difficult for the heat to dissipate,leading to the formation of bubbles and resulting in voids during solidification. Conversely,when the scanning speed is high,the laser beam impacts each position for a shorter duration,and if the heat inside the melted pool is not sufficient to melt the powder,voids could be formed due to the gaps between the raw particles and the reconsolidated materials.Moreover,the laser shock at higher scanning speed could repel the insufficiently melted powders,causing voids on the printed surface [36].

name: 2024 - J. Manufacturing Processes - Xu et al. - The influence of deformation affected region on microstructure and mechanical property o-part-19
fileName: 2024 - J. Manufacturing Processes - Xu et al. - The influence of deformation affected region on microstructure and mechanical property o.md
content: The cutting forces along the three axes in the finish milling of Samples A,B and C are presented in Fig.7.It can be seen that the forces for Sample A $( 7 0 0 \mathrm { m m } / s )$ and Sample C $( 9 0 0 \mathrm { m m } / s )$ are slightly lower than those for Sample B,and this can be attributed to a higher proportion of internal voids which reduces the local relative density of the materials. However, the differences among the cutting forces are not pronounced, indicating the similar yield and ultimate strength of the three materials. Figs.7(d) to (g) are the frequency-domain spectrums of the X,Y and Z cutting forces processed by Fast Fourier Transformation (FFT).Specifically, larger amplitudes were found at $7 5 \mathrm { H z } ,$ which is the frequency of the spindle,and $2 2 5 ~ \mathrm { H z }$ ，which is the frequency of cutting,and their high-order harmonics.The cutting/spindle frequencies of Sample B are larger because of the higher cutting force in the time-domain signals. Compared with the spectrum of Sample A，the high frequency components of X( $7 0 0 \mathrm { H z }$ to $1 2 0 0 \mathrm { H z }$ andZ( $2 1 0 0 \mathrm { H z }$ to $2 8 0 0 \mathrm { H z }$ forces are stronger in milling Sample Band Sample C. This is because the larger holes inside the samples (Figs. 5(e) and (f)) change the instantaneous cutting depth in the milling process,causing high-frequency vibration in the tool/workpiece system in the X and Z directions.

name: 2024 - J. Manufacturing Processes - Xu et al. - The influence of deformation affected region on microstructure and mechanical property o-part-20
fileName: 2024 - J. Manufacturing Processes - Xu et al. - The influence of deformation affected region on microstructure and mechanical property o.md
content: 316L is the austenitic stainless steel consisting of $\gamma$ -Fe and δ-Fe,and the proportion of the phases is influenced by the chromium equivalent $\mathrm { ( C r _ { \mathrm { e q } } ) }$ and nickel equivalent $\mathrm { ( N i _ { e q } ) }$ ,as shown in Fig.8(a). According to the chemical composition of the raw powder (Fig.1(b)),the calculated $\mathrm { C r } _ { \mathrm { e q } }$ and $\mathrm { N i _ { e q } }$ were $1 9 . 4 ~ \%$ and $1 4 . 7 ~ \%$ ，and this indicates the phase composition of the material power was $\gamma$ -austenite and δ-ferrite,which is in consistence with the results of XRD examination (Fig.8(b)).The XRD spectrums of the samples after different stages of HAsM are presented in Fig.9.Typically,the SLMed 316L stainless steel primarily forms austenite,with a small amount of ferrite being produced at grain boundaries,when the ratio of $\mathrm { C r } _ { \mathrm { e q } }$ to $\mathrm { N i _ { e q } }$ is $< 1 . 4 8$ [14,37]. However, the samples obtained by $\mu { \bf S L M }$ consist of FCC $\gamma$ -austenite,and the disappear of the ferrite peaks indicates that the δ phase had completely transformed into $\gamma$ -austenite.The differences inrelative peakintensities between the raw powders and $\mu { \sf S L M e d }$ 316L could be attributed to the presence of crystallographic textures [38].The formation of the $\gamma$ phase is influenced by the cooling rate and the ratio of chromium equivalent $\mathrm { ( C r _ { \mathrm { e q } } ) }$ to nickel equivalent $\mathrm { ( N i _ { e q } ) }$ : the high cooling rate or the low $\mathrm { C r _ { e q } / }$ $\mathrm { N i _ { e q } }$ ratio facilitates the formation of $\gamma$ -austenite [39]. The minor difference in the $\gamma$ -austenite peaks among the samples means that the heating was sufficient,and the cooling was steady within the melt pools at the three scanning speeds due to the micron-sized laser spot.
summary: 3.2. Phase analysis after different manufacturing stages - Part 1/4

name: 2024 - J. Manufacturing Processes - Xu et al. - The influence of deformation affected region on microstructure and mechanical property o-part-21
fileName: 2024 - J. Manufacturing Processes - Xu et al. - The influence of deformation affected region on microstructure and mechanical property o.md
content: The dry milling process did not cause any phase transformation or the formation of new phases.Although,in some studies [39],the transformation from austenite to martensite were identified in cutting cast $3 1 6 \mathrm { L }$ ，it was ascribed to the high Cr fraction $( \approx 1 8 \% )$ and low Ni fraction $( \leq 1 1 \% )$ ,as low nickel content is known to reduce the stacking fault energy of the austenitic phase and stimulated the transformation from austenite to martensite at high cutting temperature.In contrast,for the $\mu { \mathrm { S L M e d } }$ 316L,the high Ni fraction stabilized the austenite,and the cutting temperature was relatively low $( \approx 4 2 \ \mathrm { m / m i n } )$ which limited the formation of martensite.
summary: 3.2. Phase analysis after different manufacturing stages - Part 2/4

name: 2024 - J. Manufacturing Processes - Xu et al. - The influence of deformation affected region on microstructure and mechanical property o-part-22
fileName: 2024 - J. Manufacturing Processes - Xu et al. - The influence of deformation affected region on microstructure and mechanical property o.md
content: Fig. 9(c) shows the phases of 316L after HASM. Specifically,while no new phases are formed,the new peaks of $\gamma$ -austenite emerge,and the $\gamma$ -austenite peaks shift towards higher angles.The intensity of the (200) phase peak $( 2 \theta = 5 0 . 8 ^ { \circ } )$ ）significantly increases after HAsM, indicating that the (2oo) plane is the preferred growth direction. Yakout et al. [40] discovered that ata high energy density $( \mathrm { E p } = 1 5 6 . 3 )$ ,the preferred orientation of SLMed 316L was the (2oO) plane.The growth direction of the cubic material on the (2oo) plane becomes pronounced with the increase of energy density.Furthermore,the (111) $( 2 \theta = 4 4 ^ { \circ }$ peaksare evident in the parts after millng and the whole HASM process,indicating the preferred growth direction of the $\gamma$ -austenite.The variation of the peaks after the consecutive $\mu { \bf S L M }$ process can be attributed to crystal size effects or the lattice distortion caused by stress.In the milling process,the facial grains experienced high-strain-rate plastic deformation,which creates a work hardening region on the machined surface and contributes to defects and distortions in the crystal lattice within/ around this region.Also,impurities such as the adhered hard particles (carbides from the cutting tool or from the released build-up edge) introduced during machining can also cause crystal lattice distortions. Crystal lattice distortions change the lattice constants of the crystal and the scattering behavior of the X-ray,causing the shift of the peak.When the grain size was smaller than the wavelength of the incident X-rays, the crystal size effect occurs,and the scattering behavior of X-rays is limited,causing an overall shift of the phase peaks towards higher angles [41].The work hardening on the milled surface not only affects the phase composition of the material, but also influences the microstructure and mechanical properties.
summary: 3.2. Phase analysis after different manufacturing stages - Part 3/4

name: 2024 - J. Manufacturing Processes - Xu et al. - The influence of deformation affected region on microstructure and mechanical property o-part-24
fileName: 2024 - J. Manufacturing Processes - Xu et al. - The influence of deformation affected region on microstructure and mechanical property o.md
content:
The microstructure of the workpiece after the first-stage $\mu { \mathrm { S L M } }$ is shown in Fig.1O.The cellular grains and columnar grains at micro level were found within the melt pool,which is the typical microstructure of the SLMed 316L [42].The formation of grain categories are related to the ratio between the thermal gradient G and the solidification rate R. Columnar grains are formed at higher $\scriptstyle { \mathrm { G } } / { \mathrm { R } }$ ratio,and grow in the direction of the maximum heat flow (center of the melt pool),as shown in Fig.10.The growth of the columnar grains spans through multiple layers,as shown in Figs.1O(a)-(c). This is due to the influence of adjacent melt pools on solidified melt pools,which promote the growth of columnar grains across the pool boundary and into the solidified melt pool.At lower scanning speeds,the honeycomb structure consisting of fine-sized cellular grains was formed at the boundary of the melt pool (Fig. $\mathbf { 1 0 } ( \mathbf { a } _ { 1 } ) )$ . The size of the grains $( d )$ in SLM is related to the cooling rate $\varepsilon _ { \scriptscriptstyle \mathrm { ( } }$ ,which can be estimated with the following equation [43]:

$$
d = m { \cdot } \varepsilon ^ { - n } = m { \cdot } ( G \times R ) ^ { - n }
$$

The cooling rate of the melt pool can be presented by the $\scriptstyle { \frac { \Delta T } { \Delta t } } ,$ as the following equation [32]:

$$
\varepsilon = \frac { \Delta T } { \Delta t } = \frac { A P V ^ { 1 / 2 } } { D ^ { \frac { 5 } { 2 } } \left( 2 \rho _ { r } C K \right) ^ { 1 / 2 } } = \frac { A E _ { p } H T \nu ^ { 3 / 2 } } { D ^ { \frac { 5 } { 2 } } \left( 2 \rho _ { r } C K \right) ^ { 1 / 2 } }
$$
summary: 3.3.Microstructure and the distribution of hardness - Part 1/6

name: 2024 - J. Manufacturing Processes - Xu et al. - The influence of deformation affected region on microstructure and mechanical property o-part-25
fileName: 2024 - J. Manufacturing Processes - Xu et al. - The influence of deformation affected region on microstructure and mechanical property o.md
content:
According to Eqs.(2)& (3),considering the density is constant within the single melt pool,the cooling rate is only related to the scanning speed.Therefore,the size of the grains decreases with increase of the cooling rate,equivalent to increase of the scanning speed.At the higher scanning speed,the number of columnar grains increases significantly,whereas the grain size gradually decreases.This phenomenon can be explained by the increase of both thermal gradient and solidification rate at the higher scanning speed, which increases cooling rate $\mathbf { G } \times \mathbf { R }$ [44].Furthermore,with the increase of scanning speed, the depth and width of the melt pool decrease,as shown in Fig.l2. The width of the melt pool D can be calculated with the following model [45]:

$$
D = \sqrt { \frac { 8 \lambda P } { \pi e \rho _ { r } C V ( T _ { m } - T _ { 0 } ) } } = \sqrt { \frac { 8 \lambda E _ { p } H T } { \pi e \rho _ { r } C ( T _ { m } - T _ { 0 } ) } }
$$

The increase of scanning speed reduces the energy input per unit area,leading to the reduction in the width of the melt pool.
summary: 3.3.Microstructure and the distribution of hardness - Part 2/6

name: 2024 - J. Manufacturing Processes - Xu et al. - The influence of deformation affected region on microstructure and mechanical property o-part-26
fileName: 2024 - J. Manufacturing Processes - Xu et al. - The influence of deformation affected region on microstructure and mechanical property o.md
content: After milling,the deformation-affected layer consists of a hardening region,which appears bright when observed through the microscope (referred to as the“white layer"),and a dark softening region (known as the “dark layer") on the machined surface.The formation of the white layeris mainly due to the mechanical grainrefinement at the interface between the primary shear zone and the cutting edge.According to Figs. 11 and 14(a), a $1 0 \ \mu \mathrm { m }$ region is formed,and the microhardness of the milled surface is about $5 0 \mathrm { H V }$ higher than that of the bulk workpiece. The asymmetric indenting mark also reflects the variation of the hardness from the hardening region to the softening region (Fig.15(b)).In the hardening region, the dimension of the indentation was smaller than the bulk material (Fig.15(a)),and the size of the indentation became larger in the softening region.The nanocrystallization caused by the high-strain rate shear deformation is the major mechanism for the increase in hardness on the machined surface [29].In Fig.11,the pool boundaries are discernible,whereas the growth of the fine columnar grains is not obvious;a high density of nanoscale pores,which is the microscopic defects caused by large-strain plastic deformation,can be found within the hardening regions.The softening region is evident with the range of approx. $3 0 \mu \mathrm { m }$ ,the hardness of which is about $1 2 \mathrm { H V }$ lower than that of the bulk workpiece.In this region, the influence of thermal softening overweighs the effect of work hardening[23],and the slightly lower hardness of the Sample A indicates that the thermal effect in the mechanical cutting was more obvious.
summary: 3.3.Microstructure and the distribution of hardness - Part 3/6

name: 2024 - J. Manufacturing Processes - Xu et al. - The influence of deformation affected region on microstructure and mechanical property o-part-27
fileName: 2024 - J. Manufacturing Processes - Xu et al. - The influence of deformation affected region on microstructure and mechanical property o.md
content:
The deformation region not only changed the hardness distribution near the machined surface,but also influence the consecutive $\mu { \bf S L M }$ process.As shown in Figs.l2 and 13, there is an over $2 0 \%$ decrease in both the width and depth of the melt pool in the additive-subtractive junction areas.The high hardness in the hardening region and the compressive stress at the solid/liquid boundary could prohibit the expansion of the volume of the melt pool [46].Furthermore,according to Eq.(4),the size of the melt pool is inversely correlated to the density. Generally, the density of the AMed materials is smaller than that of the wrought counterparts because of the existence of the pores and voids caused by the insufficient melting of the powder or rapid solidification of the melt pool [23].In comparison, the local relative density of the material in the deformation region is larger because the severe distortion of the workpiece due to work hardening can eliminate the micropores produced in AM.After the second-stage $\mu { \mathrm { S L M } }$ ,the dimension of the melt pools within the connection region (used to be the deformation region) significantly (Fig.13) reduced,which reduced the cooling rate and eventually stimulated the refine of the cellular grains.

![](images/5d3eb0cd5152c0870f8db14822676625ab5a66f0ad5ad3a0515c808bf51ad5c4.jpg)  
Fig.10. The microstructure of SLMed area. (a) Sample A; (b) Sample B; (c) Sample C.
summary: 3.3.Microstructure and the distribution of hardness - Part 4/6

name: 2024 - J. Manufacturing Processes - Xu et al. - The influence of deformation affected region on microstructure and mechanical property o-part-28
fileName: 2024 - J. Manufacturing Processes - Xu et al. - The influence of deformation affected region on microstructure and mechanical property o.md
content:
Figs.l2(a) to (c) present the microstructure of the samples after the HASM. The columnar crystal can grow through the regions where used to be the deformation affected regions,and even across multiple melt pools;a significant number of nanoscale cellular grains and a small amount of fine columnar grains are found in the additive-subtractive connected area.Due to the energy distribution of the Gaussian laser beam,the higher migration rate of grain boundaries stimulates the formation of cellular grains in the high-temperature region,whereas the formation of columnar grains is favorable at the lower migration rate of the grain boundaries [47]. Because the thermal conductivity of metals with high hardness is higher than that of materials with low-hardness [48],the temperature rise in the hardening regions was larger than that in the bulk workpiece,facilitating the formation of more nanoscale cellular grains in this region,as shown in Figs. $\mathbf { 1 2 ( a _ { 1 } ) }$ and $\left( \mathbf { c } _ { 1 } \right)$ .In addition,it can be observed that fine grains in cellular structure are mainly distributed at the boundaries of the melt pool,which indicates the lower $\scriptstyle { \mathrm { G } } / { \mathrm { R } }$ ratio and the higher $\mathbf { G } \times \mathbf { R }$ value in this region.

![](images/a7d9c6f703d1f204e3c5c8552c98d83a7ad9837114a7e25ef4a8a807ffe198f8.jpg)  
Fig.11.The microstructure of SMed area. (a) Sample A; (b) Sample B; (c) Sample C.
summary: 3.3.Microstructure and the distribution of hardness - Part 5/6

name: 2024 - J. Manufacturing Processes - Xu et al. - The influence of deformation affected region on microstructure and mechanical property o-part-29
fileName: 2024 - J. Manufacturing Processes - Xu et al. - The influence of deformation affected region on microstructure and mechanical property o.md
content: However,the formation of the nano-sized cellular structure did not lead to the increase in hardness,which is different from the mechanism of grain refinement in work hardening or the refined grains strengthening.It was reported in the study of Fu etal.[49] that the hardness of the micron laser PBFed materials was smaller due to the existence of the small-sized cellular structure.This could be ascribed to the formation of the new heat-afected zone (HAZ） caused by the following $\mu \mathrm { S L M }$ process,which affected the distribution of the hardness.As shown in Fig.15(c),the indentation length in the region with larger cellular structures is $1 8 \ \mu \mathrm { m }$ ，whereas the the indentation length in the region with smaller cellular structures is $2 1 \ \mu \mathrm { m } .$ ,and it explained the reduction in this region.The reductions of hardness in the connecting regions of the three scanning speeds are different.At the scanning speed of 700 $\mathrm { m m } / s$ ,the decrease in hardness of the HAZ was $5 0 \mathrm { H V }$ ,and the range of the HAZ was $8 0 \mu \mathrm { m }$ ,both of which were larger than those of the samples at $8 0 0 \ \mathrm { m m } / s$ and $9 0 0 \ \mathrm { m m } / s$ .On one hand,more energy was accumulated in the melt pool at lower scanning speed,and stimulates the formation of the larger heat-affected zone,which is also the reason of the larger size of the melt pool. On the other hand,the hardening regions with higher thermal conductivity also affect the heat-affected zone of the second-stage $\mu { \bf S } \mathrm { L M }$ ，resulting in uneven cooling rates. Uneven cooling rates can lead to changes in grain size,thereby reducing the hardness of the joint area.
summary: 3.3.Microstructure and the distribution of hardness - Part 6/6

name: 2024 - J. Manufacturing Processes - Xu et al. - The influence of deformation affected region on microstructure and mechanical property o-part-30
fileName: 2024 - J. Manufacturing Processes - Xu et al. - The influence of deformation affected region on microstructure and mechanical property o.md
content: Fig.16 shows the stress-strain curves of samples fabricated by $\mu { \mathrm { S L M } }$ and HASM.The printing direction has a significant effect on the tensile properties of the workpiece.When the tension is parallel to the scanning direction，the three workpieces exhibit higher elongation rates compared to samples under tension perpendicular to the scanning direction.This difference is attributed to the anisotropy of the mechanical properties of the AMed metals in different directions.In the scanning direction,the intergranular bonding within the layers is the main resistance,which is the strongest,followed by the bonding between adjacent scan tracks,and the interlayer bonding [1O]. Under the tension in the vertical direction,dislocations can slide along the entire length of the grain boundary and slip plane,resulting in uniform plastic deformation.When the tension is exerted in the printing direction,plastic deformation tends to occur along the grain boundary,causing stress concentration along columnar grain boundaries [37].Columnar grains provide more grain boundaries as dislocation barriers,thereby increasing the plastic strength under tensile loading in the horizontal direction.In contrast,the difference in the tensile strengths of the three samples is insignificant, which could be ascribed to the internal defects. When tension is exerted in the printing direction, defects such as pores and cracks deteriorate the interlayer bonding，affecting the tensile strength.Similarly,under the tension in the scanning direction,cracks and pores within the single layer can lead to slightly decrease in tensile strength.Also, from the stress-strain curves,it can be found that the application of finish milling did not change the anisotropic tensile strength of the samples significantly.

name: 2024 - J. Manufacturing Processes - Xu et al. - The influence of deformation affected region on microstructure and mechanical property o-part-31
fileName: 2024 - J. Manufacturing Processes - Xu et al. - The influence of deformation affected region on microstructure and mechanical property o.md
content:
Only in the case of the HASMed sample at the scanning speed of $7 0 0 \mathrm { m m } / s$ ,the largest increase of tensile strength is significant,which is $2 0 \ \%$ higher than that of the $\mu { \sf S L M e d }$ parts.

![](images/2e8345e34f371ecf3004f96d9d498095940298be797b8103d0582a8ecbc8ba1d.jpg)  
Fig.12.Microstructure of HA/SMed area.(a) Sample A; (b) Sample B; (c) Sample C.

![](images/67fb106a501b4eea500085d700ad7447283e3c8610cd32f651c672213ae18038.jpg)  
Fig.13.(a) Changes in the melt pool width. (b) Changes in the melt pool depth.

Grain refinement,especially in the form of nanoscale cellular substructures,contributes to the excellent mechanical properties by providing high strength while maintaining good ductility [34]．As shown in Fig.12, the uniform distribution of ultrafine cellular subgrains could be found at the melt pool boundary within the connection region of the HASMed materials.According to Chen et al.[45],the plastic deformation within the melt pool was difficult to occur compared with that of at the boundary,and the failure of the materials was prone to occur along the boundary of the melt pool due to the fewer dislocations, leading to the decrease of mechanical properties of SLMed 316L. Also, Wanni et al.[5O] proposed that the refinement of dynamic slip bands caused by cellular subgrain was the main mechanism for improving the strength and ductility of DEDed SS 316L,because cellular subgrain have a hindering effect on the evolution of slip bands.In this study,the nanoscale cellular subgrains in connection regions of the HASMed samples increase the local dislocation density，contributing to the improvement of elongation rates.Compared with the HD samples, the difference on the strain among the VD samples are obvious,due to the larger connection area of the VD samples.

![](images/f35c0fdec35988febd76d72cebd44dd40ba15920fd3685f30901819d9a3b757c.jpg)  
Fig4edd of hardness in the additive-subtractive junction area.

name: 2024 - J. Manufacturing Processes - Xu et al. - The influence of deformation affected region on microstructure and mechanical property o-part-33
fileName: 2024 - J. Manufacturing Processes - Xu et al. - The influence of deformation affected region on microstructure and mechanical property o.md
content:
Fig.17 presents the micromorphology of the fractured surface of the $\mu { \bf S L M }$ samples.It can be seen that the surfaces exhibit typical ductile fracture with dimple fractures.The formation of dimples is caused by the accumulation of dislocations and stress concentration due to the existence of the carbides.The high energy melting and rapid cooling speed in SLM shorten the nucleation and crystallization time of grains, significantly promoting grain refinement and the formation of more grain boundaries.The high cooling rate also facilitates the precipitation of ferrite and promotes solid solution hardening of elements such as nickel and molybdenum [51].The high strain generated by the strengthening phase is incompatible with the plastic deformation of the matrix,and eventually causes the development of cracks and fractures of the sample [52].As shown in Figs.17(a)-(c),when the tension is in the scanning direction,unmelted powder can be found on the fracture surface,whereas the defects such as balling and large-sized porosity are insignificant.For the samples with tension in the printing direction, unmelted powder agglomeration,large-sized pores,and balling are obvious within the fractured regions,as shown in Figs.17(e)-(f),which is also one of the reasons for the low elongation rate of the $\mu { \mathrm { S L M e d } }$ samples.Fig.18 shows the fracture surface of HAsMed parts.Compared with $\mu { \mathrm { S L M e d } }$ samples,the fractured surface of HAsMed samples shows similar ductile fracture mechanism,and the fracture morphology shows typical dimple fracture.In the mixed additive-subtractive region, there was less unmelted powders,indicating that the defects during the SLM process could be removed through HAsM processing.

![](images/f1d08bb17588778ca6f312c1040afddae5befa41f9989ebcb2d93b8bfaf571a0.jpg)  
Fig and (f) the load direction is perpendicular to the scanning direction.

name: 2024 - J. Manufacturing Processes - Xu et al. - The influence of deformation affected region on microstructure and mechanical property o-part-34
fileName: 2024 - J. Manufacturing Processes - Xu et al. - The influence of deformation affected region on microstructure and mechanical property o.md
content:
The HASM of 316L stainless steel fabricated by the hybrid of milling and $\mu \mathrm { S L M }$ at scanning speeds of $7 0 0 \ \mathrm { m m } / s$ $8 0 0 \ \mathrm { m m } / s$ and $9 0 0 \ \mathrm { m m } / s$ was comprehensively investigated.Typical machining responses and the influences of the deformation-afected region on microstructures, hardness,and mechanical properties of the materials were revealed. Findings based on the experimental and theoretical analysis are concluded as follows:

·Splatter of spheriodization and unmelted powders are the typical defects of $\mathbf { \mu s L M }$ ,and the distribution of defects are more intensive at the scanning speeds of $8 0 0 \ \mathrm { m m } / s$ and $9 0 0 \ \mathrm { m m } / s$ because of the insufficient melting of the powder bed and laser shocking,which leads to higher roughness,larger cutting force and obvious vibrations in the cutting of the two materials.

· New peaks of $\gamma$ -austenite appear,and the $\gamma$ -austenite peaks shift towards higher angles.The intensity of the (2oO) phase peak( $2 0 =$ $5 0 . 8 ^ { \circ } \mathrm { ~ . ~ }$ )increased significantly,and the (111) $( 2 \theta = 4 4 ^ { \circ } .$ peaksappear after the entire HASM process.These changes in the peaks were caused by the refined crystal size and the lattice distortion induced by work hardening.   
· The category and size of the grains are related to the $\scriptstyle { \mathrm { G } } / { \mathrm { R } }$ ratio and G $\times \mathrm { \bf R } .$ Athigher scanning speed, the increase of both thermal gradient and solidification rate increased the number of columnar grains and minimized the grain size. The dimension of the melt pool decreases with the increase of scanning speed.   
·Finish milling induced deformation-affected regions consist of $1 5 \mu \mathrm { m }$ work hardening regions and $2 5 ~ { \mu \mathrm { m } }$ thermal softening regions,the

name: 2024 - J. Manufacturing Processes - Xu et al. - The influence of deformation affected region on microstructure and mechanical property o-part-35
fileName: 2024 - J. Manufacturing Processes - Xu et al. - The influence of deformation affected region on microstructure and mechanical property o.md
content:
![](images/a3ec445de06269b174d61154904533c4d0d72fae71051c4079e19330996477da.jpg)  
ig.18.Fracture morphologies of the tensile samples of the HASMed 316L stainless steel

grains within these regions after the second-stage $\mathbf { \mu s L M }$ were refined into nanoscale due to the higher local density caused by the severe plastic deformation.However, the hardness in these regions is smaller than that of the bulk due to the formation of HAZ

· The ultimate strengths of the $\mathbf { \mu } \mathbf { S L M e d }$ and HASMed samples are similar,except for the HASMed sample at $7 0 0 ~ \mathrm { m } / s$ .The elongation rates of the HASMed parts are $1 0 ~ \%$ to $3 0 ~ \%$ higher than that of the $\mathbf { \mu } \mathbf { S L M e d }$ samples because the nanoscale cellular subgrains in connection regions increase the local dislocation density,eventually the elongation rates.The fractured surfaces exhibit the typical ductile fracture mode with dimple fractures.Obvious defects including unmelted powder agglomeration, large-sized pores,and balling are found within the fractured regions,which contribute to the low elongation rate of the $\mu { \mathrm { S L } }$ Med samples.

This study investigates the fundamental mechanism of the influence ofthesubtractive manufacturing on the followed additive manufacturing,from the aspects of the microstructure in the connection region．It is anticipated the combination of different additive manufacturing,such as EBM and DED,and the finish cutting on the aerospace materials such as titanium alloys and nickel-based super alloys will be explored,and the influence of microstructures within the connection region on the mechanical properties of the parts will be investigated in further.The findings from such attempts are expected to expand the theoretical and practical knowledge on the HASM.

# ARTICLEINFO
summary: The effects of SLM process parameters on the relative density and hardness of austenitic stainless steel 316L

name: 2024 - J. Materials Research and Technology - Bakhtiarian et al. - The effects of SLM process parameters on the relative density and har-part-2
fileName: 2024 - J. Materials Research and Technology - Bakhtiarian et al. - The effects of SLM process parameters on the relative density and har.md
content:
# ABSTRACT
Handling editor: P Rios

Keywords:   
Additive manufacturing   
SLM   
AISI 316L   
Mechanical properties   
Density

Selective Laser Melting (SLM) process parameters significantly influence the microstructure and mechanical properties ofthe final product.Using the Taguchi optimization method,this investigation refined 316L austenitic stainlesstelSLMprocess parameters.Processfactors included laser power,scanningspeed,and layerthicknss, while performance criteria included relative density and hardness.A laser power of $1 8 0 ~ \mathrm { W }$ ,a scanning speed of $1 2 0 0 \ \mathrm { m m } / s$ ,and a layer thickness of $0 . 0 3 \mathrm { m m }$ produced optimal results, resulting in $1 2 5 \mathrm { ~ J } / \mathrm { m m } ^ { 3 }$ energy density and a hardness of $2 2 0 ~ \mathrm { H V }$ 、ANOVA analysis also showed that power influenced density by $2 7 . 4 9 ~ \%$ ，scanning speed by $4 5 . 5 1 \ \% ,$ and layer thickness by $2 3 . 6 0 ~ \%$ .A parameter combination led to materials with impressive tensile strengths $( 6 4 9 \pm 4 \mathrm { \ M P a } )$ ，yield strengths $( 4 0 9 \pm 3 \mathrm { \ M P a }$ )，and elongation $( 4 2 \pm 1 \ \% )$ for increasing scanning speed and lowering energy density,resulting in a decrease in ultimate strength.A SEM analysis of fracture characteristics was also conducted.As a result of a cellular microstructure,ductile dimple sizes were limited to the nanoscale,and crack propagation was impeded through a pinning efect,thus increasing defect tolerance in the SLM SS316L.According to the findings,internal defects play a significant role in crack propagation and subsequent reduction of mechanical properties.

name: 2024 - J. Materials Research and Technology - Bakhtiarian et al. - The effects of SLM process parameters on the relative density and har-part-3
fileName: 2024 - J. Materials Research and Technology - Bakhtiarian et al. - The effects of SLM process parameters on the relative density and har.md
content:
The metal additive manufacturing (AM) industry has evolved significantly due to industrial and societal challenges.Selective laser melting (SLM) stands out among these technologies,although its complexity has posed challenges to the development of new materials due to its complexity.Compared to traditional methods,which typically entail lengthy cycles and high expenses, SLM technology can produce intricate parts more efficiently and at a lower cost than traditional methods [1,2].The SLM process combines pulsed lasers and powder bed fusion to create complex 3D objects from metallic powders.Due to this technology,it has been possible to produce complex parts with complex geometries,which has resulted in better performance of the parts [3,4].

SLM has many applications that extend beyond the aerospace and automotive sectors [5].Various approaches have recently been introduced to shape AM components,but SLM has emerged as the most prevalent method [6,7].An array of components is produced using this process, including components made out of steel, titanium, aluminum, and nickel.As a result of its substantial utility within the biomedical, aerospace,energy，and automotive industries,stainless steel 316L (SS316L) has attracted extensive attention within this context [8-10].

With less than $0 . 0 3 ~ \%$ carbon content, SS316L is highly compatible with the SLM process because of its low carbon content[11-13].While SLM can offer many advantages,it can also cause a wide range of undesirable defects,adversely affecting various properties,including mechanical properties,geometric accuracy,and surface finish on the components produced.

The behavior of SS316L additive manufacturing has been the subject of numerous studies.The study by G.Sander etal.[14] investigated the corrosion properties of 316L stainless steel manufactured through selective laser melting.They observed a direct influence of build orientation on the microstructure of the produced metals and alloys.

name: 2024 - J. Materials Research and Technology - Bakhtiarian et al. - The effects of SLM process parameters on the relative density and har-part-4
fileName: 2024 - J. Materials Research and Technology - Bakhtiarian et al. - The effects of SLM process parameters on the relative density and har.md
content:

Specifically,specimens built horizontally exhibited larger grains aligned parallel to the build direction. Conversely,smaller and more equiaxed grains were observed in specimens built vertically or at a 45-degree angle.Furthermore,the researchers noted that regardless of the build orientation，specimens fabricated with SLM 316L stainless steel demonstrated higher resistance to pitting corrosion and exhibited a wider passive window compared to their wrought counterparts [14]. Parth Saxena et al.[15] studied the hardness and microstructure of stainless steel 316 using ANOVA analysis methods.Their analysis focused on assessing the impacts of layer thickness and orientation.The results of the ANOVA analysis indicated that lower layer thicknesses led to excellent hardness.This is attributed to the increased ease with which laser sources can melt thin layers of powder particles.The optimal conditions for achieving this were at a $9 0 ^ { \circ }$ orientation and with a layer thickness of $4 0 ~ { \mu \mathrm { m } }$

name: 2024 - J. Materials Research and Technology - Bakhtiarian et al. - The effects of SLM process parameters on the relative density and har-part-5
fileName: 2024 - J. Materials Research and Technology - Bakhtiarian et al. - The effects of SLM process parameters on the relative density and har.md
content:
The study conducted by Itziar Tolosa et al.[16] delved into the mechanical characteristics of SS316L steel post-processing via SLM while exploring variations arising from diferent manufacturing approaches,including alterations in building orientations.Ultimately, these attributes were compared against the established specifications for this steel in its "wrought" form.Notably,the yield strengths of this alloy were found to be more significant following the SLM process compared to its rolled state.Furthermore,it was observed that SLM specimens exhibited a hardness akin to what is seen in wrought products of this alloy.Charpy test results suggested that these specimens had a marginally lower value than wrought products’ specifications.

The investigations led by Tomasz Kurzynowski et al.[17] have revealed that laser power and scanning methods significantly influence the microstructures and textures of materials.Their findings indicate that laser energy density and scanning strategy play a crucial role in shaping the cellular substructure of austenite,determining the presence of ferrite,and influencing the type and intensity of texture.This culminated in a twofold increase in yield strength,enhanced ultimate tensile strength,and a 1.4-fold reduction in elongation at fracture compared to hot-rolled SS316L sheets.

In a study conducted by Jin Myoung Jeon et al. [18],the impact of microstructure and internal defects on the mechanical behavior of austenitic stainless steel 316L produced through selective laser melting was examined. The research revealed that the presence of pores predominantly influenced the anisotropy observed in tensile tests.Due to localized stress concentrations around these pores,it led to localized yielding and subsequent crack propagation. This,in turn,resulted in significant disparities in strength and ductility.

name: 2024 - J. Materials Research and Technology - Bakhtiarian et al. - The effects of SLM process parameters on the relative density and har-part-6
fileName: 2024 - J. Materials Research and Technology - Bakhtiarian et al. - The effects of SLM process parameters on the relative density and har.md
content:
In recent years, numerous studies have investigated printing defects, such as porosity,keyhole formation,balling,and melt pool stability [19-24]. In order to minimize defects in SLM,it is crucial to understand a range of processing parameters,such as layer thickness,scanning strategy,pattern filling distance,spot size,focus,and laser power,that are crucial to the process [25].

Pore formation,for instance,is attributed to improper selection of laser power and scan speed [26]. Larimian et al.[27] demonstrated that higher laser power and slower scanning speeds significantly enhance the mechanical properties of SLM-processed samples.Laser power exerts a more significant influence on SLM processes than scanning speed.Hsu et al.[28] noted that low laser power prevents 316L powder from melting and bonding,while high power leads to keyhole formation.

Short hatch spaces resulted in the highest density and hardness for 316L.Conversely,long hatch spaces yielded the lowest relative density for the samples.Achieving effective powder layer fusion necessitated higher energy density as hatch space increased.Ronneberg et al.[23] observed a positive and directionally dependent correlation between porosity and ductility.Horizontally constructed samples exhibited higher porosity levels but more excellent ductility,a phenomenon explained by the shape and orientation of pores.Most porosity stemmed fromsignificant fusion defects and pores with a high aspect ratio clustered along layer boundaries.Pore accumulation was evident on the fracture surfaces of both horizontal and vertical samples.

Table 2 Specifications of the NOURA M10OP SLM machine.

name: 2024 - J. Materials Research and Technology - Bakhtiarian et al. - The effects of SLM process parameters on the relative density and har-part-8
fileName: 2024 - J. Materials Research and Technology - Bakhtiarian et al. - The effects of SLM process parameters on the relative density and har.md
content: A study on the effects of laser power,scanning speed,and layer thickness on the microstructure,density,and hardness of austenitic stainless steel 316L has been conducted in this study.This study's novelty lies in assessing the effects of the SLM processs laser power, scanning speed,and layer thickness on the metallurgical and mechanical properties of stainless steel 316L.The selected specimens were evaluated as part of the metallographic and mechanical investigations.The Taguchi and ANOVA methods were used to test the effects of each parameter on the selected specimens.This work will likely lead to the developing of a standard SLM method that can be used in various industries due to its success.

content:
This study utilized AISI 316L stainless steel powder,which was atomized using $\Nu _ { 2 }$ gas. The procurement of this powder was carried out through VISTEC TECHNOLOGY SERVICES,Inc.The composition of the 316L stainless steel powder was determined using Spark Emission Table 4 The process parameters.

Spectroscopy with an OXFORD device,following the reference standard ASTM E1OlO-16.Detailed information regarding the chemical composition of the 3l6L powders can be found in Table 1. Utilizinga NOURA MloOP SLM machine,a series of 316L stainless steel cuboid parts,each measuring $1 0 \times 1 0 \times 1 0 \mathrm { m m }$ ,were fabricated. The specifications of this machine are outlined in Table 2. The study employed the Design of Experiments (DOE) approach to optimize process parameters. Three critical parameters in 3D printing via SLM were identified: laser power,scan speed,and layer thickness. The DOE was structured using Taguchi's L16 orthogonal arrays, encompassing three parameters and four levels.All parameters were set at four levels to enhance SLM's overall production efficiency. The hatching space (h) was maintained at $0 . 0 4 \ \mathrm { m m }$ 、An overview of the process parameters and their respective values is provided in Table 3. In order to evaluate the effect of scanning speed on the mechanical properties,a narrower range of scanning speeds was used to make tensile samples.According to Table 4, this selection aimed to examine the effects of speed on mechanical properties within an optimal parameter range.

name: 2024 - J. Materials Research and Technology - Bakhtiarian et al. - The effects of SLM process parameters on the relative density and har-part-11
fileName: 2024 - J. Materials Research and Technology - Bakhtiarian et al. - The effects of SLM process parameters on the relative density and har.md
content:
The choice of scanning speeds( $1 1 0 0 \mathrm { m m } / s$ $1 2 0 0 \ \mathrm { m m } / s$ ,and1300 $\mathrm { m m } / s \mathrm { \AA }$ was determined to encompass the critical variations observed in the density cube results.These speeds were selected based on their alignment with the optimal range identified in the preliminary analysis. Regarding the laser power and layer thickness for preparing the tensile samples,the laser power used was $1 8 0 ~ \mathrm { ~ W ~ }$ ，and the layer thickness employed during sample fabrication was $0 . 0 3 \mathrm { m m }$

Additionally,horizontal printing was favored due to its reported higher tensile strength,according to established research [14,29,30]. The manufacturing process involved producing three blocks following the parameters outlined in Table 4. Subsequently,sub-size samples were extracted from these blocks using EDM wire cutting.This method minimizes material damage and ensures conformity with ASTM E8M standards for specimen dimensions.

content: A scanning electron microscope (SEM) was utilized to examine the powder's structure.The particle size distribution of 316L powder was assessed using a Bettersizer 26oo instrument.The powder's Apparent Density (AD) and Tap Density (TD) were evaluated utilizing a Hall

name: 2024 - J. Materials Research and Technology - Bakhtiarian et al. - The effects of SLM process parameters on the relative density and har-part-13
fileName: 2024 - J. Materials Research and Technology - Bakhtiarian et al. - The effects of SLM process parameters on the relative density and har.md
content:
Furthermore,the powder's flow ability was gauged through the Hausner Ratio (AD/TD).The cubic samples were meticulously smoothed with sandpaper post-separation to enhance the precision of density measurements.Springs etal.[31] deduced that the Archimedes method is the most accurate and efficient approach for determining the density of waterproof samples generated through additive manufacturing. Consequently,cube density was ascertained using the Archimedes method as per ASTM B962.

An electronic scale with a precision of O.ool g was employed to weigh the samples.Each sample underwent five measurements,and prior to each reading,it was thoroughly dried.

The phase compositions of the samples were analyzed via X-ray Diffraction (XRD) using an EQUINOX300O instrument. The surface of the selected sample for XRD testing was meticulously polished to a smooth $1 \mathrm { c m } ^ { 2 }$ size.The analysis encompassed a scanning range of $2 0 =$ $3 0 ^ { \circ } - 1 0 0 ^ { \circ }$ ,a step size of $0 . 0 2 ^ { \circ }$ ,and a scanning speed of $5 ^ { \circ } / \mathrm { m i n }$ .Subsequently,the samples were cross-sectioned perpendicular to the surface following the XRD analysis.Following furtherrefinement with abrasive paper,the parts were polished using a polishing machine.In the subsequent step,the polished samples underwent a 15-s etching process with an aqua regia solution (1:3 nitric acid/hydrochloric acid).

An Optical Microscope (OM, OLYMPUS U-SWTR-3) and a Scanning Electron Microscope (SEM) were used to observe the microstructure and cellular grain structure.

name: 2024 - J. Materials Research and Technology - Bakhtiarian et al. - The effects of SLM process parameters on the relative density and har-part-14

content:
In order to evaluate the material's strength in relation to the SLM device that was used, tensile testing was conducted on a Universal Testing Machine in accordance with ISO 6892-1. The test specimens were manufactured horizontally [29].Before the tests,the surfaces of the specimens were ground to remove high-stress concentration zones that may cause premature failure during the test.A constant speed of $0 . 5 \mathrm { m m }$ per minute was used to test the specimens until rupture had been achieved.An extensometer measured the elongation of the tensile specimens during testing,and a $1 0 ~ \mathrm { K N }$ load cell was used to determine the applied force.

Vickers hardness on the cross sections (XY plane) was measured using a Mitutoyo HM-211 microhardness tester (Mitutoyo Co., Japan) with a 2O-s indentation.Mechanical tests were carried out under consistent conditions,with a minimum of three repetitions,and the mean value was computed.Additionally, SEMwas utilized to inspect the fracture surfaces of the tensile specimens.

Smaller ones occasionally aggregate on the surface of larger powder particles,as illustrated in Fig.1(b). ![](images/10285fede1e648dd849c98fce3c4d6b3522e7db6d311cdd8a608051e88997e7a.jpg) Fig at $2 0 0 ~ { \mu \mathrm { m } }$ (b)at $2 0 ~ { \mu \mathrm { m } }$ and (c)at $5 \mu \mathrm { m }$ ![](images/41693732f48b2ecaf1a4aa591242ee9eaf36ea737477fedfce66ccdde75918cd.jpg) Fig.2.Distribution of particle diameters. Satellites form due to tiny powder particles adhering to larger ones during gas atomization.This phenomenon arises from disparities in flow conditions,crystallization rates,and interactions between liquid and solid steel droplets [2].As shown in Fig.1(c),the powder surface predominantly displays a smooth texture,indicatinga blend of solidification structure and imperfections in solidification.Surface irregularities and occasional occurrences of smaller spheres signify these imperfections.While these defects may lead to an increase in surface roughness, they are not anticipated to have a significant impact on the SLM fabrication process [29]. Based on the results obtained from the particle size analyzer Bettersizer 26oo,Fig.2 presents the normal histogram illustrating the particle size distribution. In addition, Table 5 provides particle size distributions,apparent densities,tap densities,fluidities,and Hausner ratios for the 316L powder.The average particle size of the 3l6L powder measured 33.81 $\mu \mathrm { m }$

name: 2024 - J. Materials Research and Technology - Bakhtiarian et al. - The effects of SLM process parameters on the relative density and har-part-17
fileName: 2024 - J. Materials Research and Technology - Bakhtiarian et al. - The effects of SLM process parameters on the relative density and har.md
content:
A notable proportion of the particles fell below $5 2 ~ { \mu \mathrm { m } }$ in size. The Hausner ratio for the 3l6L powder was determined to be 1.12.A Hausner ratio exceeding 1.25 indicates relatively subpar flow ability.

This is primarily attributed to the propensity of smaller particles to interlock with larger ones,leading to heightened friction among particles and hindering powder mobility [32].

The powder demonstrated a flow duration of 13.93 s during the Hallflow test,exhibiting impressive flow ability due to its spherical form and the existence of small satellites.The powder flowed smoothly when dispersed thinly without agglomeration within the SLM machine.

name: 2024 - J. Materials Research and Technology - Bakhtiarian et al. - The effects of SLM process parameters on the relative density and har-part-18
fileName: 2024 - J. Materials Research and Technology - Bakhtiarian et al. - The effects of SLM process parameters on the relative density and har.md
content:
The relative density and hardness of each sample were evaluated as response variables.The average values for these response variables are outlined in Table 6.Among the 16 samples,four exhibited relative densities surpassing $9 8 ~ \%$

Sample C-4 demonstrated the lowest relative density,attributed to utilizing the lowest laser power at $1 5 0 \mathrm { W }$ ,the highest scan speed of 2000 $\mathbf { m m } / s _ { \mathrm { i } }$ ,and the thickest layer measuring $0 . 0 6 \ \mathrm { m m }$ .Figure 3 shows that process factors have a significant influence on relative density.Porosity is significantly affected by factors related to energy density,including laser power,scanning speed, hatch spacing,and layer thickness [33-35]. This influence arises from their impact on the temperature profile and liquid/gas flow dynamics within the processing area.Mathematically, relative density is defined as:

$$
\scriptstyle \mathrm { V E D } = \mathbf { P } / ( \mathbf { V } \times \mathbf { H } \times \mathbf { L } )
$$

Among these,P represents laser power,V indicates scan speed,L indicates layer thickness,and H indicates hatch spacing.According to Fig.3,there are optimal laser power values for SLM of 316L that minimize porosity [36].Low laser power or high scanning speed combined with thick layers (resulting in low energy density) can form irregular pores or crevices due to balling and inadequate melting [37].

Table 6 Results of SLM experiment.

A process parameter with a high F-value and a P-value below 0.05 (indicating $9 5 ~ \%$ confidence) significantly influences density.P-values signify the likelihood of a specific outcome occurring by chance,while Fvalues denote a relatively more significant variance among groups.For a statistical test to be considered meaningful,P-values must be less than 0.05 [41,42]. As depicted in Fig.4, each parameter—power, scanning speed,and layer thickness—influences hardness.Initially,the hardness of a material increases with higher power settings but eventually decreases with further power increases. Conversely,higher speed and thickness settings tend to reduce hardness.Both Figs.3 and 4 affirm a correlation between density and hardness values.The hardness of additively manufactured parts is influenced by microstructure and powder melting.

content:
Studies by Wakshum M. Tucho [11] and Hua-Zhen Jiang [43] have established that porosity significantly affects material hardness.The hardness of an additively manufactured component will vary depending on its microstructure and the degree of powder melting.If there is insufficient powder melting and a prevalence of pores,the hardness of the fabricated part may not reach its full potential [4O].The relationship between density and hardness is evident in Table 6,demonstrating a hardness decrease at both high and low energy densities.These findings align with those of Cherry et al. [44].

The highest recorded hardness in this study was $2 2 0 \mathrm { H V }$ .An analysis of variance (ANOVA) was conducted to determine the influence of each process parameter on the hardness of each sample.Table 8 provides the F-and P-values for individual process parameters and their interactions for all the outcomes,as mentioned earlier.It is evident from Table8 that power influences hardness by $2 6 . 1 7 \%$ ,scanning speed by $5 3 . 2 4 \%$ ,and layer thickness by $1 7 . 1 4 ~ \%$ .Notably,a built part's porosity and microstructure significantly impact its hardness. Scanning speed has a more significant effect on hardness than power,while power exerts a more significant influence than layer thickness.

name: 2024 - J. Materials Research and Technology - Bakhtiarian et al. - The effects of SLM process parameters on the relative density and har-part-23
fileName: 2024 - J. Materials Research and Technology - Bakhtiarian et al. - The effects of SLM process parameters on the relative density and har.md
content:
Fig.5 illustrates the XRD patterns of the precursor powder and the SS316L samples fabricated at two distinct Volumetric Energy Density (VED) values,31 and $1 5 6 \mathrm { \ J / m m } ^ { 3 }$ ，Neither the powder nor the solid samples exhibited any indications of ferrite presence.These findings align with those reported by Sijia Liu [45].

No distinct preference for specific crystallographic orientations is observed in the Selective Laser Melting (SLM) context.In contrast to the precursor powder, the as-built sample exhibits broad peaks resulting from residual stresses and dislocations introduced during the SLM process [46].

In the context of Selective Laser Melting (SLM),no distinct preference for specific crystallographic orientations is observed.In contrast to the precursor powder,the as-built sample exhibits broad peaks,a result of residual stresses and dislocations introduced during the SLM process [47,48].

Also,it can be seen In XRD patterns that an upward shift in Bragg angles within the manufactured samples and correlates with increased energy density.This phenomenon suggests a possible lattice distortion induced by laser-induced thermal stress [44].As indicated by Mostafa Yakout etal.[49], there isa notable increase in both horizontal and vertical stresses with rising laser energy density.This increase in energy density is known to escalate thermal stress levels,resulting ina higher temperature gradient,ultimately leading to more significant thermal stress within the material. The observed trend of upward-shifted Bragg angles aligns with this understanding.As energy density rises,the amplified thermal stress likely induces lattice distortion,contributing to the observed shift in Bragg angles.

![](images/af18e5d0ec4bbbb742fb01648b31701b391505738428d189fee2e676f36d94f4.jpg)  
Fig.5.XRD patern of the powder and parts of 316L processed by SLM under different VED.

name: 2024 - J. Materials Research and Technology - Bakhtiarian et al. - The effects of SLM process parameters on the relative density and har-part-25
fileName: 2024 - J. Materials Research and Technology - Bakhtiarian et al. - The effects of SLM process parameters on the relative density and har.md
content:
The SLM SS316L sample C-6,as detailed in Table 6 has undergone microstructural analysis using optical microscopy (OM),revealing distinct hierarchies at the macro,micro,and nanoscale levels in its asbuilt state.Layered microstructures with clearly defined melt pools are discernible at the macro level. The optical micrographs indicate complete melting of the powder,and the melt pools in vertical planes exhibit a characteristic 'fish scale’morphology (Fig. 6(a)).Fig.6(b) displays the melting traces and melt pools generated by the scanning laser beam.In sample C-6, the melt pool width measures approximately $1 3 0 \mu \mathrm { m } .$ ,while the height is about $6 0 ~ { \mu \mathrm { m } }$ ,depending on the direction of the laser beam.The melt pool size may vary based on laser spot size and input energy density [46].

With each repetition，previously heated melt pools can undergo partial re-melting,resulting in well-aligned melt pools spaced regularly. The boundaries of melt pools may have different separations due to localized inhomogeneities within them [5O].A decision was made to measure the depth of melt pool boundaries on a cross-section parallel to the build direction (xz) to compare melt pools in parts manufactured with different Volumetric Energy Densities (VEDs).According to Fig. 6, the size of the molten pool changes as the VED changes.Fig.6(a) illustrates that with a VED of $4 6 \mathrm { ~ J / m m ^ { 3 } }$ ,the melt pool is shallow,with an average depth of around $3 0 ~ { \mu \mathrm { m } }$ .On the other hand,Fig.6(b)-6(d) illustrate that with a VED of 131 $\mathrm { J } / \mathrm { m m } ^ { 3 }$ to $1 5 6 \mathrm { J / m m } ^ { 3 }$ ,the average melt pool depth increases to $6 0 ~ { \mu \mathrm { m } }$ ， $9 0 ~ { \mu \mathrm { m } }$ ，and less than $1 2 0 ~ { \mu \mathrm { m } }$ respectively.

As shown in Fig.7, the $\mathrm { d _ { p } / t _ { L } }$ value represents the depth of a melt pool relative to the nominal layer thickness.In contrast,the $\mathrm { d } _ { 0 } / \mathrm { t } _ { \mathrm { L } }$ value represents the depth of an overlapped melt pool relative to the nominal layer thickness.Table 9 provides measurements for various VEDs. This measurement aims to illustrate how melt pools,or more precisely melt volumes,impact the density of parts fabricated by SLM under different VED conditions.A VED of $1 5 6 \mathrm { ~ J / m m } ^ { 3 }$ resulted in melt pool boundaries with $\mathrm { d _ { p } / t _ { L } }$ of 9.04 and ${ \mathrm { d } } _ { 0 } / { \mathrm { t } } _ { \mathrm { L } }$ of 7.22.When the VED was $4 6 \mathrm { ~ J / m m } ^ { 3 }$ ,these values were 1.78 and 1.19,respectively.According to equation (1),melt pool volume is directly proportional to VED and inversely proportional to scanning speed.Increasing VED values promotes densification by melting and filling porosity [35].
