name: 2024 - J. Materials Research and Technology - Bakhtiarian et al. - The effects of SLM process parameters on the relative density and har-part-27
fileName: 2024 - J. Materials Research and Technology - Bakhtiarian et al. - The effects of SLM process parameters on the relative density and har.md
content: In Fig.8 (a) and (b),optical microscopy (OM) images vividly depict large columnar grains within the melt pools.These columnar grains become distinctly visible upon etching,ranging from several tens of microns to as much as $1 0 0 \mu \mathrm { m }$ .The temperature gradient determines the growth of these columnar grains they experience [29].As observed in Fig.8 (c) and (d),it is apparent that columnar grains may extend across the melt pool boundary,as the laser consistently exposes the top surface of the solid part [51]. The molten powder and previously solidified layer must be coherent in terms of chemistry and crystallography in order to allow these grains to persist.As long as voids,porosity,or balling effects did not introduce chemical or crystallographic composition variations, the nucleation of new grains was unimpeded.Due to these congruities, the grains grew in alignment with the crystal orientation of the preceding layer [44,52].Molten material solidifying in its preferred orientation at high volumetric energy density (VED) has an extended solidification period due to the substantial thermal gradient. Consequently, increasing VED leads to an enlargement in columnar grain size [35].It is confirmed in the study by Larimian etal.[53] that grain size increases with increasing energy density.They also provided an explanation for this phenomenon,highlighting that higher energy density leads to larger melt pools. These larger melt pools consequently lead to a coarsermicrostructure.

name: 2024 - J. Materials Research and Technology - Bakhtiarian et al. - The effects of SLM process parameters on the relative density and har-part-28
fileName: 2024 - J. Materials Research and Technology - Bakhtiarian et al. - The effects of SLM process parameters on the relative density and har.md
content:
At the micro level,a distinctive cellular segregation network structure is prominently observed,as depicted in Fig.8 (d),(e),and (f).A columnar grain encompasses this cellular structure, with cels ranging between 0.5 and $1 ~ { \mu \mathrm { m } }$ in diameter.Recent studies have demonstrated that neighboring cells exhibit similar crystallographic orientations, suggesting that this structure deviates from the typical characteristics of grain boundaries.The high cooling rates experienced during the SLM process give rise to this cellular structure due to non-equilibrium conditions [54,55].

Fig.8(d) illustrates that this cellular structure can manifest either in an equiaxed or bar-like configuration,contingent on the growth direction of its larger columnar grains.The high-magnification SEM image in Fig.8 (d) vividly showcases the three-dimensional morphology of the cellular structure along the longitudinal direction,revealing square, pentagon,and hexagon shapes in the transverse direction [56].

![](images/c24c47a296f5d837088b22a4605eadcc7421906d36bcd878a84d489d75652813.jpg)  
Fig. 9. Optical micrographs specimen (a) C-6 at VED of $1 2 5 \mathrm { J / m m ^ { 3 } }$ , (b) C-4 at VED of $3 1 \mathrm { J / m m ^ { 3 } }$ and (e) C-1 at VED of $1 5 6 \mathrm { J / m m ^ { 3 } }$ , SEM micrographs specimen (c anc d) C-4 at VED of $3 1 \ \mathrm { J / m m ^ { 3 } }$ and (f) C-1 at VED of $1 5 6 \mathrm { ~ J / m m ^ { 3 } }$ ,in xz-plane.

In response to laser scanning, particularly the temperature gradient, the cellular structure predominantly aligns along the building direction, with its longitudinal direction parallel to the building direction [47]. These cellular structures accumulate dislocations and residual stresses due to segregating heavy alloying elements such as Mo and Cr.The SLM process typically involves rapid melting and solidification far from equilibrium [51].

name: 2024 - J. Materials Research and Technology - Bakhtiarian et al. - The effects of SLM process parameters on the relative density and har-part-29
fileName: 2024 - J. Materials Research and Technology - Bakhtiarian et al. - The effects of SLM process parameters on the relative density and har.md
content:
Optical and scanning electron microscopy were used to examine the solidification defects in SS316L-SLM samples.Substrate porosity is significantly influenced by parameters associated with energy density, including laser power,scanning speed, hatch spacing,and layer thickness.These parameters substantially impact the temperature evolution and flow dynamics within the processed area [39].

To minimize porosity in SS316L-SLM,adjustments to laser power and scanning speed are crucial. Fig. 9(a) displays a perpendicular crosssection of sample C-6,exhibiting a density of $9 9 . 5 ~ \%$ and a Volumetric Energy Density (VED) of $1 2 5 \ \mathrm { J / m m } ^ { 3 }$ ：

The micrographs in Fig.9 (b),(c),and (d) showcase perpendicular cross-sections of sample C-4,characterized by the lowest VED and density at $9 6 . 3 0 \%$ .Lastly,Fig.9 (e) and (f) present SEM images of the sample with the highest VED of $1 5 6 \mathrm { ~ J / m m } ^ { 3 }$ ,resulting in a density of $9 8 . 6 0 \%$ ：

Fig.9 (a) depicts that the sample with the highest density exhibits a few minor pores.Notably,there were no cracks or substantial porosities observed between the layers.Additionally,tiny pores were identified at the center of the melt pool, where temperatures peaked.

According to Tables l and it is evident that the 316L powder contains 0.1 wt $\%$ nitrogen,a byproduct of its gas atomization production process.The formation of tiny,spherical pores during solidification results from gas entrapment and nitrogen absorption.

name: 2024 - J. Materials Research and Technology - Bakhtiarian et al. - The effects of SLM process parameters on the relative density and har-part-30
fileName: 2024 - J. Materials Research and Technology - Bakhtiarian et al. - The effects of SLM process parameters on the relative density and har.md
content:
The research done by Bose et al.[57] and Milad Ghayoor et al. [35] confirmed the impact of nitrogen content on porosity during the SLM process.Bose et al. investigated two distinct powder mixtures containing 0.065 mass- $\%$ and 0.27 mass $\%$ nitrogen content in the 316L alloy samples produced via selective melting by laser in the SLM process. These variations in nitrogen content within the powder mixtures resulted in observed specimen porosity ranging from $0 . 1 7 ~ \%$ to $0 . 9 1 ~ \%$ Their research highlighted that nitrogen outgassing from the melt during solidification significantly impacted specimen density during Table 10 Mechanical properties of SLM SS316L and reference.
MaterialScanning Speed (mm/s)VED (J/ mm3)Yield Stress (MPa)UTS (MPa)Elongation (%)
11100136372±6624± 850±4
21200125380±6640± 652±1
31300115409±3649± 442±1
ReferenceN/AN/A17048540
SLM processing. Specifically,the nitrogen content in SLM-built specimens was found to be contingent upon the maximum solubility of the liquid phase.Outgassing occurred if this solubility limit was surpassed, leading to lower specimen density. Conversely,if nitrogen remained below the maximum solubility,the steel absorbed nitrogen from the process atmosphere. Additionally,Milad Ghayoor's [35],study on selective laser melting of 304L provided complementary insights,attributing minor spherical porosity in SLM to gas entrapment within the powder feedstock and nitrogen gas absorption during solidification.These observations align with Bose et al.'s findings on nitrogen's impact on specimen density during the solidification phase in SLM processes.

name: 2024 - J. Materials Research and Technology - Bakhtiarian et al. - The effects of SLM process parameters on the relative density and har-part-31
fileName: 2024 - J. Materials Research and Technology - Bakhtiarian et al. - The effects of SLM process parameters on the relative density and har.md
content:
These observations reinforce the critical role of nitrogen content and its interaction with the SLM process,substantiating the link between nitrogen,porosity variation,and outgassing during solidification in additive manufacturing processes like SLM.

Microstructure images of the sample with the lowest Volumetric Energy Density (VED) of $3 1 \mathrm { ~ J } / \mathrm { m m } ^ { 3 }$ (achieved with 150 W, $2 0 0 0 \ \mathrm { m m } / s$ scanning speeds, and $0 . 0 6 \ \mathrm { m m }$ layer thickness) displayed in Fig.9 (b), (c),and (d) vividly illustrate that the voids exhibit irregular shapes and sizes.There are also irregular cavities along the borders of melt pools, indicating incomplete fusion [58]. Small triangular voids may form at the intersection of three melt pools if the top two melt pools fail to melt the bottom layer fully.Pores with irregular shapes and sizes are primarily near fusion lines,suggesting inadequate energy density.Additionally,due to the propensity of austenitic stainless steel to develop porosity when exposed to argon gas,gas holes induced by this gas are noticeable in the microstructure of these samples [59-61].

In Fig.9(e),the microstructure of a sample subjected to the highest Volumetric Energy Density (VED) ( $1 5 0 ~ \mathrm { W }$ power, $8 0 0 \ \mathrm { m m } / s$ scanning speed,and $0 . 0 3 \mathrm { m m }$ layer thickness) is depicted.Neither the powder bed nor the powder itself appear to have entrapped gas.At this elevated level of VED,which creates intense thermal conditions,powder particles undergo melting both within and between layers.

name: 2024 - J. Materials Research and Technology - Bakhtiarian et al. - The effects of SLM process parameters on the relative density and har-part-32
fileName: 2024 - J. Materials Research and Technology - Bakhtiarian et al. - The effects of SLM process parameters on the relative density and har.md
content: With increased VED,molten pools develop keyhole cavities due to the growing ratio between their depth and width [62].Fig.9(e) provides an electron microscope image of a keyhole.When high laser energy is applied to a melt pool,gas bubbles form,resulting in near-spherical defects ranging from 40 to $7 0 ~ \mu \mathrm { m }$ .Due to the keyhole effect, low melting point constituents in the alloy may vaporize and accumulate gas bubbles in the melt pools.The downward conduction of thermal energy during solidification gives rise to temperature gradients.It is important to note that these gas bubbles form well below the surface of the melt pool.Due to the high solidification rate,gas bubbles cannot escape from the surface of the melt pool [63-66].

name: 2024 - J. Materials Research and Technology - Bakhtiarian et al. - The effects of SLM process parameters on the relative density and har-part-33
fileName: 2024 - J. Materials Research and Technology - Bakhtiarian et al. - The effects of SLM process parameters on the relative density and har.md
content:
Components produced through Selective Laser Melting (SLM) were tested using the parameters outlined in Table 1O. Subsequently，a comparison was made between these results and those obtained from conventionally annealed bars,evaluating the efficacy of the two methods.

The engineering stress-strain curves of SLM 316L are presented in Fig.10 for scanning speeds of $1 1 0 0 \mathrm { m m } / s$ $1 2 0 0 \mathrm { m m } / s$ ,and $1 3 0 0 \mathrm { m m } / s$

Furthermore,these values were juxtaposed with those for wrought 316L Stainless Steel,which possesses yield strengths of $1 7 0 \ \mathrm { M P a }$ and ultimate tensile strengths of $4 8 5 \ \mathrm { M P a }$ .Notably, the stress-strain curve lacks a distinct yield stage for yield strength,as illustrated in Fig.1O. The yield strength ranges from $3 7 2 \pm 6$ MPa to $4 0 9 \pm 3$ MPa at a $0 . 2 ~ \%$ strain.

The relationship between the yield strength of 3D printed components and scanning speed has been closely examined in the study conducted by Jiangwei Liu [67].The ultimate tensile strength (UTS) slightly decreased with increasing energy density,reaching a maximum of 649 $\pm 4 \mathrm { M P a }$ at a scanning speed of $1 3 0 0 \ \mathrm { m m } / s$ (refer to Table 10). On the other hand,with rising input energy,there was a slight increase in elongation to failure (see Fig.1O).The notable deviation from elongation to failure may have been caused by unexpected defects during SLM fabrication.It is worth noting that the stress-strain curve of SLM parts does not exhibit a distinct stage of stress strengthening.

![](images/f6fc7f0a040950cb7e490e1a53c1949acd10d65369969ecb083afc16142ddcb4.jpg)  
Fig.10.Stress strain curve for SLM 316L at scanning speeds of $1 1 0 0 \ \mathrm { m m } / s$ $1 2 0 0 \ \mathrm { m m } / s$ ,and $1 3 0 0 \ \mathrm { m m } / s$

content:
![](images/df8f5acdc1dba8c396c8ce6c453501dfc741973aac150f62c515eb53350fc4f5.jpg)  
Fig.11.Fractography of tensile specimens of SLM SS316L at three different scanning speeds: (a) $1 1 0 0 \mathrm { m m } / s$ (b), $1 2 0 0 \mathrm { m m } / s$ and (c) $1 3 0 0 \mathrm { m m } / s$ (e), (d) and (f) high magnification images of tensile specimens' fractured surfaces.

Further enhancement of the tensile strength of the 3D printed parts could be achieved through processes like isostatic pressure or additional heat treatments.Table 9 illustrates that rolled 316L stainless steel exhibits an elongation of $4 0 ~ \%$ ,whereas 3D printed parts demonstrate an elongation ranging from $4 2 \pm 1 \ : \%$ to $5 2 \pm 1 \%$ .Hence,the SLM process displays a greater degree of plasticity compared to the rolling process.

name: 2024 - J. Materials Research and Technology - Bakhtiarian et al. - The effects of SLM process parameters on the relative density and har-part-35
fileName: 2024 - J. Materials Research and Technology - Bakhtiarian et al. - The effects of SLM process parameters on the relative density and har.md
content:
As depicted in Fig.11, fracture surfaces of SLM SS316L are presented at three different scanning speeds: $1 1 0 0 \ \mathrm { m m } / s$ $1 2 0 0 \ \mathrm { m m } / s$ ,and 1300 $\mathrm { { \ m m } } / s$ The specimens shown in Fig.11 (a),(b),and (c) exhibit characteristics of both ductile and brittle fractures.

Additionally,brittle fractures are discernible where melt pools have been pulled out alongside sub-micron-sized dimples,indicating ductile behavior.Ata scanning speed of $1 3 0 0 \mathrm { m m } / s$ ,the specimen demonstrates a more britle behavior than the other specimens,as per the results of the tensile tests.

The fracture surfaces of the specimens reveal numerous crater-like pores, varying in size from tens of microns to $1 5 0 ~ { \mu \mathrm { m } }$ ，These larger voids are believed to contribute to material failure during tensile tests [68].Fig.11(d) highlights spherical powder granules (indicated by black arrows) that have not undergone melting within these voids.In certain instances,some powder particles may remain either unmelted or partially melted in non-overlapping areas when the melt pools do not coincide (as depicted in Fig.11(e)).

Consequently, during tensile testing, these regions characterized by lower density and strength surrounding each melting pool are inclined to detach from the fracture surface,forming crater-like voids.While mitigating such defects by fine-tuning input scanning parameters might be feasible,eliminating them could be more challenging.Remarkably, the material's mechanical properties,including its Ultimate Tensile Strength (UTS),do not suffer adverse effects from these inevitable imperfections in SLM SS316L,such as regions with lower density.As a result,materials produced through SLM exhibit a notable resilience to defects [47,69]. Compared to previous experiments with austenitic steels,the ductile dimples observed in this study are notably more minor on average.

name: 2024 - J. Materials Research and Technology - Bakhtiarian et al. - The effects of SLM process parameters on the relative density and har-part-36
fileName: 2024 - J. Materials Research and Technology - Bakhtiarian et al. - The effects of SLM process parameters on the relative density and har.md
content:
Fig.1l(f) reveals that the intragranular cell size primarily dictates the size of the dimples.These dimples range from a few hundred nanometers to a few microns,aligning closely with the intragranular cells. Cracks occur when micro-voids at defect sites,such as secondphase inclusions,coalesce during tensile tests.Due to the prevalent presence of cellular networks,only nano-voids can form in SLM SS316L. Consequently, fractures tend to transpire more ductility at nano-void necks than micro-void necks,forming nano-sized dimples on the fracture surfaces [70,71].

In summary,tensile fractures manifest in two distinct ways: The first is the junctions of layers;a fragile crack initiates and intensifies under tension.As stress concentrations trigger the crack's progression，it adopts a scallop pattern as it extends into the micro crack within,and the second is the fact that the crack continues until it encounters the unmelted metal powder,resulting in a smooth outer surface.Upon reachinga defect-free region,fluctuations in stress intensify,leading to plastic necking and the subsequent formation of a dimple.The propagation of cracks is contingent on various factors,including crack size and type,whether it encounters unmelted powder or defect-free areas,and more.The progression of cracks manifests a diverse array of tearing patterns,such as scallops,dimples,and smooth surfaces [32,68,72,73].

name: 2024 - J. Materials Research and Technology - Bakhtiarian et al. - The effects of SLM process parameters on the relative density and har-part-37
fileName: 2024 - J. Materials Research and Technology - Bakhtiarian et al. - The effects of SLM process parameters on the relative density and har.md
content:
# 4. Conclusions
This study evaluated the impact of crucial SLM parameters on 316L hardness and density，specifically laser power,scanning speed,and hatch distance.

1 Ferrite phases were not detected in the powder,nor at the highest and lowest energy densities of $3 1 \mathrm { ~ J / m m ^ { 3 } }$ and $1 5 6 \mathrm { ~ J / m m } ^ { 3 }$   
2 With a laser power of $1 8 0 \mathrm { W }$ ,a scan speed of $1 2 0 0 \mathrm { m m } / s$ ,and alayer thickness of $0 . 0 3 \mathrm { m m }$ ,the best results were achieved,which equated to an energy density of $1 2 5 \mathrm { ~ J } / \mathrm { m m } ^ { 3 }$ .A peak density of $9 9 . 5 ~ \%$ and a hardness of $2 2 0 \ \mathrm { H V }$ were obtained from this configuration.   
3 As energy density was reduced,narrow and shallow melt pools resulted,as did unmelted powders with micro-cracks at the matrix interface. In contrast, the $1 2 5 \mathrm { J / m m ^ { 3 } }$ energy density produced large, deep melt pools without unmelted powders or cracks. Keyhole pores were formed as energy density increased.   
4 The ANOVA results indicate that scanning speed is the most significant for affecting density,followed by layer thickness and power.   
5 The porosity and microstructure of the as-built part have a major impact on its hardness.Scan speed is the most critical parameter affecting hardness,followed by power，while layer thickness is comparativelylessimportant.   
6 The yield and tensile strength of the parts range from $6 2 4 \pm 8$ MPa to $6 4 9 \pm 4$ MPa.The grain size and the defects directly affect these

values. Strength values drop as scanning speed increases and energy density decreases because of a decrease in material density.

# ARTICLEINFO
Handling editor:L Murr

Keywords:   
Powder particle   
Neck formation   
Particle bonding   
Laser powder bed fusion   
Neck size   
SS316L
summary: Effect of laser speed on neck formation in SS316L powder joining for LPBF

name: 2024 - J. Materials Research and Technology - Mazlan et al. - Effect of laser speed on neck formation in SS316L powder joining for LPBF-part-2
fileName: 2024 - J. Materials Research and Technology - Mazlan et al. - Effect of laser speed on neck formation in SS316L powder joining for LPBF.md
content: The objective ofthis study is to comprehend how changes in laser speed afect the behaviour and features of neck formation in Ss316L during powder bed fusion.This study examines the impact of various laser speeds on the neck formation in the commonly used SS316L. Uniweld Laser 30oo was used for laser joining.A constant laser power of $_ { 1 5 \mathrm { W } }$ and laser scan speed of $2 5 { - } 1 5 0 \mathrm { m m } / s$ were implemented,and powder joining within a single track was observed.Results show that neck size decreases with increasing laser scanning speed and no particle joining occurs at $1 5 0 \ \mathrm { m m } / s$ scan speed,as it is considered too fast for sufficient heat absorption and melting.As laser speed decreases to $1 2 5 \ \mathrm { m m } / s$ ,neck starts to form because the particles absorb more heat,which facilitates melting and bonding. Surface diffusion occurs early at this stage because it requires only a small amount of energy to break atomic bonds on the surfaces of particles compared to those in the internal part.This process involves atoms moving along the surfaces of the particles,facilitating the initial stages of sintering by reducing surface energy and causing neck formation between particles.At $1 2 5 \mathrm { m m } / s$ ,the particle shape remains spherical, and the average neck size is $4 9 \ { \mu \mathrm { m } }$ .At $1 0 0 ~ { \mu \mathrm { m } }$ ,the powder average neck size is $6 2 ~ { \mu \mathrm { m } }$ .Moreover,the powder completely merges at $5 0 \ \mathrm { m m } / s$ and $2 5 \ \mathrm { m m } / s$ .The neck formed between particles considerably improves the product's mechanical strength by strengthening bonds between particles.Material density increases with neck quality,and stable neck growth can reduce the porosity of the finalparts.Ensuring thermal stability inthe laser powder bed fusion alows consistent heat to particles,ensuring even temperature in materials and ultimately facilitating stable neck growth.

name: 2024 - J. Materials Research and Technology - Mazlan et al. - Effect of laser speed on neck formation in SS316L powder joining for LPBF-part-3
fileName: 2024 - J. Materials Research and Technology - Mazlan et al. - Effect of laser speed on neck formation in SS316L powder joining for LPBF.md
content: Thermal stability enables atoms in particles to migrate efficiently and prevents defects,such as bubbling,which increases porosity in printed parts.Therefore,a slow scanning speed allows particles to absorb more heatfor melting,increasing the neck size of particles.This knowledge is useful for optimizing laser processing parameters in various industrial applications.

name: 2024 - J. Materials Research and Technology - Mazlan et al. - Effect of laser speed on neck formation in SS316L powder joining for LPBF-part-4
fileName: 2024 - J. Materials Research and Technology - Mazlan et al. - Effect of laser speed on neck formation in SS316L powder joining for LPBF.md
content: Additive manufacturing (AM) is a three-dimensional (3D) printing process that produces a 3D object by adding material layer by layer through a computer-controlled process [1].3D printing has been widely used because it can produce complex geometries with low amount of material waste [2],thus drawing considerable interest from medical, aerospace,automotive,and marine industries [3,4].Various types of 3D printing techniques have been developed for diferent types of materials, offering unique advantages and specific applications.These techniques include fused deposition modelling (FDM) for plastics,selective laser sintering for metals and polymers,and stereolithography for resins [5]. One of the techniques used in metallic powder is laser powder bed fusion (LPBF)which usies a high-powered laser to selectively melt and fuse layers of metallic powder to create complex,high-precision parts [6,7]. Laser technology in manufacturing has traditionally been utilized in applications such as cutting [8],drilling [9,1O],welding [11],and joining.Recently,attention has shifted towards its use in additive manufacturing [l2]，particularly in powder joining processes.This advancement necessitates the optimization of parameters to ensure precise melting of particles layer by layer,enabling the creation of complex and high-quality components [13].In LBPF,a high-power laser was used to melt metal powder particles to form 3D parts [14-16]. The melted powder forms a liquid bridge known as necking bridges,which connect the particles [17,18].The neck is typically non-spherical with a circular cros-section,and its profile is comparable to a one-sheet hyperboloid known as kink [19].

name: 2024 - J. Materials Research and Technology - Mazlan et al. - Effect of laser speed on neck formation in SS316L powder joining for LPBF-part-5
fileName: 2024 - J. Materials Research and Technology - Mazlan et al. - Effect of laser speed on neck formation in SS316L powder joining for LPBF.md
content:
Extensive studies on LPBF have focused on laser parameters,such as laser power and scanning speed [2O,21].However,neck formation in LPBF is considerably influenced by the critical factor of powder parameters,such as particle shape,particle size and particle size distribution,which also affects neck growth ratio.Hence,neck formation between particles is one of the crucial phenomena that can be observed in AM,since the quality of particle neck affects the quality of final products.

Particle neck forms through sintering mechanisms,including surface diffusion (SD),volume diffusion (VD） and grain boundary diffusion (GBD)[22].The initial stages of neck formation involve SD mechanism phases,in which grain boundaries diffuse with neighbouring particles through a process known as necking.In this process,diffusion occurs only on the outer surface,where a small amount of heat energy is required to rearrange atoms on the surfaces of particles.Due to rearrangement of grain boundary atoms,porosity arises between particles. When substantial energy is absorbed by the particles,VD occurs,in which the neck size increases,internal particles diffuse and the pore size decreases [23]. Pores decrease in size either because solid particles enter the pores during the rearrangement of atoms to the surfaces of pores between particles [24] or gas is released from pores [25].As the sintering time increases,GBD occurs,in which rapid neck size growth occurs at grain boundaries.Such growth is aided by irregular particle shapes,which enhances grain boundary growth [26].However,determining the diffusion type in VD and GBD mechanisms is difficult because diffusion occurs in the internal parts of atoms.At the initial stage of SD, the formation of kinks between the particles can be clearly observed.For proper sintering mechanisms,the stages begin with SD,followed by VD and GBD.However,controlling this process is challenging because GBD occurs ata relatively faster rate than VD.

name: 2024 - J. Materials Research and Technology - Mazlan et al. - Effect of laser speed on neck formation in SS316L powder joining for LPBF-part-6
fileName: 2024 - J. Materials Research and Technology - Mazlan et al. - Effect of laser speed on neck formation in SS316L powder joining for LPBF.md
content: Despite the importance of interparticle necking in AM, experimental studies on the process is lacking,and studies have focused on simulation research in recent years [24,27-31].A study developed a molecular dynamics (MD) model to explore the sintering mechanism of AlSi10Mg with varying particles sizes [31]; the diffusion of unequally sized particles is faster than that of equally sized particles; this finding highlights the importance of particle size distribution in the optimization of sintering processes for materials,such as AlSiloMg.Li etal.[3O] conducted MD simulations to study the sintering behaviour of silver nanoparticles and nanoflakes of the same size.Meanwhile,Dai et al.[29] simulated neck growth through SD mechanisms in metal fibres by using the lattice Boltzmann method.Both studies found that the key mechanism for necking is SD,elucidating how atoms move across the surfaces of particles,aggregate in neck areas and facilitating bond formation and neck growth.Another study determined that the displacement per atom/mm increases with sintering temperature in the internal and surface atoms of the particles [28]. These simulations show how particles bond during sintering,emphasising the importance of factors,such as particle size and temperature.

name: 2024 - J. Materials Research and Technology - Mazlan et al. - Effect of laser speed on neck formation in SS316L powder joining for LPBF-part-7
fileName: 2024 - J. Materials Research and Technology - Mazlan et al. - Effect of laser speed on neck formation in SS316L powder joining for LPBF.md
content:
Some studies explored necking through experimentation. One study setup a dedicated experiment for sintering two isolated titanium particles with three different pulsed laser rates (1o,2O and $5 0 ~ \mathrm { k H z }$ ，and necking was observed after each round of laser irradiation [32]. Hejmady etal.[33] observed neck formation between two isolated polymer particles over time by using a custom experimental setup in situ for laser sintering.In both experiments,laser was applied to two selected powder particles.The powder was picked up by using small-diameter glass pipette with vacuum.The packed powder was inserted onto a substrate for the laser process.This aspect remains largely unexplored and requires further investigation because it may provide valuable insights into neckbehaviour in LPBF process.

In this study, neck formation during laser sintering was explored by analysing the effects of different scanning speeds.The effects of laser parameters on necking growth between particles were then examined at different scanning speeds.The range of laser energy density indicates the amount of heat that the particles absorbed during the process.The results provide a theoretical basis for determining sintering mechanism and diffusion behaviours during the laser process.The findings of this study can help in understanding and reducing the defects that occur in the selective laser melting (SLM) process.Managing the heat-affected zone (HAZ) and cooling rates ensures fine grain structures and improved mechanical properties.Nowadays,SLM machines are limited to few materials with restricted parameter specifications.Therefore, understanding how the neck form between the particles can help improve the laser system where any laser can be used to melt or sinter particles with different properties.

name: 2024 - J. Materials Research and Technology - Mazlan et al. - Effect of laser speed on neck formation in SS316L powder joining for LPBF-part-8
fileName: 2024 - J. Materials Research and Technology - Mazlan et al. - Effect of laser speed on neck formation in SS316L powder joining for LPBF.md

name: 2024 - J. Materials Research and Technology - Mazlan et al. - Effect of laser speed on neck formation in SS316L powder joining for LPBF-part-9
fileName: 2024 - J. Materials Research and Technology - Mazlan et al. - Effect of laser speed on neck formation in SS316L powder joining for LPBF.md
content:
# 2.1． Experimental setup
Fig.1(a) depicts the experimental setup for the laser sintering experiments.Laser sintering was conducted using a custom-made chamber equipped with $1 0 6 4 \mathrm { m m }$ Theta lens at the top.A laser beam would pass through the lens and irradiate the deposited powder particles on the 100 $\mu \mathrm { m }$ -thick powder bed.The laser profile used was the Gaussian beam profile of $1 5 0 \mu \mathrm { m }$ diameter with continuous wave mode made from Nd: YAG fibre laser.During laser processing,argon gas was used to prevent oxidation [34].A batch of powder was deposited onto the powder bed. Laser power was set at 15 W,and the scanning speeds ranged from 150 $\mathrm { { \ m m } } / s$ (fastest) to $2 5 \mathrm { m m } / s$ (slowest).Interparticle necking between the powder particles was observed at low laser power because high laser power would result in the solidification of melted parts and their merging with the powder bed which would hinder the observation of neck formation. In this study,the powder particle distribution was varied,and a low-power laser was used to observe the necking process to prevent overmelting and ensure only partial melting of individual tracks.Given that the powder size was $1 0 0 \mu \mathrm { m }$ and joining occurred only between particles,it was challenging to transfer the joined powder to the SEM machine.To address this,a copper tape was used to secure the joined powder,allowing for necking observation.The average neck size was then measured using ImageJ software,and only particles with an average size between 90 and $1 0 0 \mu \mathrm { m }$ were selected for analysis. Table 1 shows the process parameters for the single-track experiment. The element distribution of each lasered sample was analysed with an energy-dispersive spectroscopy system (Oxford,UK) equipped in the field emission scanning electron microscopy (FESEM) system.

name: 2024 - J. Materials Research and Technology - Mazlan et al. - Effect of laser speed on neck formation in SS316L powder joining for LPBF-part-10

A gas-atomised SS316L powder with an average diameter of unimodal of $1 0 0 ~ { \mu \mathrm { m } }$ was employed in this study.Powder samples were observed using the SEM images shown in Fig.1(b). Shape analysis was conducted usinga FESEM system (Zeiss,model Merlin Compact from Germany).The microstructural characteristics prominently depicted the presence of smooth and spherical particles within the powder composition.This spherical morphology indicate a uniform and homogeneous particle structure,which is crucial for achieving consistent and reliable sintering results.Spherical particles were the most common,which improved packing density. Compared with irregularly shaped particles, spherical particles have more uniform surface areas,allowing for consistent laser absorption for melting [35].Moreover,spherical particles ensure consistent layer thickness,which allows for constant heat absorption [36],facilitates the control of melting processes and producing high-quality,detailed final products.The particle size distribution is illustrated in Fig.1(c) and listed in Table 2.The average powder

name: 2024 - J. Materials Research and Technology - Mazlan et al. - Effect of laser speed on neck formation in SS316L powder joining for LPBF-part-13
fileName: 2024 - J. Materials Research and Technology - Mazlan et al. - Effect of laser speed on neck formation in SS316L powder joining for LPBF.md
content: The observation of single-track formations via SEM (Fig.2) revealed that the sizes of the tracks increased with decreasing scanning speed (from $1 5 0 \ \mathrm { m m } / s$ to $2 5 \ \mathrm { m m } / s$ ).The right side of Fig.2 shows the magnified view of each image in Fig. 2(a), (b),(c),(d), (e),and (f). In Fig.2(a),the scanning track was indistinct and lacked uniformity, indicating insuficient melting because of inadequate heat energy. This observation aligns with the findings of D.Wang et al.[37]，who demonstrated that high scanning speeds resulting from low energy input led to the partial melting of particles.Meanwhile,Yadroitsev etal. [38] showed that an inconsistent single track formed because of the formation of droplets. Fig.2(d) and (e) showcase a notably consistent scanning track,indicating successful melting as the scanning speed decreased. This decrease in scanning speed enabled powder particles to absorb more heat energy provided by the laser beam.Hence, extended exposure to heat energy allowed for controlled and stable melting,ensuring uniform and effective melting of powder particles and resulting in well-defined and consistent scanning tracks.The relationship between scanning speed and heat energy absorption plays a crucial role in selective laser melting,influencing the quality and uniformity of tracks produced [38,39].As the scanning speed decreased to $2 5 \ \mathrm { m m } / s$ ，the scanning track lost stability and issues,such as balling,manifested.The slow speed caused excessive heating,resulting in a balling effect and considerable increase in track thickness.Kempen etal.[4O] highlighted that low scanning speeds with high energy inputs can distort scanning tracks because of increased recoil pressure,demonstrating the critical role of scanning speed in track continuity and occurrence of discontinuities at speeds below $5 0 \ \mathrm { m m } / s$ .
summary: 3.1．Single track fabrication observations under SEM - Part 1/2

name: 2024 - J. Materials Research and Technology - Mazlan et al. - Effect of laser speed on neck formation in SS316L powder joining for LPBF-part-15
fileName: 2024 - J. Materials Research and Technology - Mazlan et al. - Effect of laser speed on neck formation in SS316L powder joining for LPBF.md
content:
To analyse neck growth after the laser process,the sample was observed under SEM,and the neck size was measured using Image J. This neck formation was highly affected by laser scanning speed. The trend of neck size over laser scanning speed is shown in Fig.4,in addition to the effect of different scanning speeds from fastest ( $\mathrm { 1 5 0 } \mathrm { m m } /$ s) to slowest $( 2 5 \ \mathrm { m m } / s )$ .The neck size increased as scanning speed decreased.At laser power of $1 5 \mathrm { W }$ and scanning speed of $1 5 0 \mathrm { m m } / s$ ,the average neck size was $0 \ \mu \mathrm { m }$ because the scanning speed was extremely fast for the particles to absorb enough heat from the laser.This poor heat absorption at $1 5 0 \ \mathrm { m m } / s$ led to an incomplete melting process because the energy to break the atom barrier for melting process is not enough.

As the laser speed decreased to $1 2 5 \ \mathrm { m m } / s$ ，neck started to form. Fig.4(b) illustrates the formation of a small neck,whilst the particle shapes remained completely circular.At this stage,reducing the scanning speed slightly ensured that the powder particles had sufficient time to interact with the laser and absorb heat.This condition provided enough energy to overcome the surface energy barrier,breaking the atomic bonds at the small neck bridges,known as kinks, that formed between particles.These kinks created vacancies,leading to atom repositioning and smoothening the surfaces [41].The Young-Laplace law played a role in kink formation.The semi-liquid state of melted powder particles resulted ina hydrophilic outer surface,which attracted liquid from neighbouring particles and contributed to kink formation. Notably,large powder particles tended to exhibit pronounced kink formation because of Young-Laplace's law,where the larger particles often engulfed the smaller particles.

name: 2024 - J. Materials Research and Technology - Mazlan et al. - Effect of laser speed on neck formation in SS316L powder joining for LPBF-part-16
fileName: 2024 - J. Materials Research and Technology - Mazlan et al. - Effect of laser speed on neck formation in SS316L powder joining for LPBF.md
content: At $1 0 0 \ \mathrm { m m } / s$ ,the average neck size increased to $6 2 \ \mu \mathrm { m } .$ , indicating that more heat energy was absorbed by the particles for melting process. Neck size increased,and powder particles almost fully diffused; however satellite shapes formed at the outer surface.The powder particles at this stage were unable to maintain their original shapes.Reducing the scanning speed to $1 0 0 \mathrm { m m } / s$ allowed particles to absorb more energy,as observed in SEM images.This phenomenon resulted in the formation of more stable and larger necking bridges,indicating a more effective melting process.The slower scanning speed at $1 0 0 \ \mathrm { m m } / s$ provided additional heat energy,leading to improved particle fusion compared to the faster $1 2 5 \mathrm { m m } / s$ speed.As the scanning speed decreased to $7 5 \mathrm { m m } / s$ complete neck formation was observed,which indicated that the powder particles absorbed sufficient energy for stable melting strong and large neck formed. Compared with the neck at $1 0 0 \ \mathrm { m m } / s$ in Fig. 4(d), the joined particles surface for $5 0 \ \mathrm { m m } / s$ in Fig.4(e) was smoother. Lastly, at $5 0 \mathrm { m m } / s$ ,the particle size doubled,suggesting that complete particle diffusion occurred,and the particles were completely mixed and integrated,ensuring optimal bonding and uniformity in the material structure.A hydrophilic state allows for the formation of neck.According to Young-Laplace law,pressure difference in molten material between two particles initiates neck growth.Equation(1） shows the related formula for Young-Laplace law,where pressure difference is inversely proportional to the radius.Pressure difference increases with decreasing radius. The Bernouli's principle states that liquids have tendency to minimise or balance the difference in energy and pressure by flowing from high-pressure areas to low-pressure areas.As shown in Fig.

However,a further decrease in the scanning speed causes in balling effect,as shown in Fig.4(f).Ata laser scanning speed of $2 5 \mathrm { m m } / s$ ,the size was threefold the original size, indicating that excessive heating process led to unnecessary particle joining. This indicates that at 50 $\mathrm { m m } / s$ ，particle joining ceased.At this speed,the particles were fully engulfed,resulting in a size twice that of the original particles. Compared to $7 5 \ \mathrm { m m } / s$ ，fewer surface bumps or irregularities were observed,suggesting that at $5 0 \ \mathrm { m m } / s$ ，the particles had completely diffused into one another.Therefore,ata slower scanning speed of 25 $\mathrm { m m } / s$ ,particles had more time to absorb heat from the laser,leading to

name: 2024 - J. Materials Research and Technology - Mazlan et al. - Effect of laser speed on neck formation in SS316L powder joining for LPBF-part-18
fileName: 2024 - J. Materials Research and Technology - Mazlan et al. - Effect of laser speed on neck formation in SS316L powder joining for LPBF.md
content:

![](images/e84a1638a4830892a6228ed4b200db69a7e5fb791d0e7c1173fde7b943fc0a1f.jpg)  
Fig.4.Neck size of powder particles at different scanning speeds.

melting and reheating of nearby particles, which could cause the balling effect due to excessive molten material forming droplets [42].This phenomenon might cause in poor thermal stability,which could lead to the entrapment of gas bubbles at grain boundaries.High laser power led to fast neck growth in conformity with Laplace law because pressure difference considerably increases when powder particles radius between the neck and particle was large.High pressure difference eventually resulted in fast and inefficient liquid flow that might cause vapor bubbles to form,which were trapped between grain boundaries.According to Randall [43], pore coarsening occurs through the Ostwald ripening effect,in which small bubbles diffuse with large bubbles and increase porosity. This mode of heat transfer can lead to the remelting of particles,adversely affecting final products.Consequently,issues,such as porosity and poor surface finish,may arise,compromising the quality and integrity of materials.According to Mazlan et al.'s study in 2023 [22],a high porosity value results in poor neck formation, leading to reduced mechanical strength and weakened planar interfaces between the layers.

name: 2024 - J. Materials Research and Technology - Mazlan et al. - Effect of laser speed on neck formation in SS316L powder joining for LPBF-part-19
fileName: 2024 - J. Materials Research and Technology - Mazlan et al. - Effect of laser speed on neck formation in SS316L powder joining for LPBF.md
content: The scanning speed of the laser played a critical role in neck formation.At slower scanning speeds,the particles absorb more heat due to higher energy density [44],resulting in a more stable heating process conducive to consistent neck formation.However,if the scanning speed was excessively slow or fast, it may cause either insufficient melting or over-melting,as illustrated in Fig.4.Thermal stability during neck growth was crucial for controlling the density of the material.An effective diffusion mechanism should progress from SD to VD,and finally to GBD.However,VD typically occured at a slower rate than GBD.Poor thermal stability could shorten the phase of VD,leading directly to GBD. This phenomenon could result in gas entrapment and pore coarsening,known as Ostwald ripening.Consequently,spherical pores were frequently observed in the final parts of printed SLM components.Therefore,moderate laser power with slow scanning speed is recommended because it ensures thermal stability during heating.This thermal stability is required for uniform neck formation and prevents overheating or underheating,which can lead to uneven neck growth and poor neck growth.

name: 2024 - J. Materials Research and Technology - Mazlan et al. - Effect of laser speed on neck formation in SS316L powder joining for LPBF-part-20
fileName: 2024 - J. Materials Research and Technology - Mazlan et al. - Effect of laser speed on neck formation in SS316L powder joining for LPBF.md
content: The neck size obtained in the previous section can be used in categorising the diffusion mechanisms in the three main stages.The diffusion stages of two neighbouring particles consist of SD,VD and GBD.The different stages during diffusion mechanism were successfully observed under SEM (Fig.5) at different laser configurations.

name: 2024 - J. Materials Research and Technology - Mazlan et al. - Effect of laser speed on neck formation in SS316L powder joining for LPBF-part-21
fileName: 2024 - J. Materials Research and Technology - Mazlan et al. - Effect of laser speed on neck formation in SS316L powder joining for LPBF.md
content: Fig.5 (a) shows the SD stage,where some particles were approximately close to one another.In the diffusion process,SD served as the initial and most critical stage in neck formation.This mechanism occured first because atoms located on the surface of particles absorb heat more rapidly compared to those within the bulk.Atoms on the surface of a material tended to move due to defects present at the atomic level.As the temperature rose,these loosely bound atoms started to break free and moved across the surface.SD,which involved this movement,required lower activation energy compared to other mass transport methods,making it more significant at lower temperatures [45].Consequently,surface atoms were more likely to melt before the interior atoms.The melting of these outer surface particles initiated the neck process,as it leads to the formation of a liquid bridge between adjacent particles.When low heat energy was applied, heat was initially absorbed by the particles,and atoms were excited,especially on the outer surface.Therefore,the partially melted outer surface areas with high surface tension were attracted to neighbouring partially melted outer surfaces.The formation of liquid bridges results in high surface energy in the neck regions.To reduce this surface energy,atoms will migrated away from the high-energy neck areas to regions of lower surface energy [46].This process caused the neck size to increase as the heating process progressed. Consequently, the volume of the partially melted particles detached from the core and formed kink,as shown in Fig.5 (d). This phenomenon is sometimes referred to as the bridging effect [47].The bottom particle had a large kink because of its small size and high absorbed energy.The kink was concave.When the kink came in contact with a neighbouring kink,the hollow area in the middle was surrounded,and gas was entrapped.These conditions increased porosity during the deformation stage when the diffusion stage was incomplete.

name: 2024 - J. Materials Research and Technology - Mazlan et al. - Effect of laser speed on neck formation in SS316L powder joining for LPBF-part-22
fileName: 2024 - J. Materials Research and Technology - Mazlan et al. - Effect of laser speed on neck formation in SS316L powder joining for LPBF.md
content:
As SD progresses,neck formation becomes more prominent.However, for subsequent diffusion mechanisms,such as VD and GBD,additional energy was required to penetrate the particle interiors.When these mechanisms took place,the surface particles were often fully melted,indicating that maximum SD had already been achieved.

High heat energy input transcended the SD stage to the VD stage,as shown in Fig.5 (b).During the diffusion stage in LPBF,the core areas within the particles partially melted as considerable heat energy was absorbed.The kinks formed in the previous stage bridged neighbouring particles,allowing the melted core material to flow and fill pores and hollow spaces.This interaction of factors,including heat absorption and kink formation,facilitated gradual melting and diffusion within particles,contributing to the overall fusion process.The diffusion of the interior part occured at a slow rate because breaking high-energy barriers required a large amount of energy [29]. This process greatly affected the quality and integrity of final products,ensuring the proper filling of voids and enhancing the structural cohesion of materials. Increment in volume diffused increased neck size,as shown in Fig.5(e). However,at this stage,neck size growth rate is very slow compared with SD and GBD.

![](images/5564a596ca6c7cb3581031dc9fee58612788aaacebaa127a8d6519884c3ea136.jpg)

name: 2024 - J. Materials Research and Technology - Mazlan et al. - Effect of laser speed on neck formation in SS316L powder joining for LPBF-part-23
fileName: 2024 - J. Materials Research and Technology - Mazlan et al. - Effect of laser speed on neck formation in SS316L powder joining for LPBF.md
content:
Once the process of VD resulted in the complete filling of hollow spaces and the melted core of both particles are were uniformly,GBD occurs.This process is faster than VD and promoted the densification of the sintering process [41].GBD accelerated the neck growth and material densification by enhancing atomic mobility along grain boundaries.This increased diffusion rate allowed for more effective particle bonding and reduced porosity,leading to larger neck sizes and a denser material with improved mechanical properties.In sintering with GBD, material moves from between particles to the neck surface.Pores released vacancies,which were then eliminated at the grain boundaries. This phenomenon caused mass to flow along the grain boundaries and deposit on the neck [41].

Therefore,with suficient heat energy,GBD was completed,and two particles successfully merged into a spherical particle with a volume twice that of each original particle,as shown in Fig.5 (c).

Fig.5(g),(h) and (i) illustrate the progression of neck size,transition from a small diameter (SD) to a medium diameter (VD) and GBD (the largest diameter is ultimately reached).

In conclusion, effective neck formation and material density control in AM depended on the progression of diffusion mechanisms.SD occured on the particle surface and resulted in weak neck strength.VD,which happened internally,required more energy but significantly enhanced neck strength and diffusion.GBD,while important, did not fully enhance neck strength without sufficient VD.Thus,a balance of all three diffusion processes is crucial for achieving optimal material properties and minimising defects such as spherical pores.

name: 2024 - J. Materials Research and Technology - Mazlan et al. - Effect of laser speed on neck formation in SS316L powder joining for LPBF-part-24
fileName: 2024 - J. Materials Research and Technology - Mazlan et al. - Effect of laser speed on neck formation in SS316L powder joining for LPBF.md
content: The EDX results provided valuable insights into how laser affects chemical composition. This information is crucial for understanding changes in material properties,detecting potential contamination or alloying element loss and ensuring the desired quality and performance of laser-processed materials.By analysing the EDX results shown in Table 3,we assessed the effect of laser treatment on SS316L and made necessary adjustments to optimise the process parameters.The results showed changes in the chemical composition of SS3l6L after laser treatment.The Ni content decreased with scanning speed,whereas Fe content showed no distinguish changes and Cr content increased.This result was in line with a 2O2l study,which stated that increase and decrease in chemical content were due to different evaporation rates in low-pressure condition [48]. This finding was already obtained by a 1964 study,which measured the evaporation rate of the chemical composition element of Ss316L at temperatures ranging from $7 6 0 ^ { \circ } \mathrm { C }$ to $9 8 0 ^ { \circ } \mathrm { C }$ under high-vacuum conditions.Bourgete etal. stated that Ni had lower evaporation rates than Fe and Ni,hence evaporated earlier.Thus, when the Ni content decreased, Cr content percentage increased.A study mentioned that the evaporation phenomena in SLM facilitate the mass transfer of melted materials to the environment.In this study,the Fe content did not show distinct changes because the laser energy density used was insufficient to melt Fe. Therefore,Cr content percentage increased with neck size.

name: 2024 - J. Materials Research and Technology - Mazlan et al. - Effect of laser speed on neck formation in SS316L powder joining for LPBF-part-25
fileName: 2024 - J. Materials Research and Technology - Mazlan et al. - Effect of laser speed on neck formation in SS316L powder joining for LPBF.md
content:
In conclusion, the evaporation of Ni and the subsequent increase in Cr content in SS316L could lead to increased brittleness and reduced mechanical strength due to Ni role in maintaining toughness [49]. Although Cr enhanced oxidation resistance,it was less effective than Ni in providing corrosion protection. These compositional changes could affect the material phase stability and overall performance.However, given that the percentage difference in composition is relatively small, the impact on the materials properties was expected to be minimal. name: 2024 - J. Materials Research and Technology - Mazlan et al. - Effect of laser speed on neck formation in SS316L powder joining for LPBF-part-26
fileName: 2024 - J. Materials Research and Technology - Mazlan et al. - Effect of laser speed on neck formation in SS316L powder joining for LPBF.md
content:
# 4．Conclusion
This investigation focused on the effects of laser scanning speed on neck formation in laser-sintered SS3l6L powder particles.The results are summarised as follows.

1.Scanning speed highly affected neck size and formation between powder particles.When a high scanning speed was used,powder particles were unable to absorb suficient heat energy for proper melting.By contrast,a low scanning speed allowed particles to absorb more heat efficiently for sufficient melting.   
2.SD was the first diffusion mechanism in sintering,whereas neck started to form.In this stage,the neck was small,which consisted of onlyan outer thin layer composed of surface particles for diffusion. The neck strength was relatively weak. The neck size was approximately $4 9 \mu \mathrm { m } .$ ,whereas small amounts of energy was suficient for SD stages to occur because SD was a fast mechanism.   
3.Another diffusion mechanism was VD.At these stages,difference in neck size was small.However,neck strength was relatively high because of the movement of the interior parts of the particles.   
4.GBD was one of the important mechanisms in sintering.At $1 0 0 \mathrm { m m } /$ s,neck size increased to $6 2 \mu \mathrm { m }$ .GBD resulted ina high neck size,and atoms were transported along the grain boundaries and promoted the densification of the materials.   
5.Increase in energy density caused the evaporation of Ni to the environment. Hence,as the Ni content decreased, Cr percentage increased in the materials.

name: 2024 - J. Materials Research and Technology - Mazlan et al. - Effect of laser speed on neck formation in SS316L powder joining for LPBF-part-27
fileName: 2024 - J. Materials Research and Technology - Mazlan et al. - Effect of laser speed on neck formation in SS316L powder joining for LPBF.md
content:
In addressing the complexities of AM,we recommend further investigation into the use of nonlocal mechanics to better describe the underlying physical processes.Nonlocal mechanics,which considers interactions across a broader range of material points,offers a more comprehensive understanding of factors such as heat distribution,stress development,and microstructural changes during AM.This approach could improve predictions of material behaviour,enhance part quality, and reduce defects.Future studies in this direction could provide valuable insights into optimizing AM technologies.

name: 2024 - Materials Today Communications - Tyagi, Manjaiah - Printability, post-processing and mechanical behaviour of sub-millimetre sized-part-3
fileName: 2024 - Materials Today Communications - Tyagi, Manjaiah - Printability, post-processing and mechanical behaviour of sub-millimetre sized.md
content: Laser powder bed fusion (LPBF） is now a well-established technique for producing metal components for practical use.Byutilizing the geometric flexibility of additive manufacturing (AM),a wide range of possibilities for part optimization using complex lattce-based structures are now available,allowing for performance improvements in various industries.Studies on such latice structures shows that the shape and size of parts and features have localized efects onresidual stresss,cooling rates inmelt pools, microstructure,and consequently, the mechanical properties of components.In the present work diferent TPMs (Gyroid,Diamond and Schwarz) lattice structures of a particular sub-millimetre cell size $( 7 0 0 ~ \mu \mathrm { m } )$ were manufactured in two separate orientations $\mathrm { 5 ^ { \circ } }$ and $9 0 ^ { \circ }$ )to the build platform.Later,post processing methods like electropolishing (EP)was used on one set of specimens to improve the surface finish of the latices and remove un-melted and trapped powder particles from the latice.Heat treatment (HT) was employed on another setto enhance the tensile yield strength. These latice structures were used to probe the influence of thin features on their manufacturability and further the tensile properties of as-built (AB)and post processed samples.The tensile characteristics of both AB and EP samples were relatively similar,although the EP samples displayed marginally lower yield strength and ultimate tensile strength (UTS) in most instances.The elastic modulus values varied between $7 . 5 \mathrm { G P a }$ to 11 GPa for lattices constructed at $9 0 ^ { \circ }$ and $0 ~ ^ { \circ }$ angles,respectively.In general, vertically constructed lattices exhibited superior UTs and percentage elongation compared to their horizontally built counterparts,except in the case of the schwarz latice.The analysis of fracture surface of diferent latice samples revealed a predominantly ductile transgranular fracture.

name: 2024 - Materials Today Communications - Tyagi, Manjaiah - Printability, post-processing and mechanical behaviour of sub-millimetre sized-part-4
fileName: 2024 - Materials Today Communications - Tyagi, Manjaiah - Printability, post-processing and mechanical behaviour of sub-millimetre sized.md
content: The development of Laser Powder Bed Fusion (LPBF) based lattice structures has received a great deal of attention recently as a result of their distinctive mechanical and functional qualities [1-3]．These structures offer several advantages,such as high strength-to-weight ratio [4-6],improved heat transfer [7-9],and enhanced energy absorption [10-l2],making them suitable for various applications.A lattice consists of a size scalable unit with 3D repetition [l3] that can be surface or strut-based skeletal,depending on the nature of the connecting elements.They are advantageous for reducing part weight and controlling stiffness,because of complete local control over wall thickness,unit geometry,surface area,and volume fraction. McGregor et al., 2021 [14] put forth a comprehensive literature review discussing the natural lattice architecture of human bones and comparing it with the Titanium based lattice structures developed for bone replacement and repair. The text also provided a systematic classification of the different lattice designs into cellular and stochastic lattice architecture.Among different lattice designs the Triply Periodic Minimal Surface (TPMS) structures have become popular due to their mathematical model-based design features which can be utilized to give them tailored properties by varying their cell size,shape and thickness.Moreover, TPMS structures are characterized by their zero mean curvature giving them smooth surfaces,free from sharp edges or junctions often found in traditional lattice structures [15,l6].Maskery et al. [17] conducted numerical investigation of such surface-based lattice structures with the objective of simplifying their design for additive manufacturing.

name: 2024 - Materials Today Communications - Tyagi, Manjaiah - Printability, post-processing and mechanical behaviour of sub-millimetre sized-part-5
fileName: 2024 - Materials Today Communications - Tyagi, Manjaiah - Printability, post-processing and mechanical behaviour of sub-millimetre sized.md
content: They developed a finite element model to predict the elastic modulus of the lattices in different directions and also observed that the cell geometry and cell orientation with respect to loading direction play a significant role in determining the elastic modulus of the lattice.Considering the advantages of the shape of these structures,the TPMS lattices exhibit a high degree of interconnectivity,with non-tortuous voids,which represent important advantages for a wide array of uses including the biomedical industry. TPMS structures possess a geometry and topology that closely resemble natural structures,making them particularly well-suited for a variety of biological applications [18].Recent advancements in LPBF technology have allowed for the production of highly complex and intricate lattice structures even with sub-millimetre feature sizes and high aspect ratios.However,the minimum feature sizes for a lattice appear to be limited by the LPBF processing parameters like laser spot diameter, laser power,scan speed and also the build orientation [2,19].

name: 2024 - Materials Today Communications - Tyagi, Manjaiah - Printability, post-processing and mechanical behaviour of sub-millimetre sized-part-6
fileName: 2024 - Materials Today Communications - Tyagi, Manjaiah - Printability, post-processing and mechanical behaviour of sub-millimetre sized.md
content: In a typical LPBF system, the laser creates a spot with a diameter of approximately $5 0 { \mathrm { - } } 1 0 0 ~ { \mu \mathrm { m } } ,$ and each layer has a thickness ranging between 30 and $1 0 0 \mu \mathrm { m }$ . The production process involves rapidly melting and cooling the material in localized areas.As consecutive layers are added,the previously melted tracks are re-melted and solidified, resulting in a complex thermal history within a volumetric unit of material.The temperature in and close to the laser focal point can fluctuate from 400 to $2 5 0 0 ~ \mathrm { K } ,$ causing the metal to exist in solid, liquid,or gas states [2O].Apart from evaporative and radiative cooling,the thermal energy produced by the laser is dissipated from the molten pool through several routes,encompassing the component itself, the supportive structures, the build platform,and to a lesser degree,the loose powder enveloping the component. Consequently, the thermal history experienced by the material depends on its geometry,which can have localized effects on the microstructure,composition, mechanical behaviour,and residual stresses of the final part. This dependency on geometry becomes more pronounced as the size of the part features is reduced to sub-millimetre scales. Smaller geometries restrict the amount of heat-conducting powder surrounding the moving melt pool. Additionally, as the features become finer, the laser scanning pattern shifts from beingpredominantlyhatch-basedtobeingpredominantly contour-based.A study by Liu et al.[21] on the effect of powder on the cooling rates shows that for temperatures higher than $4 0 0 ~ ^ { \circ } \mathrm { C }$ the effective thermal conductivity of powder increases with temperature. Further, it has also been reported that even the gas pressure maintained within the process chamber can significantly impact the conductivity of the powder where Wei et al.

name: 2024 - Materials Today Communications - Tyagi, Manjaiah - Printability, post-processing and mechanical behaviour of sub-millimetre sized-part-7
fileName: 2024 - Materials Today Communications - Tyagi, Manjaiah - Printability, post-processing and mechanical behaviour of sub-millimetre sized.md
content: [22] observed a rise in effective thermal conductivity of powder with increasing pressure. Several studies have been conducted to enquire the manufacturability of lattice structures using LPBF considering their dimensional accuracy and compressive strength. Bertocco et al.[2],printed multiple lattices using SS 17-4 PH powder with cubic and rombic dodecahedron architecture considering different cell sizes (3 to $1 0 \ \mathrm { m m }$ ）and varying LPBF processing parameters.It was observed that the vertical struts were printed with no macroscopic defects,whereas the horizontal struts showed the presence of large setalite particles and waviness in their axis.Also，the compression study on these lattices revealed adequate structural integrity for all the lattices and the suitable LPBF processing parameter to provide desired dimensional accuracy and strength were reported. In another study,López-Garcia et al. [23] manufactured AISI 316 L SS based latice structures in two orientation (horizontal and vertical) with strut sizes of $2 5 0 \mu \mathrm { m }$ $5 0 0 \mu \mathrm { m }$ and $1 \mathrm { m m }$ and showed that for fine struts the dimensional error varied from $5 \%$ to $2 5 \%$ whereas for coarse struts it was limited within $2 \%$ to $4 \%$ Further, they also observed the maximum relative error to be associated with vertically built lattices.On similar grounds, considering the manufacturability aspect of lattice structures, in a recent study on 316 L SS lattices by Olivas-alanis et al. it was reported that the LPBF process generated a strut diameter higher than the designed values and the dimensional deviations depended on the printing direction.

name: 2024 - Materials Today Communications - Tyagi, Manjaiah - Printability, post-processing and mechanical behaviour of sub-millimetre sized-part-8
fileName: 2024 - Materials Today Communications - Tyagi, Manjaiah - Printability, post-processing and mechanical behaviour of sub-millimetre sized.md
content: Precipitation-hardening stainless steel,specifically Grade $1 7 { - } 4 \mathrm { P H } ,$ is frequently used for applications requiring high strength,ductility,and toughness at high temperatures.The combination of such lattice structures with a material like SS 17-4PH can prove to be useful for applications like aerospace industry requiring lightweighting of components with optimum strength and energy absorption.Works on such lattice structures majorly focus on their compressive behaviour considering a cell size of $> 1 \mathrm { m m }$ due to easy of powder removal and good printability [2].However,in real applications a component is generally subjected to all kinds of loads be it compressive,tensile or bending.Recently,tensile testing of lattice structures is being explored for materials like Ti-6Al-4 V [24,25],Co-Cr [26] and SS 316 L [3]. Puttonen et al. [3] manufactured SS 316 L based TPMS lattice structures to study the impact of feature size and shape on susceptibility to corrosion and its localization in space and used a graded porosity lattice design to perform tensile testing of these structures.They found that among the three different wall thickness (0.867,0.515,and $0 . 3 2 3 \mathrm { m m }$ )manufactured the lattice with $0 . 3 2 3 \mathrm { m m }$ wall thickness displayed aggressive pitting.However, the tensile results did not indicate any clear signs of latent corrosion impact on mechanical behaviour.Though in this domain also,the manufacturing of submillimetre cell sized lattice structures still remains less examined. Smaller the cell size of lattice structures,higher the relative density which is expected to provide higher strength.However,as the cell size reduces the dimensions of elements in the unit cell come closer to the laser spot diameter and the irregularities in printing like powder attachment rises [3].

name: 2024 - Materials Today Communications - Tyagi, Manjaiah - Printability, post-processing and mechanical behaviour of sub-millimetre sized-part-9
fileName: 2024 - Materials Today Communications - Tyagi, Manjaiah - Printability, post-processing and mechanical behaviour of sub-millimetre sized.md
content:
Despite various design advantages of lattice structures,analysis of surfaces of stainless steel [2] and titanium [27] based lattices developed by L-PBF have revealed significant powder attachments on the surfaces.

Additionally,compared to a solid specimen,AMof lattice structures is known to have morphological deviations and micro-defects inherent to the fabrication process due to the presence of overhang features and a greater number of down-skin surfaces depending on the lattice design. Defects like strut waviness (offset of the cross-section centres from designed strut axis) is shown to adversely impact the elastic modulus of the lattice.The down-skin surfaces are the ones facing the build platform and while printing these features the powder present in the layers below gets agglomerated at the down-skin region due to diffusion of heat and causes dimensional inaccuracies [28-3O].Apart from these defects,for thin lattice structures with struts of ${ \sim } 2 0 0 \ \mu \mathrm { m }$ Mahmoud et al.[31] also observed uneven bulging melt tracks on the struts due to balling effect which occurs due to insuficient wetting of previous track by the molten metal which solidifies as spherical beads pertaining to surface tension. The presence of internal defects like porosity,lack of fusion is mitigated by optimizing the LPBF process parameters but the elimination of surface irregularities caused due to differential cooling rates,powder attachment,undercuts over the lattice elements are less addressed.For these defects,post-processing techniques like electropolishing provide great advantages as it has the capacity to evenly remove material throughout the intricacies of the lattice structure.

name: 2024 - Materials Today Communications - Tyagi, Manjaiah - Printability, post-processing and mechanical behaviour of sub-millimetre sized-part-10
fileName: 2024 - Materials Today Communications - Tyagi, Manjaiah - Printability, post-processing and mechanical behaviour of sub-millimetre sized.md
content:
This study pioneers an in-depth exploration into the printability of sub-millimetre cell size $( \sim 7 0 0 ~ \mu \mathrm { m } )$ TPMS lattice structures using LPBF technology,breaking new ground by investigating various orientations. Moreover, the research has explored viability of post-processing techniques like electro-polishing and heat treatment to significantly enhance both surface quality and mechanical properties of the as-built lattices respectively.Notably，this investigation encompasses three distinct TPMS structures Gyroid,Diamond,and Schwarz pushing boundaries in a field where literature and trials on sub-millimetre cells sized lattice structures are notably scarce.Setting a precedent,a deliberate choice of a $7 0 0 \mu \mathrm { m }$ cell size aims to achieve exceptionally fine lattice features,an area largely unexplored in existing research.By maintaininga fixed cell size and a near $5 0 \%$ relative density,this work meticulously examines the tensile behavior of these lattices in horizontally built (HB)and vertically built (VB) orientations,positioned at $0 ^ { \circ }$ and $9 0 ^ { \circ }$ angles to the build platform,respectively.Furthermore,the study delves into the profound impact of electro-polishing and heat treatment on the tensile strength of these lattice structures,offering valuable insights into advanced post-processing techniques. Table 1 Design features and corresponding mathematical equations of Gyroid, Diamond and Schwarz primitive TPMS lattice structures.
TPMS Lattice typeDesign featuresMathematical equation
Gyroidsin(y x) cos(yy)+sin(yy)cos(y z)+ sin (y z) cos(y x)
Diamondsin(yx)*sin(ψy)*sin(ψz)+sin( x)*cos (yy)*cos(ψz)+cos(ψx)*sin(ψy)*cos( y z)+cos(ψ x)*cos(ψy)*sin( z)
Schwarz8cos(ψ x)+cos(ψ y)+cos(ψ z)

name: 2024 - Materials Today Communications - Tyagi, Manjaiah - Printability, post-processing and mechanical behaviour of sub-millimetre sized-part-11
fileName: 2024 - Materials Today Communications - Tyagi, Manjaiah - Printability, post-processing and mechanical behaviour of sub-millimetre sized.md

name: 2024 - Materials Today Communications - Tyagi, Manjaiah - Printability, post-processing and mechanical behaviour of sub-millimetre sized-part-12
fileName: 2024 - Materials Today Communications - Tyagi, Manjaiah - Printability, post-processing and mechanical behaviour of sub-millimetre sized.md
content: The objective of this study was to evaluate the impact of shape of unit cell and part orientation on part printability and its mechanical behaviour (Tensile) developed using a laser spot size of $6 0 \mu \mathrm { m }$ . The study intentionally focused on the lower feature size range that is $7 0 0 \mu \mathrm { m }$ unit cell size and with a wall thickness for Gyroid and Diamond lattices ${ \sim } 2 7 0 ~ \mu \mathrm { m }$ and ${ \sim } 2 5 0 ~ \mu \mathrm { m }$ respectively whereas for Schwarz lattice the walls feature is absent by design.These design conditions were utilized to develop reoccurring lattice cells as a precise means of analyzing the mechanical response.This particular cell size was considered based on trials on less than $7 0 0 ~ { \mu \mathrm { m } }$ cell size like $5 0 0 \mu \mathrm { m }$ which led to distortions while manufacturing and improper powder removal characteristics.The present work focused on three different types of TPMs lattice structures: Gyroid,Diamond,and Schwarz,evaluating their satisfactory performance compared to other unit cell types,even at lower values of relative density,and their ability to be printed without support structures.The lattice cells included several features of interest,such as down-skin surfaces,bridging and thin walls.The geometric shape of each unit cell repeated in the structure,makes it an individual sample from a shape perspective.The designs were developed using the nTopology software (nTopology,New York,USA) with the in-built module on rectangular lattice design.The design features of each TPMS lattice(700 $\mu \mathrm { m }$ unit cell size) with the associated equation are shown in Table 1.The cell size of the TPMs lattice can be controlled by adjusting the values of coefficient ${ } ^ { \ast } \Psi ^ { \ast }$ ：

name: 2024 - Materials Today Communications - Tyagi, Manjaiah - Printability, post-processing and mechanical behaviour of sub-millimetre sized-part-13
fileName: 2024 - Materials Today Communications - Tyagi, Manjaiah - Printability, post-processing and mechanical behaviour of sub-millimetre sized.md
content:
The tensile samples were printed in the form of cuboidal blocks of dimensions $5 0 \times 1 0 \times 1 0 \mathrm { m m }$ encompassing the lattice structure at the gauge length (Fig.1).The ASTM E8 standard was employed for designing the tensile specimen.A total of 54 tensile samples were printed across 3 jobs,providing 3 samples for each condition,considering the repeatability of the testing process. The arrangement of samples remained consistent across all three jobs.The tensile samples were later drawn from these cuboids using wire cut EDM.The tensile coupons were not manufactured directly in the dog-bone shape as during trials it was observed that the manufacturing of vertical samples directly in the dog-bone shape led to distortions in the lattice region pertaining to thin features of the lattice and intrinsic high cooling rates $( \sim 1 0 ^ { 8 } \mathrm { K } / s )$ of the L-PBF process.

For the same unit cell size, each type of lattice(Gyroid,Diamond,and Schwarz) exhibits a relative density of approximately $5 0 \%$ ,considering the volume of the complete gauge length portion of the tensile samples. Furthermore,the shape of the lattice affects design features such as void size and strut thickness,as illustrated in Fig.2.Here,the strut thickness refers to the minimum diameter of the load-bearing member of the lattice.Notably,structures like the gyroid and diamond distribute the applied load more evenly across the cross-section compared to the Schwarz structure，which concentrates the load-bearing area mor. Further discussion on this topic is provided in the upcoming sections.

![](images/e1111f67c19c4dacb11dbba4ec1d7d9557a1aa837dec1385050e3ae278986973.jpg)  
Fig.1.(a) As-built cuboidal blocks in two different orientations ( $0 ^ { \circ }$ and $9 0 ^ { \circ }$ from the build platform) with lattice structure at the gauge length. (b) Design dimensions of Tensile coupons as per ASTM E8 standard.(c) Wire-cut tensile samples.

name: 2024 - Materials Today Communications - Tyagi, Manjaiah - Printability, post-processing and mechanical behaviour of sub-millimetre sized-part-14
