name: 2024 - Materials Today Communications - Tyagi, Manjaiah - Printability, post-processing and mechanical behaviour of sub-millimetre sized-part-16
fileName: 2024 - Materials Today Communications - Tyagi, Manjaiah - Printability, post-processing and mechanical behaviour of sub-millimetre sized.md
content:
# 2.2.Laser powder bed fusion process
The build setup preparation was done on 3DXpert $^ \mathrm { { . } } \textcircled { \mathbb { R } }$ software (version 15) using the STL files generated from nTopology software after meshing.The samples were fabricated using a 3D Systems DMP Flex 100 metal printer (Rock Hill, South Carolina, US) equipped with a $1 0 0 ~ \mathrm { W }$ fibre laser.An inside-out hexagon laser hatching strategy was utilized for printing all the samples,as depicted in Fig.3.The SS17-4Ph powder, supplied by 3D Systems,incorporated recycled powder sieved by a standard 45-micron mesh and reused fewer than 8 times during part printing.This ensured a powder particle size well within the desired range of 5 to $4 5 \mu \mathrm { m }$ ．According to existing literature，recycling SS17-4PH powder for up to 20 cycles is recommended.This practice has exhibited a decrease in surface roughness and internal porosities, showcasing improvement with an increased number of powder recycling cycles [32].However,contrary findings were reported by Lanzutti et al. [33] for AISI 316 L SS powder,where recycling the powder for 25 cycles resulted in larger pore sizes within the sample and an increased amount of inclusions.Nonetheless,they concluded that the quality of virgin powder was the primary factor impacting the number of inclusions in the manufactured parts. Fig. 4 displays a scanning electron microscope (SEM) micrograph of the powder,revealing the presence of satellite particles and a few distorted particles. The manufacturing process chamber was inerted using nitrogen gas. The values of the processing variables employed for manufacturing are detailed in Table 2.

The samples were built for three processing conditions i.e.as-built (AB), electropolished (EP) and heat treated (HT). The sample naming strategy followed can be understood from Table 3.

name: 2024 - Materials Today Communications - Tyagi, Manjaiah - Printability, post-processing and mechanical behaviour of sub-millimetre sized-part-17
fileName: 2024 - Materials Today Communications - Tyagi, Manjaiah - Printability, post-processing and mechanical behaviour of sub-millimetre sized.md
content:
Before metal 3D-printed parts can be utilized, they undergo crucial post-processing steps, starting with the removal of excess powders and supporting structures.Initially,the printed coupons were detached from the base plate using wire-cut EDM and then meticulously cleaned in an ethanol bath through ultrasonic treatment for $4 0 \mathrm { { m i n } }$ to eliminate all entrapped powder particles.Additional post-processing steps are essential to achieve the required surface and mechanical properties.In this study,one batch of tensile coupons underwent standard hardening heat treatment (ASTM A630,H9o0 condition) at $4 8 2 ^ { \circ } \mathrm { C } ,$ heatedatarate of $5 ~ { ^ \circ } \mathrm { C } / { \mathrm { m i n } }$ and held for $^ { 1 \mathrm { ~ h ~ } }$ ,followed by air cooling.Heat treatment serves as a vital post-processing method,aiding in relieving residual stresses developed during the L-PBF process and enhancing mechanical properties such as elastic modulus,yield strength,and ultimate tensile strength.Another batch of samples underwent electropolishing in a $1 0 \%$ vol. $\mathrm { H } _ { 2 } S 0 _ { 4 }$ solution.During electropolishing (EP),the lattice samples were made anodic (positively charged),causing the eradication of metal ions from the samples byapplying a current,as depicted in Fig.5.The voltage was maintained within the range of 4 to $5 \mathrm { V }$ using a DC power source,resulting in a current flow of approximately $3 . 3 \mathrm { \ A } .$ This condition was sustained for 4 to $5 \mathrm { { m i n } }$ to achieve the desired finish across the lattice surface.

# 2.4.Mechanical properties and geometrical analysis
Tensile testing of all samples was conducted using the WDW-100S

$1 0 0 \mathrm { k N }$ universal testing machine from IE Corporation, China, employing a displacement rate of $0 . 1 \mathrm { { m m / m i n } }$ .Due to variations in the crosssectional area of each lattice across different planes caused by their shapes,engineering stresses for individual lattice types were calculated based on the approximate minimum cross-sectional area encountered. The surface area from body block in nTopology software (Fig.6) was utilized for this calculation. The plane of minimum cross-section was determined using a trial-and-error method by gradually adjusting the plane location along the longitudinal axis.To assess the printability of lattices, 2O measurements were taken at various lattice features for parameters like strut diameter and void size using ImageJ software.These measurements provide a comparative analysis of different lattice features concerning build orientation and post-processng. Furthermore, Vickers microhardness (Hv） assessments were performed using a

fileName: 2024 - Materials Today Communications - Tyagi, Manjaiah - Printability, post-processing and mechanical behaviour of sub-millimetre sized.md
content:
During the L-PBF process, it's common to observe powder melting and slipping into the layer below,particularly noticed in the additive manufacturing of stainless steel. Consequently, rough edges may appear at the bottom surface of the lattice junctions.To evaluate the printability of the lattices,the relative density of the as-built test coupons was measured as an initial assessment.

![](images/0dcc212a052d560e1fc943670adb8cd94de3b93a18674c4ce6ed9c67791eb99c.jpg)  
Fig12.Mea structures are arranged.

![](images/45d28888ed5b45e41a9ca2ffe07b9d35765f56e525a4124bb097466aaea7fdb1.jpg)  
Fig.13.Optical micrographs of (a)& (c) As-built and (b) & (d) Heat treated.

The relative density measurements,conducted by dry weighing of the as-built lattices,demonstrated aclose agreement with the theoretical values (see Fig.7).This suggests that ata macro level, one can anticipate good printability,even for sub-millimeter TPMS latices using SS 17-4 ph material.To quantify the deviation between the as-built and postprocessed lattices,measurements for strut diameter and void size were taken as indicated in Fig.2.The strut diameterand void size exhibit an inverse relationship;a reduction in strut diameter leads to an increase in void size.As depicted in Fig.8,the HB samples exhibited greater deviation from the designed dimensions for all lattices compared to the VB samples.However, the variation in the diamond lattice was nearly equal for both build orientations.

name: 2024 - Materials Today Communications - Tyagi, Manjaiah - Printability, post-processing and mechanical behaviour of sub-millimetre sized-part-21
fileName: 2024 - Materials Today Communications - Tyagi, Manjaiah - Printability, post-processing and mechanical behaviour of sub-millimetre sized.md
content:
This deviation could potentially be attributed to the presence of struts positioned at a $4 5 ^ { \circ }$ angle to the build direction.Research has indicated that struts built at a $4 5 ^ { \circ }$ angle to the build platform tend to offer better dimensional accuracy compared to other orientations [28]. Notably, the Schwarz lattice exhibited the maximum deviation due to the inclusion of both horizontal and vertical struts in its design.Upon closer inspection,it was observed that the variation in dimensions did not stem from surface defects or unmelted particles but was primarily a result of thinner as-built features compared to the designed dimensions. This thinning of lattice features is likely caused by high thermal gradients during the L-PBF process,inducing shrinkage upon solidification. These thermal gradients tend to be more pronounced in horizontally built samples,given their increased surface area contact with the build plate.Consequently,this could be the reason for the higher geometric deviation in HB lattices.

![](images/6b5812fc3369ef673b6947ff396adeb7a1be3be829c017dcb3c3b8c691f955f3.jpg)  
Fig.14.Engineering stress-strain plots for samples built at $0 ^ { \circ }$ and $9 0 ^ { \circ }$ to the build platform for as-built,electropolished and heat-treated conditions.(a) Gyroid (b) Diamond and (c) Schwarz TPMS structures.

In such scenarios, post-processing methods such as electropolishing can be employed to eliminate unmelted powder particles and refine the surface.However,caution must be exercised to avoid excessive thinning of lattice features,as observed in the current study,which could potentially reduce the overall strength of the specimen.The difference between the surface features of samples built at $0 ^ { \circ }$ (horizontal) and $9 0 ^ { \circ }$ (vertical) to the build plate can be observed from Fig.9.

name: 2024 - Materials Today Communications - Tyagi, Manjaiah - Printability, post-processing and mechanical behaviour of sub-millimetre sized-part-22
fileName: 2024 - Materials Today Communications - Tyagi, Manjaiah - Printability, post-processing and mechanical behaviour of sub-millimetre sized.md
content: Horizontally built (HB) samples exhibit smoother surfaces compared to vertically built (VB) samples.The presence of attached powder particles exacerbates geometric inaccuracies during the manufacturing of lattice features.These inaccuracies are more pronounced on surfaces parallel to the building direction than on surfaces perpendicular to it, mainly due to the presence of partially sintered surrounding powder particles.Fig.9 illustrates that the quantity of residual powder particles attached to the surface varies with the lattice's shape,primarily influenced by the differing feature sizes of each lattice type. Cooling rates are impacted by the sizes of different lattice elements,where thinner features result in less effective cooling.Furthermore,the heat from the laser spot affects not only the solidified part but also the surrounding powder and the material from the layer beneath,leading to an uneven surface with partially melted powder particles and clusters of fused powder. Moreover,smaller void sizes (ranging from 150 to $3 5 0 ~ { \mu \mathrm { m } } )$ increase the likelihood of entrapped powder particles within the structure.This can be visually confirmed by examining the lattice against a bright light source,where open voids are distinctly visible for all lattices,confirming the absence of entrapped powder particles,at least ata macro scale.

name: 2024 - Materials Today Communications - Tyagi, Manjaiah - Printability, post-processing and mechanical behaviour of sub-millimetre sized-part-23
fileName: 2024 - Materials Today Communications - Tyagi, Manjaiah - Printability, post-processing and mechanical behaviour of sub-millimetre sized.md
content: For this study,the default processing parameters (layer thickness, laser power,scan speed,and hatch spacing)provided by the machine vendor were utilized for manufacturing the lattices. However,achieving higher quality thin-walled geometries can be further optimized by adjusting localized energy density,beam morphology,and laser scanning strategies.In certain LPBF systems, the use of pulsed laser scanning, instead of continuous wave mode,offers an alternative method to finetune the energy input.This approach provides enhanced control over the production of delicate features [34,35].By optimizing processing conditions to manufacture parts with superior surface morphology,the removal of powder from thin structures can be facilitated.Additionally, the sphericity and smaller particle size of feedstock powder also contribute positively in such cases.

name: 2024 - Materials Today Communications - Tyagi, Manjaiah - Printability, post-processing and mechanical behaviour of sub-millimetre sized-part-24
fileName: 2024 - Materials Today Communications - Tyagi, Manjaiah - Printability, post-processing and mechanical behaviour of sub-millimetre sized.md
content:
In this study,two distinct post-processing methods were employed. Electropolishing (EP) aimed to eliminate residual powder particles from voids and enhance the overall lattice surface finish,while heat treatment was performed to enhance the mechanical characteristics of the specimen,compensating for any impact the lattice might have on the part's strength.During the electropolishing process,the acid in the electrolyte solution interacts with the metal on the lattice structure's surface, causing it to dissolve.This dissolution effectively removes surface defects or roughness,resulting in a smoother and more polished surface. The process successfully eliminated significant portions of unmelted and loosely bound powder particles from the lattice structure's surface, exposing defects like undercut surfaces previously covered by partially sintered powder particles.These defects can act as sites for stress concentration, potentially initiating cracks under external loads.Moreover, this method proved useful in removing trapped powder from the lattice's thin features.Fig.1O provides a clear visual difference between the as-built and EP features of the three TPMS lattice structures.As depicted in the figure,the process resulted in void size enlargement due to the uniform removal of material from all faces of the lattice.

This observation is further supported by metallographic sections obtained from HB and VB lattices in both as-built and EP conditions,as depicted in Figs.11 and 12.Sections from EP samples exhibita reduced distribution of powder particles surrounding the lattices.Additionally, these sections reveal characteristic features such as up-skin and downskin formations,especially noticeable in overhang regions.Furthermore,phenomena like dross formation defects are evident,primarily occurring on downward-facing surfaces due to inadequate heat dissipation.

fileName: 2024 - Materials Today Communications - Tyagi, Manjaiah - Printability, post-processing and mechanical behaviour of sub-millimetre sized.md
content:
This can lead to reduction in strength of the lattice.However,one can provide a compensated design dimensions in the CAD model of the lattice to account for this removal of material to obtain the desired shape after electro-polishing.

Moreover, the parameters for electropolishing like applied current or voltage,polishing period,flow of electrolyte,temperature,and spacing between electrodes can have considerable impact on the surface quality. Optimization of these parameters can be further studied to obtain desired surface finish for LPBF lattice structures.

name: 2024 - Materials Today Communications - Tyagi, Manjaiah - Printability, post-processing and mechanical behaviour of sub-millimetre sized-part-26
fileName: 2024 - Materials Today Communications - Tyagi, Manjaiah - Printability, post-processing and mechanical behaviour of sub-millimetre sized.md
content: Fig.13 shows the optical micrographs of as-built and HT test coupons forboth the orientations.The difference between the microstructural features of HB and VB built samples is quite prominent.The thermal history of VB samples differs notably from that of HB ones.In the case of HB samples,the time duration between melted layers is considerably longer compared to VB ones.This discrepancy arises as a result of the higher melting area associated with each layer of HB specimen. This variance in layer-to-layer time intervals gives rise to a substantial contrast in terms of thermal history,specifically impacting the rate of cooling and aging temperature of the previously solidified powder. With a longer time,there is more opportunity for the heat to disperse, resulting in a gradual reduction in temperature at the conclusion of each printed layer as the time interval increases.This decrease in temperature of previously melted layers elevates the thermal gradient between the molten pool and the adjacent solid material. Consequently,higher cooling rates occur,driven by augmented heat exchange with the surroundings and previously molten layers,as outlined by Yadollahi etal. in their work [36].

name: 2024 - Materials Today Communications - Tyagi, Manjaiah - Printability, post-processing and mechanical behaviour of sub-millimetre sized-part-27
fileName: 2024 - Materials Today Communications - Tyagi, Manjaiah - Printability, post-processing and mechanical behaviour of sub-millimetre sized.md
content: Consequently,HB samples undergo a more rapid cooling rate compared to their VB counterparts.This discrepancy in cooling rates experienced during the manufacturing process gives rise to distinct microstructures and,consequently,varied mechanical properties for vertically and horizontally built samples.As shown in Fig.13 the HB microstructure shows a multimodal grain distribution with equiaxial small, elongated medium and more equiaxial large grains.The melt pool centreline led to formation of a network of dense grain bands.The heattreatment regime followed is known to lead the formation of fine precipitates or inclusions at the grain boundaries and triple junction which are shown to be rich in copper [37].This prevents the movement of dislocations during plastic deformation leading to increase in yield strength as observed in present work.However,the heat treatmentalso caused a significant reduction in ductility of the specimen $( 5 0 - 6 0 \% )$ when compared to as-built and EP condition.

name: 2024 - Materials Today Communications - Tyagi, Manjaiah - Printability, post-processing and mechanical behaviour of sub-millimetre sized-part-28
fileName: 2024 - Materials Today Communications - Tyagi, Manjaiah - Printability, post-processing and mechanical behaviour of sub-millimetre sized.md
content:
The results of the tensile testing were derived from the engineering stress-strain plots depicted in Fig.14.All samples exhibited an elastoplastic strain hardening behavior.To facilitate clearer analysis,the outcomes for each type of structure were segregated, clustering together the results for various processing conditions.Accompanying images illustrate the specific locations of sample failures along the gauge length. Stress calculations were based on the magnitude of the minimum crosssectional area of each lattice,as shown in Fig.6.The calculated areas for Gyroid and Diamond structures were approximately $5 . 1 3 5 5 \mathrm { m m } ^ { 2 }$ and $5 . 2 5 \mathrm { m m } ^ { 2 }$ ，respectively,while for Schwarz structures, it was around $2 . 0 4 1 2 \mathrm { m m } ^ { 2 }$ ，The tensile testing revealed that the behavior of Gyroid and Diamond structures was quite similar under tensile loading, attributed to their comparable cross-sectional areas and their primarily bending-dominated nature.Conversely, the behavior of Schwarz samples was erratic,with vertically built samples experiencing premature failure at the junction of the gauge length and gripping region.This occurrence might be attributed to the poor manufacturability of thin vertical struts (struts along the loading direction) in the Schwarz lattice, primarily a structure dominated by stretching.

name: 2024 - Materials Today Communications - Tyagi, Manjaiah - Printability, post-processing and mechanical behaviour of sub-millimetre sized-part-30
fileName: 2024 - Materials Today Communications - Tyagi, Manjaiah - Printability, post-processing and mechanical behaviour of sub-millimetre sized.md
content: Considering the tensile properties of different lattice structures.The variation in elastic modulus of gyroid and diamond lattices followed similar trend.The G-Hz and D-Hz series showed comparable values of modulus in the proximity of 11 GPa and $7 . 5 \ : \mathrm { G P a }$ respectively for all three conditions i.e.,AB,EP and HT.Whereas,for schwarz lattice the modulus values for S-Hz series varied between 35-40 GPa pertaining to higher stresses developed due to concentrated cross-sectional area. Moreover, the vertically built S-V series structures showed large variation in modulus value in the range of 14-36 GPa due to their unpredictable behaviouras discussed.For electro-polished parts the modulus values were slightly lower and for HT lattices were marginally higher. The impact of heat treatment was more pronounced for vertically built gyroid and diamond lattices.The G-V and D-V series lattices had lower modulus values when compared to their Hz counterparts.However, this gap was successfully reduced by employing the heat treatment regime. The G-V-HT and D-V-HT samples showed an increase in modulus of around $2 2 \%$ and $1 7 \%$ respectively.From the stress-strain plots it is seen that the VB lattice samples showed slightly better UTS and $\%$ elongation for gyroid and diamond specimen.This is contrary to the observations made for LPBF of solid SS 17-4 ph samples tested for different build orientations.In their study,Aripin etal.[38]found the strength of tensile specimen build at $9 0 ^ { \circ }$ to be lower than the samples build at $0 ^ { \circ }$ and $4 5 ^ { \circ }$ ： The direction of the melt pool layers to the load direction and porosity profiling were thought to be the causes of the variance in tensile strength.However,in case of lattice structures the load bearing struts are not always along the loading direction as in case of Gyroid and Diamond lattices.Hence the stresses developed do not act perpendicular to the melt pool layers for VB samples.

name: 2024 - Materials Today Communications - Tyagi, Manjaiah - Printability, post-processing and mechanical behaviour of sub-millimetre sized-part-32
fileName: 2024 - Materials Today Communications - Tyagi, Manjaiah - Printability, post-processing and mechanical behaviour of sub-millimetre sized.md
content: The H900 heat treatment schedule is a widely employed hardening process utilized to optimize the hardness of SS 17-4 ph material. One of the primary outcomes of the H9oo heat treatment is a substantial increase in hardness.This increase is attributed to the formation of fine precipitates,primarily Cu-rich phases and martensite,within the microstructure during aging.These precipitates hinder the movement of dislocations,contributing significantly to strengthening the material. This substantial increase in hardness,observed in the current study (refer to Fig.l6),aligns with the expected outcomes reported in literature [39]. Table 4.

name: 2024 - Materials Today Communications - Tyagi, Manjaiah - Printability, post-processing and mechanical behaviour of sub-millimetre sized-part-33
fileName: 2024 - Materials Today Communications - Tyagi, Manjaiah - Printability, post-processing and mechanical behaviour of sub-millimetre sized.md
content: Fig.17 displays SEM images capturing typical fracture surfaces observed for each lattice under both as-built and electropolished conditions.Notably,the fracture surfaces of these samples did not exhibit marked differences,as expected,since electropolishing does not significantly alter the bulk material properties.Across all struts,noticeable dimples on the fracture surfaces suggest that the primary mode of fracture for all lattices was a ductile transgranular fracture.However, the types of dimples observed on the strut surfaces were dependent on the orientation of the struts concerning the loading direction or the longitudinal axis of the specimen. In the case of the Schwarz structure, the load-bearing struts are aligned parallel to the longitudinal axis, creating a uniaxial stress condition along these struts.This stress configuration resulted in a cup-and-cone type fracture for Schwarz (both as-built and electropolished) struts,indicative of localized necking.This fracture pattern revealed predominantly equiaxed dimples on the surface.

name: 2024 - Materials Today Communications - Tyagi, Manjaiah - Printability, post-processing and mechanical behaviour of sub-millimetre sized-part-34
fileName: 2024 - Materials Today Communications - Tyagi, Manjaiah - Printability, post-processing and mechanical behaviour of sub-millimetre sized.md
content: Further,the struts of Gyroid and Diamond lattices are oriented approximately at $4 5 ^ { \circ }$ to the loading direction creating a complex stress state on the struts.This could be confirmed by the presence of parabolic dimples and cleavage surfaces on the fractured area of these struts [38, 40].The presence of partially melted particles adhering to the struts can be observed from the SEM images (Fig.17).Few studies shows that these particles increases surface roughness of the part and are detrimental to the mechanical properties of AM components [41,42].However, this observation is debatable as pointed out by Jam etal.[28].They showed that the attached powder particles can cover up the certain surface imperfections such as notched shape type defects.These defects directly influence local stress concentration and can lead to crack initiation in AM parts giving rise to misleading conclusions due to presence of attached powder particles at failure locations.For HT samples a considerable reduction in ductility was observed.This fact is supported by the observations that for HT series samples the failure was preceded bya brittle crack initiation ending with a ductile rupture of surface leaving behind distinguished surfaces of brittle cracking and ductile rupture as seen in Fig.18.

name: 2024 - Materials Today Communications - Tyagi, Manjaiah - Printability, post-processing and mechanical behaviour of sub-millimetre sized-part-35
fileName: 2024 - Materials Today Communications - Tyagi, Manjaiah - Printability, post-processing and mechanical behaviour of sub-millimetre sized.md
content:
The analysis of fracture surfaces also revealed defects like porosities present in the latices. Sometimes due to recoil pressure induced by metal evaporation,accompanied by the ejection of smaller droplets (spatters) a portion of metal gets displaced to adjacent region [43,44]. This displaced metal leaves a pore behind due to restricted flow of molten metal back to the original spot.This pore is referred to as a keyhole type porosity.Previous studies have shown that this porosity leaves a series of pores irrespective of build direction [38,45].Also, during the LPBF process,as a result of the vaporisation of low melting point metal constituents,gas bubbles may occur in the melt pool. Entrapment of gases has also been observed due to rapid melting and cooling occurring in LPBF.The spherical porosities observed in Fig.17 are a by-product of these entrapped gases.

Considering the defects in samples built at $0 ^ { \circ }$ and $9 0 ^ { \circ }$ orientation, the fracture surface of schwarz lattice built at $9 0 ^ { \circ }$ revealed large crater like holes as shown in Fig.19.Un-melted or partially melted powder particles may be trapped in the un-overlapped areas between neighbouring melt pools during the SLM process by inadequate melting.The existence of these low-density region encompassing the molten pool makes them prone to be pulled out while tensile testing leaving behind a crater like hole.Similar phenomenon was also noticed in the study by Zhong et al. (2016)[46].By altering the input scanning parameters,the severity of such flaws can be reduced,but they are challenging to completely eradicate.Such defects were more frequent in Schwarz lattices built at $9 0 ^ { \circ }$ which could be the reason for unpredictable behaviour of S-V series lattices.

name: 2024 - Materials Today Communications - Tyagi, Manjaiah - Printability, post-processing and mechanical behaviour of sub-millimetre sized-part-36
fileName: 2024 - Materials Today Communications - Tyagi, Manjaiah - Printability, post-processing and mechanical behaviour of sub-millimetre sized.md
content:
# 4. Conclusions
Three different TPMS lattice structures (Gyroid,Diamond and Schwarz) with a cell size of $7 0 0 \mu \mathrm { m }$ and in two orientation ( $[ 0 ^ { \circ }$ and $9 0 ^ { \circ }$ to the build platform were successfully manufactured using LPBF process.At macroscopic level the relative densities of as-built samples were in good agreement with the theoretical values.Based on the microscopic and mechanical analysis,following conclusions were drawn.

i. The manufacturability of lattices was compromised due to thin feature sizes,resulting in a significant presence of partially melted or completely un-melted powder particles on the surface.   
ii.Electropolishing successfully removed these particles,yet the process led to a minor reduction in overall strength and elongation of the lattice due to further thinning of struts postparticle removal. To counter this effect, compensatory measures could be implemented during the design stage,necessitating further analysis as a future scope.   
iii.Among the three structures,Gyroid and Diamond exhibited consistent results under tensile testing.However, the Schwarz structure's vertically built samples failed abruptly due to structural defects.   
iv.Heat treatment proved effective in enhancing the yield strength and hardness of lattice structures,albeit at the expense of reduced ductility.   
v.In conclusion,manufacturing sub-millimeter lattices using LPBF presents challenges,particularly regarding powder attachment over the surface.This study proposed a viable method to address this issue through post-processing techniques like Electropolishing.However,further optimization is essential to establish amore predictable methodology and attain desired properties in the final part.

name: 2025 - Int. J. Advanced Manufacturing Technology - Erman et al. - Diode area melting of SS316L using low power 450 nm lasers-part-1
fileName: 2025 - Int. J. Advanced Manufacturing Technology - Erman et al. - Diode area melting of SS316L using low power 450 nm lasers.md
content:
# Diode area melting of SS316L using low power 450 nm lasers
Sefer Can Erman1 $\textcircled{1}$ · Alkim Aydin1,3 . Kristian Groom²· Kamran Mumtaz1

Received: 28 October 2024/Accepted:19 January 2025/Published online:30 January 2025   
$\circledcirc$ The Author(s) 2025

# Abstract
This study investigates the use of Diode Area Melting (DAM) to process316L stainlessteel (SS316L),analternative to Laser Powder Bed Fusion (LPBF), utilising independently addressable, low-power $( \sim 3 . 5 \ : \mathrm { W } )$ （ $4 5 0 \mathrm { n m }$ blue lasers to address keylimitationsofPBF,inuding tralcontrol,saabilityandefciency.Anrmalisedenergydensity(NED)prog map was developed to ensure sucessul material melting. Results demonstrated that DAMcan achieve arelative density of $9 9 . 9 9 \%$ in single-layer SS316L samples using multiple $4 5 0 \mathrm { n m }$ blue diode lasers. Notably, DAM-processed SS316L exhibitedasignificantlyhigherdelta-feritecontent thansamples producedvia traditionalLPBF,whichisatributedtotheslower cooling rate in DAM ( $6 0 0 ~ ^ { \circ } \mathrm { C } / \mathrm { s }$ vs. $1 0 ^ { 7 } \mathrm { \Omega ^ { \circ } C / s } )$ . This increased delta-ferrite content enhances resistance to stress corrosion cracking in austenitic steel welds.Moreover,sub-grain cellular structures in the DAM-processed SS316L showed a $1 0 0 \%$ increase in size $( 4 \mu \mathrm { m } )$ compared to those produced by LPBF.

Keywords Diode Area Melting (DAM) $\cdot$ Laser Powder Bed Fusion (LPBF) $\cdot$ Stainless Steel 316L (SS316L) $\cdot$ 450 nm diode lasers
summary: Abstract, Diode area melting of SS316L using low power 450 nm lasers

name: 2025 - Int. J. Advanced Manufacturing Technology - Erman et al. - Diode area melting of SS316L using low power 450 nm lasers-part-2
fileName: 2025 - Int. J. Advanced Manufacturing Technology - Erman et al. - Diode area melting of SS316L using low power 450 nm lasers.md
content: Laser Powder Bed Fusion (LPBF) is a widely used Additive Manufacturing (AM) technology for the fabrication of complex metallic components.LPBF fabricates threedimensional parts by selectively melting feedstock material layer-by-layer using a rapidly scanning high-power fiber laser.LPBF is used to create components for several sectors such as the automobile and aerospace industries due to the ability to create lightweight components at a reduced lead time with a high design complexity [1].However, LPBF technology has some challenges,such as rapid cooling and heating cycles created by the use of a fast-moving laser, which can cause residual stresses and distortion in parts [2]. Zavala-Arredondo et al. [3] also emphasised the scalability limitations of this methodology and the inefficient use of high-power and high-wavelength lasers within LPBF systems.

name: 2025 - Int. J. Advanced Manufacturing Technology - Erman et al. - Diode area melting of SS316L using low power 450 nm lasers-part-3
fileName: 2025 - Int. J. Advanced Manufacturing Technology - Erman et al. - Diode area melting of SS316L using low power 450 nm lasers.md
content: Diode Area Melting (DAM) is an alternative to traditional LPBF using multiple low-power $( \sim 3 . 5 ~ \mathrm { W } )$ shortwavelength fiber-coupled diode lasers to melt feedstock material. This method was developed at the University of Sheffield and has enabled the processing of Ti6Al4V powder with $8 0 8 ~ \mathrm { n m }$ and $4 5 0 ~ \mathrm { n m }$ diode lasers previously [4-6]. This paper presents,for the first time,an in-depth study of the capabilities of the technology when processing stainless steel 316L (SS316L),a material extensively researched and processed for industrial applications using LPBF.316L's notable use in industry is due to its superior corrosion resistance [7],biocompatibility [8], strength,and cost-effectiveness [9]. SS316L is commonly preferred as an implant material in the medical field due to its excellent corrosion resistance and biocompatibility [10].Further research is being conducted on surface treatments for SS316L implants,such as electropolishing [11] and ion implantation [1O], to enhance their pitting resistance.Moreover, additively manufactured SS316L enables the production of complex geometries,making it suitable for scaffolds used in bone defect repair and joint replacements [12].Additionally, the superior pitting resistance of SS316L makes it a preferred material for use in corrosive environments, particularly in welding applications [13, 14].Additionally, numerical studies have been conducted to optimize and model the welding process of austenitic stainless steel [15].D'Andrea [16] reported that $4 0 . 7 \%$ of SS316L applications are in the petrochemical and chemical industries, $2 1 . 5 \%$ in marine onshore and offshore environments, $1 4 . 1 \%$ in biomedical applications,and $9 . 5 \%$ in the automobile sector.

name: 2025 - Int. J. Advanced Manufacturing Technology - Erman et al. - Diode area melting of SS316L using low power 450 nm lasers-part-4
fileName: 2025 - Int. J. Advanced Manufacturing Technology - Erman et al. - Diode area melting of SS316L using low power 450 nm lasers.md
content:
The laser absorptivity of metal surfaces is found to be significantly influenced by the wavelength of the laser employed [17]. The absorptivity of Ti6Al4V powder was increased by $1 4 \%$ when employing an $8 0 8 ~ \mathrm { n m }$ diode laser during DAM compared to traditional LPBF [5]. Furthermore,an additional $1 1 \%$ increase was observed when $4 5 0 \mathrm { n m }$ blue diode lasers were used in place of $8 0 8 \mathrm { n m }$ diode lasers [5]. Brandau et al.[18] investigated the absorbance of 39 different powders, varying grain sizes,at 2O different laser wavelengths. The absorptivity of the SS316L powder was measured at $7 8 . 4 \%$ using $4 5 0 ~ \mathrm { n m }$ diode lasers and at $7 1 . 2 \%$ using $1 0 7 0 \mathrm { n m }$ fibre lasers [18].

The laser power requirement for the fabrication of multilayer parts with LPBF is hundreds of watts [19-21], DAM enables the processing of single tracks and multi-layer parts with $3 . 5 { \mathrm { - } } 4 . 5 \mathrm { W }$ of power from a single-diode laser [5, 6] but scans across the powder bed at much lower speeds.In addition to laser power,it is important to discuss the differences in other process parameters, such as laser spot size, between DAM and traditional LPBF. Generally, the laser spot size in LPBF processing ranges from $5 0 \mu \mathrm { m }$ to $2 0 0 \mu \mathrm { m }$ [22-26]. In some cases, the laser spot size can increase up to $4 0 0 ~ { \mu \mathrm { m } }$ [27].In DAM, the laser spot size cannot be determined in the same way as in LPBF due to the integration of multiple diode lasers.It is influenced by the number of lasers used in the processing and is certainly wider compared to traditional LPBF,particularly in the direction perpendicular to the scanning direction.

name: 2025 - Int. J. Advanced Manufacturing Technology - Erman et al. - Diode area melting of SS316L using low power 450 nm lasers-part-5
fileName: 2025 - Int. J. Advanced Manufacturing Technology - Erman et al. - Diode area melting of SS316L using low power 450 nm lasers.md
content: The cooling rate of LPBF is typically within the range of $1 0 ^ { 3 }$ to $1 0 ^ { 8 } \mathrm { K ~ s ^ { - 1 } }$ [28]. The cyclic thermal history (i.e. rapid cooling and heating) and cooling rate of the traditional LPBF process have a significant impact on the microstructure of the resulting parts [29]. Vysotskiy et al. validated the efficacy of reducing the cooling rate through building direction to observe $\alpha$ -martensite in $1 7 { - } 4 ~ \mathrm { P H }$ samples [30]. The rapid cooling rate of Ti6Al4V results in the formation of a $\acute { \alpha }$ martensite microstructure [31]. In contrast to traditional LPBF processes,the cooling rate in DAM is significantly lower, measured at $6 0 0 ~ ^ { \circ } \mathrm { C / s }$ during the processing of Ti6Al4V [4]. The custom laser head assembly in DAM is intentionally designed to facilitate both preheating and post-heating, as well as remelting [4]. The remelting of the previously created track, facilitated by the laser beam geometry and hatch distance in DAM, leads to a slower cooling rate. This controlled cooling rate plays a crucial role in customising the microstructure of the parts. Caglar et al.[6] and Alsaddah et al.[5] successfully observed the $\beta$ -phase in Ti6Al4V due to a slower cooling rate in DAM.Additionally, the elevated cooling rate associated with LPBF applications has the potential to preclude the observation of the second phase, namely δ-ferrite,in SS316L samples [32].Nevertheless, rapid solidification has resulted in the formation of finer microstructures in the resulting parts [33]. The mechanical properties of LPBF parts with a finer microstructure than wrought samples,having higher yield strength and ultimate tensile strength [34].

name: 2025 - Int. J. Advanced Manufacturing Technology - Erman et al. - Diode area melting of SS316L using low power 450 nm lasers-part-6
fileName: 2025 - Int. J. Advanced Manufacturing Technology - Erman et al. - Diode area melting of SS316L using low power 450 nm lasers.md
content:
The majority of LPBF studies employ the volumetric energy density(VED) formulation to analyse the effects of process parameters on the densification [35] and mechanical properties [36] of the produced parts. The VED formula, presented as Eq.1, incorporates key process parameters such as $P$ is laser power(W), $\nu$ is scanning speed $\mathrm { ( m m / s ) }$ ， $h$ is hatch distance (mm),and $t$ is layer thickness (mm) [25].

$$
E _ { \nu } = { \frac { P } { \nu h t } }
$$

The VED formulation,which employs a limited number of factors (see Eq. 1),represents an appropriate methodology for comparing and evaluating energy density requirements in traditional LPBF applications involving fiber lasers.It is needed to adapt DAM to different energy density formulations which is independent of the type of processing. Thomas et al. [37] developed a normalised energy density $( \mathrm { N E D - } E _ { 0 } ^ { \ast } )$ equation which takes into account several material properties compared to VED. The multiplication of the dimensionless heat input per melt track $( E ^ { * } )$ (see Eq. 2) and dimensionless hatch distance $( h ^ { * } )$ (see Eq. 3) gives the last iteration of (NED- $E _ { 0 } ^ { * }$ ） the formula that can be shown as Eq. 4.

$$
E ^ { * } = \frac { q ^ { * } } { \nu ^ { * } l ^ { * } }
$$

where $q ^ { * }$ is a dimensionless beam power, $\nu ^ { * }$ is a dimensionless scanning speed and $l ^ { * }$ is a dimensionless layer thickness.

$$
h ^ { * } = \frac { h } { r _ { b } }
$$

where $h$ is the hatch distance $\mathrm { ( m ) }$ and $r _ { b }$ is the beam radius$\mathrm { ( m ) }$ ：

$$
E _ { 0 } ^ { * } = \frac { q ^ { * } } { \nu ^ { * } l ^ { * } h ^ { * } } = \frac { A q } { 2 \nu l h } \frac { 1 } { \rho C _ { p } ( T _ { m } - T _ { 0 } ) }
$$

name: 2025 - Int. J. Advanced Manufacturing Technology - Erman et al. - Diode area melting of SS316L using low power 450 nm lasers-part-7
fileName: 2025 - Int. J. Advanced Manufacturing Technology - Erman et al. - Diode area melting of SS316L using low power 450 nm lasers.md
content:
where $A$ is the laser absorptivity of powder, $\rho$ is the density $( \mathrm { k g } / \mathrm { m } ^ { 3 } )$ of the powder, $q$ is a laser power (W), $l$ is a layer thickness $( \mathrm { m } ) , C _ { p }$ is the specific heat $( \mathrm { J } / \mathrm { k g } . \mathrm { K } )$ of the powder,

$T _ { m }$ is the melting temperature (K) of the powder and $T _ { 0 }$ is the initial temperature (K) of the system.

Table 1 illustrates the process parameters and NED - $E _ { 0 } ^ { * }$ values that have been calculated with Eq.4 for LPBF studies processing SS316L.The process parameters mentioned have been demonstrated to successfully fabricate LPBF parts with a relative density exceeding $\sim 9 9 \%$ (except references 1 and 2 in Table 1).As can be seen in Table1,the process parameters including scanning speed, hatch distance,and spot size are selected from a range of options rather than adhering to a specific series of parameters.For instance, the scanning speed varies from 200 to $2 0 0 0 \mathrm { m m / s }$ while the hatch distance ranges from 35 to $1 2 2 \mu \mathrm { m }$ . The NED values exhibit a range of 3 to 15 forLPBF studies with SS316L.Furthermore, the Ti6Al4V powder,which was the sole material processed on DAM before this study, is illustrated in red circles in Fig.1, following the literature on LPBF. The energy requirement of SS316L is greater than that of Ti6Al4V,due to the higher density of the former. In addition, the heat capacity of SS316L is approximately $5 \%$ lower than that of Ti6Al4V [6].

Figure 1 illustrates a normalised energy diagram for LPBF literature works processing SS316L. The ratio of dimensionless volumetric heat input per scan line $( E ^ { * } )$ and hatch spacing $( h ^ { * } )$ provides the normalised equivalent energy $( E _ { 0 } ^ { * } )$ (see Eq. 4). The literature works are represented by constant $E _ { 0 } ^ { * }$ contours,which are depicted by dashed lines in Fig.1.

Figure 2(b) shows the powder's particle size distribution, measured with Malvern Mastersizer 3Ooo.The mean values of the Dv(10),Dv(50),and Dv(90) parameters for the powder sample are found to be $1 7 . 9 \mu \mathrm { m }$ $2 8 . 5 \mu \mathrm { m }$ ,and $4 3 . 9 \mu \mathrm { m }$ respectively. name: 2025 - Int. J. Advanced Manufacturing Technology - Erman et al. - Diode area melting of SS316L using low power 450 nm lasers-part-13
fileName: 2025 - Int. J. Advanced Manufacturing Technology - Erman et al. - Diode area melting of SS316L using low power 450 nm lasers.md
content: Figure 3 illustrates the schematics of DAM technology. DAM integrates independently addressable fiber-coupled $4 5 0 \mathrm { n m }$ multiple blue diode lasers into a custom scanning head,which is described in Fig.3 as a Multi Laser Head (MLH). The MLH incorporates collimating and focusing lenses,which direct and focus the beams to achieve localised melting during the fabrication process.The MLH is mounted into an $\mathbf { X } { - } \mathbf { y } { - } \mathbf { Z }$ linear stage,which allows it to move over the substrate by the intended scanning strategy.The laser configuration used in this study,illustrated in Fig. 3,consists of six blue diode lasers operating at a wavelength of $4 5 0 ~ \mathrm { n m }$ . Figure 3 highlights the configuration of the laser array,which comprises lasers with a diameter of $7 0 ~ { \mu \mathrm { m } }$ and a central distance between adjacent lasers of $9 0 ~ { \mu \mathrm { m } }$ at focus distance which is $2 7 ~ \mathrm { m m }$ for our MLH.Additionally, the laser beam profile has been measured using a NanoScan2sPryo/9/5 optical profilometer and is presented alongside MLH in Fig.3. While the spot diameter of each laser is $7 0 ~ { \mu \mathrm { m } }$ in the laser configuration (see Fig.3),the height of each laser spot increases to $1 0 7 ~ { \mu \mathrm { m } }$ in the laser beam profile (see Fig. 3). This discrepancy may arise from beam reflection due to the MLH.In the absence of a back-reflection element within the MLH assembly, the measurements could potentially be affected by the back reflection of the laser beams.Laser power loss due to the fiber connection between the diode lasers and the MLH is quantified using the Thorlabs PM40oK5 power meter kit, and the output power of both lasers is maintained at\~3.5 W.Each laser in the configuration operates at an optical power output of $3 . 5 ~ \mathrm { W } ,$ ,resulting in a total laser array power of $2 1 \ \mathrm { W }$ as detailed in Table 4.
summary: 2.2 System development and operational procedures - Part 1/2

content:
In addition to the MLH in the DAM system, there are two pistons corresponding to the reservoir and build platforms and powder delivery systems(see Fig.3),which are similar to traditional LPBF machines.Argon gas is introduced into the custom-built chamber with oxygen content monitored with a sensor to maintain an oxygen level below $1 0 0 0 \mathrm { p p m }$ throughout the processing.An air knife is situated within the build chamber, this recirculates argon gas and prevents spatter falling onto the powder bed processing area. A $1 \ \mathrm { m m }$ in thickness of powder is deposited over a metal substrate measuring $7 5 \times 7 5 ~ \mathrm { m m } ^ { 2 }$ and then laser processed. The use of a thick metal powder layer enables the quantification of melt-pool penetration depth.

# 2.3 Design of experiment Single-layer experiments are conducted with the laser array configuration illustrated in Fig. 3. The scanning speeds and the hatch distance which is the central difference between lines of track parameters,as outlined in Table 4,are employed to fabricate thirty distinct single-layer samples,each measuring $6 \times 4 ~ \mathrm { m m } ^ { 2 }$ . A stripe pattern is selected as the scanning strategy to produce single-layer samples.Table 4 illustrates the dimensions of the sample and the scanning strategy employed. The lasers are positioned perpendicular to the scanning direction (represented by the long stripes in Table 4) within the multi-laser spot configuration (see Fig. 3). The lasers remain active during processing,resulting in melt pool overlaps that are paralel to the scanning direction (long stripes in Table 4), which is a consequence of the designated hatch distance parameter. In this study, the scanning strategy is designated as SS,and the hatch distance is denoted as HD. Table 4 All process parameters and dimensions of the sample with scanning strategy in this work

Laser Power21 (6 x3.5)W

name: 2025 - Int. J. Advanced Manufacturing Technology - Erman et al. - Diode area melting of SS316L using low power 450 nm lasers-part-16
fileName: 2025 - Int. J. Advanced Manufacturing Technology - Erman et al. - Diode area melting of SS316L using low power 450 nm lasers.md
content:
Each sample is mounted in a Bakelite to facilitate the automatic metallographic procedures. Initially, the samples are ground with waterproof grinding paper of progressively finer grits,ranging from P32O to P40oo.The samples are cleaned using an ultrasonic cleaner,adding isopropanol. Subsequently, a $0 . 0 6 \mu \mathrm { m }$ particle-sized colloidal silica is applied to achieve a mirror-like finish on the surface.Kalling's No.2 Reagent is used as an etching solution to distinguish the cellular structure of samples under sub-grain level.

Samples are examined using optical microscopy (OP) and scanning electron microscopy (SEM).The crosssections of the single-layer samples have been examined under OP at $5 \times$ and $1 0 \times$ magnification.A microstructural investigation is conducted under SEM at $8 0 0 \times$ and $5 0 0 0 \times$ magnification from the cross-sectional surfaces. The top surface of the single-layer samples is investigated using SEM at $3 5 \times$ magnification to ascertain the quality of the surface in terms of balling and its morphology. Subsequently, the cross-sectional density of samples is quantified by utilising the Image J software [42], employing an optical thresholding technique.The relative densities of the samples are determined by measuring the optical microscopy images of each sample's cross-section,as illustrated in Fig. 4. Samples are cut and optical microscopy images are obtained from cross-sections to evaluate melt track characteristics in terms of melt track penetration into the powder bed.Relative density measurements are obtained from polished cross-sections by determining the region of interest, which encompasses the majority of samples (see dashed red rectangle in Fig. 4(h)).

name: 2025 - Int. J. Advanced Manufacturing Technology - Erman et al. - Diode area melting of SS316L using low power 450 nm lasers-part-17
fileName: 2025 - Int. J. Advanced Manufacturing Technology - Erman et al. - Diode area melting of SS316L using low power 450 nm lasers.md
content: The surface roughness is calculated by the Alicona Infinite Focus SL optically. The concept of surface roughness is a pervasive one in the literature,employed as a means of assessing the quality of a given part and of optimizing process parameters [21, 43, 44]. Vickers hardness measurements are performed on a cross-section of polished samples,with five individual measurements taken from each sample and averaged to eliminate extreme measurement points.Finally,X-ray diffraction (XRD) measurements are conducted using a PANalytical Aeris instrument over a range of $0 ^ { \circ }$ to $1 0 0 ^ { \circ }$ with a $1 0 { \cdot } \mathrm { m i n }$ rotating scan.

name: 2025 - Int. J. Advanced Manufacturing Technology - Erman et al. - Diode area melting of SS316L using low power 450 nm lasers-part-19
fileName: 2025 - Int. J. Advanced Manufacturing Technology - Erman et al. - Diode area melting of SS316L using low power 450 nm lasers.md
content: One of the most important key process parameters in terms of single-layer formation is the hatch distance to eliminate poor connections between adjacent melt tracks. In addition,the hatch distance/melt pool overlap should not be set too high/low to produce fully melted structures without defects.Increasing the melt pool overlap increases the number of melt tracks on the manufactured part, which can have a negative effect on surface roughness [45]. Three different hatch distance values are used to understand melt track overlap to produce single-layer formation. $2 0 0 \mu \mathrm { m }$ ， $3 0 0 \mu \mathrm { m }$ and $4 0 0 \mu \mathrm { m }$ (HD200, HD300 and HD400) are the hatch distance parameters in this work (see Table 4). The melt track overlap between each laser track is calculated using Eq. 6.In this study, the beam profile width $( b _ { w } )$ is assumed to be equal to the melt track width. According to previous research on processing Ti6Al4V in DAM [4], no significant difference exists between the two.Another reason for this assumption is the lack of capability for in-situ measurements of the melt pool width during processing. Then,Eq.7 is used to calculate the hatch distance according to the melt track overlap $( m _ { o } )$ in microns.HD200, HD300,and HD400 correspond to $6 0 \%$ ， $4 0 \%$ ，and $2 0 \%$ beam overlap respectively. Dong et al. highlighted the clear distinction between melt tracks, noting no overlap between them [46]. Furthermore,it was demonstrated that even $4 0 \%$ melt track overlap results in enhanced top surface morphology in terms of surface roughness. However, additional overlapping reduces the strength and plasticity of LPBF parts due to the formation of microcracks [46]. It has been demonstrated that a $2 5 { - } 5 0 \%$ overlap results in a stress release effect due to the re-scanning of previously scanned areas [47]. However, excessive overlap can prevent the preheating effect on a later track from the previous one.
summary: 3.1 Melt pool characterisation of single-layer formation - Part 1/4

content:
Consequently, it has been established that residual stresses increase with a high overlap ratio [47].

$$
m _ { o } [ \mu m ] = b _ { w } [ \mu m ] * o \nu e r l a p p e r c e n t a g e [ \mathcal { G } _ { o } ]
$$

$$
H D [ \mu m ] = b _ { w } [ \mu m ] - m _ { o } [ \mu m ]
$$

Figure 4 depicts optical micrographs of cross-sectional single-layer samples under $5 \times$ magnification for SS50, SS100, SS150, SS200, SS450,and SS500. The depth of the melt track at the bottom right of each micrograph and the surface roughness at the bottom left of each micrograph for all hatch distance values (e.g.HD2Oo, HD30O,and HD400) are presented.The depthof the melt track is measured from microscopy images,as illustrated in Fig. 4. Ten measurements are taken from each microscope,comprising both deep and shallow parts of the melt track geometry. The results are averaged and are presented in the bottom right corner of the micrographs in Fig. 4. Further micrographs, spanning the range from SS30O to SS4Oo,are not included here due to space limitations. It is evident that an increase in hatch distance results in a transformation of the cross-section of samples into a wave structure.This fluctuation is further emphasised by the addition of vertical red dotted lines in Figs. 4(c), (e),and (f). The relative density values and normalised energy density values are provided in the upper right and left corners of Figs. 4(a) to (s), respectively. It can be observed that the relative density values of both samples exceed $9 9 \%$ . Furthermore, the normalised energy density values exhibit a notable decline,ranging from 9.12 to 0.46, across the samples from SS50HD200 to SS500HD400 due to an increase in scanning speed and hatch distance.
summary: 3.1 Melt pool characterisation of single-layer formation - Part 2/4

content:

The melt track depths $( d _ { m } )$ are examined individually for each hatch distance set.At SS5O (Figs. 4(a) to (c)) the melt track depth is greater compared to higher speeds such as SS100 and SS150 (see Figs. 4(d) to (f) and Figs. 4(g) to (i)) for each data set.For example,the melt depth for SS50HD200 is $2 6 8 . 8 2 ~ \mu \mathrm { m }$ while the melt track depths for SS100HD200 and SS150HD200 are $2 4 1 . 1 9 ~ \mu \mathrm { m }$ and $2 1 7 . 2 9 \mu \mathrm { m }$ respectively. As the scanning speed is increased, the energy density values decrease (for details,please refer to the top left corner of Figs. 4(a) to 4(s)). Accordingly, the melt track depth trend exhibits a downward trajectory from SS50 to SS150. The reduction in the melt track depth is also attributed to scanning speed, as demonstrated by Alsaddah et al.[5]. Furthermore, the depth of the melt track observed in the samples increases following the SS15o.This is attributed to the balling issue,which has been previously validated in other DAM studies conducted at the single-layer formation section of Ti6Al4V [6].

Additionally, the poor surface roughness observed at SS450 and SS500 for HD200 and HD300 can be attributed to balling problems,which are represented by green circles in Figs. 4(m), (n),and (r).

content:
The method for measuring the relative density of the sample is described in Sect.2.4. Only the relative density of samples that have a higher scanning speed than $3 0 0 \ \mathrm { m m / m i n }$ at $\mathrm { H D 4 0 0 }$ is not measured due to the discontinuous nature of the sample due to poor overlap [49] at higher scanning speeds [50] (see Figs. 4(o) and (s)).

![](images/f1849400bd0efb3e7c717c4f97870133110c20e900ac3e423710aa85e5108292.jpg)  
Fig.5 The relative density values of samples from polished crosssections

Figure 5 illustrates the relative densities of samples from SS50HD200 to SS500HD300,apart from SS350HD400, SS400HD400, SS450HD400,and SS500HD400. It can be observed that the relative density values of all samples exceed $9 9 \%$ .The utilisation of a laser configuration enables the successful melting and fusion of the feedstock, resulting in the absence of significant porosity between each track.

The density values for both the HD3oO and HD400 samples are comparatively higher than those of samples with HD2Oo, particularly at lower speeds,such as SS50, SS150,and SS250 (see Fig. 5). Figure 6 depicts the crosssectional surfaces of select samples at $\times 1 0$ magnification, accompanied by relative density values that facilitate a more detailed analysis of porosity in comparison to the data presented in Fig. 5.The relative density values are displayed in the bottom right corners of the micrographs presented in Fig. 6.

name: 2025 - Int. J. Advanced Manufacturing Technology - Erman et al. - Diode area melting of SS316L using low power 450 nm lasers-part-24
fileName: 2025 - Int. J. Advanced Manufacturing Technology - Erman et al. - Diode area melting of SS316L using low power 450 nm lasers.md
content: The presence of minor spherical pores is indicated by red circles in samples treated with HD200 (see Figs. 6(a), (d),(g),(j)). In contrast, the number of spherical pores observed in samples treated with HD30O is relatively low in comparison to the number of pores present in HD200 samples.These pores are represented by blue circles in Figs.6(b),and (e)).Furthermore,a slight decrease in porosity is observed with an increase in scanning speed at samples with HD2OO (see the first column of Fig. 6). The porosity of the samples containing HD2Oo is found to be greater at slower scanning speeds.Porosity in LPBF samples can be classfied into three main categories: gas porosity, lack of fusion,and delamination between subsequent layers [51]. Pores that originated in samples with HD200 can be identified as gas porosity, given their spherical shape and the conditions under which they occurred (single-layer formation). An excessive degree of overlap in the melt track can result in a notable rise in temperature within the melt pool, which may subsequently give rise to several thermal issues [52].It is hypothesized that the elevated temperature in the melt pool at slow scanning speeds results in vaporization.The spherical shape of the gas porosity is the result of the entrapped gas caused by the vapour pressure [53]. It is also stated that too low hatch distance at slow scanning leads to a decrease in relative density [54]. As the scanning speed is increased, the porosity of the samples with HD3oO shows a slight increase (see the second column in Fig.6) like the literature work in LPBF SS316L [55]. Additionally, some discontinuities are observed at the base of the sample (see the blue rectangles in Figs. 6(h) and (k)).An additional increase in hatch distance results in the formation of distinct cross-sectional divisions within the samples (as illustrated by the green rectangles in Figs. 6(f),(i),and (l)).

content:
Figure 7 shows SEM micrographs of the top surfaces of single-layer samples at $3 5 \times$ magnification for SS50, SS100, SS150, SS200, SS400,and SS500. Other micrographs are not shown here due to space considerations as in Fig. 4, but in Fig. 7 micrographs of SS4OO are used in contrast to SS450 in Fig. 4 to show another range of sample morphology.

The NED values for each sample are shown in the top left-hand corner of each micrograph in Fig. 7,in addition to the surface roughness and melt track width $( d _ { w } )$ shown below each micrograph. The sample in Fig. 7(a) (SS50HD2OO which has the highest NED value among all samples in this work) gives the lowest surface roughness result of all the samples with a Ra value of $3 . 4 7 ~ \mu \mathrm { m }$ .The surface quality deteriorates as the scanning speed increases for certain hatch distance values.Furthermore, the surface quality deteriorates as the hatch distance increases for the same set of scanning speeds [57]. The NED values range from 9.12 to 0.46 and are calculated using Eq. 4.Although the relationship between energy density values and surface roughness will be addressed subsequently, it can be observed that high NED values are indicative of superior surface quality in comparison to lower NED values (see Figs.7(a) to (s)). In particular, when the energy input is below 1.52, there is a marked increase in surface roughness (see Figs.7(l) and (m) or Figs.7(n) to (o)) as a result of a lack of fusion [25]. The correlation between NED and surface roughness values primarily arises from variations in scanning speed.

content:
The surface quality of the specimens deteriorates for lowspeed specimens such as SS100HD300, SS150HD300,and S150HD4OO thanks to multiple spatters on the top surface of the samples are shown in Figs.7(e),(h),and (i). Spatter are represented by dotted white circles in Figs.7(e), (h),and (i).After Fig.7(l) to (s),the surface roughness increases due to poor top surface morphology, including balling problems. Figure 7(l) to (s) shows top surface porosity defects as dotted white rectangles.Melt traces become entangled when the scanning speed exceeds $2 0 0 \mathrm { m m / m i n }$ ,and this degrades the integrity of the samples.Balling is also observed on the top surfaces of samples at scanning speeds above $4 0 0 \mathrm { m m } /$ min, shown as dotted yellow squares in Fig.7(o),(r),and (s). The utilisation of high scanning speeds has been identified as a contributing factor to the formation of discontinuities and voids between tracks, which are commonly attributed to balling defects [58].

The melt track width of each sample is shown below each micrograph, except for further SS400HD200 samples, to allow the detection of melt track boundaries due to distortions in melt tracks,pores,balling,and lack of fusion problems.Melt track width increases as the hatch distance increases.For instance, the melt track width increases from $1 9 0 . 6 7 ~ { \mu \mathrm { m } }$ to $3 9 2 . 5 3 ~ { \mu \mathrm { m } }$ for HD200 and HD400 respectively,as shown in Figs.6(a) to(c).In the same data set, there is no significant difference in melt track width as a function of scan speed.For example, the melt track width is $2 8 8 . 2 7 \mu \mathrm { m }$ and $2 8 9 . 0 7 \mu \mathrm { m }$ for samples SS150HD300 and SS200HD300 respectively.

The NED values of all DAM samples, ranging from 0.46 to 9.12,are illustrated over constant NED contours,which are depicted as dotted lines in Fig. 8.The red rectangles represent samples treated with HD2O0, the green rectangles indicate samples treated with HD3OO,and the blue rectangles denote samples treated with HD4Oo.The black dotted polygonal area in Fig.8 represents samples with a relative density of greater than $9 9 \%$ .A total of four samples have been excluded from the region on the grounds of severe discontinuity in their cross-sectional structure. Accordingly, relative density measurements are not performed on these samples.

Table 5 shows surface roughness values and the normalised energy density (NED) values for all samples varying hatch distance and scanning speed with Eq. 4.As mentioned in the introduction,NED values forLPBF literature work related to SS316L range between 3 to 15.NED values of DAM samples in this work change from 9.12 to 0.46 and NED values of some samples equal each other due to the multiplication of hatch distance and scanning speed in Eq. 4.Additionally, Table 5 presents the relative densities for DAM samples.It is not feasible to determine the relative density of samples SS350HD400, SS400HD400, SS450HD400,and SS500HD400 (see Figs.4(o) and (s) and Figs.5 (i) and (l)) due to a substantial discontinuity along the crooked cross-section surface.The corresponding energy density values are O.65, 0.57, O.51, and 0.46, respectively (see Table 5).

Figure 9 facilitates the observation of both the existing literature on LPBF and the DAM samples (relative density of samples higher than $9 9 \%$ ） presented in this paper by mapping them into the same graph which contains constant base NED values. Initially, literature works are obtained with varying hatch distance values to facilitate comprehension according to normalised energy but independent of the y-axis. Consequently, the values are mapped onto constant NED values to ensure consistency across the data set.Normalised energy density values for literature works typically range from 4.641 to 14.32 (see Table 1),enabling the fabrication of high-density $( > 9 9 \% )$ samples.DAM facilitates the processing of fully melted and fused single-layer parts from 0.61 to 9.12 in terms of NED value,utilizing $4 5 0 ~ \mathrm { n m }$ blue diode lasers (the absorptivity of the SS316L powder increases by approximately $1 0 \%$ when a $4 5 0 \ \mathrm { n m }$ diode laser is employed instead of a $1 0 7 0 ~ \mathrm { n m }$ fiber laser [18]).It is also relevant to note that the DAM SS316L samples fabricated in this study are of a single-layer structure. The energy requirement for multi-layer SS316L samples may be higher than that for single layers.

content: Figure 1O illustrates the surface roughness (Ra) values for all samples, which are obtained at varying scanning speeds (SS50 to SS50O) and hatch distances (HD200,HD300,and HD400). The extent of melt pool overlap has a significant influence on the surface quality of the samples [57].An increase in scanning speeds has been observed to result in a deterioration of surface quality,aside from the efect of hatch distance [48]. This is illustrated in Fig.1O,which presents several surface contours.It can be seen that Ra values for HD200 increase from $3 . 4 6 9 ~ \mu \mathrm { m }$ to $1 1 . 5 3 7 ~ \mu \mathrm { m }$ between SS5O and SS250.An additional increase in scanning speed results in an elevation of surface roughness to $2 8 . 5 4 6 \ \mu \mathrm { m }$ when the scanning speed reaches $3 5 0 ~ \mathrm { m m } /$ min,as illustrated in Fig. 1O. Increased scanning speeds result in the formation of discontinuities and non-uniformity in the melt tracks,which can be attributed to balling defects [48, 5O]. The occurrence of balling problems and discontinuity problems is illustrated in Figs.7(l) to (s).A similar phenomenon is observed in both hatch distances, with surface roughness increasing significantly from $6 . 5 7 7 \mu \mathrm { m }$ to $5 1 . 7 1 8 ~ { \mu \mathrm { m } }$ and from $1 3 . 8 1 4 \mu \mathrm { m }$ to $4 9 . 0 6 \mu \mathrm { m }$ for HD300 and $\mathrm { H D 4 0 0 }$ ,respectively, while SS50 to SS500 (see Table 5).

content:
In addition to the effect of scanning speed,an increase in hatch distance (a reduction in the extent of melt pool overlap) results in the formation of waviness on the top surface of the sample,which can be attributed to the presence of poor overlapping. The surface roughness values at a constant speed, such as SS150, are $6 . 3 8 ~ \mu \mathrm { m }$ ， $1 2 . 2 5 9 ~ \mu \mathrm { m }$ ，and $2 7 . 6 8 \mu \mathrm { m }$ for HD200, HD300,and HD400, respectively. At high scanning speeds,such as those observed after SS250, surface roughness increases significantly in both HD300 and HD4Oo due to the formation of balling and porosity, as illustrated in Figs.7(n) to (s).An increase in the amount of overlap in the melt pool ensures the compactness of the top surfaces [49].

![](images/b6c09230d6e595080ec08943a2fba7da5a199769f97b7da1676b102ea8d085a9.jpg)  
Fig.11 The evolution of surface roughness (Ra) through each Normalised Energy Density (NED) value

Figure 11 depicts the surface roughness (Ra) values for varying energy density states. The normalised energy density values for certain specimens are identical,as evidenced by the comparison of SS100HD300 and SS150HD200,as illustrated in Table 5,where the energy density is observed to be 3.O4.This phenomenon can be attributed to the multiplication of hatch distance and scanning speed. The surface roughness of samples with varying NED values is presented in Fig.11. To illustrate, the energy density values for the SS300HD400 and SS400HD300 samples are identical at 0.76,while their respective roughness measurements are $4 4 . 7 5 6 ~ \mu \mathrm { m }$ and $4 7 . 0 2 5 ~ { \mu \mathrm { m } }$ .These values have been averaged and mapped in Fig. 11.

content:
The optimal surface roughness (Ra) value is observed to be $3 . 4 6 9 \ \mu \mathrm { m }$ ,while the NED value is found to be 9.12. The process parameters are SS50 and HD2Oo.Furthermore, the acceptable surface roughness results are $6 . 5 7 7 \mu \mathrm { m }$ and $6 . 3 8 0 \mu \mathrm { m }$ for the SS50HD300 and SS150HD200 samples, respectively,while the NED is 6.08 and 3.04,respectively, in terms of the existing literature on LPBF for SS316L [26, 45,59]. The optimal surface roughness results are achieved within the range of 9.12 to 3.04 in terms of NED.A slight increase is observed below 3.O4,which can be attributed to spattering,as illustrated in Figs. 7(e) and (h).

The surface roughness increases significantly when the NED value is below 1.30. The surface roughness of samples increases to $4 6 . 8 1 0 ~ \mu \mathrm { m }$ and $5 3 . 6 6 5 ~ { \mu \mathrm { m } }$ while NED equals 1.22 and 0.57 respectively (see Fig. 11 and Table 5). This is due to the presence of numerous small and large particles on the top surface,as illustrated in Figs.7(i) to (s) with white dotted circles and yellow dotted rectangles.A further factor contributing to the decline in surface quality is the presence of porosity and discontinuity along the melt track,as illustrated in Figs.7(l) to (s) by white dotted rectangles. A literature review reveals that as decrease in surface roughness and relative density is a primary cause of low energy density [38].

content:
Figure 12(a) depicts the XRD profile of SS316L austenitic stainless-steel samples with varying scanning speeds (SS50, SS200,and SS5oo,which are selected to represent low, medium,and high scanning speeds) at HD2Oo.Figure 12 illustrates the existence of two distinct phases: face-centered cubic austenite (γ phase) and body-centered cubic ferrite (δ phase). The $\gamma$ phase is corroborated by the presence of apparent diffraction peaks in the (111),(200),(220), (311), and (222) crystallographic planes,as observed in the LPBF SS316L sample referenced in the literature [6O-63].

![](images/5f3533d62096e8f6dfb05dbb979a4554f83d4652be1eea41ff313bae88b0ba1a.jpg)

name: 2025 - Int. J. Advanced Manufacturing Technology - Erman et al. - Diode area melting of SS316L using low power 450 nm lasers-part-37
fileName: 2025 - Int. J. Advanced Manufacturing Technology - Erman et al. - Diode area melting of SS316L using low power 450 nm lasers.md
content: It is typically observed that samples produced through traditional LPBF processes exhibit only the $\gamma$ austenite phase both in their as-built [6O, 64-66] and heat-treated states [64-66]. In addition to LPBF, samples manufactured by alternative methods, including casting [67] and electron beam melting [68,69], do not display the delta ferrite phase in their X-ray diffraction analysis.The presence of the small δ ferrite phase has also been documented in some of the literature on LPBF of SS316L,as referenced in [32, 39, 61, 62]. The ferrite phase is typically resistant to high temperatures,and the traditional LPBF process is unable to provide an adequate duration for the transformation into an austenitic phase [62]. Consequently, the observation of subsequent phases on samples may be prevented by the implementation of a high cooling rate at traditional LPBF [32]. It is anticipated by LPBF that the S ferrite phase may serve to reinforce the $\gamma$ austenite phase,which is susceptible to deformation [39, 62].It has also been found that delta ferrite in austenitic steel welds increases the resistance to stress corrosion cracking caused by tensile stress in corrosive environments [70].

name: 2025 - Int. J. Advanced Manufacturing Technology - Erman et al. - Diode area melting of SS316L using low power 450 nm lasers-part-38
fileName: 2025 - Int. J. Advanced Manufacturing Technology - Erman et al. - Diode area melting of SS316L using low power 450 nm lasers.md
content: The second peak in Fig. 12(a), which corresponds to the (110) plane and follows the (111) crystallographic plane, serves to validate the existence of the δ ferrite phase in SS316L DAM samples. The peaks corresponding to the (111）and(11O) crystallographic planes are represented in greater detail for the SS50HD200,SS200HD200,and SS500HD2OO samples in the sequence (NED values of samples correspond to 9.12,2.28,and 0.91 respectively),as illustrated in Figs. 12(b), (c),and (d),respectively. Furthermore,the regions explicitly depicted in Figs.12(b), (c),and (d) are highlighted with a dotted black rectangle in Fig.12(a) for the sole purpose of focusing attention on SS2ooHD200, due to the limited space available.The XRD analysis has validated that all samples (in terms of varying energy density,hatch distance,and scanning speed parameters) in this work exhibit delta ferrite phases.No coincident or specific parameters,like the previously mentioned LPBF literature works,have been identified that show a small amount of ferrite in the microstructure of DAM samples.
